1 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Henry v. City of New York


No. 142


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


94 N.Y.2d 275; 724 N.E.2d 372; 702 N.Y.S.2d 580; 1999 N.Y. LEXIS 3928


November 16, 1999, Argued  
 December 20, 1999, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, with costs, and defendant City of New York's motion to dismiss the first and second causes of action of the complaint against it denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, on behalf of her infant children, appealed a decision by the Appellate Division which held that the infant plaintiffs were not under a disability because of infancy within the meaning of N.Y. C.P.L.R. 208, thus their claims under N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 50-e were time-barred.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff mother timely filed notice of claim on behalf of each of her infant children pursuant to N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 50-e. Each claim alleged infant plaintiff ingested lead paint while living in defendant City-owned apartment. The trial court dismissed defendant's motion to dismiss, holding that the infancy toll under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 208 did not terminate when their parent filed a notice of claim on their behalf. The Appellate Division reversed, finding that infant plaintiffs were not under a disability because of infancy, thus their claims were time barred. The Court of Appeals reversed the Appellate Division, holding that N.Y. C.P.L.R. 208 tolled a statute of limitations for the period of infancy, and the toll was not terminated by the acts of a guardian or legal representative in taking steps to pursue the infant's claim. Therefore, the infant plaintiffs' suit against defendant City of New York was not time-barred.


OUTCOME: Judgment reversed. Infant plaintiffs' claims against defendant city were not time-barred. Statute of limitations was tolled for infant plaintiffs' period of infancy, and the fact that their parent took steps to pursue claim on their behalf did not terminate tolling of statute.


HEADNOTES

Limitation of Actions - Tolling - Infancy - Toll Not Terminated by Acts of Guardian

1. An infant's action against a municipality is not time-barred when the infant, through a parent or guardian, timely files a notice of claim pursuant to General Municipal Law § 50-e, but fails to commence the action within the one-year and 90-day limitation period of General Municipal Law § 50-i. The toll of a Statute of Limitations for the period of infancy afforded by CPLR 208 is not terminated by the acts of a guardian or legal representative in taking steps to pursue the infant's claim. Although the language of CPLR 208 was amended in 1974 by dropping the use of age to define infancy and using the phrase "disability because of infancy," the infancy disability is still measured by age and is not overcome when a parent, legal guardian or attorney takes steps to protect an infant's rights by filing a notice of claim, since the special status accorded an infant plaintiff by virtue of the infant's tender age has been consistently recognized, and that status is not altered by the action or inaction of the infant's parent or guardian. The amendment in question was part of a larger statutory revision changing the age of majority from 21 to 18, and there is no indication that the Legislature intended to change the application of the infancy toll. Moreover, a 1975 amendment to CPLR 208 creating a 10-year cap on the commencement of an infant's medical malpractice action was merely part of a larger package of legislative reforms having no relevance to the tolling statute.

Limitation of Actions - Tolling - Infancy - Toll Not Terminated by Acts of Guardian

2. An infant's action against a municipality is not time-barred when the infant, through a parent or guardian, timely files a notice of claim pursuant to General Municipal Law § 50-e, but fails to commence the action within the one-year and 90-day limitation period of General Municipal Law § 50-i. The toll of a Statute of Limitations for the period of infancy afforded by CPLR 208 is not terminated by the acts of a guardian or legal representative in taking steps to pursue the infant's claim. Infant plaintiffs should not be penalized by a parent's compliance with section 50-e in an effort to protect a right to recovery. Infancy itself, the state of being "a person [under] the age of eighteen" (CPLR 105 [j]), is the disability that determines the toll. An interpretation of the infancy toll which measures the time period of infancy based on the conduct of the infant's parent or guardian cuts against the strong public policy of protecting those who are disabled because of their age.

 

2 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Port Jefferson Health Care Facility v. Wing


No. 184


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


94 N.Y.2d 284; 726 N.E.2d 449; 704 N.Y.S.2d 897; 1999 N.Y. LEXIS 3926


October 20, 1999, Argued  
 December 16, 1999, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Certiorari Denied June 29, 2000, Reported at: 2000 U.S. LEXIS 4558.



DISPOSITION: Judgment appealed from and order of the Appellate Division brought up for review reversed, with costs, and judgment granted declaring Public Health Law §§ 2807-d(2)(b)(ii) and (iii) and2807-d(10)(b) constitutional.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant-State appealed the Appellate Division's (New York) order affirming the grant of summary judgment in plaintiffs' action seeking declaratory and injunctive relief, and a refund of gross receipt taxes paid, claiming that their U.S. Const. amend. XIV rights to equal protection of the law had been violated.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs brought suit challenging constitutional validity of assessments on for-profit residential health care facilities' (RHCFs) gross receipts under a statutory scheme whereby those taxes on receipts for the care of Medicaid patients are reimbursed as a recoverable expense of care. The court held a) plaintiffs did not established disparities in tax burdens approaching the inequalities require; b) the Legislature had concrete facts upon which to conclude that an RHCFs' gross receipts tax should be structured to: (1) reduce the incentive for RHCFs to prefer admitting paying patients verses Medicaid patients; and (2) encourage those RHCFs to share the burden of providing skilled nursing home care for the medically indigent. A tax exemption for receipts from the care of Medicaid patients significantly related to and furthered the State's interest in securing equality of nursing home care for the indigent. Thus, the court held that tax scheme readily passed rational basis review.


OUTCOME: Order reversed, and judgment granted declaring N.Y. Pub. Health Law §§ 2807-d(2)(b)(ii) and (iii) and 2807-d(10)(b) constitutional, because a tax exemption for receipts from the care of Medicaid patients significantly related to and furthered the State's interest in securing equality of nursing home care for the indigent.


HEADNOTES

Health - Nursing Homes - Gross Receipts Tax - Constitutionality of Statutory Scheme Reimbursing Nursing Homes for Taxes Paid on Receipts for Care of Medicaid Patients

1. Assessments of 1.2% and 3.8% on the gross receipts of residential health care facilities (RHCFs) under a statutory scheme whereby those taxes on receipts for the care of Medicaid patients are reimbursed as a recoverable expense of care are constitutional (see, Public Health Law § 2807-d [2] [b] [ii], [iii]; [10] [b]). Even if the classifications in the gross receipts assessment statutes created a discrete class of nursing homes taxed disparately on the basis of their low proportions of medically indigent patients, plaintiffs, 21 for-profit RHCFs whose non-Medicaid population is larger than the State-wide average, have failed to establish any equal protection violation under the applicable rational basis level of judicial scrutiny, which permits a classification to be upheld if there is any reasonably conceivable state of facts that could provide a justification for the classification. Plaintiffs have not established disparities in tax burdens anywhere approaching the "staggering" inequalities upheld in other taxation cases by the United States Supreme Court. The Legislature had concrete facts upon which reasonably to conclude that an RHCF gross receipts tax should be structured to reduce the incentive for higher quality-of-care RHCFs to prefer admitting patients who could finance their care from their own resources rather than Medicaid patients, and to encourage those RHCFs to share in the burden of providing skilled nursing home care for the medically indigent.

Health - Nursing Homes - Gross Receipts Tax - Constitutionality of Statutory Scheme Reimbursing Nursing Homes for Taxes Paid on Receipts for Care of Medicaid Patients

2. Assessments on the gross receipts of residential health care facilities (RHCFs) under a statutory scheme whereby the taxes on receipts for the care of Medicaid patients are reimbursed as a recoverable expense of care are constitutional under the rational basis level of judicial scrutiny. In identifying a legitimate State interest affording a rational basis for the claimed disparities in taxation among RHCFs, the State is not limited to the objectives of revenue-raising, Medicaid cost-shifting and cost-cutting, referred to in the legislative history, since nothing in the legislative history demonstrates that those objectives were exclusive. Any reasonably conceivable legitimate State interest suffices to pass equal protection muster, and the relevant State interests need not have been the primary legislative objective. Inasmuch as the challenged statutory provisions, essentially exempting Medicaid receipts from the RHCF gross receipts taxes, did not further the Legislature's cost containment or revenue-raising objective, the appropriate conclusion is not that the exemption is unconstitutional, but rather that the Legislature had other purposes in mind in enacting the exemption, namely, to mitigate the disincentive of higher quality-of-care RHCFs from admitting Medicaid patients and to encourage those nursing homes to share in the burden of caring for the medically needy. The fact that efficiently and economically operated RHCFs catering to a Medicaid clientele can earn substantial profits at Medicaid reimbursement rates has little bearing on the rationality of a classification created to provide individual RHCFs with an incentive to care for the indigent. In any event, legislative choices are not subject to courtroom fact-finding.

 

3 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Ganley v. Giuliani


No. 191, No. 192


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


94 N.Y.2d 207; 723 N.E.2d 73; 701 N.Y.S.2d 324; 1999 N.Y. LEXIS 3745


October 21, 1999, Argued  
 November 30, 1999, Decided



DISPOSITION: Case No. 191: Order reversed, with costs, and action and proceeding each remitted to Supreme Court, New York County, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein. Certified question not answered upon the ground that it is unnecessary. Case No. 192: Order reversed, with costs, and order and judgment of Supreme Court, New York County, reinstated. Certified question not answered upon the ground that it is unnecessary.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners appealed an order from the Supreme Court, New York County (New York), which determined that New York City Charter § 1127 applies to nonresidents of the city who, as a result of a merger, were transferred from a public benefit corporation or authority to city agencies.


OVERVIEW: Petitioners were former members of the transit authority and housing authority police departments residing outside the city and were involuntarily transferred to the New York City Police Department via mergers. Prior to the mergers, petitioners were not city employees. Therefore, they were not subject to New York City Charter § 1127, which required nonresident city employees, to agree to make payments in lieu of personal income taxes to the city in an amount computed and determined as if they were city residents. Petitioners sought declaratory and injunctive relief declaring that New York City Charter § 1127 was unconstitutional as applied to them. The appellate division held that that because the employees were notified of the section yet nonetheless accepted employment with the city, they confirmed their agreement to abide by the provisions of § 1127, they appealed, and this court reversed holding that the charter did not apply to them.


OUTCOME: Order reversed; none of petitioners entered into a pre-employment contract agreeing to pay the deductions, they involuntarily transferred to different departments under the city's aegis, thus the city could not impose the nonresident deductions upon them.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service - Residence Requirement - Nonresident New York City Employees Involuntarily Transferred onto Municipal Payroll - Payments in Lieu of City Income Tax

 Section 1127 of the New York City Charter, which requires nonresident City employees, as a precondition of employment, to agree to make payments in lieu of personal income taxes to the City in an amount computed and determined as if they were City residents, does not apply to municipal employees who reside outside the City and were involuntarily transferred onto the municipal payroll via mergers into municipal agencies of the public benefit corporations or authorities for which they worked. Section 1127, which explicitly applies to "every person seeking employment," envisions a voluntary, pre-employment contract between a new employee and the City. None of the petitioners entered into a pre-employment contract for section 1127 deductions; to the contrary, those employees, who had tenured civil service status at their previous agencies, were involuntarily and unilaterally transferred to different departments under the City's aegis. The City therefore cannot impose the nonresident deductions upon them. Moreover, petitioners had few options available to them once informed of the transfer: to suggest that they were required to quit their employment to protect their rights ignores the obvious. Nor did petitioners waive any right to challenge the imposition of section 1127 when they cashed their paychecks and continued to work, since they protested the City's unilateral deductions in several ways, clearly illustrating that they did not acquiesce in the transfers.

 

4 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Metropolitan Transp. Auth. v. American Pen Corp.


No. 166


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


94 N.Y.2d 154; 723 N.E.2d 50; 701 N.Y.S.2d 301; 1999 N.Y. LEXIS 3734


October 13, 1999, Argued  
 November 18, 1999, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment appealed from and order of the Appellate Division brought up for review affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant appealed the judgment of the Appellate Division (New York) that ruled that a 9 percent interest rate on a damage settlement in favor of appellees was fair and not excessive.


OVERVIEW: Appellant alleged that a 9 percent rate of interest was excessive, bringing up for review the Appellate Division's prior order that the 9 percent rate applied to prejudgment interest awards in its condemnation proceedings. The 9 percent rate specified in N.Y. Unconsol. Law § 2501 was applicable. N.Y. Unconsol. Law §2501 entitled claimants to a presumptive 9 percent interest rate with respect to any judgment or accrued claim against a public corporation. The statute also mirrored the statute applicable in condemnation proceedings against the state, parity in the state rate and the generally applicable rate to its public corporations would be consistent with the underlying purposes of N.Y. Em. Dom. Proc. Law §101, to assure that just compensation shall be paid to those persons whose property rights were acquired by the exercise of the power of eminent domain.


OUTCOME: Judgment affirmed; 9 percent interest rate applied to prejudgment interest awards in condemnation proceedings was not unfair or excessive; statute entitled claimants to a presumptive 9 percent interest rate with respect to any judgment or accrued claim against a public corporation.


HEADNOTES

Interest - Prejudgment Interest - Condemnation Award - Public Corporation

The prejudgment interest rate on property condemned by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA) is 9% as provided by McKinney's Unconsolidated Laws of NY § 2501. Although Public Authorities Law § 1276 (5) provides that the "rate of interest to be paid by the [MTA] upon any judgment for which it is liable shall not exceed four per centum per annum," section 1276 is a consent to suit provision authorizing suit against the MTA in actions for "damages, for injuries to real or personal property or for the destruction thereof," personal injuries or death, and not for constitutional claims for just compensation. It is not section 1276, but the New York State Constitution that enables condemnees to bring suit against the MTA (see, NY Const, art I, § 7 [a]). Inasmuch as the State and its agencies are never immune from claims arising out of the exercise of their power of eminent domain, a consent to suit statute is inapposite to claims for just compensation. In contrast to section 1276, McKinney's Unconsolidated Laws of NY § 2501 entitles claimants to a presumptive 9% interest rate with respect to "any judgment or accrued claim against" a public corporation, and mirrors the statute applicable in condemnation proceedings against the State.

 

5 of 992 DOCUMENTS


City of New York v. New York State Div. of Human Rights


No. 163


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


93 N.Y.2d 768; 720 N.E.2d 870; 698 N.Y.S.2d 594; 1999 N.Y. LEXIS 3434


September 15, 1999, Argued  
October 19, 1999, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment modified, without costs, in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city appealed a decision of respondent state Division of Human Rights that directed placement of respondent job applicant on a special employment eligible list with retroactive seniority, pursuant to N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 56(3).


OVERVIEW: After passing a civil service exam, respondent applicant was placed on a civil service eligible list, subject to also passing a medical exam. Ten years later, he was medically disqualified and complained to respondent New York State Division of Human Rights (SDHR), alleging disability-based discrimination. Respondent SDHR determined respondent applicant suffered discrimination based on perceived disability; awarded compensatory damages; and applying N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 56(3) retroactively, placed him on a special eligible list for one year. Appellant challenged respondent SDHR's determination and the Appellate Division upheld the law's constitutionality. Appellant appealed on constitutional grounds. The court reversed in part, declaring that N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 56(3), which created the special eligible list and retroactive seniority upon appointment, was unconstitutional because it violated N.Y. Const. art. V, § 6. However, the court upheld respondent SDHR's award of compensatory damages to respondent applicant for his original disability claim.


OUTCOME: The court reversed in part, declaring that law creating special eligible list was unconstitutional because it violated the New York Constitution's Merit and Fitness Clause. The court affirmed respondent Division of Human Rights' award of compensatory damages to respondent applicant for his original disability claim.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service - Appointment and Promotion - Special Eligible Lists and Retroactive Seniority - Violation of Constitutional Merit and Fitness Requirements

1. Subdivision (3) of Civil Service Law § 56, added by a 1994 amendment, which requires municipal employers to create special eligible lists that benefit a particular class of civil service job aspirants whose disqualification from consideration for employment is nullified through administrative or judicial action after an initial eligible list has already expired, is an unconstitutional impingement on the Merit and Fitness Clause of NY Constitution, article V, § 6. Although the Legislature creates eligible lists, its discretion is limited to the field of enforcement of the constitutional Merit and Fitness Clause, and subdivision (3) goes beyond enforcement to create a new, retroactive remedy. Appointment of an individual from a constitutionally valid expired list is unconstitutional, and the Legislature lacks the authority to override that constitutional barrier by passing a law specifically to negate that principle. Job applicants who assert that they have been wrongly ruled ineligible for a position must attack the validity of the list in question, and when such a challenge is successful, a special eligible list may be available because the original list was never valid. Because subdivision (3) substantially transforms a narrow remedy and makes special eligible lists available to any and all improperly disqualified applicants, regardless of the nature of their claim, it goes too far and breaches the constitutional barrier.

Civil Service - Appointment and Promotion - Special Eligible Lists and Retroactive Seniority - Violation of Constitutional Merit and Fitness Requirements - Compensatory Damages

2. Although an individual who was found to have been improperly disqualified for a civil service appointment on the basis of a disability is not entitled to appointment from a special eligible list pursuant to subdivision (3) of Civil Service Law § 56, which unconstitutionally requires municipal employers to create such lists for a civil service job aspirant whose disqualification from consideration for employment was nullified through administrative or judicial action after an initial eligible list has already expired (NY Const, art V, § 6), that individual is nevertheless entitled to compensatory damages for the original disability discrimination.

 

6 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Cohen v. State


No. 145


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


94 N.Y.2d 1; 720 N.E.2d 850; 698 N.Y.S.2d 574; 1999 N.Y. LEXIS 3427


August 24, 1999, Argued  
October 14, 1999, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed, without costs, and judgment granted declaring Chapter 635 of the Laws of 1998 constitutional.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Direct appeal by appellant state, challenging the judgment of a supreme court (New York), which held unconstitutional a statute requiring withholding of legislative salaries until legislative passage of the budget has occurred.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs, legislators, sought a declaratory judgment seeking a declaration of unconstitutionality of 1998 N.Y. Laws 635 (N.Y. C.P.L.R. 5601(b)(2)). The challenged statute required the withholding of legislative salaries upon the first day of the fiscal year, until legislative passage of the budget had occurred. The trial court held that the statute violated the separation of powers doctrine and N.Y. Const. art. III, § 6. On direct appeal, defendant, the state, asserted the constitutionality of the statute. The court held that the statute was not a facial abridgement of the constitutional protections and specifications regarding legislative salaries fixed by law. Nor did the law violate the separation of powers, for it did not impermissibly merge or shift the powers between the executive and legislative branches. Finally, the law did not create extortionate economic pressure, and caused no substantially different economic duress than in the ordinary lawmaking process, budget-related and otherwise.


OUTCOME: Judgment reversed; judgment granted declaring statute constitutional. Statute did not violate state constitutional protections, and did not violate separation of powers doctrine.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Statute Withholding Legislators' Salaries until State Budget is Passed - Prospective Alteration of Salaries

1. Chapter 635 of the Laws of 1998, which provides that if the Legislature has not passed a State budget by the first day of any fiscal year, then the salaries of its members shall be withheld and not paid until legislative passage of a State budget has occurred, whereupon the legislators shall receive the pay which had been withheld, is not facially unconstitutional, does not violate article III, § 6 of the State Constitution, and does not breach the governmental separation of powers doctrine. In seeking facial nullification, plaintiffs, legislators who were in office and voted against chapter 635 and others who were not yet in office, bear the burden of demonstrating that in any degree and in every conceivable application, the challenged law suffers wholesale constitutional impairment; however, the Constitution lays no constraint on the authority of one Legislature by enactment of general law to make provision prospectively for allowances to be received by the officers and members of the two houses during a succeeding legislative term, and the withholding-of-salary protocol is general, purely prospective, and does not suffer from the potentiality that legislators' votes might be manipulated by promises of reward or threats of punishment effectuated through changes in salaries or allowances. Moreover, the statutorily authorized temporary withholding of net payments of legislative salaries operates by force of law and off a neutral pivot.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Statute Withholding Legislators' Salaries until State Budget is Passed - Fixing of Salaries by Law

2. By chapter 635 of the Laws of 1998, which provides that if the Legislature has not passed a State budget by the first day of any fiscal year, then the salaries of its members shall be withheld and not paid until legislative passage of a State budget has occurred, whereupon the legislators shall receive the pay which had been withheld, the Legislature prospectively "fixed by law" an annual salary for its members (see, NY Const, art III, § 6). The law imposes a discipline within the Legislative branch itself regarding the timing and method of only its own net compensation, and does not interject an all-or-nothing infirmity, because the "contingent" nature of its adopted timing-of-payment formula does not "un-fix" the salary, in constitutional terms. The Legislature holds the constitutional key prospectively to authorize that legislators' salaries be paid in one final lump sum at the end of a legislative session--after the work of that branch has concluded and all its responsibilities discharged. Since it may do that, it surely could do what chapter 635 prescribes, which is a lesser of the greater power. This is particularly so since the release of net checks and realization of payment is accomplished simply by passage of an annual State budget, a principal constitutional duty prescribed for each legislative session. Thus, chapter 635 can in no way be viewed as a facial abridgement of the protections and specifications of article III, § 6 of the State Constitution; on the contrary, it satisfies the constitutional payment mandate, and serves as an incentive to complete constitutional budget obligations in a timely fashion.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Statute Withholding Legislators' Salaries until State Budget is Passed - Separation of Powers

3. Chapter 635 of the Laws of 1998, which provides that if the Legislature has not passed a State budget by the first day of any fiscal year, then the salaries of its members shall be withheld and not paid until legislative passage of a State budget has occurred, whereupon the legislators shall receive the pay which had been withheld, does not violate the principle of separation of powers; rather, it adds procedural oil to the delicately calibrated mechanism by which a budget is enacted. The Legislature, as a branch of government, must have "finally acted on" the appropriations submitted by the Governor before individual legislators may be paid, and that inducement does not require that the Legislature pass the Governor's budget; only that it pass some budget. The plaintiffs in this case, legislators who were in office and voted against chapter 635 and others who were not yet in office, sue as individuals, not as the Legislative branch of government; however, it is the correlative oversight of each lawmaking branch over one another--in essence a dependency, rather than a separation--that balances the overall power to protect the public's interests, not those individuals who occupy the offices of those branches at varying times. Although chapter 635 pinpoints a particular interdependence of the Legislature and Executive with respect to the budget-making process, it does not impermissibly merge or shift the powers between those two branches. In the end, the Legislature always does the legislating. It is institutional interdependence, rather than functional independence that best summarizes the idea of protecting liberty by fragmenting power.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Statute Withholding Legislators' Salaries until State Budget is Passed - Separation of Powers

4. Chapter 635 of the Laws of 1998, which provides that if the Legislature has not passed a State budget by the first day of any fiscal year, then the salaries of its members shall be withheld and not paid until legislative passage of a State budget has occurred, whereupon the legislators shall receive the pay which had been withheld, does not violate the principle of separation of powers, and even assuming that the law does recalibrate some of the negotiating leverage between the Legislative and Executive branches of government, that shift has occurred as a direct result of the Legislature's own bicameral action. Its official work was done qua branch of the government, and the Legislature has decided to restrict itself and discipline its own work and power in this fashion; that is not a cognizable separation of powers problem. Without a State budget or without messages of necessity and interim authorizations or continuing concurrent resolutions, no State expenditures could be made to anyone, including legislators. Thus, after a fiscal year concludes, and until a new budget is passed for the following year, the payment of compensation to legislators is inescapably contingent and dependent upon the extant Executive's discretionary powers. Chapter 635 does not create or result in "extortionate economic pressure," since there is no substantially different economic duress created by chapter 635 than that which is inherent in the ordinary lawmaking process, budget-related and otherwise. When the plaintiffs, legislators who were in office and voted against chapter 635 and others who were not yet in office, object to "economic pressure," they are essentially attacking the fundamental, albeit rambunctious, realities of the political structure and process, including how public monies shall be allocated; however, no basis within the judicial review function supports the extraordinary superintendence and judicial nullification of chapter 635 that plaintiffs facially seek.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Statute Withholding Legislators' Salaries until State Budget is Passed - Role of State Comptroller

5. Chapter 635 of the Laws of 1998, which provides that if the Legislature has not passed a State budget by the first day of any fiscal year, then the salaries of its members shall be withheld and not paid until legislative passage of a State budget has occurred, whereupon the legislators shall receive the pay which had been withheld, does not inject an unconstitutional delegation of power to the State Comptroller, who is authorized to determine if the budget is "sufficient for the ongoing operation and support of state government and local assistance," since the Comptroller's defined involvement fits within and fulfills his independent fiscal role as a vital part of the constitutional machinery for assuring accountability in the expenditure of State funds. By chapter 635, the Legislature has plainly confirmed the Comptroller's customary responsibility for ensuring the availability of revenues that would be expended through the enacted appropriations bills, and this reinforcement in no way authorizes the Comptroller to "determine" when legislators shall be paid. Rather, that determination remains exclusively within the control, timing and power of the bicameral Legislature itself, acting as a branch of government when it enacts a timely budget, as is its constitutional duty.

 

7 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Gelman


No. 82


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


93 N.Y.2d 314; 712 N.E.2d 686; 690 N.Y.S.2d 520; 1999 N.Y. LEXIS 1142


March 29, 1999, Argued  
May 11, 1999, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District (New York), which affirmed a conviction entered against defendant of arson in the first degree, conspiracy in the second degree, and reckless endangerment in the first degree. Defendant challenged the state of New York's resubmission of charges to a second grand jury trial after the matter was withdrawn from the first.


OVERVIEW: The conviction entered against defendant for arson in the first degree, conspiracy in the second degree, and reckless endangerment in the first degree was affirmed. Defendant challenged the resubmission of charges to a second grand jury that had been withdrawn from the first. The court held that the state of New York was not required to seek judicial intervention when the charges were resubmitted to the second grand jury. The state of New York presented little evidence of criminal conduct and there was no evidence that linked defendant to the commission of the crime. The court held that defendant's challenge of his waiver of a jury trial based on promised favorable treatment was without merit.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the conviction entered against defendant for arson in the first degree, conspiracy in the second degree, and reckless endangerment in the first degree because the state of New York did not need judicial intervention before the state resubmitted the charges to a second grand jury after the matter was withdrawn from the first.


HEADNOTES

Grand Jury - Defective Proceeding - Prosecutor's Withdrawal of Case before Consideration of Evidence and Charge

1. The prosecutor's withdrawal of a case from the Grand Jury should not be deemed a dismissal requiring judicial intervention before the case may be submitted to another Grand Jury (see, CPL 190.75) where withdrawal resulted from the People's inability to produce a necessary witness prior to the end of the Grand Jury's term, little evidence of criminal conduct had been presented to the Grand Jury, and there was no evidence linking defendant to the commission of the crime. Under limited circumstances, the withdrawal of a case is fundamentally inconsistent with the objectives underlying CPL 190.75 and, therefore, should be deemed a dismissal requiring judicial intervention before re-presentation. The key factor in determining whether an unauthorized withdrawal of the case must be treated as a dismissal is the extent to which the Grand Jury considered the evidence and the charge. Here, the Grand Jury did not consider the evidence and the charge against defendant. The People presented only two witnesses, neither of whom linked defendant to the commission of this crime. Nor can the Grand Jury's refusal to extend its term to enable the People to produce the unavailable witness be equated to a disapproval of the People's case or manipulation of the Grand Jury process. Under these circumstances, the integrity of the Grand Jury proceedings was not impaired, and withdrawal of the case was not tantamount to a dismissal.

Crimes - Right to Jury Trial - Waiver

2. Defendant's waiver of his right to a jury trial was not involuntary where defendant executed the written waiver after the Trial Judge's law clerk remarked to defendant's counsel that he agreed with counsel that defendant would be better off with a Bench trial, and that the Judge would certainly give him a fair trial. While the law clerk's remarks to defense counsel were imprudent, the claimed assertion does not render defendant's decision to waive his right to a jury trial involuntary inasmuch as no promises as to either the determination of guilt or sentencing were made by the law clerk. A promise of favorable treatment that is not fulfilled may invalidate a defendant's waiver of his right to a jury trial if reliance on that promise is objectively reasonable. Here, objectively viewed, at most there was a suggestion that the trial court would be a fair arbiter of the facts, and that this might be more than defendant could expect from a jury of his peers. There was no actual promise of favorable treatment, and any expectation that defendant or his counsel may have harbored in this regard simply was not reasonable.

 

8 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Grumet v. Pataki


No. 38


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


93 N.Y.2d 677; 720 N.E.2d 66; 697 N.Y.S.2d 846; 1999 N.Y. LEXIS 1144


February 10, 1999, Argued  
May 11, 1999, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants challenged an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed an order of summary judgment in favor of respondent taxpayers that invalidated N.Y. Educ. Law § 1504(3) as violative of the Establishment Clause of U.S. Const. amend. I, and permanently enjoined appellants from taking any action to implement it.


OVERVIEW: After the court's determinations that prior statutes violated the Establishment Clause of U.S. Const. amend. I, appellants challenged an appellate court order that affirmed summary judgment in favor of respondent taxpayers and declared a third statute, N.Y. Educ. Law § 1504(3), unconstitutional. The statute at issue allowed appellant village, comprised of Hasidic Jews, to create a separate school district for its disabled children. The appellate court unanimously affirmed a ruling that the statute was unconstitutional, because it applied to only two of the State's 1,545 municipalities and was not a truly religious-neutral law of general applicability. Appellants argued the law was constitutional because it was enacted to achieve a lawful legislative objective. The court disagreed and affirmed the lower courts' orders, holding that a statute so narrowly drawn that it delegated governmental power almost exclusively to a single religious group, and provided no assurance that its benefits would be equally available to others, was unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the lower courts' orders declaring educational statute unconstitutional because, taking into account both the origin and operation of the statute, the conclusion was inescapable that the statute had the primary effect of advancing religion and therefore constituted an impermissible accommodation to a single religious group.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Establishment of Religion - Validity of Statute Permitting Creation of School District Solely within Municipality to Meet Required Educational Needs - Governmental Neutrality

1. Chapter 390 of the Laws of 1997, which enables a village, all of whose residents are members of a religious sect, to create a separate public school district for its disabled children, violates the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment of the United States Constitution since it has the impermissible effect of advancing one religious sect and, thus, violates fundamental Establishment Clause neutrality principles. Although chapter 390 sets forth facially neutral criteria, any attempt to characterize the statute as a religion-neutral law of general applicability is belied by its actual effect, which benefits only the village in question and one other of the State's 1,545 municipalities. In practical effect, therefore, the religious community of the village in question is not merely one in a series of many communities eligible for equal treatment under chapter 390; rather, since the statute's qualifying criteria are consciously drawn to benefit said village, other communities, both religious and secular, with similar educational needs will not have equal opportunity to create a publicly funded school district under the statute. Thus, the nonneutral effect of the statute is to secure for one religious community a unique and significant benefit--a "public school" where all the students adhere to the tenets of a particular religion--unavailable to other, similarly situated communities. Moreover, allowing only one other municipality to qualify under the statute does not render it a general, religion-neutral law.

Constitutional Law - Establishment of Religion - Validity of Statute Permitting Creation of School District Solely within Municipality to Meet Required Educational Needs - Impermissible Religious Accommodation

2. Chapter 390 of the Laws of 1997, which enables a village, all of whose residents are members of a religious sect, to create a separate public school district for its disabled children, violates the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment of the United States Constitution since it has the effect of advancing one religion over another and constitutes an impermissible religious accommodation. Although the statute neither provides public aid to a parochial school nor prescribes religious practices for a public school, it delegates to a religious group the governmental power to form its own public school district, which carries with it vast powers. All Establishment Clause constitutional standards build upon the same foundation, fundamental neutrality principles, and to consider whether a statute has the impermissible effect of advancing one religion or constitutes an impermissible religious accommodation is essentially to examine both sides of a coin; under either inquiry, a statute so narrowly drawn that it delegates a significant governmental power almost exclusively to a single religious group, and provides no assurance that the statute's benefits will be equally available to others, is unconstitutional. In light of the events surrounding the enactment of chapter 390 and its legislative history, it is clear that the statute does not constitute a permissible religious accommodation; the class benefitted under it is anything but broad. Given the statute's applicability to only two municipalities, one of which is a religious sect clearly intended to be the statute's beneficiary, the secular effect of it is virtually indiscernible.

 

9 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Rudder v. Pataki


No. 61


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


93 N.Y.2d 273; 711 N.E.2d 978; 689 N.Y.S.2d 701; 1999 N.Y. LEXIS 814


March 23, 1999, Argued  
May 6, 1999, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs appealed a decision from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York) affirming an order granting summary judgment in favor of defendants and denying summary judgment for plaintiffs, in an action alleging that defendant governor's Executive Order No. 20 violated the constitutional principle of separation of powers and violated the State Administrative Procedure Act.


OVERVIEW: The court affirmed a judgment upholding an order granting summary judgment in favor of defendants and denying summary judgment for plaintiffs, in a suit alleging that defendant governor's Executive Order No. 20 violated the constitutional principle of separation of powers and violated the State Administrative Procedure Act. The court held that plaintiffs lacked standing to sue. Plaintiffs' challenge to the order was filed following the disapproval of a proposed amendment to a regulation that would have required urban hospitals to have social work departments headed by directors with master's degrees. According to the court, the organizational plaintiffs, including an organization for social workers and an organization for individuals receiving services from social workers, failed to allege cognizable harm to their members. Also, the claims did not demonstrate a sufficient nexus to fiscal activities of the state to allow for citizen-taxpayer standing under N.Y. State Fin. Law § 123-b. Finally, there was no claim of injury fairly attributable to the sphere of voting rights to justify voter standing. The court therefore did not reach any other issues.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed judgment upholding an order granting summary judgment for defendants and denying summary judgment for plaintiffs in a suit alleging that an executive order violated separation of powers and the State Administrative Procedure Act. Plaintiffs lacked standing to sue where organizational plaintiffs failed to allege cognizable harm to members, there was no citizen-taxpayer standing, and claims did not justify voter standing.


HEADNOTES

Parties - Standing - Organizational Standing - Failure to Allege Cognizable Harm to Members - Social Workers

1. In an action challenging the Governor's authority to implement an Executive Order that established the Governor's Office of Regulatory Reform (GORR), which permits gubernatorial appointees to effectively block rules proposed by executive agencies, the organizational plaintiffs representing social workers lack standing to challenge the disapproval by GORR of a proposed regulatory change which would have required the director of each organized social work department in an urban hospital to hold a master's degree in social work (MSW), since they have failed to allege any cognizable harm to their members. Although some holders of MSW's will not have the benefit of increased job prospects because GORR blocked the proposed rule change, that does not mean that any one individual member of plaintiff organizations has been or will be injured, since the organization members who hold MSW's are neither prohibited from seeking a certain portion of available jobs, nor deprived of monies to which they may be statutorily entitled. Rather, they are merely not given preference over those who do not hold an MSW degree, and at best, this amounts to only "tenuous" and "ephemeral" harm, which is insufficient to trigger judicial intervention.

Parties - Standing - Organizational Standing - Failure to Allege Cognizable Harm to Members - Social Workers

2. In an action challenging the Governor's authority to implement an Executive Order that established the Governor's Office of Regulatory Reform (GORR), which permits gubernatorial appointees to effectively block rules proposed by executive agencies, the organizational plaintiffs representing social workers lack standing to challenge the disapproval by GORR of a proposed regulatory change which would have required the director of each organized social work department in an urban hospital to hold a master's degree in social work (MSW), since the interests of the organizations representing MSW's are not entirely germane to the relief they seek in this litigation. These organizations have failed to identify any statutory or constitutional provision intended to prevent economic injury resulting from decreased employment opportunities, and neither organizational plaintiff is alleged to represent solely individuals with MSW's. As a result, it cannot be said that the interests of the organizations dovetail with the claims they put forth here. By seeking to enhance job opportunities of only some of their members--those holding MSW's--these groups implicitly seek to diminish job opportunities for other of their members--those otherwise qualified social workers who do not hold MSW's, and this imperfect alignment of interests, when considered along with the negligible injury asserted, leads to the conclusion that these organizations lack standing.

Parties - Standing - Organizational Standing - Failure to Allege Cognizable Harm to Members - Social Workers

3. In an action challenging the Governor's authority to implement an Executive Order that established the Governor's Office of Regulatory Reform (GORR), which permits gubernatorial appointees to effectively block rules proposed by executive agencies, the organizational plaintiffs representing persons who receive social work services lack standing to challenge the disapproval by GORR of a proposed regulatory change which would have required the director of each organized social work department in an urban hospital to hold a master's degree in social work, since their allegations of specific injury are tenuous. Although a principal purpose of these organizations is improving care for their members, which includes improving social work services, these organizations fail to point to a specific harm to any of their members which could be attributed to the disapproval of the proposed rule. Indeed, plaintiffs do not claim that any one person has suffered, but rather assert conclusorily that the delivery of social work could be better if the proposed rule were allowed to go forward. Without an allegation of injury-in-fact, plaintiffs' assertions are little more than an attempt to legislate through the courts. Furthermore, this is not a case where to deny standing to these plaintiffs would insulate government action from judicial scrutiny, since other actions by GORR may trigger the specific harm necessary to confer standing, and the Legislature retains its power to address the Executive Order in question.

Parties - Standing - Taxpayer Standing - Challenge to Executive Order Effectively Blocking Implementation of Proposed Rule

4. In an action challenging the Governor's authority to implement an Executive Order that established the Governor's Office of Regulatory Reform (GORR), which permits gubernatorial appointees to effectively block rules proposed by executive agencies, plaintiff, as a taxpayer, lacks standing under State Finance Law § 123-b to challenge the disapproval by GORR of a proposed regulatory change which would have required the director of each organized social work department in an urban hospital to hold a master's degree in social work, since plaintiff essentially seeks to obtain judicial scrutiny of the State's nonfiscal activities. Inasmuch as most activities can be viewed as having some relationship to expenditures, too broad a reading of section 123-b would create standing for any citizen who had the desire to challenge virtually all governmental acts. Plaintiff's claims regarding GORR's nonfiscal rule-making review function do not demonstrate a sufficient nexus to fiscal activities of the State to allow for standing under the statute.

Parties - Standing - Voter Standing - Challenge to Executive Order Effectively Blocking Implementation of Proposed Rule

5. The individual plaintiff and two organizations lack standing, as voters, to challenge the Governor's authority to implement an Executive Order that established the Governor's Office of Regulatory Reform, which permits gubernatorial appointees to effectively block rules proposed by executive agencies. Plaintiffs point to no specific constitutional provision having a connection to the franchise and no statute even tangentially related to the right to vote. Although, in some circumstances, allegations of governmental action impinging upon the constitutional separation of powers may bear so heavily on the right to vote as to dilute or impair it, plaintiffs raise no claim of injury fairly attributable to the sphere of voting rights.

 

10 of 992 DOCUMENTS


McCall v. Barrios-Paoli


No. 37


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


93 N.Y.2d 99; 710 N.E.2d 671; 688 N.Y.S.2d 107; 1999 N.Y. LEXIS 225


February 10, 1999, Argued  
April 1, 1999, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondents sought review from an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed an order granting a motion by petitioner to compel compliance with certain nonjudicial subpoenas, and directing respondents to comply with the subpoenas in an action involving the state comptroller's power to investigate the efficiency of New York City agencies.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner sought to conduct performance audits of New York City agencies. The supreme court and appellate division concluded that petitioner had authority to perform such audits. On appeal, respondents contended that use of the word "accounts" in the state constitution and statutes governing petitioner's powers limited his auditing authority to financial matters. The court acknowledged that neither source specifies what type of audits the comptroller may conduct. But it said the key constitutional phrase in N.Y. Const. art. V § 1, which empowered the legislature to assign to the comptroller supervision of the accounts of any municipality, left ample room for wider inquiry by the comptroller. Moreover, N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law §§ 33 and 34 authorized the comptroller to inquire into the financial condition and resources of a municipality. Although the statutes did not expressly permit or preclude performance audits, the court said, clearly these powers go beyond the verification of financial records and internal controls.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment, which upheld the state comptroller's power to investigate the efficiency of New York City agencies, ordering respondents to comply with 17 subpoenas for information on an array of programs. The court found that performance audits were historically one of the comptroller's core functions.


HEADNOTES

State - Comptroller - Authority to Conduct Performance Audits of New York City Agencies

1. The State Comptroller has the authority to conduct performance audits of New York City agencies, which examine the performance of government organizations, programs, activities or functions, in order to provide information to improve public accountability and facilitate decision making by parties with responsibility to oversee or initiate corrective action, because the State has far-reaching responsibility for programs and services of its political subdivisions, each year appropriating significant public monies to local governments, and the Comptroller, as the State's chief fiscal officer, is a vital part of the constitutional machinery for assuring accountability in the expenditure of those funds.

State - Comptroller - Constitutional Authority to Conduct Performance Audits of New York City Agencies

2. NY State Constitution, article V, § 1 broadly empowers the Legislature to delegate to the Comptroller both supervision of the accounts of any political subdivision of the State and administrative duties incidental thereto, and it cannot be said that the meaning of "accounts", as well as "supervision of accounts", is so plain and precise as to signify financial audits and prohibit performance audits. It is hard to think of a situation in which incompetence or laxity so general as to amount to proof of method will not also have direct relation to the accounts of the department or office subject to the criticism, since the wages of the assistants are wastefully expended if reasonably efficient service is not rendered in return. Accordingly, the Comptroller is not precluded from inquiring into the efficiency and effectiveness of the City's expenditure of State funds, and the authority to supervise the accounts of the State's political subdivisions leaves ample room for wider inquiry by the Comptroller.

State - Comptroller - Constitutional Authority to Conduct Performance Audits of New York City Agencies

3. NY State Constitution, article V, § 1 gives the State Comptroller the authority to conduct performance audits of New York City agencies, and constitutional history does not evince an intent to limit the Comptroller's authority to conducting financial audits; rather, the Comptroller's authority to supervise "accounts" mentioned in that section has never been confined to examinations of a municipality's financial records, but has included the broader inquiry contemplated by performance audits. Article V, § 1 had as its object the protection of the independent character of the Comptroller's audit function, was not intended as a limit to that core function, and permits the delegation of authority to conduct performance audits of political subdivisions of the State.

State - Comptroller - Statutory Authority to Conduct Performance Audits of New York City Agencies

4. The State Comptroller has the authority to conduct performance audits of New York City agencies. Although the General Municipal Law neither explicitly authorizes nor prohibits such audits, sections 33 and 34 thereof expressly authorize the Comptroller to examine the accounts of all municipal officers to inquire into the "financial condition," "resources" and "method and accuracy of [the] accounts" of any municipal corporation, and to examine into its "financial affairs." Those powers go beyond the verification of financial records and internal controls. The history of the statutes, moreover, unambiguously demonstrates that the Legislature expected the State Comptroller might conduct audits into the effective use of State funds by political subdivisions.

State - Comptroller - Statutory Authority to Conduct Performance Audits of New York City Agencies

5. The State Comptroller has the authority to conduct performance audits of New York City agencies, and it cannot be said that because the New York City Comptroller has the explicit authority under the New York City Charter to conduct such audits, the Legislature did not intend to duplicate those powers, since the provision of the Charter granting such authority was enacted by the people of the City and as such did not displace the State Comptroller's authority under General Municipal Law §§ 33 and 34. Moreover, there is nothing to suggest that the State Legislature intended that performance audits of the City would be conducted exclusively by the City Comptroller. In 1985, the Legislature established the Office of the Deputy Comptroller for the City of New York as a permanent division within the Office of the State Comptroller, unambiguously evidencing its intention that the State Comptroller have the power to inquire into the operations of the City and its agencies irrespective of the City Comptroller's coextensive powers. Finally, the City concedes that the State Comptroller is authorized to conduct financial audits of City agencies--a duty similarly assigned by the City Charter to the City Comptroller.

 

11 of 992 DOCUMENTS


D'Amico v. Crosson


No. 33


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


93 N.Y.2d 29; 709 N.E.2d 465; 686 N.Y.S.2d 756; 1999 N.Y. LEXIS 200


February 9, 1999, Argued  
March 25, 1999, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment of Supreme Court appealed from and order of the Appellate Division brought up for review reversed, with costs, and case remitted to Supreme Court, Erie County, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, as Chief Administrator of the Courts of the State of New York and as Representative of the Administrative Board of the Judicial Conference of the State of New York, and others, appealed from a stipulation, treated as a judgment, of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York), which declared unconstitutional the pay disparity between plaintiff judges and judges of another county.


OVERVIEW: The lower court held that defendants violated plaintiff judges' equal protection rights by causing plaintiffs to be paid less than their counterpart judges in another county. The lower court also held that plaintiffs' similar claims regarding disparity in the salaries of judges in two other counties were accordingly moot. The court on appeal determined that because N.Y. Jud. Law § 221-d prescribed and varied the pay of the judges of the county courts on the basis of geographical location, it was required to pass only rational basis review to be upheld as constitutional. The court found that defendants had submitted data that provided a rational basis for the disparity in pay between plaintiffs and the judges of the other county court. The court therefore rejected the lower court's "totality of economic indicators" test as contrary to the essential governing rational basis test. The court held that defendants were entitled to judgment as a matter of law, dismissing plaintiffs' second cause of action as it related to the pay disparity between plaintiffs and their counterpart county court judges.


OUTCOME: Judgment which declared unconstitutional the pay disparity between plaintiff judges and judges of another county was reversed. However, because the lower court invoked mootness regarding the merits of plaintiffs' two remaining causes of action as to pay disparities between plaintiffs and the judges of two other county courts, the case was remitted to the lower court for further proceedings.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Equal Protection of Laws - Rational Basis Test - Disparate Treatment Based on Geographical Location

1. Under the Equal Protection Clauses of the United States and New York Constitutions (US Const 14th Amend; NY Const, art I, § 11), a statute which causes disparate treatment but does not target a suspect class nor implicate a fundamental right is subject to rational basis scrutiny. Accordingly, in an action by Judges of the Erie County Court claiming that defendants violated their equal protection rights by causing them to be paid less than their counterpart Judges in the County Courts of certain other counties pursuant to Judiciary Law § 221-d, the statute need pass only rational basis review to be upheld as constitutional inasmuch as it prescribes and varies the pay of the Judges of the County Court on the basis of geographical location.

Judges - Judicial Salaries - Geographical Classifications - Equal Protection

2. The equal protection rights of Judges of the Erie County Court under the United States and New York Constitutions (US Const 14th Amend; NY Const, art I, § 11) were not violated because they were paid less than their counterpart Judges in the Albany County Court pursuant to Judiciary Law § 221-d, which prescribes and varies the pay of the Judges of the County Court on the basis of geographical location. Data submitted by defendants indicating that median home values were nearly 50% higher in Albany County than in Erie County, and that Albany County Court Judges have larger case loads per Judge than Erie County Court Judges provide a rational basis for the 4.6% disparity in pay between plaintiffs and the Judges of the Albany County Court. These data support the disparate treatment based on geography effected by Judiciary Law § 221-d as between the Judges of the Albany and Erie County Courts.

 

12 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Bernard v. Scharf


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


93 N.Y.2d 842; 711 N.E.2d 187; 689 N.Y.S.2d 1; 1999 N.Y. LEXIS 1216



February 23, 1999, Decided


HEADNOTES

Appeal - Academic and Moot Questions - Rehabilitation of Damaged Building

In a proceeding in which petitioners seek to compel respondents to rehabilitate a residential building which was damaged by fire, an order of the Appellate Division, which reversed an order directing respondents to restore the subject premises to a safe and habitable condition, and dismissed the petition, is reversed and the case remitted to the Civil Court of the City of New York with directions to dismiss the proceeding upon the ground of mootness, where the building has been rehabilitated following the filing of a notice of appeal to the Court of Appeals.

 

13 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Tortorici


No. 15


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


92 N.Y.2d 757; 709 N.E.2d 87; 686 N.Y.S.2d 346; 1999 N.Y. LEXIS 26


January 12, 1999, Argued  
 February 18, 1999, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Certiorari Denied October 4, 1999, Reported at: 1999 U.S. LEXIS 5252.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed, by permission of a justice of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), from an order of that court that affirmed a judgment of the Albany County Court (New York) rendered upon a verdict convicting defendant of various criminal charges.


OVERVIEW: Defendant contended that the trial court erred in not sua sponte ordering a competency hearing. On appeal, the instant court stated that a defendant was presumed to be competent, and was not entitled as a matter of right to have the question of his capacity to stand trial passed upon before the commencement of the trial. The court stated that a report certifying defendant competent to proceed to trial contained the most recent opinion of a psychiatrist who examined defendant for the purpose of determining competency to stand trial, and was therefore entitled to significant weight. The report explicitly stated that defendant had satisfactory knowledge of courtroom procedure and the duties of court officials. Moreover, defendant clearly indicated that he understood his right to be present in the courtroom and consult with counsel. At no time after defendant was certified as competent did defense counsel raise the issue of defendant's fitness to proceed or request an examination pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law 730.30. Thus, the trial judge was within his discretion in making the determination that no competency hearing was required.


OUTCOME: The instant court affirmed the decision of the court below, which affirmed a judgment of the trial court rendered upon a verdict convicting defendant of various criminal charges, on the grounds that the trial judge was within his discretion in making the requisite judicial determination that no competency hearing was required.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Fitness to Proceed to Trial - Discretion of Court to Order Competency Hearing Sua Sponte

In the prosecution of defendant, who was found to be competent by the institution where he was initially committed pursuant to a temporary order of observation, the trial court did not abuse its discretion as a matter of law by failing, on its own, to order a competency hearing under CPL article 730, notwithstanding that a psychiatrist who conducted a CPL 250.10 (3) examination to determine whether defendant lacked responsibility due to mental disease or defect at the time of the crime opined in his report that defendant was not fit to proceed to trial. CPL 730.30 (1) provides that the court wherein the criminal action is pending must issue an order of examination when it is of the opinion that the defendant may be an incapacitated person. Pursuant to CPL 730.60 (2), in cases where, as here, the institution in which a defendant has been confined has determined that the defendant is no longer incapacitated, the court may, on its own motion, conduct a hearing to determine the issue of capacity, and it must conduct a hearing upon motion therefor by the defendant or by the District Attorney. A Trial Judge determining whether a competency hearing is necessary may consider expert medical proof available to him, coupled with all other evidence and his own observations of the defendant. Here, the psychiatric report certifying defendant competent to proceed to trial contained the most recent opinion of a psychiatrist who examined defendant for the purpose of determining competency to stand trial, and therefore was entitled to significant weight. The Trial Judge additionally could consider his progressive personal observations of defendant, and continued to monitor defendant's understanding of his rights and the proceedings against him throughout the duration of the trial, even though defendant himself did not appear in court of his own volition. Further, at no time after defendant was certified as competent did defense counsel, who was in the best position to assess defendant's capacity, raise the issue of defendant's fitness to proceed or request an examination pursuant to CPL 730.30. Moreover, many of the findings in the CPL 250.10 (3) report themselves satisfy the legal standard of fitness to proceed and, thus, undercut that report's conclusions that defendant was incapable of rational participation in court proceedings and was not fit to proceed to trial.

 

14 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Hynes v. Tomei


No. 146, No. 176


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


92 N.Y.2d 613; 706 N.E.2d 1201; 684 N.Y.S.2d 177; 1998 N.Y. LEXIS 4140


October 14, 1998, Argued  
 December 22, 1998, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Certiorari Denied June 14, 1999, Reported at: 1999 U.S. LEXIS 4184.



DISPOSITION: Nos. 146 and 176: Order reversed, without costs, and judgment granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants sought review of Appellate Division of Supreme Court in Second and Fourth Judicial Departments (New York) orders, which converted the proceeding in the nature of prohibition into declaratory judgment action, declaring N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 220.10(5)(e), 220.30(3)(b)(vii), and 220.60(2)(a) to be constitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendants challenged plea provisions of New York capital punishment statute, 1995 N.Y. Laws ch. 1 (Act), as violative of their U.S. Const. amend. V and VI rights. The Act allowed defendants to be sentenced to death only after jury trial. Bench trials were not permitted in capital cases and the Act barred imposition of a death sentence upon a guilty plea. New York law thus explicitly provided two levels of penalty for the same offense, imposing death only on those who asserted innocence and proceeded to trial. The lower courts declared the provisions constitutional. On appeal, the court reversed, declaring N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 220.10(5)(e) and 220.30(3)(b)(vii) unconstitutional and deemed severed and stricken, and the remainder of the Act was unaffected. A procedure that offered an individual a reward for waiving fundamental constitutional rights, or imposed a harsher penalty for asserting it, could not be sustained.


OUTCOME: The orders were reversed because a procedure that offered an individual a reward for waiving fundamental constitutional rights, or imposed a harsher penalty for asserting it, could not be sustained.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Murder - Constitution ality of Plea Bargain Provisions of Death Penalty Statute - CPL 220.10 (5) (e) and 220.30 (3) (b) (vii) 

1. The provisions of New York's death penalty statute which afford a defendant the opportunity to ensure a maximum sentence of life without parole by pleading guilty "with both the permission of the court and the consent of the people when the agreed upon sentence is either life imprisonment without parole or a term of imprisonment for the class A-I felony of murder in the first degree other than a sentence of life imprisonment without parole" ( CPL 220.10 [5] [e]; 220.30 [3] [b] [vii]) are unconstitutional. New York's death penalty statute explicitly provides for the imposition of the death penalty only upon a jury verdict and, therefore, only those defendants who exercise the Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination and Sixth Amendment right to a jury trial put themselves at risk of death. The chilling effect on a defendant's exercise of those Fifth and Sixth Amendment rights is unnecessary and therefore excessive. The United States Supreme Court has found approval of the trial court and prosecutor is irrelevant to the constitutional analysis inasmuch as the statute's infirmity is not coercion of guilty pleas and jury waivers but needless encouragement of them. Further, while plea bargaining is permissible, statutes, such as New York's, that needlessly encourage guilty pleas, which are not constitutionally protected, by impermissibly burdening constitutional rights are prohibited. Nor does the bifurcated capital trial procedure in New York, by which a jury that finds a defendant guilty determines the sentence in a separate proceeding (see, CPL 400.27), alleviate the constitutional infirmity, since bifurcation does not eliminate the statutory framework that allows the possibility of death only after a jury trial.

Crimes - Murder - Severability of Unconstitutional Plea Bargain Provisions of Death Penalty Statute 

2. The declaration of unconstitutionality of the provisions of New York's death penalty statute which afford a defendant the opportunity to ensure a maximum sentence of life without parole by pleading guilty ( CPL 220.10 [5] [e]; 220.30 [3] [b] [vii]) does not require invalidation of the entire death penalty statute. It is clear from the face of the statute that the very purpose of the Legislature and Governor in enacting the statute was to provide for capital punishment in New York. The statute's severability clause (L 1995, ch 1, § 37) indicates that the lawmakers would not have wanted the entire statute to fail if the particular provisions regarding pleas were declared unconstitutional. Nor is invalidation of the death penalty necessary to obviate the constitutional infirmity: excision of the capital pleading provisions eliminates the prohibited burden on constitutional rights. Furthermore, the plea provisions are discrete, and by no means vital to the remainder of the statute.

Crimes - Murder - Constitution ality of Plea Bargain Provisions of Death Penalty Statute - CPL 220.60 (2) (a) 

3. CPL 220.60 (2) (a), which allows defendants who have pleaded not guilty to any indictment to withdraw the plea before a verdict, subject to certain limitations, need not be declared unconstitutional as a result of the declaration of unconstitutionality of the provisions of New York's death penalty statute which afford a defendant the opportunity to ensure a maximum sentence of life without parole by pleading guilty ( CPL 220.10 [5] [e]; 220.30 [3] [b] [vii]). While CPL 220.10 (5) (e) and 220.30 (3) (b) (vii) relate exclusively to pleas in first degree murder cases and "needlessly" encourage guilty pleas, CPL 220.60 (2) (a) is not limited to first degree murder cases, and is, therefore, constitutional in the absence of the other two unconstitutional provisions. Therefore, only CPL 220.10 (5) (e) and 220.30 (3) (b) (vii) must be stricken.

Crimes - Murder - Effect of Unconstitutionality of Plea Bargain Provisions of Death Penalty Statute 

4. In light of the declaration of unconstitutionality and severance of the provisions of New York's death penalty statute which afford a defendant the opportunity to ensure a maximum sentence of life without parole by pleading guilty ( CPL 220.10 [5] [e]; 220.30 [3] [b] [vii]), a defendant may not plead guilty to first degree murder under the resulting statute while a notice of intent to seek the death penalty is pending. However, excision of the unconstitutional provisions does not prevent pleas of guilty to first degree murder when no notice of intent to seek the death penalty is pending, since defendants in that situation face the same maximum sentence regardless of how they are convicted. Nor does excision of the provision prevent pleas of guilty to offenses not punishable by death, even when a notice to seek the death penalty is pending.

 

15 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Stahlbrodt v. Commissioner of Taxation & Fin.


No. 187


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


92 N.Y.2d 646; 707 N.E.2d 421; 684 N.Y.S.2d 466; 1998 N.Y. LEXIS 4136


November 17, 1998, Argued  
 December 17, 1998, Decided



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff shopping paper challenged the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed the dismissal of plaintiff's complaint seeking a declaration that N.Y. Tax Law § 1115(i)(C) was unconstitutional. Plaintiff contended that the 90 percent rule of § 1115(i)(C) made entitlement to sales tax exemption discriminatory.


OVERVIEW: On appeal from the dismissal of plaintiff shopping paper's complaint, plaintiff contended that N.Y. Tax Law § 1115(i)(C) was unconstitutional. The court disagreed and affirmed the constitutionality of the statute but modified the order to grant judgment to defendant tax commissioner, rather than dismiss plaintiff's complaint. First, the imposition of the sales tax at issue was not directed at the press in general, but was one of general application. Further, the 90 percent rule, which was designed to ensure that at least 10 percent of an exempt publication would be devoted to news of general interest, did not enforce any differential treatment based on the content of ideas or viewpoints expressed in plaintiff's paper. The legislature validly chose to decline to subsidize shopping papers that failed to serve community interest.


OUTCOME: The court modified the judgment dismissing plaintiff shopping paper's complaint and declared the sales tax exemption, for publications meeting the 90 percent rule, constitutional. The court held that the sales tax was of general application, and that the exemption for publications serving community interests was not discriminatory against plaintiff's paper because the distinction was not based on content.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Freedom of Press - Freedom of Speech - Tax Law Exempting Receipts from Sale of Printing Services Performed in Publishing Shopping Paper

 Tax Law § 1115 (i) (C), which conditions entitlement to the shopping paper sales tax exemption on whether advertising comprises not more than 90 percent of the printed area, is constitutional. The tax from which the exemption is available is one of general application, levied against virtually all final sales of products and services. Neither the print media in general, nor shopping papers in particular, are singled out for special treatment. Other forms of published commercial speech which are distributed free of charge, including shopping catalogs, advertising flyers and shopping center advertising sheets, do not enjoy any sales tax exemption for purchases of printing services (Tax Law § 1115 [i] [D]). Further, a taxpayer can readily qualify for the exemption. Moreover, the 90 percent rule does not enforce any differential treatment based on the content of ideas or viewpoints expressed in a shopping paper. Absent invidious discrimination, the Legislature can pick and choose between the forms of expression it decides to subsidize through a tax exemption. The Legislature may validly decline to subsidize shopping papers which fail to serve at least minimally the same social purpose as a conventional newspaper by informing the public in matters of community interest, rather than exclusively commercial interest.

 

16 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Transactive Corp. v. New York State Dep't of Soc. Servs.


No. 140, No. 141


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


92 N.Y.2d 579; 706 N.E.2d 1180; 684 N.Y.S.2d 156; 1998 N.Y. LEXIS 4041


October 13, 1998, Argued  
 December 3, 1998, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant subcontractor challenged a decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which dismissed his petition and found that respondent department of social services had awarded a public contract fairly.


OVERVIEW: Respondent department of social services awarded a public contract to build an electronic benefit transfer system. Appellant subcontractor brought an action challenging the fairness of the award.
