The appellate court dismissed appellant's petition, finding that respondent had not violated any finance law requirements and had awarded a public contract fairly. The court affirmed the appellate court's order on different grounds. The court found that appellant lacked standing, holding that appellant was not within the zone of interests protected by a procurement law, N.Y. State Fin. Law § 163, because he was not a bidder or offeror. The court also found that appellant had no common law standing because he was not seeking review of a legislative action, nor was there an impenetrable barrier to judicial scrutiny of a legislative action.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order dismissing appellant subcontractor's petition on different grounds, holding that appellant had no standing to challenge the award of a public contract because he was not within the zone of interests protected by the State Finance Law.


HEADNOTES

State - Bids and Bidders - Standing to Challenge Competitively Bid Contract

1. Petitioner trade association, joined by several local check cashing institutions, lack standing to bring a CPLR article 78 proceeding challenging the validity of a request for proposals, and the contract awarded thereunder, in connection with a new electronic benefit transfer system (EBTS) for the distribution of public assistance benefits to replace the system whereby government benefits are distributed by individual attendants at local check cashing institutions. For standing to sue, petitioners must show that they have suffered an injury in fact, distinct from that of the general public. Moreover, petitioners must demonstrate that the injury claimed falls within the zone of interests to be protected by the statute challenged. Here, because petitioner had no direct stake in the outcome of the bidding process, it did not suffer an injury in fact. Although it stood to lose remuneration for services performed under the pre-EBTS arrangement, that would be the case no matter who was awarded the contract. The injury suffered arose from the decision to have the EBTS, not from the procurement process to determine who would implement it. Additionally, petitioner's alleged injury is not within the zone of interests protected by State Finance Law § 163. The procurement process of the State, governed by State Finance Law article 11, exists to "promote purchasing from responsive and responsible offerers ... based on clearly articulated procedures" (State Finance Law § 163 [2]), but petitioner was not an offerer within the meaning of section 163 and acknowledged that it did not have the capacity to be a bidder and prime responsible contractor for this project.

State - Bids and Bidders - Standing to Challenge Competitively Bid Contract

2. Petitioner, a subcontractor of a bidder, lacks standing to bring a CPLR article 78 proceeding challenging the validity of a request for proposals, and the contract awarded thereunder, in connection with a new electronic benefit transfer system (EBTS) for the distribution of public assistance benefits to replace the system whereby government benefits are distributed by individual attendants at local check cashing institutions. For standing to sue, petitioners must show that they have suffered an injury in fact, distinct from that of the general public. Moreover, petitioners must demonstrate that the injury claimed falls within the zone of interests to be protected by the statute challenged. Petitioner, as a subcontractor and member of the "team" assembled to implement the contract, if awarded to the bidder, may be viewed as having suffered a potential economic injury, distinct from the public at large, because it lost the opportunity to perform work on the EBTS contract, and to benefit financially. Petitioner, however, is not within the zone of interests protected by State Finance Law § 163 because it was not a bidder or offerer under State Finance Law article 11. Allowing any entity to bring suit based upon its status as a "bidding team member" would confer standing for far too many potential litigants and allow those whose interests are only marginally related under State Finance Law § 163 concerns to assert collateral challenges.

State - Bids and Bidders - Statutory Taxpayer Standing to Challenge Competitively Bid Contract

3. Petitioners, a trade association, joined by several local check cashing institutions, and a New York public assistance benefits recipient and taxpayer, lack taxpayer standing under State Finance Law § 123-b to bring a CPLR article 78 proceeding challenging the validity of a request for proposals (RFP), and the contract awarded thereunder, in connection with a new electronic benefit transfer system (EBTS) for the distribution of public assistance benefits to replace the system whereby government benefits are distributed by individual attendants at local check cashing institutions. State Finance Law § 123 grants individual taxpayers "an interest in the proper disposition of all state funds and properties". However, claims which seek review of a State actor's alleged mismanagement of funds or the arbitrary and capricious distribution of funds lawfully allocated to an agency are not covered by section 123-b. Petitioners' claims are not of the kind for which State Finance Law § 123-b confers standing, inasmuch as they do not argue that the Department of Social Services acted outside its authority in issuing an RFP seeking bidders for an EBTS but, rather, take issue with the procurement procedures followed.

State - Bids and Bidders - Common-Law Taxpayer Standing to Challenge Competitively Bid Contract

4. Petitioners, a trade association, joined by several local check cashing institutions, and a New York public assistance benefits recipient and taxpayer, lack common-law taxpayer standing to bring a CPLR article 78 proceeding challenging the validity of a request for proposals, and the contract awarded thereunder, in connection with a new electronic benefit transfer system (EBTS) for the distribution of public assistance benefits to replace the system whereby government benefits are distributed by individual attendants at local check cashing institutions. A taxpayer has legal standing to challenge governmental action if the failure to accord such standing would be in effect to erect an impenetrable barrier to any judicial scrutiny of legislative action. Here, however, petitioners do not seek review of any legislative action. Further, no "impenetrable barrier" exists, as any of the bidders whose proposals were rejected could have brought suit to challenge the contract award made.

 

17 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Mental Hygiene Legal Servs. ex rel. Aliza K. v. Ford


No. 150


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


92 N.Y.2d 500; 705 N.E.2d 1191; 683 N.Y.S.2d 150; 1998 N.Y. LEXIS 4043


October 15, 1998, Argued  
December 3, 1998, Decided



DISPOSITION: The order of the Appellate Division should be reversed, without costs, the petition for a writ of habeas corpus should be denied, and judgment should be granted declaring that 14 NYCRR 57.2 is not rendered.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant challenged the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District (New York), which affirmed the decision declaring that respondent committed civil patient had a right to a judicial hearing prior to a nonemergency transfer to a secure facility.


OVERVIEW: Respondent committed civil patient was hospitalized at a state mental health center after she was found unfit to stand trial on charges of aggravated harassment. Following physical alterations, appellant representative of state psychiatric center requested that she be transferred to a secure facility. Respondent filed a writ of habeas corpus to block the transfer, claiming that she had a right to a judicial hearing prior to a nonemergency transfer. The state supreme court declared that a judicial hearing was required prior to transfer. The case was appealed. The court found that respondent's transfer implicated a liberty interest which triggered the right to due process. However, the court concluded that the requirements of due process were satisfied under the circumstances of the case and that there had been no showing that the additional safeguard of a judicial hearing would have reduced the possibility of an erroneous transfer decision. Reversing, the court held that N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 14, pt. 57 was not rendered unconstitutional by virtue of its failure to provide for a hearing prior to transfer of a patient from a nonsecure to a secure state facility.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision of the appellate court, finding that the requirements of due process were satisfied in the decision making process of appellant representative of state psychiatric center in issuing respondent committed civil patient's transfer to a secure facility.


HEADNOTES

Appeal - Academic and Moot Questions

1. A combined habeas corpus proceeding and declaratory judgment action commenced on behalf of an involuntarily committed civil patient hospitalized at a civil mental health facility of the State Office of Mental Health (OMH), which seeks to block her transfer to a secure OMH facility or to obtain her release alleging that she had a right to a judicial hearing prior to a nonemergency transfer to a secure OMH facility will not be dismissed as moot because Supreme Court has ordered her release. Even if the patient's present status renders the case moot as to her, the exception to the mootness doctrine for issues that are likely to recur applies. The Mental Hygiene Law contemplates that involuntary hospitalization in a mental health facility is often brief and temporary. That statute and its implementing regulations require frequent periodic review of a patient's status, and the release of the patient unless OMH is granted successive court orders authorizing retention (see, Mental Hygiene Law § 9.33; 14 NYCRR 57.4 [b]). Thus, this is the kind of case that is likely to recur, will typically evade review, and is substantial and novel.

Insane and Other Incompetent Persons - Involuntary Commitment - Liberty Interest of Civil Patient Transferred from Nonsecure to Secure Facility

2. The transfer of an involuntarily committed civil patient hospitalized at a civil mental health facility of the State Office of Mental Health (OMH) to a secure OMH facility, where all patients are subject to heightened security irrespective of their conduct and where a high percentage of the patients have been transferred from the criminal justice system as incompetent to stand trial (see, CPL art 730) or are committed as a result of having been found not criminally responsible by reason of mental disease or defect (see, CPL 330.20), implicates a liberty interest which triggers rights to procedural due process because the stigma of being a patient at the secure facility may be greater than that of being hospitalized at the civil mental health facility.

Insane and Other Incompetent Persons - Involuntary Commitment - Due Process of Law - Liberty Interest of Civil Patient Transferred from Nonsecure to Secure Facility

3. In a proceeding involving the potentially stigmatizing transfer of an involuntarily committed civil patient hospitalized at a civil mental health facility of the State Office of Mental Health (OMH) to a secure OMH facility, the requirements of due process were satisfied with respect to petitioner's liberty interest. The patient is being transferred to an OMH facility, not a correctional facility, and prior to the transfer request she was already confined to the Intensive Psychiatric Service unit of the nonsecure facility and her behavior required periods of enforced seclusion. Moreover, the secure facility permits freer movement of patients such as petitioner who require close supervision (14 NYCRR 57.1). Thus, petitioner has not established that her liberty interest was as severely affected as it would be by transfer to a penal, security-oriented facility operated by the Department of Correctional Services.

Insane and Other Incompetent Persons - Involuntary Commitment - Due Process of Law - Risk of Erroneous Deprivation of Liberty Interest of Civil Patient Transferred from Nonsecure to Secure Facility

4. In a proceeding involving the potentially stigmatizing transfer of an involuntarily committed civil patient hospitalized at a civil mental health facility of the State Office of Mental Health (OMH) to a secure OMH facility, the record does not substantiate the existence of any serious risk of an erroneous deprivation of the patient's liberty interest under the current transfer procedures of the Mental Hygiene Law and regulations such as would violate due process. Under the regulatory scheme, the transfer decision is primarily one of professional medical judgment as to the most appropriate therapeutic setting (14 NYCRR 57.1), and a patient for whom an application has been made has the rights of notice and complete disclosure of the documents submitted with the application, is afforded legal representation at all stages of the administrative process, and is entitled to a full review of the transfer by a qualified independent psychiatrist. At each stage, the patient and the patient's representative are entitled to submit opposing arguments and any pertinent countervailing evidence. The record does not substantiate the existence of any serious risk that these procedures give rise to erroneous transfer determinations. Nor has there been a showing that the additional safeguard of a judicial hearing would significantly reduce the possibility of an erroneous transfer decision. Shifting from mental health professionals to Judges the determination of which therapeutic environment is most appropriate would not significantly add assurance against the risk of an erroneous decision. Moreover, in the case of a violent mentally ill patient, security concerns are inextricably linked to considerations of professional medical judgment, and it is not the province of the courts to weigh the degrees of medical and security considerations which may go into any individual transfer decision.

Insane and Other Incompetent Persons - Involuntary Commitment - Due Process of Law - Governmental Interest in Not Holding Judicial Hearing Prior to Transfer of Civil Patient from Nonsecure to Secure Facility

5. In a proceeding involving the potentially stigmatizing transfer of an involuntarily committed civil patient hospitalized at a civil mental health facility of the State Office of Mental Health (OMH) to a secure OMH facility, the procedures required by 14 NYCRR part 57 satisfy the requirements of procedural due process in all respects, notwithstanding the lack of a judicial hearing prior to the nonemergency transfer to a secure OMH facility. The government in this case has a strong interest in avoiding the significant administrative and fiscal burdens which would result from the necessity of holding a prior judicial hearing each time an involuntary patient objects to being transferred to a secure facility.

Insane and Other Incompetent Persons - Involuntary Commitment - Equal Protection of Laws - Different Procedures for Determining Appropriateness of Transfer Decisions for Civil and Criminal Patients at Mental Health Facilities

6. An involuntarily committed civil patient hospitalized at a civil mental health facility of the State Office of Mental Health (OMH), who was transferred, without a judicial hearing, to a secure OMH facility due to a substantial risk that she might cause physical harm to other persons (14 NYCRR part 57), was not denied equal protection because persons found not responsible for criminal conduct by reason of mental disease or defect are entitled to a judicial hearing under CPL 330.20 for purposes of determinations of whether they suffer from a dangerous mental disorder or are otherwise mentally ill. Since 14 NYCRR part 57 and CPL 330.20 address different classes of persons posing different legal concerns, a rational basis exists for having different procedures to determine the appropriateness of transfer decisions.

 

18 of 992 DOCUMENTS


N.Y. Ass'n of Convenience Stores v. Urbach


No. 39


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


92 N.Y.2d 204; 699 N.E.2d 904; 677 N.Y.S.2d 280; 1998 N.Y. LEXIS 1825


March 24, 1998, Argued  
 July 9, 1998, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, without costs, and matter remitted to Supreme Court, Albany County, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondents, competitors of Indian retailers, and petitioners, commissioner of state taxation and finance department and others, cross appealed from an order of Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed judgments directing equal enforcement of state's tax law respecting tobacco and fuel sales.


OVERVIEW: The New York Tax Law imposed sales and excise taxes on tobacco and motor fuel sales. Federal law forbade collection of these taxes on goods sold on Indian reservations to tribal members. However, when the goods were sold on the reservation to non-Indian consumers, the taxes could be collected. The tax department promulgated regulations to facilitate collection of these taxes on reservation sales. However, it did not enforce the regulations. The competitors then filed the present suit. The court held the appellate court erred in applying the high degree of scrutiny reserved for governmental classifications based on race to the tax department's nonenforcement policy. The unique legal status of Indian tribes permitted the federal government to enact laws singling out tribal Indians even where those laws might otherwise be constitutionally offensive and the states could adopt policies to effectuate such federal laws. The tax department's specialized treatment of on-reservation tobacco and motor fuel sales was such a policy. The court held the record did not provide a basis for determining whether the tax department's nonenforcement policy was sustainable on a rational basis standard.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's order and remitted the matter to the trial court for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion.


HEADNOTES

Parties - Standing

1. Petitioners, non-Indian reservation convenience stores and their representative associations, have standing to challenge a policy of the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance forbearing from the collection of cigarette and motor fuel taxes as applied to sales made to non-Indian consumers on Indian reservations located within the State. Petitioners' grievance is essentially an equal protection claim based on differential enforcement of the tax laws and, as members of the disadvantaged class, petitioners have a right to seek judicial resolution of that claim.

Constitutional Law - Equal Protection of Laws - Enforcement of Taxing Statutes and Regulations against On-Reservation Retailers

2. A policy of the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance forbearing from the collection of cigarette and motor fuel taxes as applied to sales made to non-Indian consumers on Indian reservations located within the State does not constitute a form of race-based discrimination subject to the demanding "strict scrutiny" analysis. The unique legal status of Indian tribes permits the Federal Government to enact legislation singling out tribal Indians even where that legislation might otherwise be constitutionally offensive. Federal preferences may be granted to Indians not as a discrete racial group, but, rather, as members of quasi-sovereign tribal entities. While States do not enjoy the same unique relationship, they may adopt laws and policies to reflect or effectuate Federal laws designed to readjust the allocation of jurisdiction over Indians without opening themselves to the charge that they have engaged in race-based discrimination. The Tax Department's specialized treatment of on-reservation cigarette and motor fuel sales is clearly such a policy, since it is predicated on the Department's sensitivity to both tribal sovereignty issues and the complex restrictions imposed by the Indian Trader Laws.

Appeal - Academic and Moot Questions - Postargument Repeal of Challenged Regulations

3. In a CPLR article 78 proceeding challenging the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance's policy of forbearance from the collection of cigarette and motor fuel taxes as applied to sales made to non-Indian consumers on Indian reservations located within the State, in which respondents initially took the position in their arguments to the Court of Appeals that the Tax Department's policy of restraint was, in essence, a temporary measure adopted during a period of delicate negotiations in order to avoid actions that could be construed as "a direct affront" to the sovereign status of Indian nations and tribes, the subsequent repeal of the applicable regulations, which signified that the Tax Department had committed itself to withholding active enforcement on a long-term basis, does not render the proceeding moot. Petitioners' pleading placed in issue "[r]espondents' system-wide failure to perform their statutory ... dut[y] ... to enforce Article[s] 20 ... and ... 12-A of the New York Tax Law", as well as their failure to enforce the implementing regulations. The former aspect of the controversy survives the repeal of the regulations and takes on additional urgency in light of the tax agency's determination to abandon altogether its former enforcement mechanisms. Nonetheless, the recent administrative action so alters the landscape in which the controversy is presented that it would be unwise and unsound for the Court of Appeals to resolve it on the basis of the arguments before the Court. Accordingly, the matter is remitted to Supreme Court so that the parties can consider the need, if any, for further submissions and the court can reconsider the dispute in light of the Tax Department's newly minted long-term policy of abstaining from taking active measures to enforce the legislatively mandated excise and sales taxes on motor fuel and cigarettes destined for sale on Indian reservations.

 

19 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Diamond Asphalt Corp. v. Sander


No. 104


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


92 N.Y.2d 244; 700 N.E.2d 1203; 678 N.Y.S.2d 567; 1998 N.Y. LEXIS 1828


June 3, 1998, Argued  
 July 9, 1998, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, with costs, proceeding converted to a declaratory judgment action and judgment granted declaring that the bid selection procedures at issue violate General Municipal Law § 103(1) .


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant asphalt company sought review of the order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which granted a motion by intervenor utility companies to intervene, denied an application by the asphalt company to annul the award of certain public works contracts, and dismissed the petition filed against respondent commissioner of the New York City Department of Transportation (city).


OVERVIEW: The asphalt company submitted a substantially higher over-all bid for a street repair project compared to those submitted by other bidders. The asphalt company, however, submitted the lowest bid on the public street work portion. The high utility work portion of its bid raised its aggregate bid above the competing bids. The city awarded each contract to the lowest aggregate bidder. The asphalt company commenced an action challenging the city's selection. The lower court denied preliminary injunction relief and granted motions to dismiss, holding that the utility interference work in each contract was not "public work" within the meaning of N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 103(1), but that the mayor enjoyed a "bypass" authority, pursuant to New York City Charter § 313(b)(2). The appellate court affirmed the judgment, finding that the "total character of the arrangement" convinced it that the utility interference work did constitute "public work." On appeal, the court reversed the appellate court judgment, concluding that the legislature had not authorized the city to alter the contours of "public work" matters, and that bypass authority under § 313(b)(2) was not continued under § 103(1).


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the appellate court, converted the proceeding to a declaratory judgment action, and granted judgment declaring that the bid selection procedures violated a competitive bidding statute.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations - Bids and Bidders - "Public Works" Contract

1. Private utility interference work does not constitute "public work" under General Municipal Law § 103 (1), when municipalities determine the "lowest responsible bidder" by combined assessment of amounts bid for utility interference work--work required for private utilities to protect their facilities during street repair projects--and street reconstruction work. Utility work, prior to the creation of the joint bidding technique, did not constitute "public work." Irrespective of the asserted "integration" aspect of the public contracts, and any direct, incidental or indirect benefits to the municipality derived from aggregate bidding, the nature of the utility work remains unchanged--it is private, and for the essential benefit of a private entity.

Municipal Corporations - Bids and Bidders - Lowest Responsible Bidder - Bypass Authority of Mayor of City of New York

2. In satisfaction of General Municipal Law § 103 (1), which provides that all contracts for "public work" must be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder "except as otherwise expressly provided by an act of the legislature or by a local law adopted prior to [September 1, 1953]", bypass contractor selection authority formerly vested in the now abolished Board of Estimate by the old City Charter does not survive solely as the responsibility of the Mayor of the City of New York under New York City Charter § 313 (b) (2), which was revised in 1989 to provide that "[t]he agency letting the contract ... shall ... award the contract to the lowest responsible bidder, unless the mayor shall determine in writing, justifying the reasons therefor, that it is in the best interest of the city that a bid other than that of the lowest responsible bidder shall be accepted." The Legislature has not classified Charter § 313 as a mere "revision, simplification, consolidation, codification or restatement" of the Old Charter, nor can it be so easily labeled since it effects a substantive power reallocation with substantive legal effects and dispensative avoidance of generally applicable and important regulatory and fiscal principles. To override the plain language of the General Municipal Law, an express or definitive declaration would be required to establish that the Legislature intended to continue and transfer bypass authority of such sweeping proportions and nature solely to the chief municipal executive or designee. Even assuming Charter § 313 constitutes a mere revision or recodification, a determination that such enactments fit within the General Municipal Law exception would also demand some express action or more reasonably definitive direction by the Legislature, which is lacking here. Nor can the claim of a unilateral authority shift be buttressed on the ground that the Mayor is nevertheless subject to scrutiny by public notification requirements and judicial review under CPLR article 78.

Actions - Improper Form of Action - Conversion of CPLR Article 78 Proceeding to Declaratory Judgment Action

3. A CPLR article 78 proceeding by petitioner bidder seeking to annul the award of certain public works contracts to competitors and a preliminary injunction to prevent the certification of the let contracts is converted into a declaratory judgment action (see, CPLR 103 [c]). Although the injunctive proceeding is moot because the work under the contracts at issue is completely or substantially done, conversion is prudent and appropriate because the issues presented by petitioner effectively constitute a clear legal challenge to the validity of the relatively new and pervasive public bidding regimen being used by respondent municipality.

Appeal - Preservation of Issue for Review

4. On an appeal to the Court of Appeals from an Appellate Division order which affirmed a judgment of the Supreme Court denying an application by petitioner to annul the award of certain public works contracts, and dismissing the petition, the issue whether utility interference work in each contract is "public work" within the meaning of General Municipal Law § 103 (c) is sufficiently preserved for appellate review since both courts below plainly ruled on it, and everyone was manifestly aware of its potential significance.

 

20 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Schulz v. New York State Exec.


No. 47


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


92 N.Y.2d 1; 699 N.E.2d 360; 677 N.Y.S.2d 1; 1998 N.Y. LEXIS 1429


March 26, 1998, Argued and Submitted  
June 9, 1998, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Certiorari Denied November 2, 1998, Reported at: 1998 U.S. LEXIS 6916.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs; appeal, insofar as taken from that portion of the March 4, 1997 Appellate Division order that denied appellants' motion to enlarge the issues on appeal, dismissed upon the ground that that part of that Appellate Division order does not finally determine the action within the meaning of the Constitution.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner voters filed an action for a determination that the Clean Water/Clean Air Bond Act (Bond Act) violated N.Y. Const. art. VII, § 11, art. III, § 16. The trial court denied the voter's request for an injunction, determined that the voters lacked standing, and concluded that the Bond Act was constitutional. The Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, found that the voters had standing but affirmed. The voters appealed.


OVERVIEW: The Bond Act specified that the money received from bond sales would be expended to create a safe drinking water program and for the improvement and enhancement of water quality. The voters sought an injunction to remove the referendum from the ballot. On appeal, the court affirmed the order that the Bond Act was constitutional. The court held that the Bond Act did not violate the "single work or purpose clause" of N.Y. Const. art. VII, § 11. The voters had standing to challenge a bond issue on the basis that it infringed upon explicit voter protections provided by N.Y. Const. art. VII, §11. However, the Bond Act authorized the creation of state indebtedness for projects in a number of subcategories, all of which were directly related to the single categorical purpose of improving the state's environment. Also, the voters lacked standing to make their claim under N.Y. Const. art. III, § 16 that the Bond Act was constitutionally flawed because it required reference to separate provisions of its implementing legislation without explicitly incorporating the terms of that enactment. N.Y. Const. art. III, § 16 was not related in any way to the exercise of referendum rights.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order that the voters had standing but that the Bond Act was constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Parties - Standing - Voter Standing to Challenge State Bond Issue

1. Petitioners, as citizen-taxpayers, have standing to challenge the Clean Water/Clean Air Bond Act of 1996, which authorized the creation of a State general obligation debt of $ 1,750,000,000 to be used "for the single purpose of preserving, enhancing, restoring, and improving the quality of the state's environment" (L 1996, ch 412, § 2), as violative of the "single work or purpose" requirement set forth in article VII, § 11 of the State Constitution. As a general principle, citizen-taxpayer status does not confer standing to challenge the issuance of State bond acts. However, there are limited instances, such as here, when a voter may challenge a bond issue on the basis that it infringes upon explicit voter protections provided by article VII, § 11 of the State Constitution, which sets forth the prerequisite of a public referendum for all proposed long-term public debt, and mandates that proposed public financing schemes must be "for some single work or purpose, to be distinctly specified therein."

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Clean Water/Clean Air Bond Act of 1996 - Single Work or Purpose

2. The Clean Water/Clean Air Bond Act of 1996, which authorized the creation of a State general obligation debt of $ 1,750,000,000 to be used "for the single purpose of preserving, enhancing, restoring, and improving the quality of the state's environment" (L 1996, ch 412, § 2), does not violate the "single work or purpose" requirement set forth in article VII, § 11 of the State Constitution. The "single work or purpose" clause empowers the State to contract a debt for some single objective that may relate to more than one physical structure or, as in the case of relief bonds, may not include a physical structure, while precluding the Legislative and Executive branches from proposing bond issues aimed at "purposes" that are so imprecise as to be essentially generic, thereby allowing funding of a host of projects having no discernible common theme. The Bond Act at issue authorizes the creation of State indebtedness for projects in a number of subcategories, all of which are directly related to the single categorical purpose of improving the State's environment. Each of the subcategories--safe drinking water, improvement of solid waste facilities, remediation of contaminated properties, enhancement of air and water quality, and preservation of open spaces, parks and historic sites--is naturally and logically related to the stated unitary goal of "preserving, enhancing, restoring, and improving" the environment (L 1996, ch 412, § 2). Thus, the "single work or purpose" requirement is satisfied. Moreover, there is nothing dissonant about including projects related to the preservation of open spaces, parks and historic sites in a Bond Act aimed at conserving and improving the environment.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Clean Water/Clean Air Bond Act of 1996 - Distinct Specification of Purpose

3. The Clean Water/Clean Air Bond Act of 1996, which authorized the creation of a State general obligation debt of $ 1,750,000,000 to be used "for the single purpose of preserving, enhancing, restoring, and improving the quality of the state's environment" (L 1996, ch 412, § 2), satisfies the constitutional requirement that the purpose of the debt be "distinctly specified" in the act (NY Const, art VII, § 11) inasmuch as the Bond Act is aimed at a single purpose--"preserving, enhancing, restoring, and improving the quality of the state's environment"--and that purpose is clearly set forth in the Bond Act itself. That the particular projects for which the proceeds were to be appropriated are listed in a separate legislative enactment is of no legal consequence in this context because the Constitution requires only that the Bond Act "distinctly specif[y]" the "single work or purpose" of the bond issue; it does not require a listing of the myriad activities to be undertaken in the service of that work or purpose.

Parties - Standing - Voter Standing to Challenge Legislation Which Incorporates by Reference

4. Petitioners, as voters, lack standing to challenge the Clean Water/Clean Air Bond Act of 1996, which authorized the creation of a State general obligation debt of $ 1,750,000,000 to be used "for the single purpose of preserving, enhancing, restoring, and improving the quality of the state's environment" (L 1996, ch 412, § 2), as violative of article III, § 16 of the State Constitution, which provides that "[n]o act shall be passed which shall provide that any existing law, or any part thereof, shall be made or deemed a part of said act, or which shall enact that any existing law, or part thereof, shall be applicable, except by inserting it in such act." The purpose of article III, § 16 is not related in any way to the exercise of referendum rights, but rather prevents the Legislature from incorporating into its acts the provisions of other statutes or regulations which affect public or private interests in ways not disclosed upon the face of the act, and which would not have received the sanction of the Legislature if fully understood by it. Thus, the "evil" that article III, § 16 was intended to address is the possibility of misapprehension or unawareness among State legislators, not citizens voting in a referendum.

Parties - Standing - State Bond Issues

5. Citizen-taxpayers do not as a rule have standing to challenge bond issues, and even where the referendum requirement of NY Constitution, article VII, § 11 applies, voter standing does not exist if the underlying challenge to the statute is based upon a different provision of the State Constitution.

 

21 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Tamagni v. Tax Appeals Tribunal


No. 45


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


91 N.Y.2d 530; 695 N.E.2d 1125; 673 N.Y.S.2d 44; 1998 N.Y. LEXIS 1071


March 25, 1998, Argued  
May 14, 1998, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants taxpayers challenged the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which confirmed a determination of respondent Tax Appeals Tribunal sustaining a personal income tax assessment against taxpayers.


OVERVIEW: Taxpayers owned and maintained an apartment in New York City. The state department of taxation concluded that taxpayers were statutory residents of New York and issued a notice of deficiencies. Taxpayers petitioned for a redetermination of the deficiency. The Tax Appeals Tribunal confirmed the deficiency. Taxpayers contended that the New York State resident income tax, N.Y. Tax Law art. 22, violated the dormant Commerce Clause, U.S. Const., art. I, § 8, as applied to statutory residents of the State who claimed another State as their domicile. Taxpayers argued that, because New York gave no credit for resident income taxes paid to other States on investment income from intangible personal property, it potentially subjected them to double taxation. The court held that the statute did not substantially affect interstate commerce and, therefore, the protections of the dormant Commerce Clause were not applicable. The court also determined that, even assuming arguendo that the Commerce Clause was implicated, the tax was constitutional because the tax did not facially discriminate against interstate commerce, and States had traditionally retained broad powers to tax their own residents.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment upholding the assessment against the taxpayers.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Commerce Clause - Liability of Nondomiciliary for New York Personal Income Tax - Impact on Identifiable Interstate Market

1. Petitioners, New Jersey domiciliaries and statutory New York residents (Tax Law § 605 [b] [1] [B]) for income tax purposes, whose entire income was determined to be subject to State income tax under section 605, have not shown any demonstrable impact on an identifiable interstate market which would warrant the conclusion that the tax substantially affects interstate commerce so as to implicate the dormant Commerce Clause (US Const, art I, § 8). The New York income tax is based upon a taxpayer's resident status, without regard to any specific commercial or economic transaction or activity. While petitioner husband is engaged in interstate commerce in that he commutes daily from New Jersey, works as an investment banker in New York, and is involved in numerous economic activities while in New York, the income tax is imposed without regard to his commute, or the specific nature of his activities in this State. It is imposed solely based upon his presence and maintenance of a permanent place of abode in New York, without regard to any economic activities incidental to his presence here.

Constitutional Law - Commerce Clause - Liability of Nondomiciliary for New York Personal Income Tax - Facial Discrimination against Interstate Commerce

2. Even if the New York State income tax on the entire income of a statutory resident of the State (Tax Law § 605 [b] [1] [B]) who is a domiciliary of another State implicates the Commerce Clause (US Const, art I, § 8), the tax does not violate the dormant Commerce Clause because the tax does not facially discriminate against interstate commerce, and States have traditionally retained broad powers to tax their own residents. The first step in analyzing any law subject to judicial scrutiny under the dormant Commerce Clause is to identify the interstate market that is being subjected to discriminatory or unduly burdensome taxation. In the absence of actual or prospective competition between the supposedly favored and disfavored entities in a single market there can be no local preference, whether by express discrimination against interstate commerce or undue burden upon it, to which the dormant Commerce Clause may apply. Here, because the tax at issue does not operate to the disadvantage of any identifiable interstate market, but rather simply taxes residents based on their status as residents, it does not violate the dormant Commerce Clause. The fact that it may have "incidental effects" on interstate commerce because petitioner commutes to work in New York, thus implicating the interstate labor market, is not sufficient to prove a violation of the dormant Commerce Clause.

 

22 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Lunding v. Tax Appeals Tribunal


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


91 N.Y.2d 985; 697 N.E.2d 177; 674 N.Y.S.2d 276; 1998 N.Y. LEXIS 3057


April 29, 1998, Submitted  
May 7, 1998, Decided


HEADNOTES

Taxation - Personal Income Tax - Constitutionality of Statute Disallowing Alimony Deduction to Nonresident

Upon reargument, following remand by the United States Supreme Court, a judgment of the Appellate Division, which declared unconstitutional Tax Law § 631 (b) (6), which disallows nonresidents a full deduction for alimony payments from their State income tax liability, and annulled a determination of respondent Tax Appeals Tribunal of the State of New York sustaining a notice of deficiency, is affirmed.

 

23 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Essex County v. Zagata


No. 30


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


91 N.Y.2d 447; 695 N.E.2d 232; 672 N.Y.S.2d 281; 1998 N.Y. LEXIS 868


February 18, 1998, Argued  
April 7, 1998, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order modified, without costs, by remitting to Supreme Court, Warren County, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants County sought review of the order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which dismissed its N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 petition and determined that appellee environmental agencies had jurisdiction over the County's application for modification of the amount of solid waste that a certain landfill could receive on a daily basis.


OVERVIEW: The County challenged the judgment of the lower court, which dismissed its N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 petition and determined that the environmental agencies had jurisdiction over the county's application for modification of the amount of solid waste that a certain landfill could receive each day. The County argued that the environmental agencies lacked jurisdiction over the application and that they were entitled to the permits both on the merits and by virtue of the environmental agencies' failure to render a decision on the application within five days following the County's demand letter, requesting a decision on their application, pursuant to N.Y. Exec. Law § 809. The environmental agencies argued that the County had not provided the requisite application signature page, which tolled the § 809 time restrictions. The court affirmed the order of the lower court and held that the regulatory time under § 809 did not begin to run until the application was complete. The environmental agencies did not feel that the County's application was complete, therefore, the environmental agencies did not have to make a decision on the County's demand letter within five days under § 809.


OUTCOME: The court modified in part and affirmed in part the order of the lower court.


HEADNOTES

Limitation of Actions - 60-Day Statute of Limitations - Finality of Application for Agency Review

1. For the purpose of judicial review pursuant to CPLR article 78, a determination will be deemed final if it stands as the agency's last word on a discrete legal issue that arises during an administrative proceeding, and the injury purportedly inflicted by the agency may not be prevented or significantly ameliorated by further administrative action or by steps available to the complaining party. If further agency proceedings might render the disputed issue moot or academic, then the agency position cannot be considered "definitive" or the injury "actual" or "concrete." Accordingly, an application by appellant County for review of a request to modify a landfill operating permit, which initially was submitted to the Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC) and then forwarded to the Adirondack Park Agency (APA) by DEC pursuant to a Memorandum of Understanding, became "final" so as to trigger the 60-day Statute of Limitations under Executive Law § 818 (1) when the APA unequivocally advised appellant by letter that it was required to file a new application, consisting of a new signature page to be annexed to the copy of the DEC application and responses to interrogatories, and the "regulatory time clock" had not yet begun to run with regard to their proposal. The letter set forth the APA's definitive position and signaled the completion of agency activity. It also inflicted an actual, concrete injury on appellant. By refusing to treat the DEC application as an APA submission under the Memorandum of Understanding, the APA reset the regulatory time clock that had begun to run when the DEC previously deemed the application complete, effectively nullifying any benefits that appellant had already received by operation of Executive Law § 809's automatic review provisions. It is inconsequential that the APA had not yet reached a formal conclusion regarding the proposed modifications.

Administrative Law - Judicial Review - Challenge to Agency's Jurisdiction

2. A challenge to an agency's assertion of jurisdiction over a matter should be reviewed by a court only after a final determination--which might effectively render the dispute academic--is reached by the agency. Although the assertion of jurisdiction may constitute a definitive agency determination, an agency's erroneous assertion of jurisdiction may ultimately never cause any real injury, which is required for the finding of finality that is necessary to trigger the applicable Statute of Limitations. To allow immediate CPLR article 78 review of such jurisdictional challenges, therefore, would unnecessarily interfere with the agency process and waste judicial resources.

 

24 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Stringfellow's of New York v. City of New York


No. 17, No. 18, No. 19


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


91 N.Y.2d 382; 694 N.E.2d 407; 671 N.Y.S.2d 406; 1998 N.Y. LEXIS 137


January 14, 1998, Argued  
February 24, 1998, Decided



DISPOSITION: Nos. 17, 18 & 19: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, adult entertainment company and patrons, appealed the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department, which granted a motion by defendants, city and business improvement district, for summary judgment, dismissing the actions and declaring that the amendments to the Zoning Resolution of New York did not violate plaintiffs' rights of freedom of expression and was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs, adult entertainment companies and patrons, brought an action against defendants, city and business improvement district, alleging that the amendments to the Zoning Resolution of New York, which included an array of site limitations and anti-clustering provisions governing adult entertainment, deprived them of their right to free expression protected by N.Y. Const. art. I, § 8 and U.S. Const. amend. I. Plaintiffs appealed the decision of the lower court, which granted defendants' motion for summary judgment. The court affirmed the decision of the lower court because the amendments were aimed at the negative secondary effects caused by adult uses, which was a legitimate governmental purpose. The court determined that defendants conducted studies of their own and the nonempirical evidence was extensive and indicative of a clear relationship between adult uses and urban decay. The court concluded that defendants reasonably determined that alternatives would not adequately address the problem.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the lower court's grant of summary judgment to defendants, city and business improvement district, concluding that the amendments to the Zoning Resolution of New York did not violate the constitutional rights of free expression of plaintiffs, adult entertainment companies and patrons. The court held that the ordinance was aimed at the negative secondary effects caused by adult uses, which was a legitimate purpose.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Freedom of Speech - Zoning Amendment Geographically Restricting Adult Entertainment Establishments

1. New York City's Amended Zoning Resolution, which bars adult entertainment establishments from certain districts that are zoned for manufacturing and commercial use but also permit residential development, and permits the regulated uses in all other manufacturing districts and in all high-density, general commercial districts (Amended Zoning Resolution § 32-01 [a]; § 42-01 [a]), is not purposefully directed at controlling the content of the message conveyed through adult businesses and, therefore, does not implicate speech or conduct that is protected by the First Amendment and by NY Constitution, article I, § 8. The Federal constitutional analysis requires examination of the ordinance's "predominant purpose", while the State constitutional inquiry focuses on whether there has been "a purposeful attempt to regulate speech". In the context of these facts, however, the difference in verbiage does not significantly affect the outcome, since it is apparent from the amendments' legislative history that ameliorating the negative social consequences of proliferating adult uses was the City's only goal. Before enacting the Resolution, the City Council assembled an extensive legislative record connecting adult establishments and negative secondary effects, including numerous studies on the effects of adult establishments both within and without New York City. In view of the legislative record upon which the City Council rested its decision to regulate adult uses, enactment of the Amended Zoning Resolution was not an impermissible attempt to regulate the content of expression but rather was aimed at the negative secondary effects caused by adult uses, a legitimate governmental purpose. Moreover, it is not significant that definitions of adult uses in the Amended Zoning Resolution are based in part on the content of the entertainment offered rather than exclusively on the age of the businesses' clientele, because the test is not whether the regulated establishments are defined without reference to content but whether the ordinance's goal is unrelated to suppressing that content, and that test is plainly met here.

Constitutional Law - Freedom of Speech - Zoning Amendment Geographically Restricting Adult Entertainment Establishments - Less Restrictive Alternatives

2. New York City's Amended Zoning Resolution, which bars adult entertainment establishments from certain districts that are zoned for manufacturing and commercial use but also permit residential development, and permits the regulated uses in all other manufacturing districts and in all high-density, general commercial districts (Amended Zoning Resolution § 32-01 [a]; § 42-01 [a]), does not violate the free speech provision of NY Constitution, article I, § 8 on the ground that less restrictive methods of addressing the problems caused by adult uses, such as more aggressive enforcement of existing penal and public nuisance laws, developing targeted signage requirements and limiting adult-use zoning restrictions to new establishments, should have been pursued. The amendments represent a coherent regulatory scheme designed to attack the problems associated with adult establishments. By preventing adult businesses from locating in potential residential districts while allowing such establishments to locate in manufacturing and commercial districts, the amendments protect only those communities and community institutions that are most vulnerable to their adverse impacts. The City Council reasonably determined that the listed alternatives would not adequately address problems it sought to ameliorate.

Constitutional Law - Freedom of Speech - Zoning Amendment Geographically Restricting Adult Entertainment Establishments - Alternative Avenues of Communication

3. New York City's Amended Zoning Resolution, which bars adult entertainment establishments from certain districts that are zoned for manufacturing and commercial use but also permit residential development, and permits the regulated uses in all other manufacturing districts and in all high-density, general commercial districts (Amended Zoning Resolution § 32-01 [a]; § 42-01 [a]), adequately assures reasonable alternative avenues of communication so as not to violate the constitutional rights of free expression of plaintiffs, who are owners, operators and patrons of adult entertainment establishments. While the amendments' enforcement will lead to the forced relocation of some 84% of the City's 177 adult businesses, the City's supported allegations that the space available for adult uses constitutes over 11% of the City's total land area and about 4% when reduced by land encumbered by properties that are unlikely to be developed for commercial use, that the amended zoning code leaves at least 500 potential sites for adult establishments to relocate and operate and will allow adult businesses to remain in districts that permit a wide mix of commercial, retail, entertainment and manufacturing uses, and that all of the areas in Manhattan zoned for adult use and at least 80% of the land area in the other boroughs are within a 10-minute walk from a subway line or a major bus route, satisfy the City's initial burden of showing that the space designated for adult uses is adequate to accommodate the 177 existing adult businesses. An affidavit by a land-use planning and local government consultant, who actually visited the sites the City identified as potential receptors, which concluded that the City's zoning plan does not allow for adequate alternative avenues for adult expression is not sufficient to raise a triable question of fact as to the availability of enough potential receptor sites in view of the affiant's reliance on several assumptions that are inconsistent with controlling legal principles and the absence of any attempt by the affiant to quantify his observations or to make concrete allegations as to precisely how many of the 500 potential receptor sites identified by defendants were, in his estimate, unavailable.

Constitutional Law - Taking of Property - Zoning Amendment Geographically Restricting Adult Entertainment Establishments

4. Enforcement of New York City's Amended Zoning Resolution, which bars adult entertainment establishments from certain districts that are zoned for manufacturing and commercial use but also permit residential development, and permits the regulated uses in all other manufacturing districts and in all high-density, general commercial districts (Amended Zoning Resolution § 32-01 [a]; § 42-01 [a]), will not lead to an unconstitutional taking on the ground that much of the substantial investments plaintiff owners have made in their businesses will be lost if they are required to relocate, and the one-year amortization provision in the ordinance (Zoning Resolution §§ 52-734, 52-77) is too short to give them an opportunity to recoup their investments. Under the statutory provisions for hardship extensions, a nonconforming adult establishment may apply to the Board of Standards and Appeals for permission to continue to operate beyond the one-year amortization period set forth in the statute where it can show that it has made substantial expenditures related to the nonconformity, that such expenditures cannot be recouped within a year and that the requested extension is the minimum necessary to permit such recoupment (Zoning Resolution § 72-40). Having failed to seek relief under this provision, plaintiffs are not now in a position to complain that their constitutional due process rights have been violated.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Vagueness - Zoning Amendment Geographically Restricting Adult Entertainment Establishments

5. New York City's Amended Zoning Resolution, which bars adult entertainment establishments from certain districts that are zoned for manufacturing and commercial use but also permit residential development, and permits the regulated uses in all other manufacturing districts and in all high-density, general commercial districts (Amended Zoning Resolution § 32-01 [a]; § 42-01 [a]), is not unconstitutionally vague. The amendments' definitional provisions are sufficiently specific to provide the public with clear and reasonable notice of the type of businesses that are covered. Moreover, the ordinance's distance requirements are not too vague because they do not include a statement indicating the precise standard for measurement. To the extent that this aspect of the ordinance's provisions leaves room for confusion, the problem is procedurally remediable through administrative application and rule making. There is no indication on the present record that the City's enforcement of the distance rules will be arbitrary or uneven.

Parties - Standing - Vagueness Challenge to Zoning Amendment Geographically Restricting Adult Entertainment Establishments

6. Plaintiffs, purportedly patrons of adult entertainment establishments, lack standing to assert claims that New York City's Amended Zoning Resolution, which bars adult entertainment establishments from certain districts that are zoned for manufacturing and commercial use but also permit residential development, and permits the regulated uses in all other manufacturing districts and in all high-density, general commercial districts (Amended Zoning Resolution § 32-01 [a]; § 42-01 [a]), is unconstitutionally vague. The amendments do not directly regulate plaintiffs' conduct.

 

25 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Johnson v. Pataki


No. 227, No. 228


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


91 N.Y.2d 214; 691 N.E.2d 1002; 668 N.Y.S.2d 978; 1997 N.Y. LEXIS 3703


October 21, 1997, Argued  
December 4, 1997, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs appealed an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) dismissing the petitions for mandamus, prohibition, declaratory judgment, and injunctive relief with respect to the implementation of an executive order.


OVERVIEW: Pursuant to N.Y. Const. art. IV, § 3 and N.Y. Exec. Law § 63(2), the governor of New York issued an executive order which required the attorney-general to replace the district attorney in all investigations and proceedings arising out of the shooting of a slain police officer because the district attorney's statements, correspondence, and swift rejection of the death penalty option in prior death-eligible cases indicated that the district attorney had adopted a "blanket policy" against imposition of the death penalty. The district attorney, county voters, and taxpayers challenged the executive order. The court held that the governor acted lawfully under constitutional and statutory authority, and even if the rationale for his action were subject to judicial review, the superseder order here would be valid.


OUTCOME: The decision was affirmed because the executive order by the governor which removed the district attorney from the case underlying this dispute was a valid exercise of constitutional and statutory authority.


HEADNOTES

Appeal - Academic and Moot Questions

1. In two CPLR article 78 proceedings for mandamus, prohibition, declaratory judgment and injunctive relief with respect to the implementation of Executive Order No. 27 (9 NYCRR 5.27), which required the Attorney-General to replace the Bronx County District Attorney in all investigations and proceedings arising out of the shooting of a certain police officer, an appeal from an order of the Appellate Division affirming an order and judgment of the Supreme Court dismissing the petitions has not been mooted by the death of one defendant, the conviction of the two other defendants on Federal charges, and the dismissal of the State indictments against those two defendants. An appeal presents a live controversy where the rights of the parties will be directly affected by the determination and where the judgment has immediate consequence for them. Here, a live controversy remains because Executive Order No. 27 mandates that Bronx County pay all charges incurred by the Attorney-General in prosecuting the matter, and the validity of the charges depends on the validity of the order. Further, the District Attorney may find it necessary to initiate additional proceedings or inquiries if the Executive Order is invalidated.

Governor - Power to Supersede District Attorney with Attorney-General

2. Executive Order No. 27 (9 NYCRR 5.27), which required the Attorney-General to replace the Bronx County District Attorney in all investigations and proceedings arising out of the shooting of a certain police officer, is valid on its face, reflecting the superseder authority granted the Governor by article IV, § 3 of the New York Constitution together with Executive Law § 63 (2).

Governor - Power to Supersede District Attorney with Attorney-General

3. Executive Order No. 27 (9 NYCRR 5.27), which required the Attorney-General to replace the Bronx County District Attorney in all investigations and proceedings arising out of the shooting of a certain police officer, is not invalid on the ground that the District Attorney, a constitutional officer accountable to the local electorate, is insulated from nonconsensual superseder by a "zone of independence" based on a delegation to him of exclusive authority to prosecute crimes in Bronx County (see, NY Const, art XIII, § 13; County Law § 700 [1]). The Constitution provides for the offices of Governor, Attorney-General and District Attorneys, but it does not identify particular--let alone exclusive--prosecutorial duties or allocate the responsibility among them. While prosecutorial authority over the decades has in fact passed from the Attorney-General to the District Attorneys, the Legislature has recognized for more than 150 years the authority of the Attorney-General to prosecute crimes, even at the local level, when properly directed to do so by the Governor. Nor has such authority been restricted to instances where a local conflict of interest disabled a District Attorney, an officer within the executive branch, from prosecuting a matter. No such limitation appears in the Constitution or statutes.

Governor - Power to Supersede District Attorney with Attorney-General - First-Degree Murder Prosecutions

4. Executive Order No. 27 (9 NYCRR 5.27), which required the Attorney-General to replace the Bronx County District Attorney in all investigations and proceedings arising out of the shooting of a certain police officer, is not invalid on the ground that Executive Law § 63-d, passed in connection with the recent death penalty legislation (L 1995, ch 1), implicitly repealed the portion of Executive Law § 63 (2) pertaining to first-degree murder prosecutions. Section 63-d permits the Governor to direct the Attorney-General, when requested by the District Attorney, to assist in a potential death penalty case. Nothing in or about that section evinces a legislative intention to limit a Governor's supersession authority. These statutes simply provide two different, but complementary, avenues by which the Attorney-General can exercise the limited prosecutorial authority of that State office. There is no repugnancy indicating implicit repealer.

Constitutional Law - Separation of Powers - Executive Order Superseding District Attorney with Attorney-General

5. Executive Order No. 27 (9 NYCRR 5.27), which required the Attorney-General to replace the Bronx County District Attorney in all investigations and proceedings arising out of the shooting of a certain police officer, is not invalid under the separation of powers doctrine. Executive Order No. 27 does not promulgate any rules requiring District Attorneys to seek the death penalty and directs only supersession, as contemplated by Executive Law § 63 (2).

Governor - Power to Supersede District Attorney with Attorney-General - Death Penalty Prosecution

6. Executive Order No. 27 (9 NYCRR 5.27), which required the Attorney-General to replace the Bronx County District Attorney in all investigations and proceedings arising out of the shooting of a certain police officer, does not constitute an abuse of the Governor's authority on the ground that the Governor chose to supersede the District Attorney merely because he disagreed with the District Attorney's discretionary decision about sentencing. Although a Governor is not obliged to state reasons for superseder, Executive Order No. 27 does in fact detail the Governor's reasons for superseding the District Attorney in this instance, and they go beyond disagreement with a discretionary decision in a particular matter. The challenged Executive Order expresses the Governor's executive judgment that there was a threat to faithful execution of the death penalty law that supported this particular superseder.

 

26 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Miller v. DeBuono


No. 219


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


90 N.Y.2d 783; 689 N.E.2d 518; 666 N.Y.S.2d 548; 1997 N.Y. LEXIS 3702


October 15, 1997, Argued  
December 4, 1997, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment modified, without costs, and matter remitted to the Appellate Division, Second Department, with directions to remand to respondent Commissioner of Health for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent commissioner issued a written determination after it found that sufficient evidence supported an allegation of patient abuse by petitioner nurse aide. The determination was entered into a registry and the nurse aide was terminated pursuant to N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 10, § 415.4. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) annulled the decision and the commissioner appealed.


OVERVIEW: The commissioner claimed that the appellate court erred in annulling the discharge on the ground that it resulted from an improper retroactive application of N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 10, § 415.4 to conduct that allegedly occurred prior to the adoption of the provision. The court held that the regulation was not retroactively applied because, by its terms, it regulated future employment by barring residential care facilities from employing any nurse aide who had previously been found guilty of patient abuse. The regulation did not vary the existing definition of patient abuse, or alter the substantive law governing the nurse aide's conduct. The regulation did not change the procedural scheme by which she could seek redress. However, the substantial evidence standard of proof used in the determination was constitutionally insufficient to protect against an erroneous deprivation of the nurse aide's tangible liberty interest in pursuing employment in her chosen field. Accordingly, the nurse aide was entitled to a new determination of whether the allegation of patient abuse was substantiated by a fair preponderance of the evidence.


OUTCOME: The judgment was modified and was remitted to the commissioner for a new determination on the existing record using the constitutionally required preponderance of the evidence standard of proof.


HEADNOTES

Health - Nursing Homes - Patient Neglect 10 NYCRR 415.4 (eff Apr. 1, 1992), which specifically prohibits nursing homes from employing nurse aides "who have ... had a finding entered into the New York State Nurse Aide Registry concerning abuse, neglect or mistreatment of residents or misappropriation of their property" (10 NYCRR 415.4 [b] [1] [ii] [b]), was not improperly applied retroactively to petitioner nurse aide based upon an incident of patient abuse that antedated promulgation of the regulation. A statute is not retroactive when made to apply to future transactions merely because such transactions relate to and are founded upon antecedent events. By its terms, the provision here aims to regulate employment in futuro by barring residential care facilities from employing any nurse aide who, previously, has been found guilty of patient abuse. Moreover, respondents' promulgation of 10 NYCRR 415.4 in no way varied the existing definition of patient abuse (see, 10 NYCRR 81.1 [a]), altered the substantive law governing petitioner's conduct or changed the procedural scheme by which petitioner could seek redress. In effect at the time of petitioner's alleged conduct were statutory provisions which required the reporting of patient abuse (Public Health Law § 2803-d [1]--[4]); provided for an opportunity to challenge the State Health Commissioner's findings, seek expungement, and request a fair hearing (Public Health Law § 2803-d [6] [b], [d]); mandated the listing of sustained findings of abuse in the Nurse Aide Registry (Public Health Law § 2803-d [6] [g]); and authorized the imposition of additional penalties (Public Health Law § 2803-d [7]).

Constitutional Law - Due Process of Law - Protected Liberty Interest - Entry of Name in New York State Nurse Aide Registry Entry of a finding of patient abuse against petitioner nurse aide in the New York State Nurse Aide Registry (10 NYCRR 415.4 [b] [1] [ii] [b]), with its resultant discharge from nursing home employment and public disclosure of the finding, implicates a constitutionally protected liberty interest. The inclusion and dissemination of information contained in a register of those suspected of abuse or maltreatment which harms not only an individual's good name, integrity or standing in the community, but also affects that individual's present employment or effectively forecloses possible future employment opportunities is sufficient to constitute "stigma plus" and invoke the procedural protection of the Due Process Clause. Placement of a finding against petitioner of patient abuse in the Nurse Aide Registry clearly calls into question her reputation, honor or integrity. Moreover, once a finding has been entered in the Registry, that information is then made accessible to health care providers and future employers (10 NYCRR 415.4), and also to the public-at-large without restriction (see, 42 USC § 1396r [e] [2] [B]). Thus, by publicly branding petitioner a patient abuser, the State's action affects not only her occasion for employment in the residential health care industry, but also may well extend to prevent future employment opportunities in any arena, thereby placing a tangible burden on her employment prospects.

Constitutional Law - Due Process of Law - Protected Liberty Interest - Adequacy of Substantial Evidence Standard for Entry of Name in New York State Nurse Aide Registry Use of the substantial evidence standard of proof contained in State Administrative Procedure Act § 306 to substantiate a report of patient abuse against petitioner, a nurse aide, prior to forwarding her name to the New York State Nurse Aide Registry (10 NYCRR 415.4 [b] [1] [ii] [b]), with its resultant discharge from nursing home employment and public disclosure of the finding, is constitutionally insufficient to prevent a deprivation of petitioner's liberty interest. Evaluation of the constitutional sufficiency of administrative procedures involves the balancing of three factors: the nature of the private interest affected by the State's action; the risk of an erroneous deprivation and the effect of additional procedural safeguards; and the governmental interest. Petitioner has a legitimate interest in pursuing employment in her chosen field, and the stigma of being labeled a patient abuser may well jeopardize her future employment prospects. It is beyond dispute that New York State also has a significant interest in protecting elderly, infirm or disabled persons from the infliction of physical harm by those entrusted with their care. Substantial evidence is less than a preponderance of the evidence and, as a burden of proof, it demands only that a given inference is reasonable and plausible, not necessarily the most probable. Under the substantial evidence standard, the inclusion of a nurse aide on the Registry can be supported by nothing more than the hearsay evidence giving rise to the State Health Commissioner's initial investigation. Where, as here, mandatory inclusion on the Registry labels a nurse aide as a patient abuser, and indisputably adversely impacts on future employment opportunities, any procedural safeguard of proof by less than a preponderance of the evidence is constitutionally inadequate to protect against an erroneous deprivation of a tangible liberty interest.

 

27 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Blanco v. AT&T Co.


No. 203


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


90 N.Y.2d 757; 689 N.E.2d 506; 666 N.Y.S.2d 536; 1997 N.Y. LEXIS 3693; CCH Prod. Liab. Rep. P15,116


September 18, 1997, Argued  
November 25, 1997, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order modified, without costs, actions remitted to Supreme Court, New York County, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein, and certified question answered in the negative.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant injured parties had brought suit against appellee keyboard manufacturers for repetitive stress injuries. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) found that the accrual rule for toxic tort cases was controlling.


OVERVIEW: The court rejected the injured parties' contention that the continuing duty to warn doctrine could have been applied to extend the statute of limitations period. The court determined that RSI could not have developed until years after a person first used a keyboard, or not until after one keyboard was discarded and a person subsequently used different keyboards. The court concluded that the proper rule in RSI cases was that the cause of action accrued against a given manufacturer upon the onset of symptoms or the last use of the injury-producing device, whichever was earlier. The court rejected the injured parties' contention that accrual should have been measured not from the time they experienced RSI symptoms, but from the date they actually became aware of the nature of their injuries.


OUTCOME: The court modified the order and remitted the cases for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion, and answered the certified question in the negative.


HEADNOTES

Limitation of Actions - Three-Year Statute of Limitations - Repetitive Stress Injuries A cause of action against a keyboard manufacturer for repetitive stress injury suffered by a keyboard user accrues upon the onset of symptoms, or the last use of the keyboard, whichever is earlier. Such a rule strikes a proper balance between giving a plaintiff an opportunity to commence an action after becoming aware of a symptom of injury and providing certainty and predictability to manufacturers, employers and other economic actors in their risk assessment, while also avoiding stale claims.

Limitation of Actions - What Statute Governs - Repetitive Stress Injuries CPLR 214-c, which provides that "the three year period within which an action to recover damages for personal injury or injury to property caused by the latent effects of exposure to any substance or combination of substances ... must be commenced shall be computed from the date of discovery of the injury by the plaintiff or from the date when through the exercise of reasonable diligence such injury should have been discovered by the plaintiff, whichever is earlier" (CPLR 214-c [2]), is inapplicable to plaintiffs' causes of action against defendant keyboard manufacturers for repetitive stress injury arising from the use of keyboards. While CPLR 214-c does nominally cover situations where a plaintiff is injured due to "contact" with a "substance," it is plain from reading the statute as a whole that the types of substances intended to be covered are toxic substances. Inasmuch as a keyboard is not a toxic substance, CPLR 214-c is inapplicable to plaintiffs' claims.

Limitation of Actions - When Cause of Action Accrues - Continuing Duty to Warn In actions against defendant keyboard manufacturers for repetitive stress injury suffered by plaintiff keyboard users, the continuing duty to warn doctrine may not be applied to extend the limitations period. The gravamen of plaintiffs' claims is that defendants' keyboards were defectively designed. The bar of the Statute of Limitations cannot be avoided through an allegation that defendant had a continuing duty to warn plaintiff of the possible damaging consequences resulting from the act alleged to be negligent. As a rule, the date of injury is the benchmark for determining the accrual of a cause of action, and the mere continuation of the duty to warn into the limitations period is not enough to resurrect a cause of action premised upon an injury occurring earlier.

 

28 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Dorst v. Pataki


No. 232


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


90 N.Y.2d 696; 687 N.E.2d 1348; 665 N.Y.S.2d 65; 1997 N.Y. LEXIS 3682


October 22, 1997, Argued  
November 20, 1997, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant inmates sought review of an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed an order of the trial court in favor of respondents, governor and associated individuals. The trial court upheld an executive order prohibiting appellants from participating in any temporary release programs.


OVERVIEW: Respondent governor issued an executive order barring inmates from participation in a temporary release program if they had been convicted as a violent felony offender. Appellant inmates initiated action against respondents, governor and associated individuals, and contended that such order was unconstitutional and violative of the separation of powers doctrine. The trial court ordered that the law was a constitutional delegation. The lower appellate court affirmed, and appellants sought review. The court affirmed the lower courts' rulings.
