The court held that executive or administrative rulemaking could have entailed some policy selectivity without offending separation of powers doctrine, so long as the basic policy choices had been made and articulated by the legislature. The court held that the legislature was free to delegate rulemaking powers to the governor or to a specialized administrative body appointed by the governor. The court held that the executive order was not violative of the separation of powers doctrine.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed orders of the lower courts, which held that an executive order issued by respondents, governor and associated individuals, had not violated the separation of powers doctrine as contended by appellant inmates. The court held that the legislature was free to delegate rulemaking powers to the governor or to a specialized administrative body appointed by the governor without violating the doctrine of separation of powers.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Separation of Powers - Statute Authorizing Governor to Regulate Inmate's Participation in Temporary Work Release Program Correction Law § 851 (2) (as amended by L 1995, ch 3, § 29), which provides that "[t]he governor, by executive order, may exclude or limit the participation of any class of otherwise eligible inmates from participation in a temporary release program", does not unconstitutionally delegate the fundamental law-making power of the Legislature to the Governor in violation of the separation of powers doctrine on the ground that it delegates directly to the Governor, who lacks expertise in the field of corrections, the power to make the policy choices of adding additional classes of inmates to those statutorily ineligible for participation in one or more temporary release programs. Executive or administrative rulemaking may entail some policy selectivity without offending the separation of powers doctrine, so long as the basic policy choices have been made and articulated by the Legislature. Here, the Legislature set over-all policy regarding temporary release programs. It expressly declared that further regulatory implementation of temporary release programs may be necessary and that the Commissioner of Correctional Services, in reviewing existing regulations and promulgating new ones, was to be "guided by consideration for the safety of the community and the welfare of the inmate" (Correction Law § 852 [1]). It is of no moment that the foregoing articulation of general policy regarding temporary release programs was directed toward the Governor's appointed Commissioner of Correctional Services and not reiterated when the Governor was given similar rulemaking authority in Laws of 1995 (ch 3, § 29). Nor is it significant for separation of powers analysis that the legislative delegation of rulemaking authority went directly to the Governor rather than to the Commissioner of Correctional Services or some other experienced administrator. The Legislature is free not only to delegate rulemaking powers to a specialized administrative body appointed by the Governor, but to substitute the Governor for that body.

Constitutional Law - Separation of Powers - Statute Authorizing Governor to Regulate Inmate's Participation in Temporary Work Release Program Correction Law § 851 (2) (as amended by L 1995, ch 3, § 29), which provides that "[t]he governor, by executive order, may exclude or limit the participation of any class of otherwise eligible inmates from participation in a temporary release program", does not unconstitutionally delegate the fundamental law-making power of the Legislature to the Governor in violation of the separation of powers doctrine on the ground that it lacks appropriate standards for the Governor's exercise of the delegated power to add to the classes of inmates ineligible for temporary release. The statute's explicit direction that additional regulation of inmate participation in temporary release programs is to be "guided by consideration for the safety of the community and the welfare of the inmate" (Correction Law § 852 [1]) is an adequate standard for executive action or rulemaking.

 

29 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Jennings v. N.Y. State Office of Mental Health


No. 103


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


90 N.Y.2d 227; 682 N.E.2d 953; 660 N.Y.S.2d 352; 1997 N.Y. LEXIS 1366


April 30, 1997, Argued  
June 12, 1997, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed, with costs, and petition dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent city objected to the siting of a new residential facility for the developmentally disabled proposed under N. Y. Mental Hyg. Law § 41.34. Petitioner, the commissioner of the New York State Office of Mental Health (commissioner), conducted a hearing and approved the facility. The city sought review and the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York) annulled the commissioner's determination. The commissioner sought review.


OVERVIEW: The city argued that the new facility would result in an over concentration of such facilities in the area and that the commissioner arbitrarily excluded several facilities from consideration by limiting his analysis to the neighborhood rather than the area. Pursuant to N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law § 41.34 (c)(5), the court held that the only ground to sustain an objection to a proposed facility was if the commissioner determined that the nature and character of the area in which the facility was to be based would be substantially altered. The court found that the larger area urged by the city had no relation to physical or subjective neighborhood limits and that the commissioner's delineation of the area was entitled to deference as rational and supported by the evidence. The court found that that the city's concerns were actually related to an alcohol treatment center and another nonlicensed facility in the area. The court held that the commissioner's exclusion of these facilities from his examination was not arbitrary and the presence of these other facilities could not support the denial of a new facility when the need for such a new facility was clearly demonstrated.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the Appellate Division and dismissed the city's petition.


HEADNOTES

Mental Health -- Community Residence -- Site Selection -- Standard of Judicial Review

1. The standard of judicial review of the decision of the Commissioner of the New York State Office of Mental Health as to whether the nature and character of the area in which a proposed community residential facility is to be based would be substantially altered as a result of the establishment of the facility (Mental Hygiene Law § 41.34 [c] [5]) is whether the decision is arbitrary and capricious and whether it is supported by substantial evidence. While factual findings made pursuant to a hearing required by law must be affirmed when supported by substantial evidence in the record, an arbitrary and capricious standard of review applies for challenges to an agency's interpretation or application of a statute or regulation. However, when construction of a statute depends on an understanding of underlying operational practices or entails an evaluation of factual data and inferences to be drawn therefrom, the question of statutory interpretation is generally left to the special expertise of the agency and the determination is entitled to deference when it is not irrational or unreasonable. Rationality is the underlying basis for both the arbitrary and capricious standard and the substantial evidence rule.

Mental Health -- Community Residence -- Site Selection -- Ground for Sustaining Objection

2. In reviewing an objection to a proposed community residential facility for the mentally disabled, the Commissioner of the department responsible for licensing the proposed facility must consider the need for the facility and the concentration of similar facilities already established in the area, but the only ground provided in the statute to justify sustaining the objection is if the Commissioner determines that the nature and character of the area in which the facility is to be based would be substantially altered as a result of the establishment of the facility (Mental Hygiene Law § 41.34 [c] [5]).

Mental Health -- Community Residence -- Site Selection -- Determination of Area to be Affected

3. In reviewing an objection to a proposed community residential facility for the mentally disabled (Mental Hygiene Law § 41.34 [c] [5]), the reliance of the Commissioner of the New York State Office of Mental Health upon boundaries created by parks and main thoroughfares which residents were not likely to cross on foot in delineating the area to be affected by the establishment of the proposed residence is rational and supported by the evidence adduced at the hearing. The Commissioner's determination rationally adopts the boundaries of the neighborhood as defined by the City's own witnesses. It was the neighbors closest to the proposed site of the residence who testified about the boundaries of their neighborhood and it is in that neighborhood where the proposed facility would be located. Such evidence is of paramount importance under the State policy, which is geared towards incorporating the mentally disabled into the life of the community which is expected to provide them with sustenance. Accordingly, the Commissioner may properly focus on the potential impact upon direct "neighbors". If the proposed facility would not "substantially alter" its immediate neighborhood, it is difficult to find fault with the conclusion that adjacent areas would be little affected. Thus, the Commissioner's decision to examine the potential impact of the proposed facility upon its immediately surrounding community is entitled to deference as rational and supported by the record.

Mental Health -- Community Residence -- Site Selection -- Over Concentration of Facilities in Residential Area

4. In reviewing an objection to a proposed community residential facility for the mentally disabled (Mental Hygiene Law § 41.34 [c] [5]), it was reasonable for the Commissioner of the New York State Office of Mental Health to require proof of more than a mere recitation of the number of other facilities located in the same area to sustain the City's objection. While one of the goals of the statute is to avoid over concentration of such facilities in any one area, the mere number of "special needs" facilities within an area is not dispositive. Here, the evidence strongly supports the conceded need for the proposed residence and the City suggested no alternative site. The mere presence of other facilities already situated in a particular area cannot be the sole basis for denying the establishment of a similar new facility when such need for that facility is demonstrated. This is precisely the balance reached by the statute in which concentration is relevant but secondary to a determination that the nature and character of an area will be "substantially altered."

Mental Health -- Community Residence -- Site Selection -- Over Concentration of Facilities in Residential Area

5. In reviewing an objection to a proposed community residential facility for the mentally disabled (Mental Hygiene Law § 41.34 [c] [5]), the decision of the Commissioner of the New York State Office of Mental Health to limit his examination to certain facilities in determining whether the addition of the proposed facility would result in an over concentration of similar facilities in the same area was not arbitrary. Under section 41.34 of the Mental Hygiene Law, only facilities which are licensed by a State agency or which house former patients of the Office of Mental Health or the Office of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities must be considered. Here, many of the concerns of the residents may be traced to an Alcoholism Receiving Center and the nonlicensed residence for a group of adults recovering from addictions. The proposed residence at issue, however, is for individuals who suffer from mental disabilities, not addiction.

 

30 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Raquet v. Braun


No. 77


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


90 N.Y.2d 177; 681 N.E.2d 404; 659 N.Y.S.2d 237; 1997 N.Y. LEXIS 1354


May 7, 1997, Argued  
June 5, 1997, Decided



DISPOSITION: Braun Builders, Inc. and Benito Oliveri to dismiss denied and case remitted to Supreme Court, Erie County, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant third-party defendant building owner and tenants challenged the judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York), which denied their motion to convert cross-claims to third-party claims against respondent injured firefighters, denied the building owner's motion to amend to include claims for indemnification and contribution, and granted respondent contractors' motion to dismiss the claims against them.


OVERVIEW: One firefighter was killed and another was injured when the canopy roof on the building addition and a portion of the addition's masonry wall collapsed outward during a fire. The firefighters filed an action against the building owner, the tenants, and the contractors that designed and built the addition for violations of state and local building code provisions. The tenants asserted cross claims for indemnification and contribution against the contractors, and the building owner counterclaimed against all the contractors except for one. The contractors argued that they were exonerated from liability to the firefighters based on N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 205-a. The court disagreed, reversed the judgment, and denied the contractors' cross motions. The court held that the limitations of the statutory cause of action available to the firefighters did not affect the right of parties held liable to seek contribution and indemnification from those whose carelessness was, in whole or in part, the cause of the harm.


OUTCOME: The judgment was reversed and the contractors' motion to dismiss all claims against them was denied.


HEADNOTES

Negligence - Injuries to Firefighters - Availability of Indemnification or Contribution to Person Liable under General Municipal Law Former § 205-a A person properly held liable to an injured firefighter under former section 205-a of the General Municipal Law may seek indemnification or contribution from parties who were not in possession or control of the premises but who were allegedly responsible, in whole or in part, for the accident, even though the injured firefighter would not have a direct cause of action against the third-party defendant. A defendant may seek contribution from a third party even if the injured plaintiff has no direct right of recovery against that party, either because of a procedural bar or because of a substantive legal rule. A contribution claim can be made even when the contributor has no duty to the injured plaintiff, provided there has been a breach of a duty that runs from the contributor to the defendant who has been held liable. The "critical requirement" for apportionment by contribution under CPLR article 14 is that the breach of duty by the contributing party must have had a part in causing or augmenting the injury for which contribution is sought. Similarly, the key element of a common-law cause of action for indemnification is not a duty running from the indemnitor to the injured party, but rather is a separate duty owed the indemnitee by the indemnitor. The limitations of the statutory cause of action available to injured firefighters do not affect the right of parties held liable pursuant to that cause of action to seek contribution and/or indemnification from those whose carelessness was, in whole or in part, the cause of the harm. The primary purpose of General Municipal Law § 205-a is to ameliorate the harsh effects of the common-law firefighters rule, which precluded firefighters from recovering in tort for injuries sustained during the performance of their firefighting duties. Once the firefighter is afforded an opportunity to recover damages from a party in a position to oversee the safety of the premises--the owner or other person in control--the statutory goal is satisfied and there is no reason to prevent the party who is forced to answer in damages from shifting the economic burden to those whose negligent acts or omissions actually caused the harm.

 

31 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Homier Distrib. Co. v. City of Albany


No. 68


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


90 N.Y.2d 153; 681 N.E.2d 390; 659 N.Y.S.2d 223; 1997 N.Y. LEXIS 757


March 20, 1997, Argued  
May 13, 1997, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment appealed from and order of the Appellate Division brought up for review reversed, with costs, plaintiff's motion for partial summary judgment granted, judgment granted declaring the subject ordinance unconstitutional in violation of the Commerce Clause of the United States Constitution and directing the City of Albany to refund to plaintiff any taxes paid under protest, plaintiff's third cause of action reinstated and case remitted to Supreme Court, Albany County, for further proceedings on the third cause of action.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York) affirmed a trial court order and dismissed appellant taxpayer's action against appellee city in which the taxpayer claimed that a local ordinance that imposed a special tax on transient retailers was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer challenged the city's ordinance, which imposed a special tax on "transient" retailers who operated at temporary business sites. The taxpayer claimed that the tax discriminated in favor of local retail businesses and therefore violated the Commerce Clause. The trial court dismissed the cause of action and the appellate court affirmed, finding no Commerce Clause violation. On appeal, the court recognized that the tax burden on "transient" retailers was not imposed on retailers who operated from fixed locations within the city. Consequently, the tax conferred an economic advantage on a particular class of local businesses, i.e., those that ply their wares from fixed locations. Since, by definition, the class of favored business included only locals, the ordinance was not considered "even-handed" and was per se invalid as a violation of the Commerce Clause.


OUTCOME: The court reversed and granted the taxpayer's motion for partial summary judgment, declaring the subject ordinance unconstitutional in violation of the Commerce Clause.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Commerce Clause - Validity of Municipal Ordinance That Taxes Transient Retailers A municipal ordinance which imposes a special tax on transient retailers who operate at temporary business sites, but not retailers who operate from fixed locations within the municipality (Albany City Code §§ 7-240--7-243), discriminates in favor of local retail businesses and therefore violates the Commerce Clause of the United States Constitution (US Const, art I, § 8, cl [3]). A regulation or tax that discriminates in favor of local economic interests is invalid unless it is narrowly tailored to accomplish a compelling local purpose or, in the case of a tax, can meet the stringent standards of the "compensatory tax" doctrine. Local statutes that facially discriminate against interstate trade are subject to a virtually per se rule of invalidity. Moreover, the discriminatory character of such a law is not altered because its burden may also fall upon some local businesses. Here, the tax imposed by the ordinance confers an economic advantage on a particular class of local businesses, i.e., those that ply their wares from fixed locations. Since, by definition, the class of favored business includes only locals, the ordinance cannot be considered "even-handed" and is, thus, per se invalid. Nor can the transient-retailer tax be rationalized as a compensatory tax that is designed to approximate the tax burden that falls on fixed-location retailers whose property tax bill subsidizes the local services on which all merchants and citizens rely. There is no relationship at all between the "taxable event" that triggers the obligation to pay real property taxes, i.e., the ownership of property, and the "taxable event" that triggers the obligation to pay the transient-retailer tax, i.e., the sale of goods from a temporary location. Nor is there any necessary correlation between the amount to be paid for real estate taxes, which are measured by the assessed value of the parcel and improvements, and the amount to be paid under the transient-retailer tax, which is calculated by reference to the merchant's gross receipts. Further, although some fixed-location merchants support local services through their direct payment of real estate taxes, there are a substantial number of such merchants whose retail sites are leased and who therefore are not directly responsible for property taxes.

 

32 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Tichenor


No. 60


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


89 N.Y.2d 769; 680 N.E.2d 606; 658 N.Y.S.2d 233; 1997 N.Y. LEXIS 754


March 19, 1997, Argued  
May 8, 1997, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant challenged the decision of the Saratoga County Court (New York), which affirmed a judgment rendered upon a verdict convicting appellant of resisting arrest and disorderly conduct.


OVERVIEW: Appellant uttered an obscenity at an officer and then proceeded to shove the officer while uttering further obscenities. The officer attempted to arrest appellant but he pulled away and entered a bar where a scuffle ensued which included bar patrons. On review, appellant argued that N.Y. Penal Law § 240.20(3) offended constitutional safeguards implicating free speech, vagueness, and overbreadth under both state and federal constitutions. The court affirmed and found that the disorderly conduct statute did not circumscribe pure speech directed at an individual but was directed at words and utterances coupled with an intent to create a risk of public disorder, which the state had the authority and responsibility to prohibit, prevent, and punish. The statute was not overbroad on its face or in its particular application because it provided sufficient notice of what conduct was prohibited and was not written in such a manner as to permit or encourage arbitrary and discriminatory enforce. The court determined that the jury had plenty of evidence to weigh the whole incident and to conclude that defendant intended to cause and incite a public disturbance.


OUTCOME: The order affirming appellant's conviction for resisting arrest and disorderly conduct was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Disorderly Conduct -- Freedom of Expression Penal

1. Law § 240.20 (3), which provides that a "person is guilty of disorderly conduct when, with intent to cause public inconvenience, annoyance or alarm, or recklessly creating a risk thereof . . . [i]n a public place, he uses abusive or obscene language, or makes an obscene gesture", is not unconstitutional on the ground that it prohibits protected expression. The disorderly conduct statute does not raise subjective speech concerns. The statute applies to words and conduct reinforced by a culpable mental state to create a public disturbance, and does not circumscribe pure speech directed at an individual. Rather, it is directed at words and utterances coupled with an intent to create a risk of public disorder, which the State has the authority and responsibility to prohibit, prevent and punish. This statute is not overbroad on its face or in its particular application; instead, it is quite specifically and justifiably targeted.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Disorderly Conduct -- Vagueness

2. Penal Law § 240.20 (3), which provides that a "person is guilty of disorderly conduct when, with intent to cause public inconvenience, annoyance or alarm, or recklessly creating a risk thereof . . . [i]n a public place, he uses abusive or obscene language, or makes an obscene gesture", is not void for vagueness. The statute provides sufficient notice of what conduct is prohibited and is not written in such a manner as to permit or encourage arbitrary and discriminatory enforcement. The statutory requirement that the defendant possess an intent to cause, or recklessly create a risk of, public inconvenience, annoyance or alarm, narrows the definition, so that no inadvertent act may be punished. Further, the objective standard of public disturbance and the narrowing effect of the fact that all of the other acts proscribed by the section are publicly offensive, permit, if they do not require the conclusion that the statute is sufficiently definite.

Crimes -- Disorderly Conduct -- Sufficiency of Evidence

3. There is sufficient evidence to support defendant's conviction under Penal Law § 240.20 (3), which provides that a "person is guilty of disorderly conduct when, with intent to cause public inconvenience, annoyance or alarm, or recklessly creating a risk thereof . . . [i]n a public place, he uses abusive or obscene language, or makes an obscene gesture", arising out of an incident that occurred when defendant uttered obscenities at and shoved a police officer in front of a bar and then reentered the bar when the officer attempted to arrest him. Although the arresting officer testified that he did not initially observe any other persons outside the bar, he also indicated that because of the way he was turned facing the defendant, he was unable to see whether any of the patrons inside the bar or the doorway of the bar observed the opening provocative salvos. The officer further testified that immediately following the first face-off with defendant, a goodly number of curious or aroused bar patrons gathered in the doorway, necessitating the officer's call for backup aid. From all this evidence, the jury could reasonably infer that the defendant instigated the confrontation, intending to create a public contretemps with the potentiality of a public escalation, and was, therefore, well within the penal statute's prohibition. The fact that the defendant slipped away from the officer's grasp and reentered the bar after the street confrontation further supports a ready inference that the defendant intended to cause a "public inconvenience, annoyance or alarm."

 

33 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Grumet v. Cuomo


No. 61


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


90 N.Y.2d 57; 681 N.E.2d 340; 659 N.Y.S.2d 173; 1997 N.Y. LEXIS 740


March 19, 1997, Argued  
May 6, 1997, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant state sought review of an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York), which reversed a judgment denying respondent citizens' motion for summary judgment and declaring N.Y. Educ. Law § 1504 constitutional.


OVERVIEW: Appellant state challenged a decision which reversed a judgment denying respondent citizens' motion for summary judgment and declaring N.Y. Educ. Law § 1504 constitutional. On appeal, the court affirmed and held that § 1504 violated the Establishment Clause of U.S. Const. amend. I neutrality principles. The court interpreted the statute as having the nonneutral effect of allowing the religious community of a village to create its own school district. The statute's conferral of its special benefit on one village alone, as against virtually all other groups be they religious or nonreligious, effectively conveyed a message of impermissible governmental endorsement of the community.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed an order which reversed a judgment denying respondent citizens' motion for summary judgment and declaring an education law constitutional. The court held that a statute allowing a village to create its own school district was a violation of the Establishment Clause.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Establishment of Religion - Validity of Statute Permitting Creation of School District Solely within Municipality to Meet Required Educational Needs - Governmental Neutrality Laws of 1994 (ch 241) (adding Education Law § 1504 [3]), which provides that any municipality located wholly within a single central or union free school district but whose boundaries are not coterminous with the boundaries of the preexisting school district, may establish its own school district "whenever the educational interests of the community require it", provided that certain criteria pertaining to the enrollment and the actual valuation per total wealth pupil of new and existing school districts are met, is unconstitutional as violative of Establishment Clause neutrality principles. Notwithstanding its purported facial neutrality, chapter 241 has the nonneutral effect of allowing the Village of Kiryas Joel, whose residents are members of the Satmar Hasidic religious sect, but no other group at this time and probably ever, to create its own school district. Under the Establishment Clause, government must maintain a course of neutrality among religions, and between religion and nonreligion. The provision of a governmental benefit to a restricted class, when that class is formed along religious lines, is a telling index of nonneutral sectarian effect. Here, the qualifying criteria and the definitional cutoff, which limits a "municipality" to "a city, town or village in existence as of the effective date of this subdivision" (Education Law § 1504 [3] [g], added by L 1994, ch 241) and thereby cuts off any group, religious or nonreligious, subsequently incorporated as a municipality from utilizing the procedure established by chapter 241, are drawn in such a way that the benefit flows only to a single sect. Since no existing municipalities aside from Kiryas Joel now meet the statutory criteria, the only possibility that any other municipality will become eligible is if one were prospectively to experience a population or wealth shift sufficient to satisfy the eligibility criteria. However, any group that lacked the foresight to incorporate as a village before the enactment of the statute will be barred from creating its own school district. Out of more than 1,500 municipalities in the State of New York, Kiryas Joel is the only one now able to benefit from the law's provisions and is likely to be the only one ever to qualify. Moreover, the neutrality problem flowing from chapter 241 is not eliminated by the statutory provision requiring approval of the new district both by the municipality seeking to create its own district and by the preexisting district (see, Education Law § 1504 [3] [b], as added by L 1994, ch 241). Only Kiryas Joel presently qualifies to submit the new district proposal for voter approval, and it is this virtually exclusive preference, not the procedure set up under the statute after a municipality qualifies, that fails the test of neutrality.

Constitutional Law - Establishment of Religion - Validity of Statute Permitting Creation of School District Solely within Municipality to Meet Required Educational Needs - Governmental Advancement or Promotion of Religion Laws of 1994 (ch 241) (adding Education Law § 1504 [3]), which provides that any municipality located wholly within a single central or union free school district but whose boundaries are not coterminous with the boundaries of the preexisting school district, may establish its own school district "whenever the educational interests of the community require it", provided that certain criteria pertaining to the enrollment and the actual valuation per total wealth pupil of new and existing school districts are met, has the nonneutral effect of allowing the Village of Kiryas Joel, whose residents are members of the Satmar Hasidic religious sect, but no other group at this time and probably ever, to create its own school district and, therefore, is unconstitutional under the second prong of Lemon v Kurtzman (403 US 602) in that its primary effect is to advance or promote religion. The central question to be answered under Lemon's second prong is whether the challenged governmental action is sufficiently likely to be perceived by adherents of the controlling denominations as an endorsement, and by the nonadherents as a disapproval, of their individual religious choices. The actual effect of the challenged State action, and not merely its stated purpose, is a proper subject of Establishment Clause scrutiny. Further, in conducting the endorsement inquiry, a court must take into account the context in which the State has acted. Here, the enactment of chapter 241 would be perceived as an act of governmental favor for the sole benefit of the Satmar sect. Chapter 241 was enacted into law after the Supreme Court issued its decision in Kiryas Joel I (512 US 687) striking down Laws of 1989 (ch 748), which created a Kiryas Joel School District, as an act of legislative favoritism. Chapter 241 was adopted in direct response to the Kiryas Joel I ruling to provide the Village of Kiryas Joel with an alternative mechanism to secure its own school district. Laws of 1994 (ch 279), a companion statute to chapter 241, expressly authorizes the district's continued operation and specifically contemplates that a Kiryas Joel School District will be reconstituted pursuant to Education Law article 31. While the Legislature was perfectly within its authority in attempting to cure the constitutional infirmity of a prior law, the Legislature's attempt to remedy chapter 748 through the enactment of chapter 241 produced a law whose actual effect confers a benefit on the religious community of Kiryas Joel alone and for all practical purposes effectively replicates the prior unconstitutional law. Viewed in the context of its history and effect, the enactment of chapter 241 bestows an unmistakable imprimatur of State approval on the Satmar sect.

 

34 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Juan C. v. Cortines


No. 29


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


89 N.Y.2d 659; 679 N.E.2d 1061; 657 N.Y.S.2d 581; 1997 N.Y. LEXIS 322


February 5, 1997, Argued  
April 1, 1997, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, without costs, and petition dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant school board suspended respondent student for carrying a gun in school. The student sued the school board. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) annulled the school board's determination and the school board appealed.


OVERVIEW: The lower court applied the doctrine of collateral estoppel and ruled that the educational authorities were precluded from reviewing the reasonableness and legality of the seizure of the gun from the student in a school hallway. A ruling suppressing evidence in a previously dismissed juvenile delinquency proceeding was deemed determinative. The court considered the question of whether the doctrine of collateral estoppel applied to foreclose the education officials from separately determining the suspension and reassignment of the student. The court held that the collateral estoppel doctrine did not automatically block or limit the action and alternatives available to the educational entity and that the fact the gun had been suppressed in a prior juvenile delinquency proceeding was not preclusive. The educational entity did not share actual or functional identity as parties and did not receive in the delinquency proceedings any opportunity to contest the issues suffusing its educational responsibilities, especially as they were so prominently affected by the presence of the gun on school premises and the manner in which it was perceived and seized by school personnel.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the lower court's order and dismissed the student's petition.


HEADNOTES

Schools - Students - Suspension - Collateral Estoppel Effect in Educational Disciplinary Proceeding of Suppression Determination in Juvenile Delinquency Proceeding In an educational disciplinary review proceeding, educational authorities were not precluded from reviewing the reasonableness and legality of the seizure of a gun from a student in a school hallway under the doctrine of collateral estoppel based upon the suppression of the gun in a prior Family Court juvenile delinquency proceeding, instituted and prosecuted by the presentment agency in the name of the New York City Corporation Counsel pursuant to distinctively delegated special authorization in Family Court Act § 310.1. For the doctrine of collateral estoppel to apply, the identical issue necessarily must have been decided in the prior action and be decisive of the present action, and the party to be precluded from relitigating the issue must have had a full and fair opportunity to contest the prior determination. Here, the educational authorities in the disciplinary review proceeding did not share identity as parties and were not allied with the special role of the Corporation Counsel as presentment agency, and were not afforded any full or fair opportunity to litigate their concerns in the Family Court juvenile delinquency proceeding. They are not in legal or practical privity with the presentment agency; they had no legal or functional party status in the Family Court proceeding. In law, purpose and actual practice, the procedures and wider educational community concerns of the Board of Education and of its Chancellor are functionally and fundamentally discrete and independent from the presentment agency and that office's uniquely delegated and described responsibility in a juvenile delinquency proceeding in Family Court, such as was presented here.

 

35 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Shannon


No. 49


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


89 N.Y.2d 1000; 679 N.E.2d 633; 657 N.Y.S.2d 394; 1997 N.Y. LEXIS 312


February 13, 1997, Argued  
March 25, 1997, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, in a memorandum.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was granted permission to appeal from an order of the Supreme Court, Appellate Division in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed a judgment of the county court convicting defendant, upon his plea of guilty, of criminal sale of a controlled substance in the fifth degree. Defendant was sentenced as a second felony offender to a minimum of two and a maximum of four years in prison.


OVERVIEW: On appeal from his conviction and sentence, defendant argued that he was improperly sentenced as a second felony offender because his prior convictions were for traffic felonies, which were not predicate felonies for sentencing purposes under N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06(1)(b)(i). He contended that his equal protection rights were violated by treating his two prior traffic felonies as predicate felonies, subjecting him to harsher punishment based solely on the order in which the crimes were committed. The court disagreed and affirmed, noting that the express language of § 70.06(1)(b)(i) did not require the prior felony to be defined as such by the Penal Law in order to qualify as a second felony offender. Rather, no restrictive language preceded the statute's definition of "predicate felony conviction" for sentencing purposes. The court reasoned that the legislature designed N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06(1)(b)(i) to punish a Penal Law felony offender more harshly based on both the nature of the second felony and the commission of any prior felony. The statute served an important deterrent purpose that was neither irrational nor unconstitutional. Defendant's other argument was without merit.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the defendant's conviction and sentence for criminal sale of a controlled substance in the fifth degree.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Sentence - Second Felony Offender - Predicate Felony - Vehicle and Traffic Law Offense Non-Penal Law felonies may be considered predicate felonies for sentencing purposes under Penal Law § 70.06 (1) (b) (i) since the express language of the statute does not require that the prior felony be one defined by the Penal Law; rather, the specific omission of any restrictive language preceding the definition of what constitutes a "predicate felony conviction" for sentencing purposes indicates that the Legislature intended to include any prior felony conviction, including a Vehicle and Traffic Law felony, as a predicate felony to enhance the severity of punishment. Moreover, subdivision (1) (b) (i) stands in sharp contrast to Penal Law § 70.06 (1) (a), which explicitly limits second felony offender status to individuals who commit a "felony defined in this chapter". The Legislature designed Penal Law § 70.06 (1) (b) (i) to punish a Penal Law felony offender more harshly based on both the nature of the second felony and the commission of any prior felony. The statute serves an important deterrent purpose that is neither irrational nor unconstitutional.

 

36 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Giuliani v. Hevesi


No. 24


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


90 N.Y.2d 27; 681 N.E.2d 326; 659 N.Y.S.2d 159; 1997 N.Y. LEXIS 300


February 4, 1997, Argued  
March 20, 1997, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order modified, with costs to respondents, by reinstating the respective judgments of Supreme Court, New York County, dismissing the complaint in each action and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff city, joined by the Municipal Water Finance Authority and the Water Board, sought a declaratory judgment that the defendant city comptroller acted in excess of his powers and an injunction. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York) dismissed the action and declared that a proposed sale of the water system to the Water Board was not authorized. The city appealed.


OVERVIEW: The city leased the water system to the New York City Water Board (board). When it was confronted with a budget deficit, the city proposed to sell the system to the board with the Municipal Water Finance Authority (authority) to issue bonds to finance the purchase. The court concluded that no Environmental Impact Statement was required. When the comptroller refused to issued the bonds the city sued, but the supreme court dismissed its complaint on the ground that the bond issuance was not authorized by the governing statute. On appeal, the court agreed. The New York City Municipal Water Finance Authority Act did not permit the authority to issue bonds to finance the purchase. The use of the authority's debt power was permissible only if the purchase of the water system was a "water project" or furthered "other corporate purposes" of the authority. The water system was not a "water project." The court held that statutory authorization to issue bonds for payment of the cost of a "water project" contemplated something less than financing the purchase of the entire water system, and funding the city's general capital needs was not among the "corporate purposes" of the authority.


OUTCOME: The dismissal of the city's complaint to compel the comptroller to issue bonds to finance a purchase of the city's water system by the city's water board was affirmed because the New York City Municipal Water Finance Authority Act did not permit the proposed transaction.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations - Water Districts - Validity of Proposed Sale of New York City Water System to New York City Water Board The New York City Municipal Water Finance Authority Act (L 1984, chs 513-515) does not permit the New York City Water Finance Authority to issue bonds to finance New York City's proposed sale of its Water System to the New York City Water Board, the proceeds of which would both be applied to retiring the City's pre-1984 water and sewer debt and spent on non-Water System-related capital projects in the City. Under the statutory language, use of the Authority's debt power is permissible only if the purchase of the Water System on the terms proposed is of a "water project" or furthers "other corporate purposes" of the Authority (Public Authorities Law § 1045-o [1]). However, in permitting the Authority to issue bonds to cover necessary costs, the Legislature contemplated that a "water project" would be a component of the Water System, not the Water System itself. Nor is issuance of bonds to fund this particular transaction among the "other corporate purposes" of the Authority. The Act was adopted to facilitate the financing of needed expenditures for the maintenance and improvement of the Water System. Nowhere is there a hint that the Authority's purposes include the raising of revenues for unrelated City capital projects.

Municipal Corporations - Bonds - Construction of Municipal Bond Legislation In determining whether the New York City Municipal Water Finance Authority Act (L 1984, chs 513-515) permits the New York City Water Finance Authority to issue bonds to finance New York City's proposed sale of its Water System to the New York City Water Board, the Court gives effect to the plain meaning of the words used in the statute, thereby implementing the intent of the Legislature, and declines to adopt the proffered new statutory interpretation standard that municipal bond arrangements must be upheld unless "patently illegal." The deference exemplified by the "patently illegal" standard is most appropriate in reviewing challenges to municipal financing legislation as exceeding constitutional limitations, not whether the legislation permits the proposed transaction.

 

37 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Gazza v. New York State Dep't of Envtl. Conservation


No. 10


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


89 N.Y.2d 603; 679 N.E.2d 1035; 657 N.Y.S.2d 555; 1997 N.Y. LEXIS 99; 28 ELR 20053


January 7, 1997, Argued  
February 18, 1997, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Certiorari Denied October 6, 1997, Reported at: 1997 U.S. LEXIS 4662.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landowner sought review of an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which dismissed his action alleging that respondent New York Department of Environmental Conservation's (Department) denial of his application for a variance constituted an unconstitutional taking under the United States and New York Constitutions.


OVERVIEW: The Department denied the landowner's application for two building variances due to legislation enacted to preserve wetlands. The landowner argued that the denial was a taking despite the fact that the legislation was fully enacted and in force when he purchased the property. The court disagreed and held that the denial was proper. In so holding, the court found that (1) the Department's finding that the landowner had not sustained his burden of showing that the variances would not have an adverse impact on the tidal wetlands contained on the property was supported by substantial evidence; (2) the landowner never owned an absolute right to build on his land without a variance and a taking claim could not be based on an interest he never owned; (3) the economic value of the property had not been extinguished by the denial because the property could be used for recreational purposes; and (4) the landowner's reasonable expectations were not affected when the property remained restricted because such expectations were reflected by the landowner's consideration of the property's limitations when he made the purchase offer.


OUTCOME: The dismissal of the landowner's petition was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Taking of Property - Tidal Wetlands - Regulation of Property Prior to Purchase by Claimant The denial of a building variance pursuant to environmental regulation does not effect an unconstitutional taking (US Const Fifth Amend; NY Const, art I, § 7) for which the landowner must be justly compensated where the legislation was fully enacted and in force when he purchased the property. A property interest must exist before it may be "taken". Similarly, a taking claim may not be based upon property rights that have already been taken away from a landowner in favor of the public. Once taken, property interests are no longer owned by the private landowner and may not be sold by such party. Rather, a promulgated regulation forms part of the title to property as a preexisting rule of State law. While the remaining property interests may still be freely transferred by the landowner, a purchaser's title is necessarily limited to and by those property interests alone. Although petitioner's permit application was entitled to due consideration, petitioner's claim that the denial of his variance was a "taking" must fail because he never owned an absolute right to build on his land without a variance. Since the enactment of the wetlands regulations, the only permissible uses for the subject property were dependent upon those regulations which were a legitimate exercise of police power. Petitioner cannot base a taking claim upon an interest he never owned. The relevant property interests owned by the petitioner are defined by those State laws enacted and in effect at the time he took title and they are not dependent on the timing of State action pursuant to such laws.

Environmental Conservation - Tidal Wetlands - Denial of Variance - Substantial Evidence A determination of the Department of Environmental Conservation denying petitioner two setback variances from the requirements of 6 NYCRR 661.6, which govern tidal wetlands, to enable him to construct a single-family home on his parcel is supported by substantial evidence.

Constitutional Law - Taking of Property - Tidal Wetlands - Diminution of Value and Limitation of Uses Due to Regulation While petitioner's claim that the denial of a variance from the requirements of 6 NYCRR 661.6 to enable him to construct a single-family home on a parcel that was subject to regulation as tidal wetlands prior to the time he purchased the parcel was a "taking" must fail solely because he never owned an absolute right to build on his land without a variance, petitioner's taking claim would also be infirm under an analysis of whether the regulations result in a taking of petitioner's property by depriving the landowner of his property rights. The fact that a regulation deprives the property of its most beneficial use does not render it unconstitutional. There is support in the record for Supreme Court's conclusion that the economic value of the property had not been extinguished since it could still be used for recreational purposes and that petitioner's reasonable expectations were reflected by his consideration of the inherent limitations on the property when he made the purchase offer for thousands less than its worth without the restrictions. Thus, his "reasonable" expectations were not affected when the property remained restricted. Moreover, petitioner had the burden of showing that it is unreasonable to expect relief from a zoning restriction with respect to his claim that the finding of value does not take into account the fact that the nonresidential uses proposed by the Department of Environmental Conservation that add value to his land may not be undertaken without a variance from the Village. Although petitioner did not have to complete the application process to meet his burden on the issue, his conclusory assertion that the zoning variance would not be granted is insufficient when the record contains ample and convincing evidence to the contrary. The Village Law provides that a variance may be granted if an applicant cannot realize a reasonable return without it (Village Law § 7-712-b [2] [b]). The value of the subject property was, at most, diminished as restricted by the regulations. Thus, the alleged diminution of value and limitation of property uses caused by the environmental regulations would fall well within constitutional boundaries.

 

38 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Kim v. City of New York


No. 8


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


90 N.Y.2d 1; 681 N.E.2d 312; 659 N.Y.S.2d 145; 1997 N.Y. LEXIS 101


January 7, 1997, Submitted  
February 18, 1997, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Certiorari Denied October 6, 1997, Reported at: 1997 U.S. LEXIS 4609.



DISPOSITION: Judgment appealed from and order of the Appellate Division brought up for review affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant property owners sought review of the decision of the Supreme Court (New York), which affirmed the trial court's determination that no taking of their land occurred when appellee city raised a road to the legal grade by placing side fill on the property abutting the public roadway. The property owners appealed, contending that the lower court erred in holding that there was no permanent physical occupation of their property.


OVERVIEW: The property owners contended that placing the side fill on their property was an unconstitutional taking without just compensation and, hence, a taking. The city argued that in exercising its police powers to raise a portion of the property so that it met the legal grade of the abutting roadway, it did not take any of the property owner's land in violation of any state or federal constitution. The court found in favor of the city, holding that the common law and city charter obligated the property owners to provide lateral support to a public roadway. Thus, by virtue of the common law and city charter, the property owner's title never encompassed the property interest they claimed had been taken. The court found that when the property owners acquired title to their property, they acquired ownership of the entire parcel, including the portion abutting the public roadway, subject to the obligation to maintain lateral support to the roadway's legal grade.


OUTCOME: The judgment appealed from and order of the appeals court brought up for review was affirmed with costs.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Taking of Property - Property Encumbered by Prevailing Rule of State Property Law When Acquired Plaintiffs are not entitled to compensation for the portion of their property on which the City of New York placed side fill to maintain lateral support for a regraded public road that abutted their property because plaintiffs acquired their property with constructive notice that the property abutted a public road that was below the legal grade and, in regrading the road and raising a portion of plaintiffs' property up to the legal grade, the City acted pursuant to a long-standing common-law principle and in conformity with a provision of its Charter that was in force when plaintiffs acquired title to their property. Because the State defines the rights and obligations that constitute "property" in the absence of any superseding Federal law, the threshold step in a physical or regulatory takings inquiry is to determine whether, in light of the existing rules or understandings of State law, plaintiffs ever possessed the property interest they now claim has been taken by the challenged governmental action. Further, in identifying the background rules of State property law that inhere in an owner's title, a court should look to the law in force, whatever its source, when the owner acquired the property. Here, plaintiffs' obligation to preserve and maintain the legal grade has its roots in New York's common-law obligation of lateral support. Further, the property owner's obligation of lateral support to a public roadway finds its specific, contemporary formulation in New York City Charter § 2904 (2), which was in force when plaintiffs bought their property. Thus, the lateral-support obligation imposed on plaintiffs was a prevailing rule of the State's property law when they acquired their property and, accordingly, encumbered plaintiffs' title and the constituent bundle of rights. The City's enforcement of this legal obligation therefore does not constitute a taking of any property interest owned by plaintiffs for which they are entitled to compensation.

 

39 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re Claim of Sinker


No. 17


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


89 N.Y.2d 485; 678 N.E.2d 454; 655 N.Y.S.2d 842; 1997 N.Y. LEXIS 84


January 8, 1997, Argued  
February 6, 1997, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff claimant sought review of an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York) affirming a decision of the Unemployment Insurance Appeals Board ruling that claimant was disqualified, under N.Y. Lab. Law § 593(4), from receiving unemployment insurance benefits.


OVERVIEW: The claimant, an attorney for an abstract company, was discharged after he was convicted of mail fraud, violation of 18 U.S.C.S. § 1341, when he allegedly submitted a false insurance claim. The claimant alleged that he was not ineligible for unemployment insurance benefits, under N.Y. Lab. Law § 593(4), because his crime did not occur "in connection with" his employment. The court rejected his argument. The court ruled that the phrase "in connection with" did not solely relate to felony crimes committed against the employer, or during business hours. Rather, the court found that this phrase also included any activity that disregarded the standards of conduct which the employer had a right to expect from his employees. Here, the court found that the claimant breached his duty to remain qualified for his position when he was automatically disbarred, after his conviction was final. Moreover, the claimant's conduct further breached the duty he owed to his employer because it impaired his ability to do his job, and tarnished his employer's reputation for trustworthiness.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate division's order affirming the determination that the claimant was ineligible to receive unemployment insurance benefits.


HEADNOTES

Unemployment Insurance - Benefits - Disqualification - Act Constituting Felony A felony is "in connection with" employment for purposes of Labor Law § 593 (4), which disallows unemployment insurance benefits for a period of one year after a claimant loses his or her job as a result of an act constituting a felony "in connection with" that employment, if it results in breach of a duty, express or implied, the claimant owes the employer. The scope of such duty will vary depending on the nature of the employment involved. Accordingly, benefits were properly denied appellant, an attorney whose employment as Chief Title Counsel to a title abstract company was terminated after his conviction of a felony arising from his submission of a false insurance claim for theft of personal property. Here, appellant violated a basic duty owed his employer: to remain qualified for his position, a status he lost when he was automatically disbarred under Judiciary Law § 90 (4) (a). Moreover, appellant's employer was a fiduciary entrusted with handling funds for real estate closings and also acted as agent for insurance companies underwriting title insurance policies for its customers and, as Chief Title Counsel, appellant personally dealt with numerous insurance companies. Thus, his conviction for defrauding an insurance company not only impaired his ability to perform his job effectively but also necessarily tarnished his employer's reputation for trustworthiness in the relevant business community.

 

40 of 992 DOCUMENTS


National Ass'n of Indep. Insurers v. State


No. 7


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


89 N.Y.2d 950; 678 N.E.2d 465; 655 N.Y.S.2d 853; 1997 N.Y. LEXIS 87


January 7, 1997, Argued  
February 6, 1997, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs, in a memorandum.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs appealed from an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Second Judicial Department (New York), reversing an order of the supreme court granting plaintiffs' motion to enjoin enforcement of N.Y. Tax Law art. 15 pending a decision on its constitutionality.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff insurance carriers sought a declaration that N.Y. Tax Law art. 15 was unconstitutional and an injunction against its implementation. The supreme court enjoined enforcement, and the appellate division reversed. The court of appeals affirmed the appellate division's order. Article 15 was presumptively constitutional. Plaintiffs' challenge to article 15 rested on speculative assertions since article 15 had not yet gone into effect. It was premature to conclude that article 15 would result in double taxation or the overpayment of taxes. If and when an individual was actually injured by article 15, the court would consider its constitutionality at that time.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate division's order, because plaintiffs' challenge to the statute hinged on speculative assertions inasmuch as the statute had not yet gone into effect and no one had yet been subjected to double taxation or an overpayment of taxes.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - Sales and Use Taxes - Prepayment of Sales Tax on Motor Vehicle Damage Insurance Awards - Possibility of Overpayment or Double Taxation An order of the Appellate Division which reversed an order granting plaintiffs a preliminary injunction enjoining defendants from enforcing Tax Law article 15, which provides for the prepayment by insurers of sales tax on motor vehicle damage insurance awards, and granted defendants summary judgment declaring the statute constitutional, should be affirmed where plaintiffs' facial constitutional challenge hinges on speculative assertions regarding possible actions by future claimants, motor vehicle repair shop owners and dealers, since the sets of facts posed by plaintiffs are not presently before the Court of Appeals and, thus, it cannot be presumed that the statute will result in overpayment of taxes or double taxation as a result of insurers overpaying or repair shops and dealers refusing to accept credit vouchers issued by the Commissioner of Taxation and Finance.

Taxation - Sales and Use Taxes - Prepayment of Sales Tax on Motor Vehicle Damage Insurance Awards - Possibility of Denial of Refund Request An order of the Appellate Division which reversed an order granting plaintiffs a preliminary injunction enjoining defendants from enforcing Tax Law article 15, which provides for the prepayment by insurers of sales tax on motor vehicle damage insurance awards, and granted defendants summary judgment declaring the statute constitutional, should be affirmed where plaintiffs allege that the statutory scheme violates due process because it does not allow for a refund in the event that the funds remitted to the State by insurers exceed the amount of sales tax actually assessed, since it cannot be presumed that a refund would be denied. The statute does not on its face preclude the Commissioner of Taxation and Finance from refunding excessive or double taxes to claimants or insurers; rather, it specifically incorporates the provisions of Tax Law article 28, which provides for the refund or credit of taxes improperly collected or paid, to the extent that they are not inconsistent with any provision of Tax Law article 15, and that general refund provision is not inconsistent with the two specific sales tax refund provisions of article 15 (i.e., § 341 [e] [1], [2]).

 

41 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Castle Oil Corp. v. City of New York


No. 270


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


89 N.Y.2d 334; 675 N.E.2d 840; 653 N.Y.S.2d 86; 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 3599


November 19, 1996, Argued  
 December 20, 1996, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant city appealed an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed an award of summary judgment to plaintiff petroleum companies on their suit to have New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 11-602(8)(b)(3) declared unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Petroleum companies that were subject to the state franchise and petroleum taxes and the city's general corporation tax instituted a declaratory judgment action seeking a declaration that New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 11-602(8)(b)(3) was unconstitutional insofar as it prohibited deduction of the petroleum tax on a corporate income tax return. The court on appeal agreed that § 11-602(8)(b)(3) lacked either a constitutional or a statutory basis on which to ground its disallowance on the deduction, even though it was originally valid. The court found that the state had amended the authorizing legislation for this prohibition and now allowed corporate taxpayers to deduct petroleum taxes when calculating net income for purposes of the N.Y. Tax Law art. 9-A franchise tax. Consequently, the court held that the corresponding city provision for general corporation taxes was unconstitutional under N.Y. Const. art. XVI, § 1 because it did not conform to either the Model Local Law or N.Y. Tax Law art. 9-A.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the award of summary judgment to the petroleum companies.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - General Corporation Tax - Constitutionality of Disallowance of Deduction for Payment of Petroleum Gross Receipts Tax Administrative Code of the City of New York § 11-602 (8) (b) (3) is unconstitutional as of June 1, 1990 insofar as it prohibits deduction of petroleum taxes imposed pursuant to Tax Law article 13-A in determining New York City general corporation tax liability, because of the subsequent repeal of the predicate State Tax Law provision supporting its enactment (see, L 1990, ch 190, §§ 212, 385 [q] [2], repealing relevant portion of Tax Law § 208 [9] [b] [4]). Under our form of State government, the exclusive power of taxation is lodged in the State Legislature (NY Const, art XVI, § 1). Municipalities such as the City of New York have no inherent taxing power, but only that which is delegated by the State. Moreover, the delegation of State taxing power to a municipality must be made in express terms by enabling legislation. Here, the enabling act, which granted the City the authority to enact local legislation imposing a net income tax on businesses in a form "substantially" following a Model Local Law appended to the enabling act (L 1966, ch 772), and which, as amended, states that the City's general corporation tax shall "substantially" follow the Model Local Law, but "may be amended for the purpose of conforming it with similar provisions of article[] 9-A [of the State Tax Law] ... as presently in effect or as they may be amended" (L 1967, ch 699, § 1), requires continuing conformity with either the Model Local Law or a provision of article 9-A. For section 11-602 (8) (b) (3) to fall within the parameters of the enabling act, therefore, it must derive its authority from a provision of the Model Local Law or article 9-A of the State Tax Law. The Model Local Law, however, contains no provision prohibiting the deduction of article 13-A taxes. Moreover, once the State repealed Tax Law § 208 (9) (b) (4), which prohibited the deduction of article 13-A taxes, the necessary State law predicate for the City's prohibition of the deduction was eliminated. The subsequent enforcement of section 11-602 (8) (b) (3) transgresses the fixed parameters and exceeds the authorization of the enabling act, and therefore violates article XVI, § 1 of the State Constitution.

 

42 of 992 DOCUMENTS


City of New York v. Patrolmen's Benevolent Ass'n


No. 288


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


89 N.Y.2d 380; 676 N.E.2d 847; 654 N.Y.S.2d 85; 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 3604


November 13, 1996, Argued  
December 19, 1996, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant patrolmen's associations sought review of the order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed a judgment denying the patrolmen's motion to dismiss plaintiff city's complaint, and granted the city's cross motion for a summary judgment declaring that 1996 N.Y. Laws ch. 13 was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The parties were unable to reach an agreement with respect to a successor collective bargaining agreement. Defendant patrolmen's association sought to transfer to the public employment relations board plaintiff city's impasse panel request pending before the board of collective bargaining (BCB). The city objected and commenced an action seeking a declaration that 1996 N.Y. Laws ch. 13 was is unconstitutional. The appellate court affirmed the judgment denying the patrolmen's motion to dismiss the city's complaint, and granted the city's cross motion for a summary judgment declaring that ch. 13 was unconstitutional. On appeal, the patrolmen argued that the state interest exception applied. The court held that ch. 13 was unconstitutional on the ground that it violated the home rule provision of N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 2. The court determined that the city's BCB continued to have exclusive jurisdiction over collective bargaining impasses between the city and its police officers. The court concluded that the legislation could be upheld under any substantial state interest exception to the requirements of art. IX, § 2.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment denying defendant patrolmen's association's motion to dismiss plaintiff city's complaint because a statute governing impasse procedures between the city and the patrolmen was unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations - Home Rule Powers - Constitutionality of Statute Subjecting New York City Police to PERB Impasse Procedures Laws of 1996 (ch 13), which empowers the Public Employment Relations Board (PERB) to invoke procedures to be followed in the event of disputes which reach an impasse in the course of collective negotiations between the public employer and the New York City police, and removes the exemption of the New York City police and fire department members from PERB's binding arbitration impasse procedures, is unconstitutional because it was not enacted in compliance with the home rule requirements of article IX, § 2 of the State Constitution. Under article IX, § 2 of the State Constitution, a special law which relates to the property, affairs or government of New York City violates the Constitution unless enacted upon a home rule message from the City. Chapter 13 is a special law because it applies only to New York City, and it relates to the "property, affairs or government" of New York City as it regulates the bargaining process between the City and its police department members and thus relates to the terms and conditions of employment of this local public safety force. Moreover, chapter 13 cannot be upheld under any substantial State interest exception to the requirements of article IX, § 2 of the Constitution since chapter 13 does not serve to advance nor is it reasonably related to the professed State concerns which prompted its enactment--serious public safety concerns. Chapter 13 itself does not expressly identify any State concern motivating its enactment, and the legislative history of chapter 13 discloses that the reason for chapter 13's introduction and passage was to create State-wide uniformity with respect to impasse procedures available to police department members under Civil Service Law § 209.

Statutes - General and Special Laws Laws of 1996 (ch 13), which empowers the Public Employment Relations Board (PERB) to invoke procedures to be followed in the event of disputes which reach an impasse in the course of collective negotiations between the public employer and the New York City police, and removes the exemption of the New York City police and fire department members from PERB's binding arbitration impasse procedures, is a special law. A special law is one "which in terms and in effect applies to one or more, but not all ... cities" (NY Const, art IX, § 3 [d] [4]). By virtue of chapter 13, only New York City, among all units of local government throughout the State, is prohibited from providing for a local public employment relations board with jurisdiction over binding arbitration procedures when an impasse is reached in negotiations with its police force.

Statutes - General and Special Laws - Law Relating to Property, Affairs or Government of Municipality Laws of 1996 (ch 13), which empowers the Public Employment Relations Board (PERB) to invoke procedures to be followed in the event of disputes which reach an impasse in the course of collective negotiations between the public employer and the New York City police, and removes the exemption of the New York City police and fire department members from PERB's binding arbitration impasse procedures, relates to the "property, affairs or government" of New York City within the meaning of the municipal home rule provisions of NY Constitution, article IX, § 2, as it regulates the bargaining process between the City and its police department members and thus relates to the terms and conditions of employment of this local public safety force.

Municipal Corporations - Home Rule Powers - Standard for Applicability of State Interest Exception to Home Rule Provisions of State Constitution For the State constitutionally to enact a special law on local affairs without complying with home rule requirements (NY Const, art IX, § 2), its interest in the subject matter must be substantial and, as a corollary to the constitutional balancing of overlapping local and State interests requiring that the subjects of State concern must be directly and substantially involved, the enactment must bear a reasonable relationship to the legitimate, accompanying substantial State concern. Thus, State legislation impacting especially on a locality is only valid if it can be stated that the statutes in question serve a supervening State concern, and relate to life, health and quality of life of the People of the State. The substantial State concern which will be permitted to trump constitutional home rule requirements regarding a particular enactment cannot be derived purely from speculative assertions on possible State-wide implications of the subject matter, having no support in the language, structure or legislative history of the statute. To the contrary, reliance should be placed upon the stated purpose and legislative history of the act in question to find, or reject, a substantial State concern.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Severance of Statute to Save Constitutional Portion Where the Court of Appeals affirmed lower court holdings that Laws of 1996 (ch 13), which empowers the Public Employment Relations Board (PERB) to invoke procedures to be followed in the event of disputes which reach an impasse in the course of collective negotiations between the public employer and the New York City police (ch 13, § 1), and removes the exemption of the New York City police and fire department members from PERB's binding arbitration impasse procedures (ch 13, § 2), is unconstitutional, it will not strike down as unconstitutional only section 1 of chapter 13 and leave standing section 2. In the absence of evidence that the Legislature would have intended that section 2's amendment of Civil Service Law § 209 remain effective if the primary purpose of the act--to provide PERB with jurisdiction over an impasse between the City and its police force--could not be given effect, there is no basis to sever chapter 13 and uphold section 2.

 

43 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Lunding v. Tax Appeals Tribunal


No. 260


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


89 N.Y.2d 283; 675 N.E.2d 816; 653 N.Y.S.2d 62; 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 3587


November 13, 1996, Argued  
 December 18, 1996, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Certiorari Denied May 19, 1997, Reported at: 1997 U.S. LEXIS 3094.



DISPOSITION: The judgment of the Appellate Division should be reversed, with costs, the petition dismissed and judgment granted declaring Tax Law @ 631(b)(6) constitutional.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant tax commissioner appealed a judgment from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which partially converted respondent non-resident taxpayers' proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 to an action for a declaratory judgment, declared N.Y. Tax Law § 631 (b) (6) unconstitutional, granted the remainder of the petition, and annulled a determination of respondent tax appeals tribunal.


OVERVIEW: In this combined action for a declaratory judgment and N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 relief, respondent non-resident taxpayers challenged the constitutionality of N.Y. Tax Law § 631 (b) (6), which disallowed non-residents a full deduction for alimony payments from their New York State income tax liability. The lower court declared the statute violative of the Privileges and Immunities Clause, and respondent tax commissioner appealed. The court reversed, ruling that disparate tax treatment of alimony paid by a non-resident was fully justified in light of the disparate treatment of income: nonresidents were taxed only on income earned in New York, while residents were taxed on all income earned from whatever sources. The disallowance was substantially justified by the fact that respondent taxpayers' alimony payments were wholly linked to personal activities outside the state. The state's treatment of alimony deductions was rationally related to its substantial policy of taxing only those gains realized and losses incurred by a non-resident in New York and was rationally related to its policy of limiting a non-resident's deductions to those attributable to income-producing activities in New York.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the lower court's judgment and held that the New York Tax Law disallowing respondent non-resident taxpayers a full deduction for alimony payments from their New York State income tax liability was constitutional. The court found that the law's disparate treatment was fully justified and rationally related to substantial state policies.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - Personal Income Tax - Constitutionality of Statute Disallowing Alimony Deduction to Nonresident - Privileges and Immunities Clause Tax Law § 631 (b) (6), which disallows nonresidents a full deduction for alimony payments from their New York State income tax liability, is not unconstitutional as violative of the Privileges and Immunities Clause of the United States Constitution. The Privileges and Immunities Clause does not mandate absolute equality in tax treatment and is not violated where there is a substantial reason for the difference in treatment, and the discrimination practiced against nonresidents bears a substantial relationship to the State's objective. New York's disparate tax treatment of alimony paid by a nonresident is fully justified in light of the disparate treatment of income: nonresidents are taxed only on income earned in New York, while residents are taxed on all income earned from whatever sources. The advantage granted residents is offset by the additional burden of being taxed on all sources of income. Nonresidents are not denied all benefit of the alimony deduction since they can claim the full amount of such payments in computing the hypothetical tax liability "as if a resident" under Tax Law § 601 (e). Furthermore, the disallowance is substantially justified by the fact that petitioner's alimony payments are wholly linked to personal activities outside the State.
