Taxation - Personal Income Tax - Constitutionality of Statute Disallowing Alimony Deduction to Nonresident - Equal Protection and Commerce Clauses Tax Law § 631 (b) (6), which disallows nonresidents a full deduction for alimony payments from their New York State income tax liability, is not unconstiutional as violative of the Equal Protection and Commerce Clauses of the United States Constitution. Nothing in the Fourteenth Amendment prevents the States from imposing unequal taxation on nonresidents, so long as the inequality is rationally related to the furtherance of a legitimate State interest. New York's treatment of alimony deductions is rationally related to its substantial policy of taxing only those gains realized and losses incurred by a nonresident in New York, while taxing residents on all income from whatever sources. Further, the challenged treatment is rationally related to its policy of limiting a nonresident's deductions to those attributable to income-producing activities in New York. Even if this matter concerning alimony payments were deemed to involve interstate commerce, the statute would not violate the Commerce Clause for the same reason.

 

44 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Blue Cross & Blue Shield v. McCall


No. 254


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


89 N.Y.2d 160; 674 N.E.2d 1124; 652 N.Y.S.2d 218; 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 3177


October 17, 1996, Argued  
 November 19, 1996, Decided



DISPOSITION:  Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent insurers filed an action challenging the constitutionality of N.Y. Ins. Law art. 43 (article 43) audits by appellee state comptroller (comptroller). On appeal, the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York) reversed the lower court, declaring that N.Y. Const. art. V, § 1 prohibited the legislature from assigning to the comptroller any duty concerning article 43 audits.


OVERVIEW: The insurers were private nonprofit health insurance providers organized under article 43. The superintendent of insurance (superintendent) was responsible for conducting article 43 audits. The legislature passed a bill giving the comptroller the same authority as the superintendent to conduct audits of nonprofit health insurers. The comptroller audited the insurers, issuing subpoenas for records and documents. The insurers filed an action challenging the constitutionality of the audit. The court held that the plain language of N.Y. Const. art. V, § 1 prohibited the legislature from delegating article 43 audits to the comptroller. Article 43 audits were within the administrative duties of the insurance department. Those same duties, funded by moneys suballocated from the insurance department, were also "administrative duties" when performed by the comptroller. N.Y. Const. art. V, § 1 prohibited the legislature from delegating administrative duties to the comptroller that were not incidental to the supervision of the state's fiscal affairs. Administrative audits of private nonprofit insurers did not serve that fundamental duty of the comptroller.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order, with costs.


HEADNOTES

State - Comptroller - Power to Audit Insurance Companies NY Constitution, article V, § 1 prohibits the Legislature from assigning to the defendant State Comptroller the power to conduct audits of private not-for-profit health insurance corporations pursuant to Insurance Law article 43. Article 43 audits are within the administrative duties of the Insurance Department. Those same duties, funded by moneys suballocated from the Insurance Department, are also "administrative duties" when performed by the Comptroller. NY Constitution, article V, § 1 prohibits the Legislature from delegating administrative duties to the Comptroller that are not incidental to the supervision of the fiscal affairs of the State. That fundamental duty of the Comptroller is not served by administrative audits of private not-for-profit insurers. Moreover, defendants' attempt to narrow the definition of the term "administrative duties" to merely nonauditing duties finds support neither in the history nor in the plain language of article V, § 1.

 

45 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Brown v. State


No. 186


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


89 N.Y.2d 172; 674 N.E.2d 1129; 652 N.Y.S.2d 223; 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 3175; 75 A.L.R.5th 769


September 4, 1996, Argued  
 November 19, 1996, Decided



DISPOSITION:  Order modified, without costs, and case remitted to the Court of Claims for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant claimants sought review of the judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed an order of the Court of Claims granting a motion by respondent State to dismiss the claimant's civil rights claims and dismissing the claim for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction.


OVERVIEW: The claimants instituted an action on behalf of nonwhite males, who were stopped and examined by police while investigating a stabbing. The claimants sought monetary damages, alleging unconstitutional acts on the part of the State. The State moved to dismiss, contending that the court of original jurisdiction lacked subject-matter jurisdiction and that the claimants failed to state a cause of action. It granted the motion, holding that: 1) constitutional torts were not cognizable in that court; 2) that direct actions for violations of the New York State Constitution's Bill of Rights, specifically the right to be free from unreasonable searches and seizures and the right to equal protection under the law, under N.Y. Const. art. I, §§ 11 and 12, were not cognizable claims absent some link to a common-law "traditional" tort; 3) that actions for negligent training and supervision were not cognizable claims where the underlying harms were themselves not matters within the court's jurisdiction; and 4) that actions based on 42 U.S.C.S. § 1981 do not lie against states. The court modified the decision, finding subject-matter jurisdiction and cognizable state constitutional arguments.


OUTCOME: The court found that the Court of Claims had jurisdiction over all the causes of action asserted. The court found that the claimants' causes of action based on violations of the New York State Constitution, as well as a claim for negligent training and supervision, were facially sufficient to state causes of action. They were to be reinstated. The remaining causes of action were properly dismissed. The lower court's judgment was modified.


HEADNOTES

Torts -- Constitutional Torts

1. A constitutional tort is any action for damages for violation of a constitutional right against a government or individual defendants. Constitutions assign rights to individuals and impose duties on the government to regulate the government's actions to protect them. It is the failure to fulfill a stated constitutional duty which may support a claim for damages in a constitutional tort action.

State -- Court of Claims -- Jurisdiction of Constitutional Tort Claims

2. Damage claims against the State based upon violations of the State Constitution come within the jurisdiction of the Court of Claims. The State's waiver of sovereign immunity contained in Court of Claims Act § 8, which provides that "[t]he state hereby waives its immunity from liability and action and hereby assumes liability and consents to have the same determined in accordance with the same rules of law as applied to actions in the supreme court against individuals or corporations", includes all claims over which the Court of Claims has jurisdiction--appropriation, breach of contract and torts--and applies the rule of respondeat superior to the State (see, Court of Claims Act § 9 [2]). Inasmuch as there is no clear definition by which wrongs are classified as torts, the Legislature could not have used the term when enacting section 9 (2) with a precision that would limit the jurisdiction of the Court of Claims solely to common-law torts or those recognized at the time. It is more likely that the term was used generally to indicate a branch of the law broader than the then-existing categories and subject to expansion as new wrongs supporting liability were recognized. Moreover, while the waiver contained in section 8 is limited to liability actions similar to those which may be brought in Supreme Court against individuals and corporations (see, Court of Claims Act §§ 8, 12 [1]), constitutional torts are sufficiently similar to claims which may be asserted by individuals and corporations in Supreme Court to satisfy the statutory requirement. Accordingly, the jurisdiction of the Court of Claims is not limited to common-law tort causes of action, and damage claims against the State based upon violations of the State Constitution come within the jurisdiction of the Court of Claims.

State -- Claim against State -- Viability of Claims Based on 42 USC § 1981

3. Although the Court of Claims has jurisdiction to hear claims based on 42 USC § 1981, claimants do not state causes of action against the State pursuant to 42 USC § 1981 based upon the actions of State defendants relating to the stop, questioning and examination of the nonwhite claimants during an investigation of a crime. No suit lies against the State under 42 USC § 1983 because the State is not a "person" within the meaning of the statute, and section 1983 provides the exclusive Federal damages remedy for violation of the rights guaranteed by section 1981. Thus, the State is not a "person" within the statute and it cannot be liable in an action based on section 1981.

State -- Claim against State -- Viability of Claims Based on Violations of Equal Protection and Search and Seizure Clauses of State Constitution

4. A cause of action to recover damages may be asserted against the State for violation of the Equal Protection and Search and Seizure Clauses of the State Constitution (NY Const, art I, §§ 11, 12). The rights guaranteed by these two provisions have common-law antecedents warranting a tort remedy for invasion of the rights they recognize. Moreover, implying a damage remedy here is consistent with the purposes underlying the duties imposed by these provisions and is necessary and appropriate to ensure the full realization of the rights they state. Further, these sections establish a duty sufficient to support causes of action to secure the liberty interests guaranteed to individuals by the State Constitution independent of any common-law tort rule. Common-law tort rules are heavily influenced by overriding concerns of adjusting losses and allocating risks, matters that have little relevance when constitutional rights are at stake. In addition, the duties imposed upon government officers by these provisions address something far more serious than the private wrongs regulated by the common law. Damages are a necessary deterrent for such misconduct. Accordingly, claimants' allegations that the defendant State's officers and employees deprived them of the right to be free from unlawful police conduct violating the Search and Seizure Clause and that claimants were treated discriminatorily in violation of the State Equal Protection Clause, based upon police actions in connection with the stop, questioning and examination of claimants while investigating a crime, are facially sufficient to state causes of action.

 

46 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Tug Buster Bouchard Corp. v. Wetzler


No. 225


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


89 N.Y.2d 830; 675 N.E.2d 1223; 653 N.Y.S.2d 271; 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 3166


October 8, 1996, Argued  
 November 14, 1996, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs, in a memorandum.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - Petroleum Gross Receipts Tax In a proceeding challenging the constitutionality of the Petroleum Business Tax (see, Tax Law § 301), an order of the Appellate Division, which modified a judgment canceling notices of deficiency and declaring section 301 unconstitutional, by declaring only Tax Law § 301 (a) (1) (ii) unconstitutional, should be affirmed. Inasmuch as respondent State explicitly conceded the unconstitutionality of the tax as applied to petitioners, the decision of the Appellate Division is affirmed and nothing more need be decided with respect to this case.

 

47 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Straniere v. Silver


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


89 N.Y.2d 825; 675 N.E.2d 1222; 653 N.Y.S.2d 270; 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 4994


October 16, 1996, Argued  
 November 14, 1996, Decided


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Speech or Debate Clause - Immunity of Legislators for Legislative Activities - Determination of Assembly Speaker to Require Home Rule Message for Secession Legislation for Borough of Staten Island In a proceeding challenging the constitutionality of a determination of the Speaker of the State Assembly that a bill providing for the secession of the Borough of Staten Island from the City of New York required a home rule message before it could be reported out of committee, an order of the Appellate Division, which affirmed the dismissal of the petition, is affirmed for the reasons stated in the opinion thereat, which concluded that home rule determinations of the type at issue are part and parcel of the legislative process and are routinely made by the Speaker of the Assembly; that the Speaker's decision to require a home rule message for the Secession Bill was an integral part of the legislative process, and thus a legislative act for which respondents were immune by virtue of the Speech or Debate Clause (NY Const, art III, § 11); that the Speech or Debate Clause protection does not begin with the onset of committee deliberations since many important legislative activities entitled to Speech or Debate Clause immunity, including the drafting of bills and the reference of bills to committee, occur prior to this stage of the legislative process; that there was no merit to petitioners' argument that the Speech or Debate Clause does not shield erroneous determinations by legislators and their staffs since the privilege would be virtually worthless if courts determining its applicability had to carefully examine the acts ostensibly shielded; that because judgments of legality or constitutionality obviously involve "questioning" of legislative acts, courts may not strip acts taken in the legislative process of their constitutional immunity by finding that the acts are substantively illegal or unconstitutional; that there was no support in the record for petitioners' argument that the challenged determination was not made in conformance with the accepted procedure; that even if a violation of the Assembly's rules were demonstrated, such violation would not abrogate Speech or Debate Clause immunity; and that judicial review must be limited to determining whether the action constitutes a legitimate legislative activity, and once a determination is made that the action is within the purview of legitimate legislative activity, the court's review must end.

 

48 of 992 DOCUMENTS


New York City Transit Auth. v. Executive Dep't, Div. of Human Rights


No. 179


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


89 N.Y.2d 79; 674 N.E.2d 305; 651 N.Y.S.2d 375; 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 3162


September 3, 1996, Argued  
 October 22, 1996, Decided



DISPOSITION:  Order modified in accordance with the opinion herein, with costs to complainant against petitioner New York City Transit Authority and matter remitted to the Appellate Division, First Department, for consideration of issues raised but not considered on the appeal to that court and, as so modified, affirmed, with costs to petitioner Union against complainant.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: After her discharge, appellant employee, a practicing Seventh Day Adventist, filed a discrimination complaint with respondent, the State of New York, Executive Department, Division of Human Rights (Division), alleging that respondents, employer and union, had violated N.Y. Exec. Law § 296(10)(a). The Division found in favor of the employee. The Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division annulled the Division's order. The employee appealed.


OVERVIEW: It was undisputed that the employee was discharged only because of her inability to work a normal weekend shift due to her religion. The employer argued that it was excused from its duty to accommodate the employee because it had a collective bargaining agreement with the union, which required that senior employees be given preference in selecting their days off. The employee and the Division contended that the collective bargaining agreement did not expressly prohibit voluntary "swaps" and, therefore, it did not shield the employer from its good-faith responsibility under § 296(10)(a). On appeal, the court first held that § 296(10)(a), by its terms, applied only to employers. Thus, the union was not a proper party to the action. The court also held that the appellate court should not have exonerated the employer. The employer did not have to file a formal grievance to force the union to permit it to arrange a voluntary "swap" for the employee. However, the employer did have a duty to take reasonable steps in an effort to reach an accommodation of the employee's religious needs. The employer failed to show that it exerted such reasonable efforts.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the part of the order exonerating the employer but otherwise affirmed and remitted the case to the appellate court for consideration of issues raised but not considered on appeal.


HEADNOTES

Civil Rights - Discrimination in Employment - Collective Bargaining Agent as Employer In a proceeding pursuant to the Human Rights Law (Executive Law § 290 et seq.) alleging that complainant's employer and her collective bargaining agent discriminated against her because of her religiously motivated Sabbath observance (Executive Law § 296 [10]), the collective bargaining agent is not a proper party. Executive Law § 296 (10) (a), the sole predicate for this Human Rights Law proceeding, makes it unlawful "for any employer to prohibit, prevent or disqualify any person from, or otherwise to discriminate against any person in, obtaining or holding employment, because of his observance of any particular day or days ... as a sabbath ... in accordance with the requirements of his religion" (emphasis supplied). By its terms, the prohibition is aimed only at employers, a class that plainly does not include the collective bargaining agent in this situation.

Civil Rights - Discrimination in Employment - Religion - Observation of Sabbath In a proceeding pursuant to the Human Rights Law (Executive Law § 290 et seq.), an order of the State Division of Human Rights finding that complainant's employer discriminated against her by discharging her because of her inability to work a normal weekend shift due to her religiously motivated Sabbath observance (Executive Law § 296 [10]) is upheld. Where, as here, the mandate of the statute conflicts with the strictures of a collective bargaining agreement, which complainant's union interpreted as requiring that senior employees be given preference in selecting their days off, an employer caught in such a conflict is obligated only to make a "good faith" effort to accommodate a Sabbath-observing employee. The "good faith" standard requires that the employer show that it exerted reasonable efforts to accommodate its Sabbath-observing employees. This standard does not require proof that an accommodation was actually found, but rather that a genuine search for reasonable alternatives was undertaken. Here, although the employer did not have to go so far as to file a formal grievance to force the union to permit it to arrange a voluntary "swap" for the complainant, the employer did have a duty to take reasonable steps short of such labor litigation in an effort to reach an accommodation of her religious needs. The record, however, is devoid of proof that any such steps were taken. Since there was no showing that such a search was conducted here and since it is undisputed that the complainant was discharged only because of her inability to work a normal weekend shift, the finding of the Human Rights Division that the employer violated section 296 (10) was supported by substantial evidence and its determination should be upheld.

Appeal - Court of Appeals - Remand to Administrative Agency In a proceeding pursuant to the Human Rights Law (Executive Law § 290 et seq.) in which the Appellate Division annulled an order of the State Division of Human Rights finding that complainant's employer discriminated against her by discharging her because of her inability to work a normal weekend shift due to her religiously motivated Sabbath observance (Executive Law § 296 [10]), and the Court of Appeals modified the Appellate Division order by reversing the order insofar as it exonerated the employer, the matter is remitted to the Appellate Division for consideration of issues raised but not considered on the appeal to that Court, and there is no need to remand the matter for consideration before the agency. Once the State Division of Human Rights found probable cause to believe discrimination had occurred and set the matter down for a hearing, it was incumbent on the employer to come forward with whatever proof it had to show that an accommodation could not have been accomplished without undue economic hardship. Having chosen to rely exclusively on the existence of a union-enforced seniority system to establish its economic hardship defense, which the agency rejected, the employer cannot now claim that it should, in fairness, be given a new opportunity to recast its strategy and put forth a different set of facts in defense of its position.

 

49 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Gagliardo v. Dinkins


No. 210


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


89 N.Y.2d 62; 674 N.E.2d 298; 651 N.Y.S.2d 368; 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 3161


September 12, 1996, Argued  
 October 22, 1996, Decided



DISPOSITION:  Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff housing and transit police officer retirees (retirees) challenged an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed the trial court's orders declaring 1993 N.Y. Laws ch. 375, § 18 (b) and N.Y.C., N.Y., Admin. Code § 13-191 to be constitutional and granting summary judgment to defendant mayor dismissing the complaints that had been filed separately by the retirees.


OVERVIEW: The court held that under the variable supplements fund (VSF) legislation, the New York City Employees' Retirement System (NYCERS) trustees were not required, but were merely permitted to invest in equity securities. The amount of employer contributions to the NYCERS fund was totally unaffected by the legislation either directly or indirectly, and the statutory formula for the transfers of excess investment earnings guarantees that reserved funds would be maintained at a level equivalent to what would exist in the pension fund if all assets were invested in high-grade fixed income debt securities. Thus, the financial integrity of the NYCERS pension reserves to assure the fund's ability to meet its pension obligations was protected. Thus, the transfer of excess investment earnings from the NYCERS pension fund into the VSFs was not a violation of the Pension Impairment Clause, N.Y. Const. art. V, § 7. The court held that the transfer of VSF assets to New York City and the VSF benefit payments to those deemed eligible was not an unconstitutional gift under N.Y. Const. art. VIII, § 1 or a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA).


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's decision to affirm the trial court's decision granting summary judgment to the mayor and finding the VSF legislation to be constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service - Retirement and Pension Benefits - Constitutionality of Variable Supplements Fund - Pension Impairment Clause The transfer of excess investment earnings from the New York City Employees' Retirement System (NYCERS) pension fund into variable supplements funds (VSFs) to provide additional financial benefits to certain retirees of the New York City Transit Police (Administrative Code of City of NY § 13-191 et seq.), does not constitute a violation of the New York State Constitution's tion's Pension Impairment Clause (NY Const, art V, § 7), which provides that "membership in any pension or retirement system of the state or of a civil division thereof shall be a contractual relationship, the benefits of which shall not be diminished or impaired". To prevail on a claim of a violation of article V, § 7, plaintiffs, Transit Police retirees who receive NYCERS pension benefits but are statutorily ineligible for VSF benefits, must show that by reason of the formula-based transfer of excess investment earnings from the NYCERS pension fund to the VSFs some benefit set forth in the pension contract of the Administrative Code is diminished or impaired. Here, the statutory formula used to identify surplus investment earnings guaranteed that the pension fund corpus would not be impaired. Inasmuch as no provision of the statutory NYCERS pension contractual relationship requires the pension fund to pass on excess investment earnings to its members, the subsequent transfer of surplus earnings had no impairment effect whatsoever on plaintiffs' retirement benefits by way of reducing the employers' statutory liability for contributions to the pension fund or in any other manner undermining the ability of NYCERS to meet plaintiffs' retirement benefits or pension payment obligations to any other retirees (see, Administrative Code §§ 13-127, 13-133). Moreover, the VSF legislation does not restrict the NYCERS trustees' discretion or their autonomous judgment with regard to NYCERS investments and earnings resulting in any possible impairment of the pension fund reserves.

Civil Service - Retirement and Pension Benefits - Constitutionality of Variable Supplements Fund - Unconstitutional Gift of Public Moneys The transfer of variable supplements fund (VSF) assets to New York City and the VSF benefit payments to certain retirees of the New York City Transit Police (see, Administrative Code of City of NY § 13-191 et seq.) deemed eligible are not an unconstitutional gift under New York Constitution, article VIII, § 1 on the ground that the VSF legislation expressly declares that the variable supplements are not to be construed as pension fund or retirement system benefits. The variable supplements fund payments here were created through collective bargaining as additional future compensation for services actually rendered by police officers within the bargaining unit during the life of the agreement. In addition, these supplemental benefit payments serve the important purpose of attracting and retaining qualified candidate-officers and providing an inducement to remain in active police service. Therefore, these payments do not constitute a gift in violation of article VIII, § 1.

Civil Service - Retirement and Pension Benefits - Constitutionality of Variable Supplements Fund - Unconstitutional Gift of Public Moneys The transfer of variable supplements fund (VSF) assets to New York City and the VSF benefit payments to certain retirees of the New York City Transit Police (see, Administrative Code of City of NY § 13-191 et seq.) deemed eligible are not an unconstitutional gift under New York Constitution, article VIII, § 1 on the ground that Civil Service Law § 201 (4) excludes from the definition of "terms and conditions of employment ... any benefits provided by or to be provided by a public retirement system, or payments to a fund or insurer to provide an income for retirees, or payment to retirees or their beneficiaries". The constitutional prohibition on gifts of public funds is not necessarily subject to statutory definitions of terms or conditions of employment for purposes of governing labor-management relations between civil service employees and public or governmental employers under the Taylor Law (Civil Service Law § 200 et seq.). Thus, because the eligible retirees receiving the supplemental payments have furnished a corresponding benefit to the City of New York, the compensatory VSF payments in consideration for those benefits to the municipality do not constitute an impermissible gift within the meaning of the Constitution.

Civil Rights - Discrimination Based on Disability - Ineligibility of Certain Disability Retirees for Variable Supplements Fund Benefits - Americans with Disabilities Act The limitation on eligibility for variable supplements fund (VSF) benefits to certain retirees of the New York City Housing Police who have attained 20 or more years of service toward the minimum eligibility period for such payments does not improperly exclude officers who have retired as a result of disabilities, in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) (42 USC § 12101 et seq.). To fall within the protection of the ADA, an individual must be otherwise qualified for participation in the benefit program of the public entity (see, 42 USC § 12132). The term "qualified individual with a disability" is defined as an individual with a disability who, with or without reasonable modifications to rules, policies, or practices, meets the essential eligibility requirements for the receipt of services or the participation in programs or activities provided by the public entity (42 USC § 12131). Therefore, each of the plaintiffs can only invoke the protection of the ADA if they are qualified individuals who meet the essential eligibility requirements but were "excluded from participation in" or "denied the benefits of the services, programs, or activities of a public entity ... by any such entity" because of their disability (42 USC § 12132). Plaintiffs meet neither of these criteria. The eligibility requirement for VSF benefits precludes from benefits only officers with less than 20 years of credited service, not those who retired because of a disability. Consequently, the eligibility requirement does not discriminate against or burden disabled individuals in a manner different from or greater than the burdens it places on nondisabled individuals.

Civil Rights - Discrimination Based on Disability - Ineligibility of Certain Disability Retirees for Variable Supplements Fund Benefits - State Human Rights Law The limitation on eligibility for variable supplements fund (VSF) benefits to certain retirees of the New York City Housing Police who have attained 20 or more years of service toward the minimum eligibility period for such payments does not improperly exclude officers who have retired as a result of disabilities, in violation of the State Human Rights Law (Executive Law § 296 [1] [a]). Providing a disability pension program separate from a service pension does not violate the Human Rights Law's prohibition against discrimination based on disability. Given the different needs of service and disability retirees and the unique benefits offered to each retirement classification, it cannot be said that the limitation on VSF eligibility wrongly excludes disabled officers in violation of State law.

Civil Service - Retirement and Pension Benefits The combined 1987 and 1992-1993 variable supplements fund (VSF) legislation, pursuant to which the VSFs were created out of surplus investment earnings of New York City Employees' Retirement System (NYCERS) funds, and the City of New York guaranteed VSF benefit payments to eligible retirees of the New York City Transit Police and Housing Police in return for the transfer of 15% of the VSFs' assets to the City on a one-time basis, is not an unlawful scheme to divert pension funds to the City. The City and participating employers are required by statute to maintain the NYCERS fund, through annual contributions, at a level which is actuarially sufficient to meet anticipated pension benefit payments irrespective of whether there are transfers of any excess investment earnings. Thus, employer contributions remain unaffected by this legislation. Independent of any transfer of excess investment earnings to the VSFs, NYCERS can and must maintain a level of employer contributions sufficient to meet existing and anticipated pension fund obligations. Moreover, the 1987 legislation which created the VSFs out of surplus investment earnings of NYCERS funds was entirely separate from and unrelated to the 1992 and 1993 modifications whereby VSF benefits from the already created VSFs were converted from discretionary payments to definite benefits on a fixed payment schedule.

 

50 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Ballentine v. Koch


No. 211


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


89 N.Y.2d 51; 674 N.E.2d 292; 651 N.Y.S.2d 362; 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 3159


September 12, 1996, Argued  
 October 22, 1996, Decided



DISPOSITION:  Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff retired police officers appealed the judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed an order that granted a motion to dismiss by defendants, mayor and others, in the officers' challenge to the constitutionality of legislation affecting the method of funding their supplements fund.


OVERVIEW: Retired police officers who received or were eligible to receive payments from the Police Officer's Variable Supplements Fund (POVSF) brought an action against the mayor and others challenging the constitutionality of 1988 N.Y. Laws 247, which changed the funding and benefit structure of the POVSF. The court affirmed the dismissal of the complaint. The court held that the legislation was not an unconstitutional impairment of contractual pension rights in violation of N.Y. Const. art. V, § 7. The court found that the legislation established a benefit scheme expressly outside the purview of N.Y. Const. art. V, § 7, by defining the POVSF as neither a pension nor retirement system and by reserving to the legislature the unilateral right to amend or repeal the POVSF statutory provisions. The court also held that the legislation did not violate the Federal Contract Clause, U.S. Const. art. I, § 10. Given the highly conditional and discretionary nature of the original benefit scheme, and the express statutory repudiation of any right to disbursements, the officers were unable to demonstrate that the legislation changed any terms of an existing contractual relationship.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the dismissal of the officers' complaint.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service - Retirement and Pension Benefits - Changes to Police Officer's Variable Supplements Fund - Pension Impairment Clause Laws of 1988 (ch 247), which changed the funding and benefit structure of the Police Officer's Variable Supplements Fund (POVSF), does not unconstitutionally impair contractual pension rights in violation of article V, § 7 of the New York Constitution. The POVSF--a separate fund to be funded from the investment earnings of the existing pension fund and to provide supplemental benefits to some Police Pension Fund members--grew out of collective bargaining negotiations between defendant municipality and plaintiffs' bargaining representative, the Police Benevolent Association (PBA). In enacting the provisions creating and governing the POVSF in 1970, the Legislature defined the POVSF as not a pension or retirement system, and reserved to the Legislature the unilateral right to amend or repeal the POVSF statutory provisions (see, Administrative Code of City of NY § 13-269 [b]; § 13-271 [b] [2]), thereby establishing a benefit scheme expressly outside the purview of article V, § 7. The legislative history demonstrates that the union and the City agreed to the implementing language that effectively took the POVSF outside the scope of article V, § 7's protections, and plaintiffs have failed to demonstrate on this record that the plaintiffs' collective bargaining representative was acting outside the scope of its representational authority in agreeing to the statutory provisions at issue such as would invalidate the PBA's waiver of the constitutional protections of article V, § 7. Moreover, there is no public policy barring enforcement of the waiver in this case. A waiver of article V, § 7's protections, as to funds ordinarily included in the calculation of pension benefits, does not in itself violate public policy, and such a waiver may be implied from the plaintiffs' course of conduct. Nor is there any general prohibition preventing the creation of benefits for retired public employees that exist separately from the applicable pension or retirement system.

Civil Service - Retirement and Pension Benefits - Changes to Police Officer's Variable Supplements Fund - Federal Contract Clause Laws of 1988 (ch 247), which changed the funding and benefit structure of the Police Officer's Variable Supplements Fund (POVSF), a separate fund to be funded from the investment earnings of the existing pension fund and to provide supplemental benefits to some Police Pension Fund members, does not unconstitutionally impair contractual pension rights in violation of the Federal Contract Clause (US Const, art I, § 10, cl [1]). Analysis of a Contract Clause claim begins with a determination of whether the State law has, in fact, operated as a substantial impairment of a contractual relationship. However, where there is no existing contractual agreement regarding the terms changed by the legislation, there is no need to consider whether there was in fact an impairment and whether it was substantial. Here, under the original implementing legislation, the receipt of POVSF payments was made contingent on the existence of excess Pension Fund investment earnings and on the POVSF trustees' exercise of discretion with respect to disbursements from the supplemental fund. Consequently, under this benefit scheme, plaintiffs were not assured that funds for supplemental payments would be available, or that the payments, if made, would be of a certain amount or continue for any specified duration. Moreover, the statute itself expressly stipulated that it did not create any contractual rights as to the POVSF payments (Administrative Code of City of NY § 13-271 [b]). Given the highly conditional and discretionary nature of the original benefit scheme, and the express statutory repudiation of any right to disbursements, plaintiffs are unable to demonstrate that the 1988 legislation changed any terms of an existing contractual relationship.

 

51 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Pringle v. Wolfe


No. 166


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


88 N.Y.2d 426; 668 N.E.2d 1376; 646 N.Y.S.2d 82; 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 1529


June 5, 1996, Argued  
June 28, 1996, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Certiorari Denied December 2, 1996, Reported at: 1996 U.S. LEXIS 7204.



DISPOSITION: The judgment of Supreme Court should be reversed, with costs, and Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1193(2)(e)(7) declared constitutional.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, state commissioner of motor vehicles, challenged a judgment of the Supreme Court of New York in Wayne County, which declared N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1193(2)(e)(7) unconstitutional and enjoined appellant from enforcing it against respondent.


OVERVIEW: Respondent, whose license had been suspended pursuant to N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1193(2)(e)(7), pending his prosecution for driving while intoxicated, argued that the statute violated the due process clause. Appellant argued that in light of its paramount interest in maintaining highway safety, the pre-suspension hearing -- at which respondent had an opportunity to rebut the trial court's findings regarding his blood alcohol level -- was sufficient. The court agreed with appellant, finding that even though respondent's interest in driving pending his prosecution was substantial, the suspension's temporary nature and the availability of a pre-suspension hearing and immediate hardship relief reduced the risk of erroneous deprivation. The court also found that appellant had a paramount interest in highway safety, and that any other process would not adequately serve that interest.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment, holding that the availability of a pre-suspension hearing and hardship relief, along with the fact that suspension was temporary, meant the intrusion on respondent's right to drive was not too extensive in light of appellant's paramount interest in highway safety.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles -- Operating Vehicle while Under Influence of Alcohol or Drugs -- Validity of Statutory Suspension of Driver's License Pending Prosecution -- Due Process of Law

1. The prompt suspension law (Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1193 [2] [e] [7]), which under certain circumstances mandates the suspension of a driver's license to operate a motor vehicle pending prosecution for driving while intoxicated, affords the driver all the process that is constitutionally due. A driver's license is a substantial property interest that may not be deprived without due process of law. The due process inquiry consists of a balancing of the private interest that will be affected by the official action; the risk of an erroneous deprivation of such interest through the procedures used, and the probable value, if any, of additional or substitute procedural safeguards; and the Government's interest, including the function involved and the fiscal and administrative burdens that the additional or substitute procedural requirement would entail. Here, though the private interest affected by the prompt suspension law is substantial, the severity of the license suspension is mitigated by its temporary duration, the availability of a conditional license and hardship relief, and the significant protection of a presuspension judicial hearing, which militates heavily in favor of the statute's constitutionality. Further weighing against the driver's interest in maintaining his license are the slight risk of an erroneous deprivation and the overriding State interest in the prompt removal of a safety hazard from its streets. Thus, the prompt suspension law accords with due process requirements.

Motor Vehicles -- Operating Vehicle while Under Influence of Alcohol or Drugs -- Validity of Statutory Suspension of Driver's License Pending Prosecution -- Opportunity of Driver to Present Presuspension Rebuttal Evidence

2. The prompt suspension law (Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1193 [2] [e] [7]), which under certain circumstances mandates the suspension of a driver's license to operate a motor vehicle pending prosecution for driving while intoxicated, entitles the driver to present evidence to rebut the court's tentative findings that the accusatory instrument is sufficient on its face and that there exists reasonable cause to believe that the driver operated a motor vehicle with the proscribed blood alcohol level before the court may order the license suspension.

Motor Vehicles -- Operating Vehicle while Under Influence of Alcohol or Drugs -- Validity of Statutory Suspension of Driver's License Pending Prosecution -- Vagueness

3. The prompt suspension law (Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1193 [2] [e] [7]), which under certain circumstances mandates the suspension of a driver's license to operate a motor vehicle pending prosecution for driving while intoxicated, is not unconstitutionally vague on the ground that subdivision (2) (e) (7) (a) mandates suspension where the driver "at the time of arrest" had a blood alcohol level over .10 of 1%, and it is not a crime to be intoxicated at the time of the arrest. The language in section 1193 (2) (e) (7) (a) must be read in conjunction with subclause (b), which provides that a prima facie showing for license suspension is established only when the court finds reasonable cause to believe the driver operated a motor vehicle with the proscribed blood alcohol level. The language of subclause (a) does not alter this required prima facie showing and consequently does not render the statute void for vagueness.

 

52 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Long Island Power Auth. v. Shoreham-Wading River Cent. Sch. Dist.


No. 107


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


88 N.Y.2d 503; 670 N.E.2d 419; 647 N.Y.S.2d 135; 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 1189


March 27, 1996, Argued  
June 13, 1996, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Motion denied by Long Island Power Auth. v. Shoreham-Wading River Cent. Dist., 88 N.Y.2d 1010, 672 N.E.2d 600, 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 3121, 649 N.Y.S.2d 375 (1996)
Related proceeding at Initiative for Competitive Energy v. Long Island Power Auth., 178 Misc. 2d 979, 683 N.Y.S.2d 391, 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 553 (N.Y. Sup. Ct., 1998)



DISPOSITION:  Judgment appealed from and order of the Appellate Division brought up for review modified, without costs, in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) affirmed the trial court's grant in part defendant county's motion for summary judgment, and held that intervenor plaintiff lighting company's tax liability ceased, that plaintiff power authority's payments in lieu of taxes (PILOTs) began upon the transfer of the power plant, and that the PILOTs would continue in perpetuity. All parties appealed.


OVERVIEW: The cross-appeals involved the construction of provisions of the Long Island Power Authority Act (LIPA Act), N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law §§ 1020 to 1020-hh. The trial court held that: 1) the lighting company's tax liability ceased and the power authority's PILOTs began upon the transfer of the power plant; 2) any excess PILOTs based upon a determination reducing the assessed valuation of the power plant would be subject to full refunds; and 3) the power plant was nonoperative prior to and on the day of transfer; and the power plant PILOTs for the first year would be 100 percent of the taxes and assessments the lighting company would have been required to pay had the transfer not occurred, after which PILOTs would be reduced by 10 percent of the previous year's amount until the PILOTs equaled the taxes and assessments the lighting company would have been required to pay, which payments would then continue in perpetuity. On appeal, the court that: 1) the power authority's PILOT obligation began with the December 1, 1992-November 30, 1993 taxable year, and 2) PILOTs on the power plant were to be reduced each year by 10 percent of the PILOT of the preceding year.


OUTCOME: The appellate court order was modified, without costs, and, as so modified, was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Public Authorities - Long Island Power Authority - Acquisition and Closure of Shoreham Nuclear Power Plant - Commencement of Payments in Lieu of Taxes With respect to the acquisition and decommissioning of the Long Island Lighting Company's (LILCO) Shoreham Nuclear Power Plant by the Long Island Power Authority (LIPA) (see, Public Authorities Law §§ 1020--1020-hh), the effective date for substitution of LIPA's obligation to make payments in lieu of taxes (PILOTs) for LILCO's real property tax liability on the plant begins with Suffolk County's December 1, 1992 through November 30, 1993 tax year, notwithstanding that the plant was transferred to LIPA on February 29, 1992. The general rule is that ownership of real estate on the taxable status date determines whether the property is subject to real property taxation for the entire ensuing taxable year, irrespective of the property's subsequent acquisition by a tax-exempt entity during that taxable year. The general rule may be overcome by legislation indicating a contrary intention. Here, the tax status date for the December 1, 1991 through November 30, 1992 taxable year was June 1, 1991 (Suffolk County Tax Act former § 5), and real property taxes owed on the plant for that taxable year became a lien on that property on December 1, 1991. Thus, Shoreham's statutory tax-exempt status as property of LIPA did not go into effect before the June 1, 1991 tax status date, and the taxes owed for the December 1, 1991 through November 30, 1992 taxable year became a lien on the property before it was acquired by LIPA. Moreover, there is no indication in the statutory language or legislative history that the Legislature intended to override the general rule and make Shoreham's tax-exempt status, triggering LIPA's PILOT obligation, effective immediately upon acquisition.

Public Authorities - Long Island Power Authority - Acquisition and Closure of Shoreham Nuclear Power Plant - Calculation of Payments in Lieu of Taxes - Duration of Payments in Lieu of Taxes With respect to the acquisition and decommissioning of the Long Island Lighting Company's (LILCO) Shoreham Nuclear Power Plant by the Long Island Power Authority (LIPA) (see, Public Authorities Law §§ 1020--1020-hh), LIPA's obligation for payments in lieu of taxes (PILOTs) for LILCO's real property tax liability on the plant under Public Authorities Law § 1020-q (1) is perpetual, subject to reduction until its attainment of its legally and properly assessed valuation in a nonoperative state, as determined by way of agreement of the parties to the action, or by a court of competent jurisdiction. Inasmuch as the LIPA Act only expressly limits the decreases in PILOTs to that point of equivalency to tax levies on a nonoperative facility, the most reasonable construction of section 1020-q (1) directs gradual reduction of the size of PILOTs until they reach a floor level of taxes and assessments which the taxing jurisdictions would have received from LILCO based upon a properly assessed valuation of a defunct Shoreham plant. A total elimination of PILOTs on the Shoreham plant in its nonoperative state would have defeated the overriding purpose of section 1020-q (1), to provide a substitute stream of municipal revenue on all LILCO property acquired by LIPA, for the taxes which fairly and properly would have been received from year to year by each taxing jurisdiction if such acquisition had not occurred. Moreover, the literal language of section 1020-q (1) controls regarding the rate of reduction of PILOTs and, therefore, PILOTs on Shoreham are to be reduced each year by 10% of the PILOT of the preceding year.

Public Authorities - Long Island Power Authority - Acquisition and Closure of Shoreham Nuclear Power Plant - Refunds for Overpayments of Payments in Lieu of Taxes With respect to the acquisition and decommissioning of the Long Island Lighting Company's (LILCO) Shoreham Nuclear Power Plant by the Long Island Power Authority (LIPA) (see, Public Authorities Law §§ 1020--1020-hh), Public Authorities Law § 1020-q (3), which provides that no local governmental taxing jurisdiction "shall be liable to [LIPA] or any other entity for a refund of property taxes originally assessed against the Shoreham plant", bars recovery of any refund from any such taxing jurisdiction of taxes previously paid, which refund may have become due as a result of a "judicial determination that the Shoreham plant assessment was excessive, unequal or unlawful for any of the years from [1976] to [January 15, 1987]", and directs that LIPA was to "discontinue and abandon all proceedings, brought by its predecessor in interest, which seek the repayment of all or part of the taxes assessed against the Shoreham plant", should not be read as completely immunizing the various taxing jurisdictions from refund liability for overpayments of payments in lieu of taxes (PILOTs) (Public Authorities Law § 1020-q [1]) based upon inflated assessed valuations of Shoreham following enactment of the LIPA Act. The plain language of Public Authorities Law § 1020-q (3) does not prohibit an action by LIPA to recover PILOT overpayments. Section 1020-q (3) bespeaks of a legislative intent limited to relieving the local taxing jurisdictions from the drastic impact of substantial refund liability for past taxes and assessments challenged by LILCO, not PILOTs prospectively imposed following LIPA's acquisition of the Shoreham plant.

 

53 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Symphony Space v. Pergola Props.


No. 155


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


88 N.Y.2d 466; 669 N.E.2d 799; 646 N.Y.S.2d 641; 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 1523


May 2, 1996, Argued  
June 13, 1996, Decided



DISPOSITION:  Order affirmed, with costs, and certified question answered in the affirmative.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant mortgagee's assignee challenged the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed the trial court's order that granted summary judgment to plaintiff mortgagor and denied the summary judgment motion of the mortgagee's assignee. The lower courts found that the commercial option was unenforceable under the Rule against Perpetuities and that rescission was inappropriate.


OVERVIEW: The court held that New York's current statutory Rule against Perpetuities, codified in N.Y. Est. Powers & Trusts Law § 9-1.1, applied to commercial options to purchase real property. The court held that the option could not qualify as an option appurtenant and significantly deterred development of the property. The court found plain language of the instrument indicated that the option could potentially be exercised more than 24 years after its creation, which was more than the 21 years permitted under § 9-1.1. The saving statute, N.Y. Est. Powers & Trusts Law § 9-1.3, mandated that unless a contrary intention appeared, it should be presumed that the creator intended the estate to be valid. Given the contrary intention manifested in the instrument itself, § 9-1.3 was inapplicable. The court found that the remedy of recission could not be applied because there was an irreconcilable conflict in applying a remedy that was designed to void a transaction because it failed to carry out the parties' true intent to a transaction in which the mistake made by the parties was the application of the Rule against Perpetuities, the purpose of which was to defeat the intent of the parties.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the lower courts' determination that the commercial option was unenforceable under the Rule against Perpetuities and that rescission was inappropriate.


HEADNOTES

Perpetuities - Rule against Perpetuities - Option to Purchase Commercial Property Options to purchase commercial property are not exempt from the prohibition against remote vesting embodied in New York's Rule against Perpetuities (EPTL 9-1.1 [b]). The common-law rule against remote vesting encompasses purchase options that might vest beyond the permissible period of 21 years after one or more lives in being at the creation of the estate and any period of gestation involved and, therefore, EPTL 9-1.1 (b) necessarily encompasses such options. Inasmuch as the common-law prohibition against remote vesting applies to both commercial and noncommercial options, the Legislature intended EPTL 9-1.1 (b) to apply to commercial options as well. Creation of a general exception to EPTL 9-1.1 (b) for all commercial purchase options would remove an entire class of contingent future interests that the Legislature intended the statute to cover; such statutory reformation would require legislative action.

Perpetuities - Rule against Perpetuities - Remote Vesting - Option to Purchase Commercial Property An option to purchase commercial property which grants its holder absolute power to purchase the property at the holder's whim and at a token price set far below market value, necessarily discourages the property owner from investing in improvements to the property and significantly impedes the owner's ability to sell the property to a third party, as a practical matter rendering it inalienable; thus, the option agreement creates precisely the sort of control over future disposition of the property that EPTL 9-1.1 (b) seeks to prevent.

Perpetuities - Rule against Perpetuities - Remote Vesting - Exemption for Option Appurtenant An option to purchase commercial property held by the lessee of a portion of the premises comprised of both commercial space and a theater is not an option appurtenant that is exempt from the prohibition against remote vesting (EPTL 9-1.1 [b]) where the holder of the option occupies only the commercial space, resulting in a disincentive for the owner to improve the theater space because it will eventually be claimed by the option holder at the predetermined purchase price, the option is contained in an agreement separate from the lease, and the option exceeds the term of the lease.

Perpetuities - Rule against Perpetuities - Remote Vesting - Corporate Option to Purchase Commercial Property An option to purchase commercial property created on December 1, 1978 which may be exercised "at any time after July 1, 1979," so long as the closing date is scheduled during 1987, 1993, 1998 or 2003 permits exercise of the option beyond the permissible period involved (EPTL 9-1.1 [b]). Where, as here, the parties to a transaction are corporations and no measuring lives are stated in the instruments, the perpetuities period is simply 21 years, and the subject option could potentially be exercised as late as July 2003--more than 24 years after its creation in December 1978.

Perpetuities - Rule against Perpetuities - Remote Vesting - Option to Purchase Commercial Property - Saving Statute With regard to an option to purchase commercial property executed in connection with a sale-partial leaseback of the subject premises, which established a 24-year exercise period by providing that the option may be exercised "at any time after July 1, 1979," so long as the closing date is scheduled during 1987, 1993, 1998 or 2003, the saving statute (EPTL 9-1.3) cannot be invoked to shorten the duration of the exercise period so as to satisfy the 21-year requirement in the prohibition against remote vesting embodied in New York's Rule against Perpetuities (EPTL 9-1.1 [b]), since the unambiguous language of the option agreement expresses the parties' intent that the option be exercisable "at any time" during a 24-year period. The saving statute seeks to avoid annulling dispositions due to inadvertent violations of the Rule against Perpetuities by presuming that the creator intended the estate to be valid, but its provisions are merely rules of construction. While the statute obligates reviewing courts, where possible, to avoid constructions that frustrate the parties' intended purposes, it does not authorize courts to rewrite instruments that unequivocally allow interests to vest outside the perpetuities period.

Perpetuities - Rule against Perpetuities - Remote Vesting - Option to Purchase "At Any Time" after Maturity of Mortgage Note The provision of an option to purchase commercial property executed in connection with a December 31, 1978 sale-partial leaseback of the subject premises that authorizes the option to be exercised "at any time" following the maturity of a mortgage note given to the seller by the buyer allows the option to be exercised after the 21-year period of the prohibition against remote vesting embodied in New York's Rule against Perpetuities (EPTL 9-1.1 [b]), since the only limit on duration is the designation of December 31, 2003 as the latest possible closing date which, when the agreement's 90-day notice period is factored in, would permit the option to be exercised until October 2003.

Perpetuities - Rule against Perpetuities - Remote Vesting - Option to Purchase for Defined Period Contingent on Lease Termination or Mortgage Default The provisions of an option to purchase commercial property executed in connection with a December 31, 1978 sale-partial leaseback of the subject premises, which permit exercise of the option for a defined period contingent on termination of the lease or contingent upon the buyer's default on a purchase-money mortgage given as part of the transaction, allow the option to be exercised after the 21-year period of the prohibition against remote vesting embodied in New York's Rule against Perpetuities (EPTL 9-1.1 [b]), since neither the lease nor the mortgage expires until a date in 2003. Accordingly, the lease could be terminated, or the buyer could default on the mortgage, some time prior to 2003 but after the 21-year period lapses in December 1999 and the option could be exercised during this interval.

Perpetuities - Rule against Perpetuities - Remote Vesting - Saving Statute - Contingent Option to Purchase With respect to the provisions of an option to purchase commercial property executed in connection with the December 31, 1978 sale-partial leaseback of the subject premises, which permit exercise of the option for a defined period contingent on termination of the lease or contingent upon the buyer's default on a purchase-money mortgage given as part of the transaction, and allow the option to be exercised after the 21-year period of the prohibition against remote vesting embodied in New York's Rule against Perpetuities (EPTL 9-1.1 [b]) because neither the lease nor the mortgage expires until a date in 2003, the duration of the exercise period cannot be shortened to satisfy the 21-year requirement by invoking the presumption under the saving statute (EPTL 9-1.3 [d]) that the parties expected the contingencies to occur, if at all, within the 21-year period. The option agreement specifies that the closing date could be scheduled as late as December 31, 2003 and, therefore, the parties manifested their expectation that the contingency might occur and the option might be exercised well beyond December 1999. Given this contrary intention in the agreement itself, the saving statute is inapplicable.

Perpetuities - Rule against Perpetuities - "Wait and See" Approach The "wait and see" approach to the Rule against Perpetuities (EPTL 9-1.1)--an interest is valid if it actually vests during the perpetuities period, irrespective of what might have happened--is rejected. The law of New York is settled that the validity of a provision under the Rule against Perpetuities be judged by the circumstances existing at the time of the grant. Moreover, the language of EPTL 9-1.1 itself that an interest is invalid "unless it must vest, if at all, not later than twenty-one years after one or more lives in being" (EPTL 9-1.1 [b]) precludes a determination of the validity of an interest based upon what actually occurs during the perpetuities period.

Perpetuities - Rule against Perpetuities - Availability of Rescission as Remedy for Failed Option to Purchase Where an option to purchase commercial property executed in connection with a sale-partial leaseback of the subject premises fails as violative of the prohibition against remote vesting embodied in the Rule against Perpetuities (EPTL 9-1.1 [b]), the contract of sale will not be rescinded due to the mutual mistake of the parties. While CPLR 3005 provides that when relief against mistake is sought, it shall not be denied merely because the mistake is one of law rather than fact, that provision removes technical objections in instances where recoveries can otherwise be justified by analogy with mistakes of fact, and here the parties' mistake is nothing more than a misunderstanding as to the applicable law. Moreover, the remedy of rescission lies in equity and is a matter of discretion; there is an irreconcilable conflict in applying a remedy which is designed to void a transaction because it fails to carry out the parties' true intent to a transaction in which the mistake made by the parties was the application of the Rule against Perpetuities, the purpose of which is to defeat the intent of the parties. Granting rescission would be contrary to New York's public policy reflected in the Rule against Perpetuities since it would lead to the same result as enforcing the option and tend to compel performance of contracts violative of the Rule.

 

54 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Griffin v. Coughlin


No. 73


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


88 N.Y.2d 674; 673 N.E.2d 98; 649 N.Y.S.2d 903; 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 1522


February 15, 1996, Argued  
June 11, 1996, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Certiorari Denied January 6, 1997, Reported at: 1997 U.S. LEXIS 59.



DISPOSITION:  Order reversed, without costs, and judgment granted prohibiting respondents from conditioning petitioner's participation in the Family Reunion Program on petitioner's attendance in the subject Alcohol and Substance Abuse Treatment Program.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner inmate sought review of a judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York), which affirmed a judgment of the trial court, which dismissed petitioner's complaint against respondents, commissioner of correctional services and individuals. Petitioner contended that requirement that he participate in drug/alcohol program to obtain expanded family visitation violated the Establishment Clause of U.S. Const. amend. I.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner inmate, who was an atheist, initiated action against respondents, commissioner of correctional services and individuals, and contended that the requirement that he participate in the drug/alcohol program in order to obtain expanded family visitation violated the Establishment Clause of U.S. Const. amend. I. The trial court dismissed petitioner's complaint, and the appellate court affirmed. Petitioner sought review. The court held that, pursuant to the Establishment Clause, the state and respondents were prohibited from using their power to force one to profess a religious belief or participate in a religious activity. The court held that an atheist or agnostic inmate was not allowed to be deprived of eligibility for a prison privilege program for refusing to participate in a drug/alcohol program when such program necessarily entailed mandatory attendance at and participation in a curriculum which adopted in major part religious-oriented practices. The court reversed judgments of the lower courts.


OUTCOME: The court reversed judgments of the lower courts, which dismissed petitioner inmate's complaint against respondents, commissioner of correctional services and individuals. The court held that respondents violated Establishment Clause of First Amendment by depriving petitioner of eligibility for expanded family visitation program for refusing to participate in drug/alcohol program that required mandatory attendance in religious-oriented practices.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Establishment of Religion - Mandatory Alcohol and Drug Addiction Program at State Correctional Facility Adopting 12-Step Alcoholics Anonymous Methodology Under the Establishment Clause of the United States Constitution's First Amendment, an atheist or agnostic inmate may not be deprived of eligibility for expanded family visitation privileges for refusing to participate in the sole alcohol and drug addiction program at his State correctional facility when the program necessarily entails mandatory attendance at and participation in a curriculum which adopts in major part the religious-oriented practices and precepts of Alcoholics Anonymous (A.A.). Doctrinally and as actually practiced in the 12-step methodology that comprises the heart of the A.A. program, adherence to the A.A. fellowship entails engagement in religious activity and religious proselytization. Followers are urged to accept the existence of God as a Supreme Being, Creator, Father of Light and Spirit of the Universe. In "working" the 12 steps, participants become actively involved in seeking such a God through prayer, confessing wrongs and asking for removal of shortcomings. These expressions and practices constitute, as a matter of law, religious exercise for Establishment Clause purposes. Moreover, even if the governing principles and practices of A.A., as incorporated in the correctional facility's Alcohol and Substance Abuse Treatment (ASAT) Program, do not necessarily require an atheist participant to accept the existence of God in the religious sense, or to engage in religious activity, the mandatory and exclusive incorporation of A.A. doctrine and practices in the ASAT Program violates Establishment Clause principles prohibiting governmental endorsement of religion, and requiring governmental neutrality with respect to religion.

Constitutional Law - Establishment of Religion - Endorsement of Religion under Lemon Test - Mandatory Alcohol and Drug Addiction Program at State Correctional Facility Adopting 12- Step Alcoholics Anonymous Methodology Under the second prong of the three-part Lemon test for primary Establishment Clause analysis ( Lemon v Kurtzman, 403 US 602), State action is invalid if its "primary effect" is to advance or promote religion. State-coerced adherence to a religious sect is not necessary to prove an Establishment Clause violation under any portion of the Lemon test. A "primary" effect of advancing religion does not connote that the religious consequences of the State action must predominate over any secular objective or consequence. No measurement or weighing of the respective secular and religious effects is required. A violation is established if the State action's inevitable effect is to aid and advance religion. Moreover, an endorsement of religion violating the Establishment Clause can be determined by examining whether the message that the government's practice communicates may be fairly understood as favoring or promoting religion. That is, it must be ascertained whether the challenged governmental action is sufficiently likely to be perceived by adherents of the controlling denominations as an endorsement, and by the nonadherents as a disapproval, of their individual religious choices. Accordingly, the inclusion of the 12-step methodology that comprises the heart of the Alcoholics Anonymous (A.A.) program, and A.A.'s other doctrines and meeting practices in a mandated, exclusive drug addiction and alcoholism rehabilitation program at a State correctional facility constitutes the prohibited endorsement of religion violating the Establishment Clause. It is simply unimaginable that inmates in the inherently authoritarian atmosphere of a prison would not perceive that such a mandatory, exclusive program, facially containing expressions and practices that have always been religious, favors inmates who adhere to those beliefs, and symbolically condones the religious proselytizing those expressions literally reflect.

 

55 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Town of Orangetown v. Magee


No. 76


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


88 N.Y.2d 41; 665 N.E.2d 1061; 643 N.Y.S.2d 21; 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 674


March 19, 1996, Argued  
April 30, 1996, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs, and certified question answered in the affirmative.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff town appealed from an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed the trial court's judgment for defendant developers on their counterclaims for an order compelling reinstatement of a building permit and damages pursuant to 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983.


OVERVIEW: After developers began working on a site, the building inspector, at the town supervisor's direction, revoked their building permit. Town then sued to compel the removal of a building on the site. On review, the court held that developers were entitled to reinstatement of the permit because they had a vested right in the planned construction, as the permit was legally issued. The record supported the trial court's conclusion that developers had sufficiently committed the land to the use authorized by the permit prior to revocation. Thus, the revocation resulted in an unconstitutional deprivation of developers' property rights. The court thus held that developers stated a cause of action for damages under 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983 because the acts of town in revoking developers' permit denied them substantive due process of law. Developers had established a protectable property interest in the building permit. Due process assured them the right to be free from arbitrary municipal actions destructive of this interest. The record supported the conclusion that the building inspector's revocation of the permit was solely for political reasons and thus arbitrary and capricious.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order review.


HEADNOTES

Civil Rights - Federal Civil Rights Claim - Deprivation of Vested Right - Legally Issued Building Permit A vested right can be acquired when, pursuant to a legally issued permit, the landowner demonstrates a commitment to the purpose for which the permit was granted by effecting substantial changes and incurring substantial expenses to further the development. The landowner's actions relying on a valid permit must be so substantial that the municipal action results in serious loss rendering the improvements essentially valueless. Accordingly, where there is support in the record for the lower courts' factual finding that defendants had sufficiently committed the land to the use authorized by the permit legally issued by plaintiff to defendants to develop the land prior to plaintiff's revocation of the permit, and the permit was revoked for unlawful reasons, the revocation resulted in an unconstitutional deprivation of defendants' property rights. Accordingly, defendants are entitled to reinstatement of the building permit in conformity with the zoning ordinances in effect at the time of the revocation.

Civil Rights - Federal Civil Rights Claim - Ripeness for Judicial Review - Determination of Town Building Inspector to Revoke Building Permit A determination of plaintiff Town's Building Inspector revoking defendants' permit to develop real property in the Town is final and, therefore, defendants' counterclaim under 42 USC § 1983 seeking damages on the ground that the Building Inspector's determination was arbitrary and capricious is ripe for judicial review notwithstanding that defendants did not appeal the determination to the Town Zoning Board of Appeals. With respect to a substantive due process claim involving a land use decision under section 1983 based on arbitrary and capricious conduct, the decision sought to be reviewed must be final, but it is unnecessary that the landowner pursue administrative remedies to determine how the regulation in question applies to the property or avail itself of State procedures for determining compensation. The finality requirement is concerned with whether an official authorized to make the determination has arrived at a decision that inflicts injury. Here, under the Town's ordinances, the Building Inspector was the "initial decisionmaker" vested by law with the exclusive and unfettered authority to decide the question of revocation and he clearly had done so when he revoked defendants' permit and halted work on the project. The Zoning Board was not authorized to revoke a permit or even participate in the Inspector's decision to revoke. Its power was restricted to the review of the Inspector's final decision. Thus, a determination by the Board was not necessary and defendants' counterclaim for section 1983 relief is ripe for judicial review.

Civil Rights - Federal Civil Rights Claim - Unlawful Revocation of Building Permit Defendants successfully established a claim for damages pursuant to 42 USC § 1983 based on plaintiff Town's Building Inspector's arbitrary and irrational revocation of their permit to develop real property in the Town. To succeed on a claim for damages pursuant to 42 USC § 1983, defendants were required to establish deprivation of a protectable property interest by one acting under the authority of law. Due process assures the right to be free from arbitrary or irrational municipal actions destructive of a cognizable property interest. Here, defendants established that the rights to develop their land had become vested under State law, and that they would have received the limited future authorizations necessary to complete the project. On this evidence, the Town had engendered a clear expectation of continued enjoyment of the permit sufficient to constitute a protectable property interest for purposes of a section 1983 claim. Further, the evidence in the record supports the trial court's conclusion that the Building Inspector's revocation of defendants' permit was arbitrary and capricious because it was without legal justification and motivated entirely by political concerns. The Building Inspector's actions may be imputed to the Town, since the Town Zoning Code, which necessarily reflects Town policy, vests the Building Inspector, alone, with the authority to revoke building permits. The Building Inspector therefore implements Town policy and the Town, by enacting the legislation, accepted the possibility that he would exercise this authority in an arbitrary and capricious manner.

Damages - Inadequate and Excessive Damages - Wrongful Revocation of Development Permit A damages award of $ 5,137,126 to defendants on their counterclaim against plaintiff Town pursuant to 42 USC § 1983 for the wrongful revocation of defendants' permit to develop real property in the Town will not be overturned as incorrectly computed or excessive. The parties agreed to a certain formula to measure damages. Implementing that formula, the Town stipulated to values for the building and the land before and after taking, the difference between the two numbers, the equity ratio and the market rate of return. The court determined other values based upon the evidence and directed the parties to compute the damages using the formula and submit their determination. It based its final award on those submissions. Inasmuch as the figures used were either supported by evidence or agreed upon by the parties, there is no basis to interfere with the award.

 

56 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Curiale v. Ardra Ins. Co.


No. 114


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


88 N.Y.2d 268; 667 N.E.2d 313; 644 N.Y.S.2d 663; 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 696


March 28, 1996, Argued  
April 30, 1996, Decided



DISPOSITION:  Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) affirmed a nonfinal order of the trial court in favor of respondent, Superintendent of Insurance of the State of New York, and against appellant insurance company, which struck the insurance company's answer unless it posted a bond or other security.


OVERVIEW: The insurance company's answer had been stricken because it did not post a preanswer security pursuant to N.Y. Ins. Law § 1213(c). The insurance company argued that as applied, § 1213(c) violated the procedural due process guarantees of the Federal Constitution. The court found that N.Y. Ins. Law § 1213(c), as applied to the insurance company, was constitutional. The state's interest in ensuring the availability of funds from which a judgment against a foreign or alien unlicensed insurer may be promptly paid, instead of requiring claimants to resort to far-flung forums for satisfaction of their judgments, justified striking the answer of a foreign or alien insurer if that insurer failed to provide adequate preanswer security. The court found that the evidence which the insurance company sought to introduce at the inquest was irrelevant because the liability on the claims was conceded.


OUTCOME: The order of the court of appeals was affirmed, with costs.


HEADNOTES
