Insurance - Liquidation of Insurer - Service of Process on Superintendent of Insurance as Attorney for Unauthorized Insurers - Bond Requirement as Condition to Interposing Answer Insurance Law § 1213 (c), which provides that before any unauthorized foreign or alien insurer files any pleading in any proceeding against it, it shall deposit security in an amount to be fixed by the court sufficient to secure payment of any final judgment which may be rendered against it in the proceeding, but that preanswer security may not be required if the Superintendent of Insurance certifies that the alien insurer maintains funds in New York sufficient to satisfy a potential judgment, and no security is required if the alien insurer is licensed to do business in New York State, does not unconstitutionally deprive appellant alien reinsurer of due process of law insofar as it authorized entry of a default judgment against appellant when appellant failed to post security in the amount set by the court in a proceeding by the Liquidator to recover reinsurance proceeds under policies issued to an insolvent insurer by appellant. The Insurance Law clearly provides notice that preanswer security will be required if an alien insurer chooses to conduct business in New York without a license. The State's interest in ensuring the availability of funds from which a judgment against a foreign or alien unlicensed insurer may be promptly paid, instead of requiring claimants to resort to far-flung forums for satisfaction of their judgments, justifies striking the answer of a foreign or alien insurer if that insurer fails to provide adequate preanswer security. The importance of the State interest here outweighs appellant's interest in litigating the merits of the Liquidator's claims without posting preanswer security sufficient to pay any judgment.

Judgments - Default Judgment - Inquest In a proceeding by the Liquidator seeking to recover reinsurance proceeds under policies issued to an insolvent insurer by appellant alien reinsurer, wherein appellant failed to deposit security in an amount set by the trial court, resulting in the entry of a default judgment against appellant pursuant to Insurance Law § 1213 (c), appellant's attempt to introduce evidence that certain P-claims were covered by other agreements as well as the reinsurance agreement at issue was properly excluded as irrelevant at the damages inquest inasmuch as the Liquidator presented evidence that all the claims designated with a P prefix were covered under the agreement at issue and appellant's liability for claims under that agreement was conceded.

 

57 of 992 DOCUMENTS


United Servs. Auto. Ass'n v. Curiale


No. 94


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


88 N.Y.2d 306; 668 N.E.2d 384; 645 N.Y.S.2d 413; 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 678


March 21, 1996, Argued  
April 30, 1996, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent foreign taxpayer filed a declaratory judgment action against appellant Superintendent of the State of New York Insurance Department, alleging that N.Y. Tax Law § 1505-a was unconstitutional. Both parties filed motions for summary judgment, and the trial court granted taxpayer's motion. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) affirmed the judgment. Superintendent sought review.


OVERVIEW: In New York, foreign insurers were subject to retaliatory taxes, which were designed to retaliate against foreign states with more onerous tax laws than New York. Generally, a tax credit was allowed for New York Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD) tax surcharges. However, N.Y. Tax Law § 1505-a disallowed an MCTD surcharge credit against retaliatory taxes for foreign insurers. Taxpayer argued that the denial of the credit violated the Equal Protection Clause of the United States Constitution. The appellate court affirmed the trial court's finding that § 1505-a was unconstitutional, concluding that the intent to increase or protect revenues at the expense of foreign insurers did not constitute a legitimate purpose sufficient to withstand an equal protection challenge. The court held that § 1505-a resulted in unconstitutional discrimination because it was unsupported by a legitimate governmental purpose. Specifically, § 1505-a did not protect the MCTD fund because taxpayer did not avoid paying the MCTD surcharge simply by receiving a credit; taxpayer was not seeking a refund of the MCTD surcharge but a credit against its retaliatory taxes.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District Tax Surcharge - Constitutionality of Denial of Credit against Retaliatory Taxes Tax Law § 1505-a (d) (8), insofar as it denies a credit to foreign insurers for the payment of the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD) tax surcharge against retaliatory taxes imposed under Insurance Law § 1112, is unsupported by a legitimate governmental purpose and, therefore, violates the Equal Protection Clause (US Const 14th Amend). A State tax statute will withstand an equal protection challenge if the classification at issue has a legitimate purpose and is rationally related to achievement of that purpose. Retaliatory taxation is legitimate precisely because it aims to equalize domestic and foreign taxation. A system of retaliatory taxation, which by definition discriminates between domestic and foreign insurance companies, is constitutionally sound insofar as it aims to equalize the tax burden of domestic and foreign insurers, but the imposition of retaliatory tax beyond the point of equalization solely to generate revenue at the expense of foreign insurers lacks legitimacy. Here, the only purpose served by disallowing the credit is revenue generation, but since this redounds to the exclusive detriment of foreign insurers, it is illegitimate and will not support the State's retaliation beyond the point of equalization.

 

58 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Gordon


No. 82


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


88 N.Y.2d 92; 666 N.E.2d 203; 643 N.Y.S.2d 498; 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 668


March 20, 1996, Argued  
April 25, 1996, Decided



DISPOSITION:  Order affirmed.



CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York), which reversed the trial court's order dismissing a criminal indictment. After identification of defendant by a witness was suppressed, defendant moved to dismiss the indictment pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 210.20(1)(b), on the grounds that the evidence before the grand jury was legally insufficient.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged in a criminal indictment with robbery in the first degree, criminal possession of stolen property in the fifth degree, and criminal possession of a weapon in the fourth degree. After identification of defendant by a witness was suppressed, defendant moved to dismiss the indictment pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 210.20(1)(b) and (h), on the grounds that the evidence before the grand jury was legally insufficient and that there was a legal impediment to conviction. The trial court granted the motion to dismiss, but the appellate decision reversed. On appeal, the court noted that a trial court's function on a motion to dismiss pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 210.20(1)(b) was limited to an assessment of the legal sufficiency of the evidence at the time of the indictment, not in light of subsequent developments. The court reasoned that suppression of the identification did not negate any elements of the charged crimes and, although the absence of identification might create a difficulty for the prosecution at trial, it did not render it impossible to obtain a conviction against defendant.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate division's judgment reversing the dismissal of the indictment, reinstating the indictment, and remitting the case to the trial court for further proceedings on the indictment.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Indictment - Sufficiency of Evidence before Grand Jury - Suppression of Identification of Defendant The indictment of defendant for robbery in the first degree and related crimes arising from the armed holdup of the victim was not rendered legally insufficient (see, CPL 210.20 [1] [b]) due to the suppression of the victim's identification of defendant. In the context of a Grand Jury proceeding, legally sufficient evidence means proof of a prima facie case, not proof beyond a reasonable doubt. If competent prima facie evidence underlying an indictment is subsequently rendered inadmissible by extrinsic proof, the legal sufficiency of the indictment is not undermined as the court's function on a motion to dismiss an indictment pursuant to CPL 210.20 (1) (b) is limited to an assessment of the legal sufficiency of the evidence at the time of the indictment, not in light of subsequent events. The relevant inquiry on a motion to dismiss an indictment pursuant to CPL 210.20 (1) (b) is whether the evidence before the Grand Jury, viewed most favorably to the People, would support a determination of guilt. Here, the victim's positive identification of defendant, together with the arresting officer's testimony, as presented to the Grand Jury, satisfied this threshold standard.

Crimes - Indictment - Dismissal Based on Legal Impediment to Conviction - Suppression of Identification Evidence The indictment of defendant for robbery in the first degree and related crimes arising from the armed holdup of the victim need not be dismissed on the ground that the suppression of the victim's identification of defendant constitutes a legal impediment to defendant's conviction (see, CPL 210.20 [1] [h]). Suppression of the identification evidence simply diminishes the quantum of proof against defendant but does not negate any elements of the charged crimes. While the absence of the identification may create difficulty for the prosecution at trial, it certainly does not render it impossible for the People to obtain a conviction against defendant.

 

59 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Poslock v. Teachers' Retirement Bd.


No. 109


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


88 N.Y.2d 146; 666 N.E.2d 528; 643 N.Y.S.2d 935; 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 673


March 28, 1996, Submitted  
April 25, 1996, Decided



DISPOSITION:  Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff contestants appealed from an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which modified a supreme court judgment denying a motion by defendant designated beneficiary for judgment notwithstanding the verdict for contestants, and directed the distribution of decedent's retirement benefits, except for certain term insurance, to the designated beneficiary.


OVERVIEW: Decedent, a schoolteacher, died. Under a retirement system for schoolteachers, decedent's designated beneficiary was entitled to receive a lump-sum payment of decedent's accumulated retirement benefits. Based on conversations between the decedent and contestants, the contestants challenged the beneficiary designated in the applicable forms. The jury found for the contestants and the supreme court denied a motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict. The appellate division modified and directed that the designated beneficiary was to receive the retirement benefits, except for certain term insurance. The contestants were not successful on appeal. The court held that conversations between the decedent and the contestants regarding decedent's retirement benefits did not fall within the life insurance proceeds exception to the testimonial bar of N.Y. C.P.L.R. 4519, the "Dead Man's Statute." The court agreed with the appellate division that decedent's schoolteacher retirement benefits were different from the proceeds of typical life insurance policies, because the proceeds belonged to the decedent before his death.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the appellate division that modified the supreme court judgment and directed the distribution of decedent's retirement benefits to the designated beneficiary, except for certain term insurance.


HEADNOTES

Evidence - Dead Man's Statute - Oral Communications with Decedent Regarding Distribution of Retirement Benefits Conversations between a decedent and parties contesting rights to decedent's lump-sum retirement benefits, excluding the life insurance component, under the New York City Teachers' Retirement System payable on decedent's death do not fall within the exception to the testimonial bar of the Dead Man's Statute (CPLR 4519) that relates solely to life insurance proceeds. The proceeds of a life insurance policy never belong to the deceased and do not come into existence until his or her death; accordingly, they are excepted from the evidentiary prohibition of the statute that contemplates property or an interest which belonged to the deceased in his lifetime and the title to which has passed by assignment or otherwise through him to the party who is protected by the section. Decedent's assets in his vested retirement plan belonged to him during his lifetime and were sufficiently manageable by him in ways that are significantly distinct from the life insurance assets. Nor did they merely come into existence on his death. Moreover, the purpose of CPLR 4519 is to protect estates from perjurious claims. If decedent had not designated any beneficiary, the final payout upon his death would have gone directly to his estate--a feature that is part of the CPLR 4519 protection against postdeath fabrications.

Trial - Verdict - Sufficiency of Evidence - Action to Recover Lump-Sum Retirement Benefits Payable on Decedent's Death In an action seeking recovery of lump-sum retirement benefits payable on decedent's death under a retirement plan, the evidence was insufficient to support the jury's verdict in favor of plaintiffs, individuals named in an alleged beneficiary designation, absent plaintiffs' testimony which is inadmissible pursuant to the Dead Man's Statute (CPLR 4519), since that testimony constituted the only evidence of the content of the alleged beneficiary designation that a notary testified he saw decedent sign and another witness allegedly mailed to the Retirement System. Without the key testimony, the jury would have been left to speculate about what the Retirement System had in fact received. Since all three copies of the alleged beneficiary designation "disappeared" in various and curious ways, there is no way to ascertain, without resort to the witness testimony, the content of what the decedent allegedly signed. CPLR 4519 was designed to ward off the dangers and adverse consequences of this very kind of unverifiable development.

 

60 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Lee TT v. Dowling


No. 54, No. 55


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


87 N.Y.2d 699; 664 N.E.2d 1243; 642 N.Y.S.2d 181; 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 324


February 8, 1996, Argued  
April 4, 1996, Decided



DISPOSITION: No. 54: Order affirmed, with costs. No. 55: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondents, Department of Social Services commissioners, challenged orders from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department and in the First Judicial Department (New York) that annulled their determinations denying requests by petitioners, individuals listed on the register of child abuse, to have their names expunged.


OVERVIEW: Respondents, Department of Social Services commissioners, denied the requests of petitioners, individuals listed on the register of child abuse, to have their names expunged from that list after finding that there was some credible evidence supporting the allegations of child abuse. The appellate divisions granted the requests and annulled respondents' determinations, and on appeal, the court affirmed, holding that the Due Process Clause of U.S. Const. amend. XIV required respondents to substantiate reports of child abuse by a fair preponderance of the evidence before they could be disseminated to providers and licensing agencies as a screening device for future employment. The court concluded that the state had impaired the constitutionally protected interest of petitioners in future employment and that respondents' procedures did not protect petitioners from an improper deprivation of that interest. Three factors were considered and weighed: petitioners' potential loss of employment; respondents' interest in protecting children and in controlling expense; and the high risk of positive false findings of abuse when a bare minimum of evidence was used to support allegations.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order that annulled the denials of respondents, Department of Social Services commissioners, to requests for expunction from the register of child abuse because respondents' procedures requiring only a bare minimum of evidence did not protect petitioners, individuals listed on that register, from an improper deprivation of their protected interest in future employment.


HEADNOTES

Social Services - Register of Child Abuse and Maltreatment - Expungement Hearing - Standard of Proof - Due Process The Due Process Clause of the Federal Constitution requires the Department of Social Services to substantiate reports of child abuse entered in the New York State Central Register of Child Abuse and Maltreatment by a fair preponderance of the evidence before they may be disseminated to providers and licensing agencies as a screening device for future employment (see, Social Services Law §§ 422, 424-a). During the investigative process the information may be retained on the strength of some credible evidence supporting it and released to those health care and law enforcement agencies under the terms and conditions listed in section 422 (4) (A). No report shall be released to providers or licensing agencies, however, until a fact finder determines after a hearing that the report is substantiated by a fair preponderance of the evidence or the subject's time to move for expunction has expired.

Constitutional Law - Due Process of Law - Protected Liberty Interest - Entry of Name in Register of Child Abuse and Maltreatment Petitioners, a child psychologist and two foster parents, who are the subjects of reports of abuse entered in the New York State Central Register of Child Abuse and Maltreatment, and whose present employment was affected and whose future employment in the child care area is effectively foreclosed as a result of inclusion in the Central Register, have a protected liberty interest entitling them to the constitutional guarantee of due process (US Const 14th Amend; NY Const, art I, § 6). There is no constitutional prohibition against the State maintaining a list of suspected abusers. Nor is the stigma resulting from petitioners being branded child abusers constitutionally protected. However, a loss of liberty results if some more "tangible" interest is affected or a legal right is altered, and the additional injury may be found in the loss of employment or the foreclosure of future employment opportunities.

Social Services - Register of Child Abuse and Maltreatment - Expungement Hearing - Insufficiency of "Some Credible Evidence" Standard of Proof - Due Process Application of the "some credible evidence" standard to the substantiation of reports of child abuse filed with the New York State Central Register of Child Abuse and Maltreatment does not protect petitioners, a child psychologist and two foster parents, from an improper deprivation of their constitutionally protected liberty interest in present and future employment in the child care field, and the right to pursue adoption. The potential loss of employment as either a child psychologist or a foster parent, or of the right to pursue adoption of a child are substantial interests, as is the State's parens patriae interest in preserving and promoting children's health and welfare and protecting them from abuse. However, the "some credible evidence" standard places the risk of error entirely on the subject of the report for there is no requirement that the fact finder must consider, let alone evaluate, evidence favorable to the subject; this process results in a disturbingly high number of false positive findings of abuse and substantial injury to constitutionally protected private interests.

Social Services - Register of Child Abuse and Maltreatment - Predeprivation Expungement Hearing Subjects of child abuse reports entered in the New York State Central Register of Child Abuse and Maltreatment are entitled to a predeprivation hearing to determine by a fair preponderance of the evidence whether reports of abuse can be substantiated and relevant to future employment or licensure in the absence of any evidence from the State that a predeprivation hearing will involve excessive costs or be unduly burdensome when compared to a postdeprivation hearing as currently provided for by Social Services Law § 424-a (2) (a).

 

61 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Gernatt Asphalt Prods. v. Town of Sardinia


No. 48


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


87 N.Y.2d 668; 664 N.E.2d 1226; 642 N.Y.S.2d 164; 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 313


February 7, 1996, Argued  
March 28, 1996, Decided



DISPOSITION:  Order reversed, with costs, and order and judgment of Supreme Court, Erie County, reinstated.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant township challenged the order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York), which reversed the trial court decision converting the proceeding to an action for a declaratory judgment and declared that amendments to the township's zoning ordinance, which excluded mining as a permitted use in the township, were validly and constitutionally adopted.


OVERVIEW: Respondent miner challenged the legality of amendments to the township's zoning ordinance. The court found the principal issues presented were whether: (1) the township violated statutory provisions relating to referral and public notice of the amendments when it enacted some but not all of the amendments proposed; (2) the New York State Mined Land Reclamation Law (MLRL), N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 23-2701 et seq., superseded the township's authority to amend its zoning ordinance in a manner that eliminated mining as a permitted use throughout the township; and (3) the township's action constituted impermissible exclusionary zoning. The township argued: (1) that the MLRL did not preempt local zoning legislation determining permissible uses within zoning districts; (2) that it did not engage in exclusionary zoning; (3) that the amendments conformed to a comprehensive plan; and (4) that it complied with public notice for hearings. The court reversed the lower court. The township did not violate the notice and referral requirements because the amendments as adopted were a subset of the amendments as proposed, and the recipients of the notices and referrals were clearly so advised.


OUTCOME: The township's authority to amend its zoning ordinance to eliminate mining as a permitted use in the municipality was not preempted by the MLRL. That statute specifically exempted local zoning enactments from its preemptive reach. The township did not engage in unconstitutional exclusionary zoning. The open meetings law was not violated. The court reversed the lower court's order and reinstated the trial court's judgment.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Notice of Proposed Amendments

1. Respondent Town did not violate the public notice provisions of Town Law §§ 264 and 265 regarding proposed amendments to a local zoning ordinance when it enacted the two repealer provisions but not the special use permit amendment that were included in the public notice. The public notice required by sections 264 and 265 is notice of the time and place of the hearing in order that the public shall have an opportunity to be heard. The sufficiency of the notice is tested by whether it fairly apprises the public of the fundamental character of the proposed zoning change. Here, the notice briefly described the proposed new special permit section of the Zoning Ordinance, advised that copies of the entire text of the proposed amendments were available, and invited submission of written as well as public comment at the hearing. It clearly advised the public that three separate though related amendments were contemplated, including the repealer provisions subsequently enacted, and there was nothing inaccurate or misleading about it. That petitioner interpreted the publication as an all-or-nothing proposal, and prepared and directed its comments and objections exclusively to the adoption of the special permit provision and not the repealer provisions, cannot be blamed on any deficiency in the published notice.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Referral of Proposed Amendments to Planning Board

2. Respondent Town did not violate the referral requirements of General Municipal Law § 239-m and Sardinia Town Ordinance § 12.01, which require the local municipality to refer proposed zoning amendments to the County Planning Board and the Town Planning Board, respectively, for a report and recommendation, when it referred three proposed amendments to the Planning Boards--two repealer provisions eliminating mining as a permitted use and a special use permit amendment for mining on existing sites--but adopted only the repealer provisions without rereferring the proposed amendments. The County and Town Planning Boards received notice of the three proposed amendments. Thus, it cannot be said that the Town failed to refer the matter as required by statute. Moreover, the Planning Boards were clearly notified that the effect of the amendments, both as proposed and as enacted, was to limit mining operations in the Town to currently existing mining sites. The only functional difference between the amendments as proposed and as enacted related to the legal status of the use of currently operating mine sites, which was of little relevance to traffic, population density, community appearance and facilities, and other matters within the domain and concern of the Planning Boards (see, General Municipal Law § 239-l). Accordingly, having referred the proposed amendments to the Planning Boards as required by General Municipal Law § 239-m and Sardinia Zoning Ordinance § 12.01, the action by the Town Board in adopting only the repealer provisions did not render those referrals defective.

Mines and Minerals -- Mined Land Reclamation Law -- Preemption of Local Zoning Ordinance

3. The Mined Land Reclamation Law (ECL 23-2701 [MLRL]) does not preempt respondent Town's authority to determine that mining should not be a permitted use of land within the Town, and to enact amendments to the Town's Zoning Ordinance in accordance with that determination. The supersession provision of the MLRL (ECL 23-2703, as amended) provides that "[f]or the purposes stated herein, this title shall supersede all other state and local laws relating to the extractive mining industry; provided, however, that nothing in this title shall be construed to prevent any local government from ... enacting or enforcing local zoning ordinances or laws which determine permissible uses in zoning districts" (ECL 23-2703 [2] [b]). The patent purpose of the 1991 amendment of the statute was to withdraw from municipalities the authority to enact local laws imposing land reclamation standards that were stricter than the State-wide standards under the MLRL. The language of this amended provision accords with the distinction previously recognized in the statute between zoning ordinances, which are not subject to preemption by the MLRL, and local ordinances that regulate mining activities, which are subject to such preemption. There is nothing in the legislative history of the amendment to the statute suggesting that the Legislature intended the MLRL to go further and limit municipalities' broad authority to govern land use.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Exclusionary Zoning

4. While a municipality may not engage in exclusionary zoning, i.e., improperly using its zoning power to keep people out, a municipality is not obliged to permit the exploitation of any and all natural resources within the town as a permitted use if limiting that use is a reasonable exercise of its police powers to prevent damage to the rights of others and to promote the interests of the community as a whole. Accordingly, respondent Town properly amended its Zoning Ordinance to eliminate mining as a permitted use, but continue existing mines as lawful nonconforming uses. On its face, the Town's action in limiting mining activity to nonconforming use status on existing sites was lawful and, even if the test for exclusionary zoning applied to industrial uses, nothing in the record suggests that the Town did, in fact, exclude that use or exercise its police powers to regulate mining for improper purposes. To the extent the amendments prohibit the development of new mines, there is no vested right to have the existing Zoning Ordinance continue unchanged if the Town Board rationally exercised its police power and determined that a change in the zoning was required for the well-being of the community.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Comprehensive Plan

5. Respondent Town's action in amending its Zoning Ordinance to eliminate mining as a permitted use, but continue existing mines as lawful nonconforming uses, is valid inasmuch as it accords with the comprehensive plan manifested in the Town's Zoning Ordinance originally enacted. The essential purpose of the requirement that rezoning be in accordance with a comprehensive plan is to guard against ad hoc zoning legislation affecting the land of a few without proper regard to the needs or design of the community as a whole. A municipality may change its Zoning Ordinance, however, to promote the general welfare and to respond to changed conditions in the community. Here, the original Zoning Ordinance's authorization of mining throughout the Town as a matter of right indicated that the Town in 1969 considered mining to be generally beneficial and consistent with the character and needs of the community. In 1993, the Town Board considered that some 600 acres of land within the Town were presently being mined and would continue to be mined, and that those operating sites could be expanded to their property boundaries as nonconforming uses. The record further reveals that in enacting the amendments which prohibit further expansion of mining, the Town Board was responding to legitimate concerns created by its continued growth in the Town and the potential for major portions of the Town's area to be devoted solely to mining operations. Moreover, the Town removed mining as a permitted use throughout the municipality. Thus, the Board did not act irrationally or engage in ad hoc zoning legislation.

Municipal Corporations -- Open Meetings Law -- Propriety of Executive Session of Town Board

6. Petitioner's contention that respondent Town Board violated the Open Meetings Law (Public Officers Law § 100 et seq.) by drafting new legislation at an executive session of the Town Board held after a public hearing concerning three proposed amendments to the Town's Zoning Ordinance is without merit where, following the executive session, the Board enacted two of the amendments proposed which were not new or different from the proposed amendments, and it tabled the remaining proposed amendment. Petitioner has failed to assert any fact controverting the Town's sworn allegation that the executive session was conducted only for a permissible purpose under Public Officers Law § 105 (1) (d)--to obtain legal opinions and advice from the Town's Counsel about the adoption of the proposed amendments.

Parties -- Standing -- SEQRA Challenge

7. An owner of property that is the subject of rezoning has a legally cognizable interest in being assured that the town satisfied the State Environmental Quality Review Act (SEQRA) (ECL art 8) before taking action to rezone its land and, therefore, has standing to challenge the SEQRA review undertaken as part of the zoning enactment without the need to allege the likelihood of environmental harm. Accordingly, petitioner, the owner of a potential mining site it intends to operate in the future that is affected by amendments to the Town's Zoning Ordinance removing new mining operations from the permitted uses within the Town, has standing to challenge respondents' compliance with SEQRA in connection with the amendments.

Environmental Conservation -- Environmental Quality Review -- Amendment to Zoning Ordinance That Differs from Proposed Amendment

8. Respondent Town Board's review of the environmental effects of an amendment to the Town's Zoning Ordinance that continued existing mining operations throughout the Town as lawful, but nonconforming uses, was in compliance with the State Environmental Quality Review Act (SEQRA) notwithstanding that the Full Environmental Assessment Form, which provided the basis for the Town Board's negative declaration and findings, was completed with respect to a proposed amendment that would have rendered mining on existing sites a specially permitted use rather than a nonconforming use. The currently operating mines that became nonconforming uses under the adopted amendments were required to be operating under valid Department of Environmental Conservation permits. Pursuant to the proposed amendments, the primary requirements of the application to the Town for a special permit were conditions designed merely to provide assurance to the Town that the applicant was in compliance with the requirements of the Mined Land Reclamation Law. Thus, the fact that the special permit provision was not enacted would not have any independent effect upon the environmental considerations raised under SEQRA except that, under the proposed amendments, the Town would be authorized to impose conditions related to ingress and egress to public thoroughfares and the routing of mineral transport vehicles over Town roads. While such authority is lacking under the present Zoning Ordinance, the Town Board, when completing the Environmental Assessment Form with respect to the special permit amendments, concluded that that amendment to the Zoning Ordinance would have no effect on existing transportation systems in the Town. Thus, even in that aspect, the special permit amendment was no different from the Ordinance as it now exists.

Environmental Conservation -- Environmental Quality Review -- Validity of Rapid Review

9. Respondent Town Board's rapid review of the environmental effects of proposed amendments to the Town's Zoning Ordinance eliminating mining as a permitted use, which was completed at a single work session of the full Town Board and resulted in all questions on the Full Environmental Assessment Form being answered in the negative, was not invalid under the State Environmental Quality Review Act on the ground that it was conducted too quickly. That the Board answered all the questions in the negative, and that it was able to do so quickly, does not establish that its review was inadequate as a matter of law. The record reflects that the Town Board identified the relevant areas of environmental concern as related to the proposed action, took the requisite "hard look" at them and in its negative declaration set forth a reasoned elaboration of the basis for its determination. Given the nature of the proposed action here, which would have only beneficial environmental effect, and the focus of the Assessment Form, which is to identify negative environmental effects of the proposed action, the Town Board's rapid review and completion of the Environmental Assessment Form was not arbitrary or capricious.

 

62 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Johnson


No. 10


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


87 N.Y.2d 357; 662 N.E.2d 1066; 639 N.Y.S.2d 776; 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 65


January 3, 1996, Argued and Submitted  
February 13, 1996, Decided



DISPOSITION:  Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York) affirming the judgment of conviction for the crime of reckless murder under circumstances evincing a depraved indifference to human life, which was a violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 125.25.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was indicted on the charges of intentional murder, under N.Y. Penal Law § 125.25(1), and reckless murder under circumstances evincing a depraved indifference to human life, under N.Y. Penal Law § 125.25(2). The jury returned a guilty verdict on the depraved mind charge. Defendant argued that the supreme court erred in instructing the jury to "blend" its consideration of the two inconsistent counts by allowing them to consider lesser included charge of manslaughter for each murder count after it considered the major murder counts. The court ruled that this procedure was acceptable because statutory law setting forth these crimes did not dictate the order in which the jury should consider the charges. Moreover, the court noted that the procedure chosen by the supreme court avoided a possible miscarriage of justice by permitting the jury to consider the offenses in the decreasing level of culpability to avoid the possibility of erroneously convicting on a lesser included offense. The court also ruled that § 125.25(2) was not unconstitutionally vague because the language relating to conduct "with a depraved indifference to human life" was well understood.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate division's order affirming the supreme court's judgment of conviction for reckless murder under circumstances evincing a depraved indifference to human life.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Instructions - Order in Which Jury to Consider Various Offenses Submitted In the prosecution of defendant for intentional murder (Penal Law § 125.25 [1]) and reckless murder under circumstances evincing a depraved indifference to human life (Penal Law § 125.25 [2]), where a lesser included offense was submitted to the jury for each of the murder counts (manslaughter, first degree, for the intentional murder count, and manslaughter, second degree, for the depraved mind murder count), the court correctly instructed the jury to consider the charges in the following order: intentional murder under the first count; if not guilty, then depraved mind murder under the second count; if not guilty, then manslaughter in the first degree under the first count; and, if not guilty, then manslaughter in the second degree under the second count. The jury was properly instructed to consider the inconsistent murder counts in the alternative, but was not required to consider the various greater and lesser offenses of each count as a whole. Nothing in CPL article 300 directs the order in which the jury should consider the various offenses submitted to it. The jury could permissibly consider the offenses in alternating order during their deliberations. Moreover, such a procedure avoids a possible miscarriage of justice. If the jury must consider and render a verdict on every offense submitted under the first count before considering any other count, it could find defendant guilty of manslaughter as a lesser included offense under the first count submitted, before reaching the inconsistent offense of depraved mind murder under the second count and, thus, be forced to convict defendant of a lesser crime than his conduct actually warranted.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Depraved Mind Murder under Penal Law § 125.25 (2) Penal Law § 125.25 (2), which proscribes reckless murder under circumstances evincing a depraved indifference to human life, is not unconstitutionally vague. Conduct with depraved indifference to human life is well understood.

 

63 of 992 DOCUMENTS


A.J. Temple Marble & Tile v. Union Carbide Marble Care


No. 11


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


87 N.Y.2d 574; 663 N.E.2d 890; 640 N.Y.S.2d 849; 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 66


January 3, 1996, Argued  
February 13, 1996, Decided



DISPOSITION:  Order modified, without costs, in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed. Certified question answered in the negative.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, franchisor, its parent companies, and individuals, sought review of the ruling of the New York Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department, which affirmed the trial court's denial of defendants' motion to dismiss plaintiff franchisee's cause of action for fraud in the inducement to purchase a franchise in violation of the New York Franchise Sales Act, N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law §§ 680-69.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff franchisee filed suit against defendants, franchisor, its parent companies, and individuals, alleging fraud in the inducement to purchase franchises in violation of the New York Franchise Sales Act, N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law §§ 680-695. The lower courts ruled against defendant nonfranchisor's motion to dismiss the claim of jointly liability under N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 691(3). The court affirmed the decision, as modified, finding that, pursuant to § 691(3), joint and several liability applied only to those controlling persons, partners, officers, directors, and employees of the franchisor whose actions "materially aided" the statutory violations, and dismissed the claims of defendants for whom plaintiff failed to plead sufficient facts. The court held that the words "materially aids" in § 691(3) referred to all potentially jointly and severally liable defendants, and that the persons enumerated in § 691(3) were not automatically vicariously liable, as plaintiff argued. The court also determined that federal securities law imposed liability only on controlling persons, and so declined to impose such liability to defendant nonfranchisors in the absence of legislative intent.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the denial of defendant nonfranchisors' motion to dismiss, as modified. Joint and several liability applied to those controlling persons, partners, officers, directors, and employees of the franchisor whose actions "materially aided" the statutory violations. The words "materially aids" referred to all potentially jointly and severally liable defendants, so that defendants were not automatically vicariously liable.


HEADNOTES

Franchises - Franchise Sales Act - Joint and Several Liability Under General Business Law § 691 (3), which imposes joint and several liability on certain persons for fraudulent activities in connection with the registration, sale and promotion of franchises, only executive officers, directors, and controlling persons of the franchisor whose actions materially aid the statutory violations are subject to imposition of joint and several liability. A plain reading of section 691 (3), which states that "[a] person who directly or indirectly controls a person liable under this article, a partner in a firm so liable, a principal executive officer or director of a corporation so liable, a person occupying a similar status or performing similar functions, and an employee of a person so liable, who materially aids in the act of [sic] transaction constituting the violation, is also liable jointly and severally with and to the same extent as the controlled person, partnership, corporation or employer", indicates that the qualifying phrase "materially aids" refers to all of the potentially jointly and severally liable defendants--controlling persons, partners, officers, directors, and employees of the franchisor--not only employees of the franchisor.

Franchises - Franchise Sales Act - Joint and Several Liability - Sufficiency of Allegations of Materially Aiding Misrepresentations In an action by plaintiff franchisee against defendant franchisor, the corporations that established the franchisor, and certain officers, directors and employees of the corporate defendants, alleging that defendants had violated the antifraud provision of the New York Franchise Sales Act (General Business Law § 687) by fraudulently representing, inter alia, that the purchase of a franchise included the use of certain trademarks and service marks and by concealing a preexisting plan to limit capital investment and abandon the franchise business if certain financial goals at various check points were not met, the allegations of the complaint that the president of the franchisor's board of directors developed the business plan with its limit on capital investment and financial check points, that he directly participated in the unlawful franchise sales, and that he was responsible for misrepresentations in the solicitation materials, are sufficient to state a claim for the imposition of joint and several liability against the president under General Business Law § 691 (3). If true, these allegations unambiguously indicate that the president materially aided the misrepresentations and omissions complained of.

Franchises - Franchise Sales Act - Joint and Several Liability - Sufficiency of Allegations of Materially Aiding Misrepresentations In an action by plaintiff franchisee against defendant franchisor, the corporations that established the franchisor, and certain officers, directors and employees of the corporate defendants, alleging that defendants had violated the antifraud provision of the New York Franchise Sales Act (General Business Law § 687) by fraudulently representing, inter alia, that the purchase of a franchise included the use of certain trademarks and service marks and by concealing a preexisting plan to limit capital investment and abandon the franchise business if certain financial goals at various check points were not met, the complaint fails to state a claim for imposition of joint and several liability under General Business Law § 691 (3) against the parent corporation of a subsidiary that established the franchisor, the subsidiary itself and a certain individual because it alleges no more than their relationship to the franchisor, that is, their position as a controlling person or director and officer. Nor is the conclusory statement that the Chair of the franchisor participated in and directed the unlawful conduct a sufficient factual allegation that his actions materially aided the franchisor's violations so as to support the imposition of joint and several liability against the Chair. Moreover, the allegation that the Chair of the parent corporation approved of the business plan is similarly deficient, since it is not the plan itself that is alleged to be in violation of the statute, but defendants' concealment of that plan in promoting the franchise.

 

64 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Khan v. Zoning Bd. of Appeals


No. 249


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


87 N.Y.2d 344; 662 N.E.2d 782; 639 N.Y.S.2d 302; 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 7


October 17, 1995, Argued  
January 16, 1996, Decided



DISPOSITION:  Order reversed, with costs, and petition dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants zoning board and others sought review from an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which had reversed the zoning board's denial of a zoning variance sought by appellee landowner pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78.


OVERVIEW: A landowner sought to construct a residence on property that had been subjected to environmental zoning requirements soon after he bought it; when the zoning board denied a variance requested by the landowner pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78, the landowner filed suit seeking to overturn the zoning board's decision. On review the zoning board's decision was eventually overturned and the zoning board appealed. The court held that (1) there was no need for a common law rule to protect landowners possessing parcels in single and separate ownership from circumstances such as these, (2) in order to prevail, the landlord had to show entitlement to the variance as a matter of law, (3) consideration of the area variance sought involved weighing of the competing interests of the individual and the community, (4) there had been no abuse of discretion in the denial of the variance, and (5) the denial of the variance had not constituted a confiscatory taking.


OUTCOME: The lower court's order and judgment was reversed and the landowner's petition was dismissed.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Single and Separate Ownership Exemption -- Applicability to Environmental Zoning Regulations

1. A single and separate ownership exemption contained in a Village zoning ordinance, which provides that nonconforming or substandard property may be exempt from minimum lot or area regulations where its ownership was different from that of any adjoining land on the effective date of the ordinance and is still so owned, relates to area and width, and has no application to an environmental zoning regulation designed to protect property from the effects of floods. Accordingly, respondent owner of an unimproved parcel located in a flood plain area who purchased the parcel prior to enactment by the Village of "Resource Protection" regulations that limited development and restricted new construction on environmentally sensitive areas, including flood plains, is not entitled under the Village ordinance's single and separate ownership exemption to a building permit for construction of a residence on the parcel that is otherwise prohibited by the "Resource Protection" regulations.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Common-Law Single and Separate Ownership Exemption

2. There is no need for a common-law rule to protect landowners who possess parcels in "single and separate ownership" situations. A municipality may in the reasonable exercise of its police powers change its zoning to control land use and development. A municipality that chooses to make such changes may, but need not, exempt existing owners of substandard lots from the changes' more onerous effects. As one of several ways to accomplish this, a municipality may provide through its ordinance for exemptions for property that is held in single and separate ownership. In the usual case, such exemptions are self-executing and no application to the local Zoning Board of Appeals is necessary. In contrast, where the municipality has not created an exemption as a matter of legislative grace, the property owner can ordinarily utilize the local provisions for obtaining a variance. Failing that, an owner who perceives himself or herself aggrieved can bring a judicial proceeding alleging an unconstitutional taking or some governmental arbitrariness in the denial of a variance. Since the owner's constitutional rights are amply protected by the availability of such proceedings, there is no legal basis for overriding the municipality's legislative choice by creating a separate common-law right that would automatically exempt property owners from area restrictions without an individualized assessment of hardship.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Variance -- Area Variance under Village Law § 7-712-b (3) (b)

3. Before granting an area variance pursuant to Village Law § 7-712-b (3) (b), a Zoning Board must engage in a balancing test, considering the factors outlined in the statute and weighing the benefit to the applicant against the detriment to the health, safety and welfare of the neighborhood or community. The applicant need no longer establish practical difficulties in the use of his land.

Constitutional Law -- Taking of Property -- Environmental Zoning Regulations as Effecting Confiscatory Taking

4. Where the Village Zoning Board of Appeals denied respondent parcel owner's application for a variance and building permit as prohibited by the Village's environmental zoning regulations, respondent's argument that such denial amounted to a confiscatory taking is rejected because respondent failed to offer proof of the value of the property before and after the regulation went into effect.

 

65 of 992 DOCUMENTS


DeTroia v. Schweitzer


No. 250


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


87 N.Y.2d 338; 662 N.E.2d 779; 639 N.Y.S.2d 299; 1996 N.Y. LEXIS 8


October 17, 1995, Argued  
January 16, 1996, Decided



DISPOSITION:  Order reversed, with costs, and judgment of Supreme Court, Nassau County, reinstated.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant property owners sought review of a decision by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which upheld the denial of a building permit by respondent, the Zoning Board of Appeals of the Village of Farmingdale (zoning board).


OVERVIEW: Appellant property owners sought a building permit without applying for and being granted a variance from the dimensional requirements of Village of Farmingdale, N.Y., Code § 105-39 (as amended in 1959 and 1988), under the single and separate ownership exemption of Village of Farmingdale, N.Y., Code § 105-154. Respondent zoning board denied the permit because the total area of appellants' lot exceeded § 105-39's minimum, notwithstanding that the lot was rendered substandard by subsequently enacted minimum frontage and width restrictions. The trial court annulled respondent's denial of the permit, but the appellate court reversed. On further appeal, the court reversed, finding respondent's interpretation too restrictive because it arbitrarily undermined the exemption clause's purpose and it would unconstitutionally deprive property owners of their land's value when their lots were rendered substandard as to width or frontage by a zoning ordinance. The court also held respondent's interpretation improper because it violated the rule on construing zoning ordinances, which resolved ambiguities in language in favor of property owners.


OUTCOME: The court reversed respondent zoning board's denial of a building permit to appellant property owners because respondent's interpretation of the relevant zoning ordinance was too restrictive and violated established rules of statutory construction.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations - Zoning - Construction of Single and Separate Ownership Exemption Respondent Zoning Board of Appeals' (ZBA) construction of the single and separate ownership exemption of section 105-154 of the Code of the Village of Farmingdale, which provides for the relief of lots which became substandard as a result of the subsequent adoption of zoning restrictions, as applying only to lots substandard in total square footage area, not as to width and frontage, is unsupportable. Under the canon of construction that a term of greater comprehension includes a lesser term, the reference to a "plot smaller in area" in the exemption, rather than specifying an exemption based solely in terms of square feet, should be interpreted as subsuming all of the dimensional restrictions (frontage, width and square footage) included in the term "Lot area" set forth in the Village Code. Further, the ZBA's confined interpretation undermines the ameliorative purpose of the single and separate ownership exemption--to protect long-term property owners from amendments that render useless their previously conforming property--and gives rise to arbitrary and inconsistent applications of it. Moreover, the ZBA's interpretation of the term "area" violates the rule of construction for zoning ordinances that any ambiguity in the language used must be resolved in favor of the property owner.

 

66 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Federal Home Loan Mortg. Corp. v. New York State Div. of Hous. & Community Renewal


No. 313


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


87 N.Y.2d 325; 662 N.E.2d 773; 639 N.Y.S.2d 293; 1995 N.Y. LEXIS 4758


November 30, 1995, Argued  
December 28, 1995, Decided



DISPOSITION:  Following certification of a question by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit and acceptance of the question by this Court pursuant to section 500.17 of the Rules of Practice of the New York State Court of Appeals, and after hearing argument by counsel for the parties and consideration of the briefs and the record submitted, certified question answered in the affirmative.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, mortgage corporation, brought a declaratory judgment action in federal district court against defendant, New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR), seeking a ruling as to whether, upon dissolution of a cooperative corporation, the units were subject to rent regulation. On appeal from a ruling in favor of the DHCR, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit certified the question to the court.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff argued that the Division of Housing and Community Renewal's regulation limiting the exemption for cooperatives for only so long as that type of ownership was maintained impermissibly restricted what the Rent Stabilization Law (RSL), New York City, N.Y. Admin. Code § 26-501 et seq., designed to be a permanent exemption for cooperatively owned units. The court found that because the RSL provided in clear terms that a building otherwise eligible for rent stabilization was exempt from such regulation if owned as a cooperative, it followed that as soon as a multiple dwelling was no longer owned as a cooperative, the RSL and Rent Stabilization Code (Code) again become applicable to it. The renewed application of the RSL did not violate the Constitution's prohibitions against physical takings because the plaintiff bought the building with knowledge that it was occupied and to be operated as a rental accommodation, and the RSL and Code provisions gave clear notice that upon loss of cooperative status the building would be subject to rent regulation. No new use of the property had been forced upon plaintiff, and no unconstitutional physical taking had been effectuated.


OUTCOME: The certified question was answered in the affirmative.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and Tenant - Rent Regulation - Reversion of Cooperative to Rent-Regulated Status upon Foreclosure A multiple dwelling exempt from the Rent Stabilization Law by virtue of its cooperative ownership reverts to its former rent-regulated status upon foreclosure and the return of the building to operation as rental housing. By its terms, the Rent Stabilization Law (RSL) applies to "Class A multiple dwellings not owned as a cooperative" (Administrative Code of City of NY § 26-504). The Rent Stabilization Code provides that its protections apply to all housing accommodations regulated under the RSL except housing accommodations contained in buildings owned as cooperatives "for so long as they maintain [cooperative] status" (9 NYCRR 2520.11 [l]). A dissolved cooperative is not a cooperative and thus is not entitled to an exemption under the RSL. The RSL and the regulation are uniform in effect--the building is exempt for "so long as" it maintains cooperative status--and the Division of Housing and Community Renewal has not exceeded its rule-making authority in promulgating the regulation.

Constitutional Law - Taking of Property - Physical Taking - Reversion of Cooperative to Rent-Regulated Status upon Foreclosure The reversion of units of a cooperative to regulated rent upon foreclosure does not effect an unconstitutional physical taking on the ground that it forces the owner to accept rent-regulated tenants. Inasmuch as the owner is not being forced to use the property in a new manner, no unconstitutional physical taking has been effectuated.

Constitutional Law - Taking of Property - Regulatory Taking - Reversion of Cooperative to Rent-Regulated Status upon Foreclosure The reversion of units of a cooperative to regulated rent upon foreclosure does not effect an unconstitutional regulatory taking on the ground that no legitimate State interest is substantially served by granting the protections of the Rent Stabilization Law (RSL) to former proprietary lessees of a failed cooperative corporation (see, Rent Stabilization Code [9 NYCRR] § 2520.11 [l]). The RSL and the Code do not purport to give former shareholders of failed cooperative corporations special treatment. Regardless of prior status, upon foreclosure the building is simply treated in the same manner as other New York City housing accommodations that are regulated under the RSL and former proprietary lessees become renters in a market that is plagued by a housing emergency. They are given no further protections than other similarly situated tenants threatened with the loss of their homes, and the same legitimate State interests served by application of the RSL in a housing shortage--preventing eviction and resulting vulnerability to homelessness of the identified beneficiaries--are advanced.

Constitutional Law - Due Process of Law - Reversion of Cooperative to Rent-Regulated Status upon Foreclosure Inasmuch as the Rent Stabilization Law (Administrative Code of City of NY § 26-504) and the Rent Stabilization Code (9 NYCRR 2520.11 [l]) have plain and uniform application to a cooperative upon foreclosure, the law is not unconstitutionally vague, notwithstanding the absence of an express provision detailing the method for setting the initial rent after foreclosure.

Landlord and Tenant - Rent Regulation - Reversion of Cooperative to Rent-Regulated Status upon Foreclosure Not Absurd or Unworkable Inasmuch as the Rent Stabilization Law (Administrative Code of City of NY § 26-504) and the Rent Stabilization Code (9 NYCRR 2520.11 [l]) have plain and uniform application to a cooperative upon foreclosure, a prospective lender, having clear notice of the regulatory impact, is capable of governing its methods of financing cooperatives accordingly to factor in the possibility of reversion to rent regulation upon foreclosure and, therefore, reversion to rent stabilization does not lead to an absurd or unworkable result.

 

67 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Campaign for Fiscal Equity v. Marino


No. 296


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


87 N.Y.2d 235; 661 N.E.2d 1372; 638 N.Y.S.2d 591; 1995 N.Y. LEXIS 4763


November 27, 1995, Argued  
December 28, 1995, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, with costs, and judgment granted declaring in accordance with the opinion herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant lobbyists and others filed a combined N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding and declaratory judgment action seeking declaration that the respondent state legislative officials' action of withholding from the governor bills passed violated the N.Y. Const. art. IV, § 7. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York) affirmed the grant of respondents' motion to dismiss. The lobbyists and others appealed.


OVERVIEW: The issue was whether the state constitution mandated that a bill passed by both houses of the legislature should have been presented to the governor. The relevant bill was never presented to the governor before completion of the legislative session. The appellate division held that the issue was a matter for the legislature but the state constitution did not require presentment to the governor nor require a timetable for presentment. The lobbyists and others argued that the practice of retaining passed bills effectively blocked executive action in approving or vetoing them, thus the presentment clause was violated. The court agreed. The court expressly rejected the state legislative officials' argument that the phrase "before it becomes a law" contained in the presentment clause was conditional, discretionary, or vested in the legislature full and unreviewable power over a bill until the time it chose to present legislature to the governor. The court did find that a retroactive ruing in the case was not warranted. The court concluded that the relevant bill should have been presented to the governor within a reasonable time after it was passed by the legislature.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the appellate division, and judgment was granted, declaring the practice of retaining bills that had passed both houses of the legislature unconstitutional prospectively from the date declared.


HEADNOTES

Legislature - Presentment of Passed Bills to Governor The Presentment Clause of the New York Constitution (art IV, § 7) mandates that a bill passed by both houses of the Legislature be presented to the Governor for enactment into law or vetoing within a reasonable time after its passage. Accordingly, the practice of retaining bills that have passed both houses of the Legislature is unconstitutional prospectively from December 28, 1995.

 

68 of 992 DOCUMENTS


West-Fair Elec. Contrs. v. Aetna Cas. & Sur. Co.


No. 271


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


87 N.Y.2d 148; 661 N.E.2d 967; 638 N.Y.S.2d 394; 1995 N.Y. LEXIS 4448


October 24, 1995, Argued  
December 7, 1995, Decided



DISPOSITION: Following certification of questions by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit and acceptance of the questions by this Court pursuant to section 500.17 of the Rules of Practice of the New York State Court of Appeals, and after hearing argument by counsel for the parties and consideration of the briefs and the record submitted, certified question No. 1 answered in the affirmative, and certified question No. 2 not answered as academic.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The court, upon certification of questions from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, considered the question of whether a pay-when-paid provision in a subcontract, which transferred the risk of an owner's default from a general contractor to a subcontractor, violated state public policy as set forth in the Lien Law. Defendant contractor stopped payments to plaintiff subcontractor when the owner became bankrupt.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff subcontractor filed suit in federal district court against defendants, contractor and insurance company. Defendant contractor refused to pay plaintiff for construction work because the owner of the property had declared bankruptcy and had failed to pay defendant contractor. Defendants moved for summary judgment, arguing that the subcontract contained a pay-when paid provision which limited defendant contractor's liability to the sums it received from the owner. Plaintiff cross-moved for summary judgment, arguing that the pay-when-paid provision resulted in a waiver of its ability to enforce the mechanics' lien. The trial court found for plaintiff, and the federal appellate court certified the question to the court of whether a pay-when-paid provision violated state public policy as set forth in the Lien Law. Upon certification, the court held that a pay-when-paid provision which forced the subcontractor to assume the risk that the owner failed to pay the general contractor was void and unenforceable as contrary to public policy as set forth in N.Y. Lien Law § 34. The pay-when-paid provision extinguished plaintiff's ability to enforce his lien against the owner.


OUTCOME: The court, upon certification of questions from the federal appellate court, held that a pay-when-paid provision which forced a subcontractor to assume the risk that the owner failed to pay the general contractor was void and unenforceable as contrary to public policy. A pay-when paid provision that merely fixed a time for payment did not indefinitely suspend a subcontractor's right to payment upon failure of an owner to pay the contractor.


HEADNOTES

Liens - Mechanic's Lien - Pay-When-Paid Provision as Condition Precedent Void A pay-when-paid provision in a subcontract, which transfers the risk of an owner's default from a general contractor to a subcontractor, violates New York public policy as set forth in the Lien Law. The Lien Law provides that article 2, which governs mechanics' liens, "is to be construed liberally to secure the beneficial interests and purposes thereof" (Lien Law § 23). The Lien Law also provides, "[n]otwithstanding the provisions of any other law, any contract, agreement or understanding whereby the right to file or enforce any lien created under article two is waived, shall be void as against public policy and wholly unenforceable" (Lien Law § 34). As a matter of contract law, the owner and the general contractor are liable to plaintiff for the work plaintiff has been authorized to perform, and performed, under the subcontract agreement. However, a pay-when-paid provision as a condition precedent requires plaintiff to defer payment for its work until the general contractor has been paid by the owner. The waiver of the right to enforce mechanics' liens occurs by operation of the pay-when-paid provision because mechanics' liens may not be enforced until a debt becomes due and payable, and the pay-when-paid provision as a condition precedent prevents the subcontractor from establishing the existence of a present amount, due and unpaid, arising from the subcontractor's performance and owed by the general contractor.

 

69 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re Backal


No. 283


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


87 N.Y.2d 1; 660 N.E.2d 1104; 637 N.Y.S.2d 325; 1995 N.Y. LEXIS 4427


October 26, 1995, Argued  
November 30, 1995, Decided



DISPOSITION: Determined sanction accepted, without costs, and Honorable Lorraine Backal removed from the office Judge of New York City Civil Court, Bronx County.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner judge sought review of a determination of respondent State Commission on Judicial Conduct (New York), which found that judge should be removed from office because of judicial misconduct committed before she resigned from office.


OVERVIEW: Judge was charged with judicial misconduct stemming from her conversations and financial dealings with a third party who was engaged in drug-dealing and money-laundering schemes. The judge also failed to report a cash gift from that party. Instead of answering the complaint against her, judge resigned. The commission thereafter found that judge should have been removed from her position based on her conduct. Judge appealed on the ground that the commission could only remove judges who were sitting at the time penalty was imposed, thereby rendering N.Y. Jud. Law § 47, which allowed the commission to exercise disciplinary jurisdiction over resigned judges, unconstitutional under N.Y. Const. art. VI, § 22. On appeal, the court held that § 47 was constitutional because discipline was warranted to maintain public confidence in the judiciary. The evidence was also sufficient against judge where it was deemed admitted and advising a known lawbreaker on preserving the fruits of his crime and furnishing a hiding place therefor were acts antithetical to judge's duty to uphold the law.


OUTCOME: The court accepted the commission's determined sanction of removal against judge for judicial misconduct.


HEADNOTES

Judges - Removal from Office - Validity of Statute Conferring Jurisdiction to Remove Resigned Judge Judiciary Law § 47, which grants the Commission on Judicial Conduct and the Court of Appeals jurisdiction to remove a resigned Judge for 120 days from the date of resignation, is not rendered unconstitutional on the ground that NY Constitution, article VI, § 22's grant of authority to the Commission on Judicial Conduct to remove "judges" applies only to those sitting at the time the penalty is imposed. The constitutional grant of authority to the Commission to discipline and remove "judges" necessarily and logically covers all acts of misconduct undertaken by a Judge while serving in office. The fact that a particular Judge may no longer hold that office at the time removal is sought or recommended by the Commission, due to the Judge's postmisconduct resignation, does not preclude the Commission or the Court of Appeals from exercising their respective disciplinary powers.

Judges - Removal from Office Petitioner, a Civil Court Judge who, prior to resigning from office, engaged in serious judicial misconduct based upon statements to and financial dealings with a third party who was engaged in drug-dealing and money-laundering schemes, and her failure to report a $ 1,500 cash gift from that party, is removed from office. As a member of this State's judiciary governed by exacting standards of honor and propriety, petitioner was obligated to conduct herself at all times in a manner that reflected her own personal respect for the letter and spirit of the law. Advising a known lawbreaker on preserving the fruits of his crime and furnishing a hiding place for those fruits are acts that are antithetical to that obligation. Similarly, accepting a cash gift for participating in the wrongdoer's concealment efforts and agreeing to mislead law enforcement authorities is behavior that borders on criminal conduct and is certainly inconsistent with a Judge's pledge to uphold the law. A Judge who places herself and her associates above the law in this manner prejudices the administration of justice or at least creates an appearance of impropriety by her actions. That petitioner's misconduct occurred in her home where she may have had an expectation of privacy and that her statements were made to a person she considered to be a close associate do not mitigate the wrongfulness of her conduct. Judges are accountable at all times for their conduct--including their conversation--both on and off the Bench (Code of Judicial Conduct, canon 2 [A]). Further, no family, social or other relationships shall carry influence over the Judge's judicial conduct or judgment (Rules of Chief Administrator of Courts [22 NYCRR] § 100.2 [b]).

 

70 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Demperio


No. 270


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


86 N.Y.2d 549; 658 N.E.2d 718; 634 N.Y.S.2d 672; 1995 N.Y. LEXIS 4419


October 24, 1995, Argued  
 November 29, 1995, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, accusatory instrument reinstated and case remitted to the Justice Court of the Town of Geddes for further proceedings on the accusatory instrument.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state was granted permission by the court to appeal an order of the Onondaga County Court (New York). The county court affirmed an order of the justice court declaring N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1193(2)(b)(3) to be unconstitutionally vague, and dismissing a charge against defendant of aggravated unlicensed operation of a motor vehicle in the second degree.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was stopped while driving and was charged with aggravated unlicensed operation of a motor vehicle in the second degree in violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 511(2)(a). He had prior convictions of driving while intoxicated and driving while ability impaired. As a result, his license had been revoked under the recidivist statute, N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1193(2)(b)(3), for a minimum of one year. Defendant had not applied for reinstatement of his license. The lower courts agreed with defendant that § 1193(2)(b)(3) was unconstitutionally vague in that it failed to inform violators that a new application was required to have a revoked license reinstated. On the state's appeal, the court reversed. It reasoned that the word "revoke" was commonly understood to have an element of permanence. Any possible doubt as to the meaning of the word as used in § 1193(2)(b)(3) was laid to rest by the immediately following paragraph, which gave defendant reason to know that upon revocation, a new license application was required. Furthermore, each person whose license was revoked due to alcohol-related offenses was sent written notice that it was necessary to apply for a new license.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order and reinstated the accusatory instrument. The case was remitted to the justice court for further proceedings on the accusatory instrument.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Vagueness of License Revocation Provision of Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1193 (2) (b) (3) Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1193 (2) (b) (3), which prescribes the minimum period of revocation of a driver's license where the license holder is convicted of driving while under the influence of alcohol or drugs within 10 years of a conviction for driving while under the influence of alcohol or drugs, is not unconstitutionally vague in that it does not inform violators that they must make a new application in order to have a revoked license reinstated. A presumption of constitutionality attaches to enactments of a coequal branch of government. Further, the word "revoke"--meaning to annul, void or cancel--is commonly understood as having a core element of permanence. Moreover, any possible doubt as to the meaning of the word as used in Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1193 (2) (b) (3) would be laid to rest by the immediately following subdivision (2) (c), which provides that "where a license is revoked pursuant to paragraph (b) of this subdivision, no new license shall be issued after the expiration of the minimum period specified in such paragraph, except in the discretion of the commissioner."

 

71 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Commissioner of Social Servs. ex rel. Rebecca G. v. Bernard B.


No. 267, No. 268


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


87 N.Y.2d 61; 661 N.E.2d 131; 637 N.Y.S.2d 659; 1995 N.Y. LEXIS 4421


October 24, 1995, Argued  
November 29, 1995, Decided



DISPOSITION: Nos. 267 and 268: Order modified, without costs, by remitting to Family Court, Franklin County, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant Commissioner of the Franklin County Department of Social Services challenged orders from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which upheld judgments of the family court and ruled that respondent unwed fathers could not be responsible under N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 366 or Fam. Ct. Act § 514 for the birth-related expenses incurred by the department on behalf of the child and mother.


OVERVIEW: The Commissioner sought to hold unwed fathers in two cases liable for the birth-related medical expenses incurred by the department on behalf of the mothers and children. The lower courts had determined that since the fathers were eligible for Medicaid at the time of the births and, thus, unable to pay at that time, they were not liable under either N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 366 for the expenses related to the children or Fam. Ct. Act § 514 for the expenses related to the mothers. On appeal, the court ruled that the lower court correctly determined that, under N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 366, the proper test for determining liability for a child's birth expenses was ability to pay at the time the expenses were incurred. Thus, the fathers were not liable for such expenses. The court found, however, that the lower court erred in determining that the same test applied to liability for the mother's expenses. The court found that no statute required that result. Thus, the court ruled that under Fam. Ct. Act § 545, a father's present ability to pay was the proper test for liability. The court ruled that such rule had a rational basis and, as such, did not violate equal protection.


OUTCOME: The court modified the orders from the appellate division and, as modified, affirmed. The court ruled that unwed fathers could be held responsible for the mother's expenses incurred during delivery based upon the father's ability to pay at the time of the action, not the birth, and remitted to the family court to determine the fathers' present ability to pay for the mother's birth-related expenses.


HEADNOTES
