Social Services - Medical Assistance - Liability of Unwed Father for Birth-Related Medical Expenses - Present Ability to Pay Standard An unwed father's liability for birth-related medical expenses incurred by a County Department of Social Services on behalf of the mother should be determined under a present ability to pay standard. Under the Federal Medicaid program an unwed father is liable, as a "responsible relative", for reimbursement of the child's birth expenses under the standard set forth in Social Services Law § 366--the ability to pay at the time the birth-related expenses occurred, as evidenced by his Medicaid eligibility status. However, the unwed father is not a "responsible relative" of the mother; his liability for the mother's expenses is neither premised on, nor forbidden by, section 366, but rests on the basis of third-party liability under the Federal Medicaid statutory scheme. The statutory basis for the unwed father's third-party liability for the mother's birth-related expenses is found in Family Court Act §§ 514 and 545. Section 545 unambiguously focuses on the unwed father's present ability to pay, as measured by his current resources and his earning capacity. Moreover, while section 514 states that the court may order an unwed father to pay for the mother's confinement costs in its discretion, it is clear that the court's discretion is to be exercised consistently with the present means and ability standard of section 545. Thus, in light of the clear mandate in Family Court Act article 5 to measure the unwed father's third-party liability under a present means and ability standard, and because neither the Federal Medicaid program nor Social Services Law § 366 requires application of a different standard, there is no statutory basis for making the unwed father's liability for the mother's birth-related expenses dependent on his ability to pay at the time the expenses were incurred.

Constitutional Law - Equal Protection of Laws - Liability of Either Parent for Birth-Related Expenses of Child Born out of Wedlock Family Court Act § 514, while phrased to impose potential liability for a mother's birth-related expenses only on fathers, is properly understood as authorizing the court to impose liability without regard to gender when read in connection with subsequently enacted Family Court Act § 545 which imposes liability for these costs on either parent.

Constitutional Law - Equal Protection of Laws - Liability of Unwed Fathers for Birth-Related Expenses - Rational Basis Scrutiny Family Court Act §§ 514 and 545 do not discriminate on the basis of gender in the context of an unwed father's liability for the birth-related expenses of the mother on the ground that as a matter of law the mother is protected against recoupment under the applicable Medicaid provisions for her own birth expenses (see, Social Services Law § 369 [2] [b]; 42 USC § 1396a [a] [18]; § 1396p [b]), while the father, even if in the same financial position as the mother at the time of the birth, may be held liable for these same expenses under the Family Court Act; therefore, the difference in treatment of fathers and mothers is subject only to rational basis scrutiny. The mother is eligible for Medicaid assistance in connection with her pregnancy and birth-related costs as a direct recipient based on her medical condition of pregnancy, and under the applicable Medicaid provisions, a recipient is protected against liability for Medicaid benefits that were lawfully paid. Thus, the mother's condition of pregnancy provides the basis for her eligibility for benefits and at the same time, provides the basis for her immunity from recoupment. The unwed father, because he is not pregnant and does not give birth, is not a direct recipient of any medical assistance in connection with his child's birth and, thus, he is not protected by the statutory provisions that prohibit recoupment from direct recipients. Accordingly, rather than gender, it is the physical condition of pregnancy that distinguishes the unwed mother and father's statutory liability for the mother's birth-related expenses. Absent a showing that distinctions involving pregnancy are mere pretexts designed to effect an invidious discrimination against members of one sex or the other, a classification based on pregnancy does not constitute a gender-based classification, and there is no evidence here that the pregnancy-based distinction in the statutes was pretextual.

Constitutional Law - Equal Protection of Laws - Liability of Unwed Fathers for Birth-Related Expenses - Rational Basis for Distinction between Unwed Fathers and Unwed Mothers For purposes of recoupment of an unwed mother's birth-related expenses incurred by a County Department of Social Services, there is a rational basis for the distinction between unwed fathers, against whom third-party liability is imposed for such expenses pursuant to Family Court Act §§ 514 and 545, and unwed mothers, who are immune from recoupment. The difference in treatment of fathers and mothers rests on the physical status of pregnancy. The imposition of third-party liability on unwed fathers in this context furthers the congressional policies underlying the Medicaid program. Additionally, the Legislature could rationally determine that imposing the threat of future liability on a medically indigent pregnant woman might discourage her from obtaining medical care necessary for the health and survival of both herself and the child, a consideration not applicable to the liability of the unwed father. Because they are, thus, rationally related to a physical distinction--pregnancy--the imposition of different standards of liability with respect to medically indigent expectant mothers and fathers is not unconstitutional.

Constitutional Law - Equal Protection of Laws - Liability of Unwed Fathers for Birth-Related Expenses - Rational Basis for Distinction between Unwed Fathers and Married Fathers Applying the present ability to pay standard of Family Court Act §§ 514 and 545 to determine the liability of an unwed father for the mother's birth-related expenses does not result in an unconstitutional differentiation among fathers on the basis of marital status because a married father who is indigent at the time of his child's birth will permanently escape liability for his spouse's confinement and birth-related costs as a "responsible relative" under Social Services Law § 366, which looks solely to his ability to pay at the time the expenses were incurred, while an unwed father who was indigent at the time of the birth would not necessarily escape liability as a responsible third party under Family Court Act §§ 514 and 545, since those provisions look to his ability to pay at the time of the support hearing. The distinction between married and unmarried fathers with respect to the mother's birth-related expenses is rationally based. Pursuant to his statutorily imposed spousal support obligations, a married father has an ongoing duty of support to his wife, including liability for her confinement costs and any other necessary medical expenses (Family Ct Act §§ 412, 416). An unmarried father is liable only for the mother's pregnancy and birth-related expenses since it is the child that provides the only legal connection between the two unwed parents. The far more limited liability of the unwed father for the mother's needs justifies the more favorable treatment of the married father regarding the mother's birth expenses. Moreover, a married father, indigent at the time of birth, is exempt from any future liability for his wife's or child's birth-related expenses to avoid the destructive effect of future liability on the relationships within the family unit.

 

72 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. First Meridian Planning Corp.


No. 275


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


86 N.Y.2d 608; 658 N.E.2d 1017; 635 N.Y.S.2d 144; 1995 N.Y. LEXIS 3578


September 12, 1995, Argued  
 November 2, 1995, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants challenged the order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Third Judicial Department (New York), which reinstated an indictment charging defendants with fraud in the sale of securities under N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 352-c(6) and N.Y. Penal Law § 190.65.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were charged with fraud in the sale of securities. The trial court dismissed the indictment as duplicitous and held that the evidence was insufficient to show criminal responsibility. It also held that the sale of numismatic coins did not constitute the sale of securities. The appellate court reinstated the indictment and ruled that there was prima facie evidence that the sale of numismatic coin portfolios constituted the sale of securities. On appeal, the court held that the indictment was not invalid for facial duplicity. Since N.Y. Penal Law § 190.65(1)(a) provided that one act or multiple acts could constitute a scheme to defraud, defendants could be convicted if there was found a single scheme in which each one participated. The court also held that there was sufficient evidence to infer a single scheme and the sale of the coins constituted the sale of securities.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order reinstating the indictment since defendants could be convicted under the indictment if a single scheme was found to exist and there were sufficient evidence to show that the sale of numismatic coins constituted the sale of securities under the statute.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Scheme to Defraud - Sales of Financial Plans to Investors - Duplicitous Count of Indictment The count of an indictment charging defendants with scheme to defraud in the first degree (Penal Law § 190.65) arising out of the investment promotional activities of defendant corporation, its officers and sales personnel is not invalid for facial duplicity in that it charges in a single count the commission of more than one offense. Where a crime by its nature as defined in the Penal Law may be committed either by one act or by multiple acts and can be characterized as a continuing offense over time, the indictment may charge the continuing offense in a single count. Scheme to defraud in the first degree can by its very nature be committed by multiple acts and permits, if not requires, characterization as a continuing offense committed over time. Thus, a person is guilty of a scheme to defraud when "he [or she] ... engages in a scheme constituting a systematic ongoing course of conduct with intent to defraud ten or more persons or to obtain property from ten or more persons by false or fraudulent pretenses, representations or promises, and so obtains property from one or more of such persons" (Penal Law § 190.65 [1] [a]). However, to avoid the danger that defendants may be convicted on that count with leas than a unanimous verdict, the trial jury in this case should be instructed that they must all agree upon the existence of the same single scheme to defraud and must also be unanimous as to each defendant found guilty that he or she participated in that same over-all scheme alleged in the indictment.

Crimes - Indictment - Sufficiency of Evidence - Scheme to Defraud - Sales of Financial Plans to Investors Despite the presence of some diversity of criminal actors, modalities and victims, the evidence may support the existence of a single, unitary over-all scheme to defraud. Accordingly, the evidence before the Grand Jury was prima facie sufficient to permit the Grand Jury reasonably to infer the existence of a unitary scheme to defraud arising out of the investment promotional activities of defendant corporation, its officers and sales personnel in connection with investments in numismatic coin portfolios, art portfolios and condominiums. The proof disclosed, and the indictment alleged, common techniques, misrepresentations and omissions of material facts employed in all transactions. Further, defendant corporation played a pivotal role in all of the transactions, as a constant nucleus through whom the contacts with all investors were initiated and maintained. Thus, the claim of the defendants involved with numismatic coins of unawareness of and the absence of any participation in defendant corporation's promotions of investments in artworks and condominiums is unavailing to negate the existence of a single over-all scheme to defraud.

Fraud - Martin Act - Fraud in Sale of Securities - Numismatic Coins as "Securities" In a prosecution arising out of the investment promotional activities of certain defendants with respect to numismatic coin portfolios, the Grand Jury could find that the sale of numismatic coin portfolios constituted the sale of securities so as to support the validity of the counts of the indictment charging those defendants under the Martin Act (General Business Law art 23-A) with fraud in the sale of securities (General Business Law § 352-c [6]). In criminal prosecutions under the Martin Act, investment contracts are "other securities" within the Act's definition of "securities". (General Business Law § 352-c [1].) An investment contract means a contract, transaction, or scheme whereby a person invests his money in a common enterprise and is led to expect profits solely from the efforts of the promoter or a third party. It is immaterial whether the shares in the enterprise are evidenced by formal certificates or by nominal interests in the physical assets employed in the enterprise. Here, there was an investment of money, as defendant corporation's clients were induced to purchase numismatic coin portfolios for the purpose and in the expectation of making a profit from ultimate resale. That investment was in a common enterprise; it is not required that the investor acquires a share in a common fund. Moreover, there was evidence before the Grand Jury that the profits were expected to be derived solely from the efforts of the promoter or a third party. Defendants' representations assured investors that a critically important guarantee of the profitability of the numismatic coin portfolio investments was the expertise of the dealers in selecting the coins to be purchased, monitoring their value in a fluctuating market, aiding in making resale decisions and providing assistance with resales.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Vagueness of Martin Act - Numismatic Coins as "Securities" In the prosecution of defendants under the Martin Act (General Business Law art 23-A) arising out of investment promotional activities involving, inter alia, numismatic coin portfolios, construction of General Business Law § 352-c (6), which provides for the imposition of criminal liability upon a person who intentionally engages in fraud while engaged in inducing or promoting the sale of "securities", to include the sale of numismatic coins as a sale of "other securities" within the statute's definition of "securities" does not render the statute unconstitutionally vague. The "void for vagueness" doctrine requires that a penal statute provide the ordinary citizen with adequate notice of the exact conduct prohibited, while at the same time affording law enforcement officials some objective standard to avoid the possibility that the law will be arbitrarily enforced. Of these dual purposes of the doctrine, the provision of minimal guidelines to discourage arbitrary or discriminatory enforcement is the more important objective. The doctrine, however, recognizes that some forms of conduct which a State may validly make subject to penal sanctions cannot, and need not, be defined with precision. The vagueness doctrine does not adjudge the language of a criminal statute in the abstract, but rather in the animating context of well-defined usage and court construction which determines its meaning. Here, prior judicial construction of "other securities" was amply sufficient to meet the requirements of the void for vagueness doctrine in enforcing the Martin Act by providing adequate notice to the public, and objective standards for law enforcement officials.

 

73 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re Jacob


No. 195, No. 196


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


86 N.Y.2d 651; 660 N.E.2d 397; 636 N.Y.S.2d 716; 1995 N.Y. LEXIS 3579


June 5, 1995, Argued  
 November 2, 1995, Decided



DISPOSITION: No. 195: Order reversed, without costs, petition reinstated, and matter remitted to Family Court, Oneida County, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein. No. 196: Order reversed, without costs, petition reinstated and matter remitted to Family Court, Putnam County, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In two consolidated cases, appellant proposed adoptive parents sought review of the decisions of the Appellate Division of the New York Supreme Courts in the Second and Fourth Judicial Department, which affirmed the family courts' dismissal of appellants' petitions for adoption.


OVERVIEW: Appellant proposed adoptive parents petitioned the family courts to adopt. One appellant petitioned to adopt his girlfriend's son with permission of the biological father, while other appellant petitioned to adopt the child of her lesbian partner. The appellate courts affirmed the denial of the petitions by the family courts. The court reversed both decisions, finding that appellants had standing under N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law §110, which allowed unmarried adult persons to adopt, and citing laws and regulations that supported adoption rights of separated married adults and homosexuals. Language in § 110 referring to married couples "together" was intended to ensure that married couples mutually agreed to adopt. The lesbian appellant could adopt her partner's child because N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law §117 would not have severed the natural mother's ties, and was not applicable for purposes of standing. Section 117 was intended to protect the property interests of the adopted child. The court noted that other statutes specifically dealt with termination of rights, and cited examples where severance was not required, as with stepparent adoptions.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the denial of appellant proposed adoptive parents petitions because unmarried adult persons were statutorily allowed to adopt, and the lesbian appellant could adopt her partner's child because the law cited by the lower courts would not have severed the relationship of the biological mother from the child. Severance was not a necessary outcome of an intrafamily adoption, as exemplified by stepparent adoptions.


HEADNOTES

Adoption -- Who May Adopt -- Unmarried Partner of Child's Biological Mother

1. An unmarried partner of a child's biological mother, whether heterosexual or homosexual, who is raising the child together with the biological parent, has standing to adopt under Domestic Relations Law § 110, which provides that an "adult unmarried person or an adult husband and his adult wife together may adopt another person." The statute uses the word "together" only to describe married persons and thus does not preclude an unmarried person in a relationship with another unmarried person from adopting. Further, the pattern of amendments to the statute since the end of World War II evidences a successive expansion of the categories of persons entitled to adopt regardless of their marital status or sexual orientation. Thus, a reading of section 110 granting unmarried second parents standing to adopt is consistent with the words of the statute as well as the spirit behind the modern-day amendments to the statute: encouraging the adoption of as many children as possible regardless of the sexual orientation or marital status of the individuals seeking to adopt them.

Adoption -- Effect of Adoption -- No Termination of Biological Mother's Parental Rights upon Adoption by Unmarried Partner

2. The unmarried partner of a child's biological mother, whether heterosexual or homosexual, who is raising the child together with the biological parent, has standing to adopt the child pursuant to Domestic Relations Law § 110, and such adoption is not precluded by Domestic Relations Law § 117, which literally applied would require the termination of the biological mother's rights upon such adoption. The Legislature's chief concern in section 117 was the resolution of property disputes upon the death of an adoptive parent or child, not the standing of an individual to adopt. Further, section 117 does not invariably require termination in the situation where the biological parent, having consented to the adoption, has agreed to retain parental rights and to raise the child together with the second parent, viz., stepparent adoptions, adoptions by minor fathers and open adoptions. Given that section 117 is open to two differing interpretations as to whether it automatically terminates parental rights in all cases, a construction of the section that would deny children the opportunity of having their two de facto parents become their legal parents, based solely on their biological mother's sexual orientation or marital status, would not only be unjust under the circumstances, but also might raise constitutional concerns in light of the adoption statute's historically consistent purpose--the best interests of the child.

Statutes -- Construction -- Adoption Statute

3. Inasmuch as adoption in New York State is solely the creature of statute, legislative purpose as well as the legislative language must be construed strictly and applied rigorously. Thus, the adoption statute must be applied in harmony with the humanitarian principle that adoption is a means of securing the best possible home for a child.

 

74 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Shack


No. 231


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


86 N.Y.2d 529; 658 N.E.2d 706; 634 N.Y.S.2d 660; 1995 N.Y. LEXIS 3580


September 20, 1995, Argued  
 November 2, 1995, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of the judgment of the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) which affirmed his conviction for a violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 240.30(2).


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of violating N.Y. Penal Law § 240.30(2) after a jury found that he had made repeated threatening and harassing phone calls to a complainant with no purpose of legitimate communication. The judgment was affirmed upon appeal despite defendant's arguments to the contrary for the following reasons: First, because § 240.30(2) proscribed only conduct and expressly removed from its application legitimate communication, defendant could not invoke U.S. Const. amend. I or N.Y. Const. art. I, § 8 to support a challenge to the facial validity of the statute. In addition, the court found that the statute was not overbroad because it did not infringe protected rights of defendant or chill the exercise of free speech rights by others. Second, the statute was not unconstitutionally vague because the court found it to have adequately described elements of the proscribed conduct and to have provided sufficient notice to potential offenders. Finally, the accusatory instrument was not defective for lack of specificity just because it alleged that the offense occurred over a significant period of time, because the statute was amenable to characterization as a continuing crime.


OUTCOME: The judgment was affirmed because the statute under which defendant was convicted did not violate the U.S. Const. amend. I or New York's constitution, because the statute was not overbroad or unconstitutionally vague, and because the accusatory instrument was not defective for lack of specificity.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Facial Validity of Aggravated Harassment Statute

1. Penal Law § 240.30 (2), which provides that a person is guilty of aggravated harassment in the second degree when, with intent to harass, annoy, threaten or alarm another person, he makes a telephone call, whether or not a conversation ensues, with no purpose of legitimate communication", proscribes only conduct and expressly removes from its application "legitimate communication", and, therefore, a defendant charged with violating section 240.30 (2) may not invoke the First Amendment or NY Constitution, article I, § 8 to support a challenge to the facial validity of the statute. Moreover, even if section 240.30 (2) is construed to proscribe speech, a declaration of facial overbreadth does not automatically follow. To the extent Penal Law § 240.30 (2) limits a caller's right to free speech, it permissibly subordinates that right to the recipient's right to be free of unwanted telephone calls. The statute is narrowly drafted and furthers the State's compelling interest in protecting its citizens from persons who employ the telephone, not to communicate, but for other unjustifiable motives.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Validity of Aggravated Harassment Statute as Applied

2. Penal Law § 240.30 (2), which provides that a person is guilty of aggravated harassment in the second degree when, with intent to harass, annoy, threaten or alarm another person, he makes a telephone call, whether or not a conversation ensues, with no purpose of legitimate communication, is not unconstitutional as applied to defendant, who was convicted of aggravated harassment in the second degree, since his liability arose from his harassing conduct, not from any expression entitled to constitutional protection.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Overbreadth of Aggravated Harassment Statute

3. Penal Law § 240.30 (2), which provides that a person is guilty of aggravated harassment in the second degree when, with intent to harass, annoy, threaten or alarm another person, he makes a telephone call, whether or not a conversation ensues, with no purpose of legitimate communication, is not unconstitutional on the ground that it is so broadly worded that it may reach a substantial amount of constitutionally protected expression. Even if the statute may, on rare occasion, reach constitutionally protected expression, it cannot be concluded that the statute's overbreadth, if any, is substantial.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Vagueness of Aggravated Harassment Statute

4. Penal Law § 240.30 (2), which provides that a person is guilty of aggravated harassment in the second degree when, with intent to harass, annoy, threaten or alarm another person, he makes a telephone call, whether or not a conversation ensues, with no purpose of "legitimate" communication, is not unconstitutionally vague with respect to the conduct of defendant, who was convicted of aggravated harassment in the second degree, for failing to give adequate notice of the nature of proscribed conduct, and permitting arbitrary and discriminatory enforcement, because the subjective term "legitimate" is incapable of precise definition. The phrase "no legitimate purpose of communication", notwithstanding its subjective quality, would be understood to mean the absence of expression of ideas or thoughts other than threats and/or intimidating or coercive utterances. Moreover, by including a specific intent element in the statute, the Legislature has removed the possibility that a defendant could be unaware of his criminal conduct. This specific intent element also removes the possibility that criminal liability would be imposed based on the unascertainable sensitivities of the victim. Further, there is no possibility of arbitrary enforcement. The combination of the described standards and the clear and understandable elements of the criminal conduct adequately defines the criminal conduct for the police officers, Judges and juries who will enforce the statute. Because of the very nature of the conduct proscribed by Penal Law § 240.30 (2), enforcement of the statute is unlikely to occur in the absence of a victim's complaint to authorities and, given the opportunity to consider the veracity of the complainant and to engage in preliminary investigation, this statute vests no more discretion in the police than any other statute which proscribes malevolence or misconduct toward another person.

Crimes -- Information -- Continuing Crime -- Aggravated Harassment

5. Aggravated harassment in the second degree (Penal Law § 240.30 [2]) may be characterized as a continuing crime and, therefore, an information charging defendant with one count of aggravated harassment in the second degree, which alleges that defendant "on or about and between December 12, 1990 & May 20, 1991 ... with the intent to harass, annoy, threaten and alarm [the victim], did make a series of telephone calls to [her] with no purpose of legitimate communication", is not defective for lack of specificity because it did not identify the particular dates on which defendant was alleged to have made harassing telephone calls. When a crime may be committed by multiple acts over time and is amenable to characterization as a "continuing crime", the count in the charging instrument may properly allege that the single offense was committed over a significant period of time. A continuing crime is one that by its nature may be committed either by one act or by multiple acts and readily permits characterization as a continuing offense over a period of time. By its terms, Penal Law § 240.30 (2) imposes criminal liability for making a single telephone call, if placed with the requisite intent and lack of legitimate purpose. While a defendant may annoy, harass, or, more likely, threaten or alarm another person with a single telephone call, the statute does not necessarily contemplate a single act. Further, the Legislature intended to proscribe repeated telephone calls to a residence that might drive a person to distraction. Thus, despite the statutory reference to a single phone call, the provision and its history readily permit characterization as a continuing offense over time.

Crimes -- Appeal -- Preservation of Issue for Review

6. Defendant's contention that he was deprived of a fair trial by the introduction of evidence of his mental illness through the testimony of the victim because her testimony violated the psychologist/patient privilege which attended their relationship (see, CPLR 4507) is not preserved for review by the Court of Appeals on defendant's appeal from the Appellate Term order affirming his conviction. Although defense counsel successfully obtained a pretrial ruling that the victim could not testify about defendant's condition or medication unless defendant opened the door to such testimony, defense counsel affirmatively injected the issue of defendant's mental illness into the trial during her opening statement, and thereafter raised no relevant objection to the victim's testimony.

 

75 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Rochester Tel. Corp. v. PSC


No. 233


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


87 N.Y.2d 17; 660 N.E.2d 1112; 637 N.Y.S.2d 333; 1995 N.Y. LEXIS 3565; 166 P.U.R.4th 205


September 21, 1995, Argued  
October 31, 1995, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner telephone corporation challenged a judgment from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which confirmed two determinations of respondent utility commission that imputed revenues to the telephone corporation creating a rebuttable presumption that a two percent royalty would be imputed for rate-making purposes, denied all petitions for rehearing, and dismissed the petition.


OVERVIEW: The utility commission reduced the permissible utility rate the telephone corporation could charge its ratepayers by imputing revenue to it in the form of a two percent royalty arising out of improper cost-shifting and uncompensated transfers of it's intangible assets between it and its subsidiaries and affiliates. The telephone corporation sought to exploit such intangible assets as its name and reputation by closely associating itself with its affiliates in various advertising campaigns. On review, the court affirmed, concluding that the royalty and the rebuttable presumption of a royalty in the future were rational means for achieving just and reasonable utility rates. The court found that: 1) a justiciable controversy existed; 2) the telephone corporation benefitted from the use of a non-rate-based asset paid for by the ratepayers and, as such, the utility commission could allocate part of the cost borne by the ratepayers to the shareholders; 3) the issue of whether the royalty presumption was an unconstitutional taking under the Commerce Clause was not justiciable; and 4) the actions by the utility commission did not impose an impermissible burden on interstate commerce.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment upholding the determinations by the utility commission.


HEADNOTES

Courts - Justiciable Questions An appeal to the Court of Appeals from a judgment of the Appellate Division in a CPLR article 78 proceeding confirming determinations of respondent Public Service Commission (PSC) which reduced the permissible rate petitioner utility could charge its ratepayers by imputing revenue to the utility in the form of a 2% royalty arising out of improper cost-shifting and uncompensated transfers of intangible assets between the utility and its subsidiaries and affiliates, and created a rebuttable presumption of a 2% royalty in the future for other regulated utilities, should not be dismissed as nonjusticiable with respect to petitioner because a Joint Stipulation between the parties fixed the rates petitioner could charge its customers through the year 2001, regardless of the outcome of the appeal, or, with respect to intervenor utilities, because no utility except for petitioner had been ordered to pay a royalty. Even if some aspects of a controversy have become nonjusticiable through a change in conditions, review is still appropriate if substantial questions remain on which an effective disposition can be made. Here, although the Joint Stipulation resolved the propriety of PSC's application of the 2% royalty to petitioner's case through December 31, 2001, a justiciable controversy exists as to PSC's general authority to order payment of a 2% royalty based upon a utility's relationship with its subsidiaries and affiliates. An article 78 proceeding is the proper avenue to obtain review of a PSC ruling allegedly beyond its authority. Further, given PSC's refusal to entertain further general challenges in individual rate cases, appellants have no other forum in which to challenge the authority of the PSC to impute a 2% royalty and impose the rebuttable presumption.

Public Utilities - Rate Making - Validity of Public Service Commission's Imputation of 2% Royalty Payment with Respect to Utility's Investment in Unregulated Operations - Uncompensated Use of Utility's Name and Reputation The regulated value assurance mechanism (RVAM) component of a 2% royalty imposed by respondent Public Service Commission (PSC) on petitioner utility, which was designed to compensate ratepayers for the imprudent, uncompensated transfers of petitioner's intangible assets, such as its name and reputation, between petitioner and its subsidiaries and affiliates has a rational basis and is supported by the record. The record contains support for PSC's conclusion that petitioner's name and reputation have value, which petitioner sought to exploit by closely associating itself with its affiliates in various advertising campaigns, and petitioner's unregulated subsidiaries and affiliates did not pay for the use of petitioner's logo and name. Where a utility derives benefit from the use of a non-rate-based asset paid for by the ratepayers, the PSC may allocate part of the cost borne by the ratepayers to the shareholders. Insofar as the ratepayers have borne the costs for creating value in petitioner's name and reputation, the ratepayers are entitled to a prudent use of those assets. The RVAM properly compensates ratepayers for petitioner's imprudence in allowing the free use of its intangible assets rather than impermissibly granting ratepayers a direct interest in those assets.

Public Utilities - Rate Making - Finding of Imprudence by Utility A fair reading of the Public Service Commission (PSC) opinion which imposed a 2% royalty on petitioner utility arising out of improper cost-shifting and uncompensated transfers of petitioner's intangible assets between petitioner and its subsidiaries and affiliates indicates that the PSC concluded that petitioner acted imprudently by permitting its subsidiaries and affiliates to use valuable intangible assets, such as petitioner's name and logo, free of charge, and that the PSC considered the prudence standard in making its determinations. Though it would have been preferable for the PSC to explicitly state that petitioner acted imprudently, there is no reason to require the incantation of certain "magic" words when PSC's opinion clearly contains, through the use of other words, a finding of imprudence. Accordingly, because the record supports that finding, the Appellate Division's affirmance of PSC's imprudence determination will not be disturbed by the Court of Appeals.

Public Utilities - Rate Making - Validity of Public Service Commission's Imputation of 2% Royalty Payment with Respect to Utility's Investment in Unregulated Operations - Application of Royalty as Rebuttable Presumption to Other Utilities Respondent Public Service Commission's (PSC) conclusion that petitioner utility's imprudence in permitting its subsidiaries and affiliates to use valuable intangible assets free of charge could be imputed to all utilities through imposition of a rebuttable presumption of a 2% royalty in the future is rational. The circumstances which led to the imprudence finding as to petitioner are not unique to that utility. Further, PSC considered the submissions of numerous regulated utilities who, at PSC's invitation, participated in the underlying hearings. It was reasonable to conclude that a utility that permits its subsidiaries and affiliates to exploit valuable intangible assets for free, acts imprudently. Moreover, the imputation of the royalty does not result in an automatic obligation to pay the royalty. Utilities will have the opportunity to challenge the application of the presumption to their individual cases.

Public Utilities - Rate Making - Validity of Public Service Commission's Imputation of 2% Royalty Payment with Respect to Utility's Investment in Unregulated Operations - Improper Shifting of Costs The positive benefits component of a 2% royalty imposed by respondent Public Service Commission (PSC) on petitioner utility, which was designed to address the improper shifting of costs from the unregulated subsidiaries and affiliates to the regulated utility, is supported by the record. The record contains evidence of actual costs imposed on ratepayers as a result of petitioner's diversification and evidence of petitioner's abundant incentive to shift costs from its unregulated subsidiaries and affiliates to its monopoly operations. Given the complexity of the relationships between various utilities and their subsidiaries and affiliates, as well as the volume of transactions that must be scrutinized, PSC's conclusions that certain costs could not be adequately quantified and that current oversight systems could not capture all cases of improper cost shifting, were rational and supported by the record.

Public Utilities - Rate Making - Validity of Public Service Commission's Imputation of 2% Royalty Payment with Respect to Utility's Investment in Unregulated Operations - Rationality of Quantification of Royalty at 2% Respondent Public Service Commission's (PSC) exercise of discretion in setting at 2% the level of a royalty designed to compensate ratepayers for the uncompensated use of petitioner utility's intangible assets by its subsidiaries and affiliates and the costs of diversification, without imposing a penalty on petitioner, did not lack a rational basis. Rate making is a highly technical field within the special expertise of the PSC. In quantifying the royalty, PSC applied the expertise it had acquired in the context of previous settlements, where the amount of rate adjustments could not be precisely or objectively determined. The record also contained evidence that the PSC had previously imputed a percentage in quantifying objectively unascertainable items such as reasonably anticipated productivity improvements and allowances for certain types of advertising. PSC's exercise of judgment in this highly technical field was reasonable, especially given the ability of individual utilities to rebut the 2% figure. The PSC envisioned situations in which individual utilities would be required to pay a different or no royalty percentage, and this built-in flexibility renders the rebuttable presumption rational because any royalty ultimately imposed will be tailored to the individual circumstances of particular utilities.

Courts - Justiciable Questions - Unconstitutional Taking Claim Appellant utilities' argument that the rebuttable presumption created by respondent Public Service Commission of a 2% royalty in the future for rate-making purposes whenever a utility invests in competitive enterprises constitutes an unconstitutional taking under the Federal and New York State Constitutions is not justiciable because the impact of the rebuttable presumption cannot be evaluated separate and apart from the actual application of the royalty to a particular utility.

Courts - Justiciable Questions - Commerce Clause Violation The issue whether the rebuttable presumption created by respondent Public Service Commission of a 2% royalty in the future for rate-making purposes whenever a utility invests in competitive enterprises violates the Commerce Clause may properly be decided by the Court of Appeals because the relevant standard for determining the validity of State statutes affecting interstate commerce permits evaluation of the widespread, general effects of a State regulation. Evaluation of the royalty need not be limited to the effects generated by specific applications of the rebuttable presumption, but rather the royalty's general effects on interstate commerce may be considered.

Public Utilities - Rate Making - Constitutionality of Public Service Commission's Imputation of 2% Royalty with Respect to Utility's Investment in Unregulated Operations - Commerce Clause The rebuttable presumption created by respondent Public Service Commission (PSC) of a 2% royalty in the future for rate-making purposes whenever a utility invests in competitive enterprises does not violate the Commerce Clause. The royalty is to be applied evenhandedly, since the applicable PSC opinion contains no exemptions for investment in New York State subsidiaries or affiliates. Moreover, since the royalty is imposed on the utilities, not on out-of-State subsidiaries and affiliates, the financial impact on interstate commerce appears negligible. Since the State has a legitimate interest in setting just and reasonable utility rates, and the royalty is rationally related to that end, PSC's actions do not impose an impermissible burden on interstate commerce.

 

76 of 992 DOCUMENTS


New York State Dormitory Auth. v. Board of Trustees


No. 141


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


86 N.Y.2d 72; 653 N.E.2d 1159; 629 N.Y.S.2d 989; 1995 N.Y. LEXIS 1800


April 27, 1995, Argued  
 June 29, 1995, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order modified, without costs, in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant New York State Dormitory Authority challenged an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed a supreme court's order in consolidated proceedings pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 and N.Y. Real Prop.Tax art. 7, dismissing petitions challenging special benefit assessments levied by appellee water district.


OVERVIEW: The water district decided to construct a new drinking water treatment facility and imposed a special benefit assessment. The supreme court dismissed petitions challenging the special assessment. The appellate division held that the Dormitory Authority was not exempt from the special assessment under N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 1685, and that the assessment methodology was valid and proper. On appeal, the court agreed with the propriety of the methodology used, but concluded that the Dormitory Authority was exempt under N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 1685, and modified the judgment accordingly. The court found that the word "assessment" as used in N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 1685 did not include a special assessment of the kind issue against the Dormitory Authority. Under N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 1685 and N.Y. Real Prop. Tax § 102(2) used the term "assessment" differently, and that if the word "assessment" in N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 1685 was to be interpreted in accordance with the definition provided in N.Y. Real Prop. Tax § 102(2) to refer to an estimate of property value, N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 1685 would be rendered legally meaningless.


OUTCOME: Because the court found that the Dormitory Authority was statutorily exempt from the special assessment, the court modified the order of the appellate division that affirmed the supreme court order dismissing petitions challenging the special benefit assessments. As so modified, the court affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Public Authorities - State Dormitory Authority - Exemption from Taxation - Special Assessment The term assessment as used in Public Authorities Law § 1685, which provides that, because "the creation of the [dormitory] authority ... is in all respects for the benefit of the people ... the state of New York covenants with the holders of the bonds that the [dormitory] authority shall be required to pay no taxes or assessments upon any of the property acquired by it or under its jurisdiction, control, possession or supervision", includes a "special assessment" such as that imposed by respondent Fire and Water District to finance a new drinking water treatment facility and, therefore, the Dormitory Authority was entitled to an exemption from that special assessment under section 1685. Public Authorities Law § 1685 and RPTL 102 (2) use the term "assessment" differently, with Public Authorities Law § 1685 referring to a form of taxation from which the Authority is to be excused, while RPTL 102 (2) refers instead to an estimate of property value upon which a tax is ultimately based. If the word "assessment" in Public Authorities Law § 1685 is to be interpreted in accordance with the definition provided in RPTL 102 (2) to refer to an estimate of property value, the provisions of Public Authorities Law § 1685 are rendered legally meaningless. Using the current RPTL definition of "assessment" to limit Public Authorities Law § 1685 would thus contravene principles of sound statutory construction.

Municipal Corporations - Water and Sewer Rates - Validity of Benefit Assessment Methodology The benefit assessment methodology used to assess charges against property owners within respondent Fire and Water District, pursuant to which the benefit to be conferred on each parcel was to be calculated by assigning all existing residential structures in the District one to three benefit assessment units based on the District average of gallons consumed, gallons required per day, by assigning larger commercial structures benefit assessment units based on their actual metered daily consumption, and by projecting the reasonably likely development and resulting water needs over time of undeveloped parcels based on zoning ordinances and approvals as well as factors such as parcel shape, frontage and topography, is valid and proper and the special assessments imposed thereunder, fully authorized by the District's voters, were valid and constitutional. A detailed study was performed by the Board of Trustees before implementation of the assessment methodology and, in the absence of a showing to the contrary, the assessment is presumed valid. In any event, these taxpayers failed to offer sufficient proof that the amounts of the special assessments levied against them were substantially in excess of the undisputed benefits they will ultimately receive as a result of the new water treatment plant.

 

77 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Reform Educ. Fin. Inequities Today v. Cuomo


No. 2


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


86 N.Y.2d 279; 655 N.E.2d 647; 631 N.Y.S.2d 551; 1995 N.Y. LEXIS 1137


January 3, 1995, Argued  
 June 15, 1995, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order modified in accordance with the opinion herein, with costs to defendants-respondents, and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, a non-profit organization and related parties, sought review of an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) affirming, as modified, the supreme court's order dismissing the declaratory judgment action brought against defendants, mayor and related parties, which challenged the state's financing of public schools under U.S. Const. Amend. XIV and N.Y. Const. art. XI, § 1.


OVERVIEW: The non-profit organization and related parties alleged that the disparity in the amount of money spent per pupil between the wealthy school districts and the poorer districts violated N.Y. Const. art. XI, § 1, and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment. The court ruled that the non-profit organization and related parties failed to state a cause of action under N.Y. Const. art. XI, § 1 because they failed to allege that the students in the poorer districts were deprived of a sound basic education. Article XI, § 1 did not require that all school facilities be substantially equal. A gross disparity in funding, alone, was insufficient to establish the absence of a sound basic education. The court also ruled that the complaint failed to state a cause of action under the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment. The desire to provide local control over education was a rational basis upon which to base the financing system. Modification of the appellate court's decision, however, was necessary to reflect only that the allegations raised in the complaint did not demonstrate that the financing system was unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court modified the appellate court's order to reflect the fact that the allegations, as advanced in the complaint, failed to state a cause of action. The remainder of the appellate court's order affirming the supreme court's dismissal of the action was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Public School Financing System - Validity under Education Article of State Constitution Plaintiffs' allegations that the statutory scheme by which New York finances its public schools violates the Education Article of the State Constitution (art XI, § 1) because of the extreme disparities in funding between property-poor and property-rich school districts fail to state a cause of action. Article XI, § 1 does not mandate that all educational facilities and services be substantially equal throughout the State. Rather, it was intended to require the Legislature to provide a State system of free schools availing all of the State's children of a sound basic education. Plaintiffs do not claim that students in their districts are receiving something less than a sound basic education and, therefore, even accepting plaintiffs' allegations of gross disparities as true, their cause of action must fail because they do not state a claim that the disparities have caused students in the poorer districts to receive less than a sound basic education.

Constitutional Law - Equal Protection of Laws - Public School Financing System Plaintiffs' allegations that the statutory scheme by which New York finances its public schools violates the Equal Protection Clauses of the Federal and State Constitutions because of the extreme disparities in funding between property-poor and property-rich school districts fail to state a cause of action. The State educational funding scheme will be upheld if it is supported by a rational basis, and the desire to provide local control of education provides such basis. As plaintiffs' equal protection arguments are dependent upon the adoption of a more exacting standard, those equal protection challenges must fail.

Constitutional Law - Public School Financing System In an action challenging the constitutionality of New York's system for financing its public elementary and secondary schools, the Appellate Division's broad and definitive declaration of the constitutionality of the State educational financing system is modified to declare that the school financing scheme of the State of New York has not been shown in this case to be unconstitutional.

 

78 of 992 DOCUMENTS


City of New York v. State


No. 117B


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


86 N.Y.2d 286; 655 N.E.2d 649; 631 N.Y.S.2d 553; 1995 N.Y. LEXIS 1144


February 16, 1995, Argued  
 June 15, 1995, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff municipal entities appealed an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed a trial court's order, as modified, that granted defendants', State and State officials, motion to dismiss the complaint because the municipal entities lacked the legal capacity to sue and failed to state a cause of action for declaratory and injunctive relief related to public schools funding.


OVERVIEW: The municipal entities brought suit against the State and State officials because the State statutory scheme for funding public education allegedly violated several State and Federal constitutional provisions. The court affirmed the order of the appellate court and held that the municipal entities lacked the legal capacity to bring suit against the State because they failed to bring their claims within any recognized exception to the general rule that municipalities lacked the capacity to sue the State. Because the municipal entities were simply political subdivisions or creatures of the State, the only exceptions to the general rule, which the municipal entities failed to prove, were: (1) where an express statutory authorization to bring such a suit existed; (2) where the State legislation adversely affected a municipality's proprietary interest in a specific fund of moneys; (3) where the State statute impinged upon the "Home Rule" powers of a municipality; and (4) where the municipal entities asserted that if they were obliged to comply with the State statute they would by that very compliance be forced to violate a constitutional proscription.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the appellate court, with costs, and dismissed the suit because of the municipal entities' lack of capacity to bring suit against the State and State officials and for failure to state a cause of action.


HEADNOTES

Schools - State Aid to School Districts - Capacity of Municipalities to Challenge Constitutionality of State's School Funding Scheme The City of New York, Board of Education of the City, its Mayor and Chancellor of the City School District (municipal plaintiffs) lack capacity to bring an action against the State and various State officials challenging the constitutionality of the present State statutory scheme for funding public education. Municipalities and other local governmental corporate entities and their officers lack capacity to mount constitutional challenges to acts of the State and State legislation. This general incapacity to sue flows from judicial recognition of the juridical as well as political relationship between those entities and the State. Municipal corporate bodies--counties, towns and school districts--are merely subdivisions of the State, created by the State for the convenient carrying out of the State's governmental powers and responsibilities as its agents. As purely creatures or agents of the State, municipal corporate bodies cannot have the right to contest the actions of their principal or creator affecting them in their governmental capacity or as representatives of their inhabitants. The only recognized exceptions to the general rule barring local governmental challenges to State legislation are: an express statutory authorization to bring such a suit; where the State legislation adversely affects a municipality's proprietary interest in a specific fund of moneys; where the State statute impinges upon "Home Rule" powers of a municipality constitutionally guaranteed under article IX of the State Constitution; and where the municipal challengers assert that if they are obliged to comply with the State statute they will by that very compliance be forced to violate a constitutional proscription. Here, however, the municipal plaintiffs have failed to bring their claims within any recognized exception to the general rule that municipalities lack capacity to sue the State and their action must be dismissed.

 

79 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Campaign for Fiscal Equity v. State


No. 117A


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


86 N.Y.2d 307; 655 N.E.2d 661; 631 N.Y.S.2d 565; 1995 N.Y. LEXIS 1145


February 16, 1995, Argued  
 June 15, 1995, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, a non-profit organization of community school boards and others, appealed from the order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York) that dismissed claims against defendants, the State of New York and its officials, in a challenge to the constitutionality of the state's public school financing system which allegedly did not provide the opportunity to obtain a proper education to students in the city of New York.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs, a non-profit organization of community school boards and others, filed an action that sought a declaratory judgment against defendants, the State of New York and its officials. It alleged that the state's public school financing system was unconstitutional because it did not provide school students in the city of New York an opportunity to obtain a sound basic education. The state supreme court dismissed equal protection claims and claims under Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (Title VI), 42 U.S.C.S. § 2000d et seq., for failure to state a cause of action. The appellate division dismissed the other claims. The court modified the order, holding that plaintiffs pled sustainable claims under the Education Article of N.Y. Const. art. XI, § 1, and under the implementing regulations of Title VI, 34 C.F.R. § 100.3(b)(2). Plaintiffs alleged gross educational inadequacies that, if proven, could support a finding that the school financing system was unconstitutional under the Education Article. In challenging the allocation of education aid, plaintiffs provided statistical support for the disparity between aid distributed to the city's minority and non-minority students.


OUTCOME: The court modified the appellate division's dismissal and held that the claims filed by plaintiffs, a non-profit organization of community school boards and others, which challenged the constitutionality of the state's public school financing system were sufficient to survive a motion to dismiss because they alleged gross educational inadequacies and a disparity between the distribution of education aid between minority and non-minority students.


HEADNOTES

Schools - State Aid to School Districts - Constitutionality of State's Public School Financing System The Education Article of the State Constitution (NY Const, art XI, § 1) requires the State to offer all children the opportunity of a sound basic education consisting of the basic literacy, calculating, and verbal skills necessary to enable children to eventually function productively as civic participants capable of voting and serving on a jury. Thus, in an action challenging the constitutionality of the State's public school financing system under, inter alia, the Education Article, the State will have satisfied its constitutional obligation if the physical facilities and pedagogical services and resources made available under the present system are adequate to provide children with the opportunity to obtain these essential skills. While plaintiffs rely on the minimum State-wide educational standards established by the Board of Regents and the Commissioner of Education, proof of noncompliance with one or more of the Regents' or Commissioner's standards may not, standing alone, establish a violation of the Education Article because many of those standards exceed notions of a minimally adequate or sound basic education. Further, performance levels on standardized competency examinations are helpful, but should also be used cautiously. The trial court will have to evaluate whether the children in plaintiffs' districts are in fact being provided the opportunity to acquire the basic literacy, calculating and verbal skills necessary to enable them to function as civic participants capable of voting and serving on a jury. In order to succeed in the specific context of this case, plaintiffs will have to establish a causal link between the present funding system and any proven failure to provide a sound basic education to New York City school children.

Schools - State Aid to School Districts - Constitutionality of State's Public School Financing System - Sufficiency of Cause of Action under Education Article of State Constitution The nonschool board plaintiffs have properly stated a cause of action challenging New York State's public school financing system as violative of the Education Article of the State Constitution (NY Const, art XI, § 1) based upon allegations that New York City students are not receiving the opportunity to obtain an education that enables them to speak, listen, read, and write clearly and effectively in English, perform basic mathematical calculations, be knowledgeable about political, economic and social institutions and procedures in this country and abroad, or to acquire the skills and knowledge necessary to participate in democratic self-government, supported by fact-based claims of inadequacies in physical facilities, curricula, numbers of qualified teachers, availability of textbooks, library books, etc. Taking as true the allegations in the complaint, plaintiffs allege and specify gross educational inadequacies that, if proven, could support a conclusion that the State's public school financing system effectively fails to provide for a minimally adequate educational opportunity.

Schools - State Aid to School Districts - Constitutionality of State's Public School Financing System - Equal Protection of Laws - Federal and State Constitutions Plaintiffs have failed to state a cause of action challenging New York State's public school financing system as violative of the Equal Protection Clauses of the Federal and State Constitutions (US Const 14th Amend; NY Const, art I, § 11). Education is not a fundamental right under the United States Constitution or the State Constitution and, therefore, the rational basis test is the appropriate standard for equal protection analysis under both Constitutions. Any disparities in educational funding among school districts in the State arising from the State's financing scheme are rationally based upon and reasonably related to a legitimate State interest--the preservation and promotion of local control of education. Moreover, while plaintiffs have alleged that the State's educational funding methodology has a disparate impact upon African-American and other minority students, no discriminatory intent has been charged, and an equal protection cause of action based upon a disproportionate impact upon a suspect class requires establishment of intentional discrimination.

Schools - State Aid to School Districts - Sufficiency of Discrimination Cause of Action under Title VI of Civil Rights Act Plaintiffs have failed to state a cause of action that the State's public school financing system violates title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 USC § 2000d) because the complaint contains no showing of intentional discrimination, which is required to succeed on a title VI claim.

Schools - State Aid to School Districts - Sufficiency of Discrimination Cause of Action under Implementing Regulations of Title VI of Civil Rights Act Plaintiffs have stated a cause of action that the State's public school financing system violates the implementing regulations of title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (see, 34 CFR 100.3 [b] [2]). Under title VI's implementing regulations, proof of discriminatory intent is not a prerequisite to a private cause of action against governmental recipients of Federal funds. A validly stated cause of action under the title VI regulations has two components: whether a challenged practice has a sufficiently adverse racial impact and, if so, whether the practice is nevertheless adequately justified. Here, New York State is a recipient of Federal funds for education, and plaintiffs have alleged that the State's benefit distribution practice has the effect of subjecting minority students to discrimination on the basis of their race, color, or national origin supported by statistics pointing to the disparity between the total and per capita education aid distributed to New York City's predominantly minority student population as opposed to the amount distributed to the State's nonminority students, and defendants have not yet advanced a substantial justification for the challenged practice at this procedural point.

 

80 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Schulz v. State


No. 133


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


86 N.Y.2d 225; 654 N.E.2d 1226; 630 N.Y.S.2d 978; 1995 N.Y. LEXIS 1142


April, 26, 1995, Argued  
 June 14, 1995, Decided



DISPOSITION:  Order modified, without costs, in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff citizen-taxpayers challenged an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which dismissed a complaint that sought to enjoin the results of a bond referendum because defendant board had allegedly used public funds to produce false materials in favor of the bond. The complaint also alleged defendant government officials used state moneys in violation of N.Y. Const. art. VII, § 8(1).


OVERVIEW: Based on allegations that defendant board had used public funds to prepare and distribute false promotional materials in favor of an affirmative vote on a bond proposition, plaintiff citizen-taxpayers sought to enjoin the results of a bond referendum. Plaintiffs also alleged that defendant government officials had printed documents with state moneys to serve private political purposes in violation of N.Y. Const. art. VII, § 8(1). When the trial court dismissed plaintiffs' complaint, plaintiffs sought review. The court affirmed in part and reversed in part. In affirming, the court found plaintiffs' action against defendant board was properly dismissed for lack of subject matter jurisdiction because N.Y. Educ. Law § 2037 conferred exclusive original jurisdiction upon the Commissioner of Education regarding all disputes over the validity of school district elections. In reversing, the court held defendant government officials had transgressed constitutional boundaries because documents produced with state moneys had not been disseminated to educate, inform, advocate, or promote voting, but instead had been disseminated to enlist the public's support in opposition to a political party.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed a judgment dismissing a complaint that sought to enjoin a bond referendum's results because the Commissioner of Education had exclusive original jurisdiction over disputes concerning the validity of school district elections. It reversed a judgment dismissing a complaint that alleged defendant government officials had used state moneys unconstitutionally because the moneys had been used to promote a partisan political position.


HEADNOTES

Schools - Bond Referendum - Jurisdiction of Commissioner of Education over Claim of Invalidity of Referendum Plaintiffs' cause of action seeking to enjoin or invalidate the results of a school district's bond referendum because of the alleged distribution at public expense of partisan and false promotional literature regarding the referendum by the Board of Education was properly dismissed because Education Law § 2037 confers exclusive original jurisdiction upon the State Commissioner of Education regarding all disputes over the validity of school district meetings and elections. Judicial review of any unfavorable decision by the Commissioner regarding a complaint made pursuant to section 2037 would have been available and could have fully addressed plaintiffs' claim that false and partisan promotional materials were disseminated at school district expense. That plaintiffs' complaint regarding the school board's distribution of the allegedly tainted materials was couched in terms of a constitutional violation did not obviate the statutory mandate to originate the matter before the Commissioner.

Contempt - When Appropriate - Disobedience of Invalid Court Order Inasmuch as Supreme Court lacked original subject matter jurisdiction over plaintiffs' cause of action seeking to enjoin or invalidate the results of a school district's bond referendum--exclusive original jurisdiction residing in the Commissioner of Education pursuant to Education Law § 2037--Supreme Court also lacked jurisdiction to entertain and then grant plaintiffs' application for an order temporarily staying the referendum and, therefore, disobedience of that order cannot be punished as a contempt.

Constitutional Law - Taking of Property - Sufficiency of Cause of Action Plaintiffs' cause of action alleging that the unconstitutional uses of certain public funds violated their rights under the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution as a taking of their property without due process of law was properly dismissed since they have not alleged any actual appropriation of their individual property by the governmental action they describe, or even an indirect invasion of their specific property rights through regulation of the use thereof. Plaintiffs merely alleged that governmental revenues, concededly acquired lawfully through State or local tax levies, have been misused or misapplied to private purposes and, therefore, they have not validly alleged any violation of the Due Process or "Takings" Clauses of the Federal Constitution.

Constitutional Law - Unconstitutional Gift of Public Funds - Publication of Partisan Political Newsletter by State Agency Plaintiffs' allegations that the publication and mailing of a newsletter by the Governor's Office of Economic Development constituted the use of State moneys to serve private political purposes of the Governor, his campaign committee and the State Democratic Committee in violation of NY Constitution, article VII, § 8 (1) properly states a cause of action where the subject document, disseminated on the eve of the 1992 Presidential campaign, sought to enlist the public's support in opposition to the alleged Republican position on the welfare and Medicaid reform issues in addition to containing factual information which would have been of assistance to the electorate in making all educated decision on whose position to support. The use of public funds out of a State agency's appropriation to pay for the production and distribution of campaign materials for a political party or a political candidate or partisan cause in any election would fall squarely within article VII, § 8 (1)'s prohibition against gifts or loans to private enterprises. Under the applicable constitutional standard, election material may be disseminated at public expense to educate, inform, advocate or promote voting on any issue, provided it is not to persuade nor to convey favoritism, partisanship, partiality, approval or disapproval by a State agency of any issue. Here, the latter part of the document is patently designed to exhort the electorate to make an avowed, public commitment in support of a particular position advocated by one political faction and, therefore, plaintiffs have stated a valid cause of action under article VII, § 8 (1), notwithstanding that the newsletter also contains information that, standing alone, would be considered a proper attempt to educate the public.

 

81 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Orvis Co. v. Tax Appeals Tribunal


No. 138, No. 139


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


86 N.Y.2d 165; 654 N.E.2d 954; 630 N.Y.S.2d 680; 1995 N.Y. LEXIS 1140


April 27, 1995, Argued  
 June 14, 1995, Decided



DISPOSITION: No. 138: Judgment modified, with costs to appellant-respondent Commissioner, and matter remitted to the Appellate Division, Third Department, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed. No. 139: Judgment reversed, with costs, and petition dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant state tax commissioner sought review of a decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York), which held that appellee vendors were not, under the Commerce Clause, required to collect state use taxes based on their sales to New York customers, because neither vendor maintained a substantial physical presence in New York.


OVERVIEW: The court held that the appellate division applied the improper standard. Rather than a substantial physical presence, the commissioner was required to prove only a minimum connection with the state in order to be authorized to collect the use tax. The court reviewed the Supreme Court jurisprudence, concluding with Quill Corporation v. North Dakota, 504 U.S. 298. The court read Quill as adopting a middle course, rejecting the requirement of some physical presence of the vendor as a minimum connection in the taxing state to support the jurisdiction to tax under the Due Process Clause, but requiring some physical presence of an interstate mail-order vendor in the taxing state for validity of the authority to tax under the Commerce Clause. In this case, there was substantial evidence to support the State Tax Appeals Tribunal's determination that the vendors' activity in New York was sufficient to impose the obligation to collect compensating use taxes on their taxable retail sales to New York customers. Both vendors sent salesmen into the state, resulting in substantial sales.


OUTCOME: In the case of one vendor, the court affirmed the judgment as modified, awarded costs to commissioner, and remitted the matter to the Appellate Division for further proceedings. In the case of the other vendor, the court reversed the judgment, awarded costs, and dismissed the petition.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - Sales and Use Taxes - Out-of-State Vendor - Nature of Presence in New York Necessary under Commerce Clause to Impose Tax Collection Duty In order to impose a duty on an out-of-State vendor to collect a compensating use tax (Tax Law § 1110) from its New York clientele without contravening the Commerce Clause (US Const, art I, § 8), a physical presence of the vendor is required, which need not be substantial but must be demonstrably more than a "slightest presence". And it may be manifested by the presence in the taxing State of the vendor's property or the conduct of economic activities in the taxing State performed by the vendor's personnel or on its behalf. Accordingly, there was substantial evidence to support the determination of the Tax Appeals Tribunal that the activity of petitioner, a Vermont vendor, in New York was sufficient to impose the obligation to collect compensating use taxes on its retail sales to New York customers where petitioner's substantial wholesale business in New York was generally accomplished by means of its sales personnel's direct solicitation of retailers through visits to their stores in New York, subject only to approval of all orders in Vermont. Moreover, the affidavits of petitioner's officers suggest systematic visitation to all of its as many as 19 wholesale customers on the average of four times a year, which demonstrably exceeds the "slightest presence" of petitioner in New York.

Taxation - Sales and Use Taxes - Out-of-State Vendor - Nature of Presence in New York Necessary under Commerce Clause to Impose Tax Collection Duty In order to impose a duty on an out-of-State vendor to collect a compensating use tax (Tax Law § 1110) from its New York clientele without contravening the Commerce Clause (US Const, art I, § 8), a physical presence of the vendor is required, which need not be substantial but must be demonstrably more than a "slightest presence". And it may be manifested by the presence in the taxing State of the vendor's property or the conduct of economic activities in the taxing State performed by the vendor's personnel or on its behalf. Accordingly, there was substantial evidence to support the determination of the Tax Appeals Tribunal that the activity of petitioner, a Vermont vendor, in New York was sufficient to impose the obligation to collect compensating use taxes on its retail sales to New York customers where petitioner's hardware and software sales agreements obligated it to provide a charge-free visit of a computer software installer at its customer's site in New York if problems necessitating the visit occurred within the first 60 days of installation. Moreover, petitioner's invoices showed charges for travel expenses to its New York customers' locations on 41 occasions, in order to resolve the more intractable problems involving its computer hardware and software, during the three-year audit period, in which petitioner had 154 taxable transactions in New York. There was ample support in the record for the Tax Appeals Tribunal's finding that petitioner's trouble-shooting visits to New York vendees and its assurances to prospective customers that it would make such visits enhanced sales and significantly contributed to petitioner's ability to establish and maintain a market for the computer hardware and software it sold in New York. Petitioner's activities in New York were, thus, definite and of greater significance than merely a slightest presence.

 

82 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Bourquin v. Cuomo


No. 61


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


85 N.Y.2d 781; 652 N.E.2d 171; 628 N.Y.S.2d 618; 1995 N.Y. LEXIS 1131


April 27, 1995, Argued  
 June 13, 1995, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, with costs, defendants' motion for summary judgment granted, plaintiffs' cross motion for summary judgment denied and judgment granted declaring that Executive Order No. 141 is constitutional.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff citizen and plaintiff various non-profit corporations brought an action against defendant governor, which sought a preliminary injunction enjoining implementation of the Executive Order No. 141, N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 9 § 4.141. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial District (New York) reversed the dismissal of the action and declared Executive Order No. 141 unconstitutional. The governor appealed.
