Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - "Access Fee" Tax Deduction for Interstate Long-Distance Carriers Tax Law § 186-a (2-a) which, with respect to calculation of the deduction from income permitted long-distance carriers for access service fees paid to local exchange carriers in connection with long-distance intrastate telephone calls, requires that the deduction be allocated against interstate and international revenues prior to apportionment to New York (see, Tax Law § 184 [4]) violates the Commerce Clause (US Const, art I, § 8). In computing the allowable access fee deduction, the statute requires apportionment of access fees only by long-distance carriers which engage in interstate commerce and are unable to directly account for their New York revenues. By requiring the interstate long-distance carrier to calculate the deduction before apportionment to New York of a percentage of its entire gross income based upon the proportion of the carrier's property in New York, the statute has the practical and real effect of treating differently long-distance carriers similarly situated in all respects except for the percentage of their property located within New York State. While a wholly intrastate long-distance carrier may deduct all of its New York access fees, the interstate carrier is limited to its apportionment percentage, even though both companies are reporting 100% of their New York taxable income. The access fees are fixed and easily traceable to New York and, therefore, the access fees are already apportioned to the State. Requiring the deduction to be taken before apportionment plainly creates a direct commercial advantage to intrastate long-distance carriers. Moreover, no showing has been made by the State that the discriminating methodology advances a legitimate local purpose that cannot be adequately served by reasonable nondiscriminatory alternatives.

 

99 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Hope v. Perales


No. 23


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


83 N.Y.2d 563; 634 N.E.2d 183; 611 N.Y.S.2d 811; 1994 N.Y. LEXIS 989


January 13, 1994, Argued  
May 5, 1994, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellee women sought to enjoin appellant commissioners in the Supreme Court of New York from implementing New York's Prenatal Care Assistance Program (PCAP), N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2520 et seq. The trial court enlarged New York's PCAP to include medically necessary abortions, and the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) affirmed that the statute was unconstitutional. The commissioners appealed.


OVERVIEW: The women claimed that New York's PCAP was unconstitutional because it was underinclusive in failing to include medically necessary abortions in a prenatal care public funding scheme for women with incomes up to 85 percent over the federal poverty level. Congress created PCAP to afford federal reimbursement to states providing prenatal care and related services for needy pregnant women with household incomes exceeding the Medicaid eligibility standard. The women contended that the legislature violated an obligation under the Due Process Clause not to influence the exercise of a fundamental right by funding childbirth and not abortion. The court held that New York's PCAP was constitutional. The women failed to establish their contention that New York's PCAP even indirectly infringed the right of reproductive choice. There was no evidence that eligible women were coerced, pressured, steered, or induced by New York's PCAP to carry pregnancies to term. New York's PCAP did not in any sense burden a fundamental right and bore a rational relationship to the state's interest in providing much-needed prenatal care to low-income women.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate division's order and declared the statute constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Social Services - Medical Assistance - Constitutionality of Prenatal Care Assistance Program - Failure to Include Abortion Funding - State Constitution

1. The Prenatal Care Assistance Program (PCAP) (Public Health Law § 2520 et seq.) is not facially invalid under the State Constitution because it fails to include medically necessary abortions in a prenatal care public funding scheme for women with incomes up to 85% over the Federal poverty level. PCAP does not in any sense burden a fundamental right, and it bears a rational relationship to the State's interest in providing much-needed prenatal care to low-income women.

Social Services - Medical Assistance - Constitutionality of Prenatal Care Assistance Program - Failure to Include Abortion Funding - Due Process of Law - Equal Protection of Laws - State Constitution

2. The Prenatal Care Assistance Program (PCAP) (Public Health Law § 2520 et seq.) does not violate the Due Process Clause of the State Constitution (NY Const, art I, § 6) on the ground that it infringes the right of reproductive choice by funding certain childbirth services for eligible women--those with incomes up to 85% over the Federal poverty level--but not abortion. There is no evidence that PCAP even indirectly infringes the right of reproductive choice. The PCAP-eligible woman presumptively has the financial means to exercise her fundamental right of choice. That the Legislature in the circumstances elects to subsidize certain prenatal services cannot, in and of itself, be deemed coercive, and no showing has been made that such a woman would be influenced by PCAP to carry a child to term. Nor does PCAP penalize the exercise of the right of choice, as it does not deny eligibility for any benefit to which participants choosing to abort would otherwise be entitled. Moreover, a challenge to PCAP asserting a denial of equal protection (NY Const, art I, § 11) fails for much the same reasons.

Social Services - Medical Assistance - Constitutionality of Prenatal Care Assistance Program - Failure to Include Abortion Funding - Aid to Needy and Public Health Clauses of State Constitution

3. The Prenatal Care Assistance Program (PCAP) (Public Health Law § 2520 et seq.), which covers the cost of enumerated pregnancy-related services for women with incomes up to 85% over the Federal poverty level, does not violate the Aid to the Needy (NY Const, art XVII, § 1) and Public Health (NY Const, art XVII, § 3) Clauses of the State Constitution by excluding coverage for medically necessary abortions without regard to the financial or medical need of the participants. PCAP-eligible women are presumptively able to afford abortion, a legislative premise not rebutted on the record. The contrary cannot be inferred from the mere fact that PCAP was enacted. Moreover, it cannot be said beyond a reasonable doubt that, by not including abortion funding in PCAP, the Legislature transgressed its powers to promote the State's interest in aiding the needy and promoting public health in such manner, and by such means as the Legislature may from time to time determine (NY Const, art XVII, § 1, 3).

 

100 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Village of Valatie v. Smith


No. 48


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


83 N.Y.2d 396; 632 N.E.2d 1264; 610 N.Y.S.2d 941; 1994 N.Y. LEXIS 328


February 16, 1994, Argued  
March 30, 1994, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order modified, without costs, by denying defendant's cross motion for summary judgment and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff village sought review of an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York), which granted defendant mobile home owner's cross motion for summary judgment in an action challenging the facial validity of a local law that terminated the nonconforming use of mobile homes, outside of mobile home parks, upon the transfer of ownership of either the mobile home or the land upon which it sat.


OVERVIEW: A local ordinance terminated the nonconforming use of a mobile home upon the transfer of ownership of either the mobile home or the land upon which it sat. When defendant owner inherited a mobile home from her father, plaintiff village instituted an action to have the mobile home removed. The trial court granted defendant's cross motion for summary judgment, reasoning that the right to continue a nonconforming use runs with the land and that the portion of the ordinance setting termination at the transfer of ownership was unconstitutional. The appellate court affirmed. The court modified the order of the appellate court and denied defendant's cross motion for summary judgment. The court found that the law was not rendered invalid because the original owner enjoyed a right that could not be transferred to a subsequent owner. The test for the validity of an amortization period was whether the period unreasonably inflicted substantial loss on the owner or failed to comport to the reasonableness required by due process. Thus, the court held that defendant failed to overcome the presumption of the law's validity and prove unconstitutionality beyond a reasonable doubt.


OUTCOME: The court modified the order of the lower court and denied defendant mobile home owner's cross motion for summary judgment because she failed to carry her burden of showing that the local law was unreasonable on its face.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations - Zoning - Nonconforming Use - Facial Validity of Local Law Terminating Nonconforming Use upon Change in Ownership - Relation of Amortization Period to Land Use Objectives or Owner's Financial Recoupment Needs

1. Defendant has failed to carry her burden of showing that chapter 85 of the Village Code of the Village of Valatie, which terminates the nonconforming use of a mobile home upon the transfer of ownership of either the mobile home or the land upon which it sits, is facially unconstitutional on the ground that the use of a change in ownership as the termination date is not reasonably related to the Village's legitimate interest in land use planning because the length of the amortization period must be related either to land use objectives or to the financial recoupment needs of the owner. The length of the amortization period need not be based on a municipality's land use objectives. Instead, the setting of the amortization period involves balancing the interests of the individual and those of the public. Here, in striking that balance, the Village considered a nonfinancial interest of the individual owners--the individual's interest in not being displaced involuntarily through establishment of a predetermined amortization period set by the Village--and defendant has not demonstrated why such an approach is irrational or explained why a municipality should be barred constitutionally from considering the nonfinancial interests of the owners in setting an amortization schedule.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Viability of Facial Challenge to Statute Constitutionally Applied to Litigant

2. Defendant's contention that chapter 85 of the Village Code of the Village of Valatie, which terminates the nonconforming use of a mobile home upon the transfer of ownership of either the mobile home or the land upon which it sits, is facially unconstitutional on the ground that the use of a change in ownership as the termination date might prevent some owners from recouping their investment is unavailing. Defendant has not claimed that she was so injured, and a litigant cannot sustain a facial challenge to a law when that law is constitutional in its application to that litigant.

Municipal Corporations - Zoning - Nonconforming Use - Facial Validity of Local Law Terminating Nonconforming Use upon Change in Ownership - Regulation of Ownership

3. Defendant has failed to carry her burden of showing that chapter 85 of the Village Code of the Village of Valatie, which terminates the nonconforming use of a mobile home upon the transfer of ownership of either the mobile home or the land upon which it sits, is facially unconstitutional on the ground that the use of a change in ownership as the termination date violates the fundamental rule that zoning deals basically with land use and not with the person who owns or occupies it, because the right to the nonconforming use is enjoyed only by those who owned the property when the local law was enacted and cannot be transferred. Here, no individual is singled out for special treatment in land use regulation. Moreover, the mere fact that the right cannot be transferred or that later owners are treated disparately from the original owner is insufficient to sustain defendant's facial challenge to the ordinance.

 

101 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Thompson


No. 36


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


83 N.Y.2d 477; 633 N.E.2d 1074; 611 N.Y.S.2d 470; 1994 N.Y. LEXIS 329


February 10, 1994, Argued  
March 30, 1994, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was convicted of the class A-1 felony of the sale of cocaine. The trial court refused to sentence defendant according to the minimum mandatory sentence and imposed a sentence of eight years to life. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) affirmed defendant's sentence. The State appealed.


OVERVIEW: Defendant, a 17-year-old, sold an undercover police officer two ounces, 33 grains of cocaine. She was convicted. The trial court, however, refused to sentence her to the minimum mandatory sentence, which was 15 years to life, on the grounds that such a sentence would constitute cruel and unusual punishment. The appellate court affirmed. On further review, the court disagreed. Contemporary standards of decency did not prevent imposing a sentence of 15 years to life imprisonment upon defendant, an older adolescent, for a direct volitional sale of more than two ounces of cocaine. Cocaine sales were a grave offense and justified severe punishment.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's decision to affirm defendant's sentence of eight years to life for the sale of cocaine.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Sentence - Cruel and Unusual Punishment - Mandatory Minimum Sentence for A-I Felony - Sale of Drugs by 17 Year Old

1. Sentencing defendant, who was 17 years old at the time of the crime, to the mandatory minimum of 15 years to life imprisonment for a class A-I felony conviction arising from her sale of 2 ounces, 33 grains of cocaine to an undercover officer in a known drug location for $ 2,000, is not so grossly disproportionate to the crime as to constitute cruel and unusual punishment (US Const 8th Amend; NY Const, art I, § 5). The selling of narcotic drugs represents a grave offense of the first magnitude. Further, in comparison to the sanctions for other crimes under the Penal Law and for the same or similar drug offenses in other jurisdictions, the mandatory sentences for drug offenses, while relatively severe, are not irrationally so, given the epidemic dimensions of the problem. The punishment received by defendant's confederate, who was the principal in the drug operation in which defendant's sale took place--a sentence of 15 years to life imprisonment pursuant to a bargained plea of guilty to one of the five criminal sales of a controlled substance in the first degree charged in the indictment--does not establish gross disproportionality. Moreover, the undisputed evidence as to the extent of defendant's culpability in the cocaine sale and the threat she poses to society is not overly favorable to defendant. The only strongly mitigating factor, defendant's youth, is alone insufficient to establish gross disproportionality for constitutional purposes.

Crimes - Sentence - Cruel and Unusual Punishment - Factors to be Considered

2. In reviewing whether imposition of the mandatory minimum sentence upon defendant would constitute cruel and unusual punishment (US Const 8th Amend; NY Const, art I, § 5), on the ground that the sentence is grossly disproportionate to the crime, the Court of Appeals considered the gravity of defendant's crime, that is, the harm it causes society and its comparative seriousness in light of the punishments for other State crimes and for the same offense in other jurisdictions, as well as in comparison to the punishment of the other charged participant, and also reviewed defendant's personal history and her role in the commission of this criminal offense, and found no strongly mitigating factors, other than her youth, which was determined to be alone insufficient to establish gross disproportionality for constitutional purposes.

 

102 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Medical Soc'y v. State Dep't of Health


No. 46


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


83 N.Y.2d 447; 633 N.E.2d 468; 611 N.Y.S.2d 114; 1994 N.Y. LEXIS 321


February 16, 1994, Argued  
March 29, 1994, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, a medical society and physicians, sought review of a judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York) declaring that N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 19 was enforceable after adoption of the resource-based relative value scale (RBRVSF) fee schedule by appellee U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).


OVERVIEW: The appellate court reversed the trial court's judgment that N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 19 was unenforceable after January 1, 1992 when the HHS adopted the RBRVSF fee schedule. The court, on appeal by the medical society and physicians, affirmed the appellate court's judgment. The court held that N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 19 was enacted in the contemplation that it would operate in conjunction with the Federal Budget Omnibus Reconciliation Act of 1989. Thus, a rational construction of § 19 was that the term "reasonable charge" was used to refer to Medicare's recognized, reasonable payment amount as determined by HHS, irrespective of the particular methodology employed to calculate that amount. This construction accorded with the legislature's purpose in enacting § 19. Although § 19's fee restrictions were effectuated by reference to the federal payment amount, the statute was otherwise complete and contained all the information required for intelligent and discrete action by the legislature. Accordingly, it violated neither the letter nor the spirit of proscription against incorporation by reference contained in N.Y. Const. art. III, § 16.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the appellate court, which reversed the trial court's judgment declaring that N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 19 was not applicable to physicians' services provided on or after January 1, 1992.


HEADNOTES

Health - Medicare - Reasonable Charges for Medicare Beneficiaries - Effect of Federal Adoption of Resource-Based Relative Value Scale

1. Public Health Law § 19, which, effective January 1, 1991, placed percentage caps on charges made by physicians to Medicare beneficiaries in excess of the "reasonable charge for that service as determined by the United States secretary for health and human services [HHS]", did not become unenforceable as of January 1, 1992, when HHS stopped using the "reasonable charge" method of reimbursement and adopted a fee schedule based on a resource-based relative value scale. The Legislature's purpose in enacting section 19 was to prevent physicians who use balance billing from charging Medicare beneficiaries excessive amounts for certain services. The Legislature was aware that the "reasonable charge" system would be discontinued as of January 1, 1992. Nevertheless, it enacted section 19 in the contemplation that the statute would operate in conjunction with the strong provisions of the Federal Omnibus Reconciliation Act of 1989 to increase the number of fully participating physicians who, rather than balance bill, would accept the reasonable rate as full payment for all services for all Medicare patients. Thus, a rational construction of the statute at issue is that the term "reasonable charge" was used by the Legislature to refer to Medicare's recognized, reasonable payment amount as determined by HHS, irrespective of the particular methodology employed to calculate that amount. To interpret the statute in any other fashion would frustrate the clear intent of the Legislature and lead to an absurd result.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Legislative Incorporation by Reference - Public Health Law § 19 

2. Public Health Law § 19, which, effective January 1, 1991, placed percentage caps on charges made by physicians to Medicare beneficiaries in excess of the "reasonable charge for that service as determined by the United States secretary for health and human services [HHS]", as construed to apply to a fee schedule based on a resource-based relative value scale, adopted by HHS effective January 1, 1992, in the place of the "reasonable charge" scale that was utilized when section 19 was enacted, does not violate the constitutional proscription against legislative incorporation by reference (NY Const, art III, § 16), on the ground that it incorporates by reference a future amendment to the Medicare Act. The constitutional proscription applies where incorporation by reference results in the creation of substantive obligations or requirements. Although section 19's imposition of fee restrictions is effectuated by reference to the Federally recognized payment amount, the statute is otherwise complete and contains all the information required for intelligent and discrete action by the Legislature. The statute does not incorporate any new substantive requirements or obligations. The Legislature, in enacting section 19, was concerned with capping the amount above Medicare's recognized payment schedule for physicians' services to Medicare beneficiaries--irrespective of the particulars involved in calculating that amount.

 

103 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Weinberg


No. 34


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


83 N.Y.2d 262; 631 N.E.2d 97; 609 N.Y.S.2d 155; 1994 N.Y. LEXIS 265


February 9, 1994, Argued  
March 17, 1994, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) affirming the trial court's judgment of conviction for the crimes of failure to file a tax return, in violation of N.Y. Tax Law. § 1801, and repeated failure to file a tax return, in violation of N.Y. Tax Law § 1802.


OVERVIEW: On appeal, defendant argued that the legislature did not intend § 1802 to be applied retroactively because a portion of the conduct needed for conviction under § 1802, past failure to file returns, occurred prior to the effective date of § 1802. The court ruled that § 1802 was not being applied retroactively in his case because the actual unlawful conduct, the subsequent failure to file a return, occurred after the statute's effective date. The fact that an antecedent act occurred prior to the effective date did not violate the prohibition against ex post facto laws. The court also ruled that the trial court did not err in providing the jury with a supplemental instruction on the essential element of timeliness. The trial court had a duty, under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 310.30 to respond to the jury's request that the elements of the offenses be repeated. The fact that the trial court initially omitted a discussion on the timeliness element, and had to bring the jury back to correct the omission, did not render the instruction unfair. Finally, the court ruled that, based on a prior decision, defendant was not entitled to introduce the concept of jury nullification in summation.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate division's order affirming the trial court's judgment of conviction.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Repeated Failure to File Tax Return - Retroactive Application of Tax Law § 1802 

1. Tax Law § 1802 proscribing repeated failure to file a tax return, which became effective on November 1, 1985 and was made applicable to all offenses committed on or after such date, was not retroactively applied to defendant who was convicted under section 1802 based upon his failure to file New York State personal income tax returns for the years 1983, 1984 and 1985. A statute is not retroactive when made to apply to future transactions, merely because such transactions relate to and are founded upon antecedent events. Here, defendant "committed" the section 1802 offense when he failed to file his 1985 tax return by April 15, 1986, having then failed to file his returns for three consecutive years as provided by section 1802. His conduct thus falls within the plain statutory language concerning the applicability of the section.

Crimes - Repeated Failure to File Tax Return - Ex Post Facto Law

2. Tax Law § 1802 proscribing repeated failure to file a tax return, which became effective on November 1, 1985 and was made applicable to all offenses committed on or after such date, does not constitute an unconstitutional ex post facto law as applied to defendant based upon his failure to file New York State personal income tax returns for the years 1983, 1984 and 1985. Defendant did not commit the repeated failure to file offense until he failed to file his 1985 return by April 15, 1986, a point in time well after section 1802's effective date. A conviction under section 1802 is not to be viewed as either a new jeopardy or additional penalty for the earlier nonfilings. It is a stiffened penalty for the latest crime, which is considered to be an aggravated offense because a repetitive one. Moreover, defendant, having failed to file returns for the two consecutive years of 1983 and 1984, was given fair warning by the enactment of section 1802 that his failure to file a return for 1985 would result in criminal liability for repeated failure to file under that section.

Crimes - Instructions - Supplementary Instructions - Propriety of Correction of Prior Supplementary Instruction Absent Request by Jury

3. In the prosecution of defendant for failure to file a tax return (Tax Law § 1801) and repeated failure to file a tax return (Tax Law § 1802), the trial court did not commit error in giving supplemental instructions to the jury regarding a timeliness element in any of the offenses, i.e., that the statute is violated by a failure to file within the time required by law (see, Tax Law § 1801 [a]), on the grounds that the instruction on timeliness was unrequested and unbalanced, where, after the court reread the elements of both offenses to the jury at the jury's request, the court recognized that it had failed to reiterate the timeliness element of the offenses and reinstructed the jury regarding that element. The trial court fulfilled its duty to respond meaningfully to the jury's inquiry by correcting its prior supplementary instruction to assure that the jury was not deliberating under a misapprehension of the law (see, CPL 310.30). The timeliness instruction cannot be characterized as unrequested since the inclusion of the timeliness requirement was especially pertinent to rendering a meaningful response to the jury's inquiry here in light of the fact that defendant did ultimately file untimely returns. Moreover, defendant's claim that the timeliness instructions were so unbalanced as to preclude the jury from properly considering the main defense theory--i.e., that defendant lacked intent to evade taxes--is unpersuasive as the court explicitly prefaced the timeliness instruction with a reiteration that the individual must intend to evade the tax.

Crimes - Verdict - "Jury Nullification" - Presentation of Concept of Jury Nullification during Defense Summation Prohibited

4. In the prosecution of defendant for failure to file a tax return (Tax Law § 1801) and repeated failure to file a tax return (Tax Law § 1802), the trial court correctly prohibited defendant from presenting the concept of jury nullification during summation. While there is nothing to prevent a petit jury from acquitting although finding that the prosecution has proven its case, this so-called "mercy-dispensing power" is not a legally sanctioned function of the jury and should not be encouraged by the court. Permitting defense counsel instead to encourage the jury to abdicate its primary function would directly contravene the trial court's authority to instruct the jury that they must follow and properly apply the law.

 

104 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Saratoga Water Servs. v. Saratoga County Water Auth.


No. 14


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


83 N.Y.2d 205; 630 N.E.2d 648; 608 N.Y.S.2d 952; 1994 N.Y. LEXIS 159


January 12, 1994, Argued  
February 22, 1994, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant private utility challenged the judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which confirmed the trial court's ruling in an eminent domain proceeding brought by appellee public utility. The private utility argued that N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 1199-eee(5) unconstitutionally limited the court's power to determine just compensation designated to the judiciary by N.Y. Const. art. I, § 7.


OVERVIEW: Appellee public utility brought eminent domain proceedings in order to acquire the physical facilities of appellant private utility pursuant to the authority of N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 1199-eee(5). The private utility argued that § 1199-eee(5) unconstitutionally restricted the court to determining the value of the property taken solely to the "income capitalization" method, which it felt was inadequate. The court held that the power given to the court by N.Y. Const. art. I, § 7a to provide just compensation for property taken by eminent domain could not be limited by the legislature. Therefore, § 1199-eee(5), interpreted in the light of its presumed constitutionality, was held to only imply a preference for the income capitalization method, but not to require it as the sole means of determining the condemned property's value. This meant, the court held, that the court's inherent authority to determine just compensation was not impermissibly restricted by the statute. The court also rejected other constitutionality arguments, including that the statute was unconstitutionally vague because it required the court to determine the value on a date contingent on future events.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court and found the statute by which appellee public utility brought eminent domain proceedings against appellant private utility did not restrict the court's constitutional authority to determine compensation in eminent domain proceedings. The court held that the statute preferred but did not require the income capitalization method in determining the value of condemned property.


HEADNOTES

Eminent Domain - Award - Water Authority - Just Compensation

1. In a proceeding challenging two determinations of respondent Water Authority condemning petitioners' assets and real property for the creation of a countywide coordinated public water system, petitioners' contention that Public Authorities Law § 1199-eee (5) impermissibly mandates exclusive use of the income capitalization method in determining compensation in condemnation situations and that such a legislative command effectively usurps the power to determine just compensation designated to the judiciary by the State Constitution (NY Const, art I, § 7) is rejected; the just compensation which the State Constitution requires to be paid to the owner of property taken under the power of eminent domain cannot be reduced to inflexible formulas or inexorable rules, and the language of Public Authorities Law § 1199-eee (5) implies only a preference for and does not dictate the method of valuation to be employed. The statute reflects the Legislature's attempt to protect the property owner's right to just compensation by allowing Supreme Court to use methods other than income capitalization while simultaneously providing the condemnor with an avenue of escape in case of an unusually high valuation. Although the income capitalization method, which seeks to set the value of property based on its expected net yield to the owner, has become the preferred approach in valuating income-producing property, it remains subject to criticism, principally because of the speculative nature of the valuation criteria used, and because earned income imperfectly reflects the actual value of a utility whose rates are subject to regulation. Supreme Court retains its appropriate power in the legislative scheme, as it determines in the first instance whether income capitalization is to be utilized, and the unusual solution chosen by the Legislature is constitutionally tolerable given the unique valuation problems inherent in public utilities takings. Furthermore, section 1199-eee (5) affects public utilities only; because compensation for condemnation of the nonutility petitioners' property is governed by the provisions of the EDPL, rather than section 1199-eee (5), the challenged statute in no way infringes on their constitutional right to receive just compensation.

Eminent Domain - Award - Water Authority - Vagueness of Authorizing Statute 

2. In a proceeding challenging two determinations of respondent Water Authority condemning petitioners' assets and real property for the creation of a countywide coordinated public water system, petitioners' contention that Public Authorities Law § 1199-eee (5) is unconstitutionally vague because it requires courts to value property as of some indeterminable future date is rejected; while ordinarily, compensation is fixed as of the instant the condemnee's property is taken by the vesting of title in the condemnor, the challenged statute provides that title shall vest and compensation shall be paid after valuation of the property by Supreme Court. The statute abrogates the general rule that no taking occurs under the statute until title vests to the extent of chronologically separating the "taking" or "acquisition" event from the vesting of title. Pursuant to EDPL article 4, respondent takes possession of the property at the end of the acquisition proceeding upon the filing of an acquisition map, and valuation takes place as of that date. Title vests later under section 1199-eee (5), when the appeals process is exhausted, in order that the condemnor may be able to withdraw the proceeding in the event Supreme Court determines income capitalization should not be used, and in order to comply with the settled rule that a condemnor cannot abandon an appropriation after title vests. Inasmuch as valuation takes place as of the time of the taking, the statute is not unconstitutionally vague.

Eminent Domain - Public Use - Water Authority - Excessive Taking

3. In a proceeding challenging two determinations of respondent Water Authority condemning petitioners' assets and real property for the creation of a countywide coordinated public water system, petitioners' contention that the proposed acquisition includes property beyond respondent's statutory authority to condemn was properly rejected by the Appellate Division as specious. Public Authorities Law § 1199-eee (5) plainly provides respondent with the authority "[t]o acquire * * * any real or personal property or any interest therein, * * * as [respondent] may deem necessary, * * * to carry out the purpose of this title" (emphasis added).

 

105 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Voliton


No. 7


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


83 N.Y.2d 192; 630 N.E.2d 641; 608 N.Y.S.2d 945; 1994 N.Y. LEXIS 163


January 6, 1994, Argued  
February 22, 1994, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed his conviction for assault in the third degree and resisting arrest. Defendant claimed that substantive due process barred convicting him for actions in response to the illegal seizure of his person by police and that, because the police's acts were unlawful, his arrest was not authorized.


OVERVIEW: The court affirmed an order upholding defendant's conviction for assault in the third degree and resisting arrest. The appellate division had vacated defendant's two second-degree assault convictions, holding that police unlawfully seized defendant by detaining him without a reasonable suspicion that criminal activity was afoot. The illegality of the seizure negated a necessary element of second-degree assault. Defendant claimed that substantive due process barred convicting him for actions in direct response to the illegal seizure and that, because the police acted unlawfully, defendant's arrest was not authorized, negating an element of resisting arrest. The court held that defendant failed to preserve for review his claim that substantive due process barred convicting him for his response to the seizure. Also, the court held that defendant did not timely request a jury instruction that he would have been justified in using force in self-defense against excessive force employed by the police to detain him. Defendant's third-degree assault against an officer, during his initial encounter with his police, furnished the predicate for defendant's subsequent authorized arrest.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed order upholding defendant's conviction for assault in third degree and resisting arrest, where defendant failed to preserve for review his claim that substantive due process barred convicting him for actions in response to his illegal seizure by police. Defendant did not timely request jury instruction that he would have been justified in using physical force in self-defense against excessive force employed by police.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Appeal - Preservation of Issue for Review - Unlawful Search and Seizure

1. In the prosecution of defendant for assault and resisting arrest stemming from an incident which began when police officers detained defendant by blocking his vehicle and displaying their weapons without having any reasonable suspicion that criminal activity was afoot at the time, defendant has failed to preserve for appellate review his contention, raised for the first time before the Appellate Division, that substantive due process bars convicting him for actions in direct response to the unlawful seizure of his person by the police. Defendant's objection does not fall within the narrow class of cases in which preservation by timely objection has been held unnecessary; such exceptions have been limited to errors going to the very organization of the court or at such basic variance with the mode of procedure mandated by law that they impair the essential validity of the criminal proceedings, and the preservation rule has been generally applied to due process objections of the type raised here.

Crimes - Resisting Arrest - Sufficiency of Evidence

2. In the prosecution of defendant for resisting arrest and other offenses stemming from an incident which began when police officers detained defendant by blocking his vehicle and displaying their weapons without having any reasonable suspicion that criminal activity was afoot at the time, defendant's contention that because the Appellate Division expressly found that the acts of the police in detaining and attempting to seize him were unlawful at the time the alleged injuries to the police were inflicted, defendant's arrest by the police was not "authorized", thus negating an essential element of the crime of resisting arrest (see, Penal Law § 205.30), is rejected. Defendant was also convicted of assault in the third degree based upon the jury's finding that one officer was injured by contact with defendant's car during the initial encounter as a result of defendant's reckless conduct in maneuvering his automobile to avoid being detained by the officers, and there is no issue properly before the Court of Appeals of defendant's justification for his use of force in this initial encounter with the police. Therefore, defendant's commission of an assault against one officer during the initial encounter between defendant and the police furnished the predicate for his subsequent authorized arrest by the second officer, and his conviction for resisting that arrest was properly affirmed by the Appellate Division.

 

106 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Ruotolo v. State


No. 1


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


83 N.Y.2d 248; 631 N.E.2d 90; 609 N.Y.S.2d 148; 1994 N.Y. LEXIS 122


January 5, 1994, Argued  
February 17, 1994, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) certified the question whether its order, which reversed an order of the Court of Claims dismissing an action by respondent claimants against appellant State of New York to recover under N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 205-e for injuries to police officers, was properly made.


OVERVIEW: A parolee killed a police officer and wounded two others and claimants brought an action against the State of New York for wrongfully allowing the assailant to remain on parole. The action was dismissed for failure to state a claim and, while an appeal was pending, the legislature enacted N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 205-e to establish a claim for police officers injured in the line of duty. After the appellate division affirmed the dismissal, § 205-e was twice amended to expressly make the remedy retroactive and broaden the scope of coverage. The appellate division granted reargument, reversed the dismissal, and certified the question whether reversal was proper. The court answered the question in the affirmative and affirmed. The legislative waiver of immunity expressed in § 205-e rested on an adequate moral obligation and did not violate the no-gift provision of N.Y. Const. art. VII, § 8 because it did not grant a judgment or bestow a gift of state property but merely allowed the claimants an opportunity to seek redress. The legislature had directed reexamination and determination of a judgment not on the merits without impairing the state's right to defend itself.


OUTCOME: The court answered the certified question in the affirmative and affirmed the order of the appellate division.


HEADNOTES

Statutes - Retroactive Application of Statute - Claim against State - Injuries to Police Officers - Finality of Prior Determination

1. A claim against the State to recover for injuries and wrongful death arising out of the 1984 shooting of three police officers by a parolee should be permitted to go forward in the Court of Claims. While the first series of this litigation ended with the claims ruled out of court, the Legislature, in enactments reactive to the court rulings, persisted in trying to allow the claims to be heard in the Court of Claims, and the State challenges the authority and power of the Legislature to enact chapter 474 of the Laws of 1992, which purports to allow the claims pursuant to General Municipal Law § 205-e to be pressed retroactively. When the Court of Appeals denied leave to appeal in the first round of litigation, the Legislature did not become forever barred from exercising its substantial powers, including that of surrendering some of the State's own vested rights with respect to the matter. A Court of Appeals denial of leave to appeal from an order of the Appellate Division affirming a grant by the Court of Claims of defendant's motion to dismiss by way of summary judgment is a final determination; while the first series of litigation is thus deemed to be a final determination which created some vested rights in the State with respect to the matter at issue, the Appellate Division in the first series of litigation did not reach the question of the statute's application to this case. General Municipal Law § 205-e allowed for an existing cause of action which the courts in the first series of litigation found to be not available in the circumstances of and at that time; therefore, the claim was not extinguished and was ripe for express reopener by way of judicial determination under the ensuing legislation at chapter 762 of the Laws of 1990, which would allow judicial resolution of the claims. It purposefully clarified the original intent of the Legislature to make General Municipal Law § 205-e retroactive; thus, the defendant State cannot plausibly maintain that the Legislature did not intend to give retroactive application to the remedies provided for in General Municipal Law § 205-e with respect to claimants who had litigated claims to final judgment before the amendments were enacted.

Statutes - Retroactive Application of Statute - Claim against State - Injuries to Police Officers - Constitutional Prohibition against Gift or Loan to Individual - Moral Obligation

2. A claim against the State to recover for injuries and wrongful death arising out of the 1984 shooting of three police officers by a parolee should be permitted to go forward in the Court of Claims. While the first series of this litigation ended with the claims ruled out of court, the Legislature, in enactments reactive to the court rulings, persisted in trying to allow the claims to be heard in the Court of Claims, and the State challenges the authority and power of the Legislature to enact chapter 474 of the Laws of 1992, which purports to allow the claims pursuant to General Municipal Law § 205-e to be pressed retroactively. When the Court of Appeals denied leave to appeal in the first round of litigation, the Legislature did not become forever barred from exercising its substantial powers, including that of surrendering some of the State's own vested rights with respect to the matter. While that power is not absolute and is constitutionally circumscribed, when the Legislature finds and demonstrates, as here, that there is an adequate moral obligation as the basis for retroactively remedying the particular restrictions of General Municipal Law § 205-e, which otherwise barred the statutory claims advanced by claimants, the Legislature's power and exercise of that public policy choice should not be nullified by the courts. The New York Constitution specifically forbids the gift or loan of property to a specific individual (NY Const, art VII, § 8), and when the Legislature demonstrates that an enactment challenged under this provision was both in response to a moral obligation of the State and does not undermine previously vested rights, the courts will not interfere with the exertion. The Legislature has found that the nature of modern police work has exposed police officers to an unprecedented risk of death and physical injury, and the resultant revival of claims of injured officers and representatives of deceased officers against individuals found liable for such deaths or injuries did not grant judgment or bestow a direct, tangible gift of any forbidden State property; the claimants are allowed a lower order of entitlement--an opportunity to prove that the State was negligent in a special context and in recognition of a moral obligation.

Statutes - Retroactive Application of Statute - Claim against State - Injuries to Police Officers - Due Process of Law

3. A claim against the State to recover for injuries and wrongful death arising out of the 1984 shooting of three police officers by a parolee should be permitted to go forward in the Court of Claims. While the first series of this litigation ended with the claims ruled out of court, the Legislature, in enactments reactive to the court rulings, persisted in trying to allow the claims to be heard in the Court of Claims, and the State challenges the authority and power of the Legislature to enact chapter 474 of the Laws of 1992, which purports to allow the claims pursuant to General Municipal Law § 205-e to be pressed retroactively. When the Court of Appeals denied leave to appeal in the first round of litigation, the Legislature did not become forever barred from exercising its substantial powers, including that of surrendering some of the State's own vested rights with respect to the matter. The Appellate Division properly found that the retroactive effect granted under General Municipal Law § 205-e did not violate the constitutional prohibition against "the audit and allowance of a time-barred claim" (NY Const, art III, § 19). While the State has advanced the argument that a violation of due process as against its own interests occurred by the Legislature, in effect, overriding the State's own vested rights, the Attorney-General is under a paramount duty to defend legislative action in enacting statutes; the State which enacted legislation may not be heard to complain that the enactment is void as a violation of due process.

 

107 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Rent Stabilization Ass'n v. Higgins


No. 259


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


83 N.Y.2d 156; 630 N.E.2d 626; 608 N.Y.S.2d 930; 1993 N.Y. LEXIS 4357


November 16, 1993, Argued  
December 21, 1993, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, property owners, challenged the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York), which affirmed a judgment of the Supreme Court denying a motion by property owners for summary judgment, and declaring the "family member" succession rights regulations promulgated by respondent, Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR), to be a valid exercise of its administrative power.


OVERVIEW: The legislature designated DHCR the sole administrative agency to administer the regulation of residential rents under the rent control and rent stabilization statutes and to amend the Rent Stabilization Code. Property owners sought a preliminary injunction and a declaration that the new regulations were unconstitutional and invalid, in defining the persons to be afforded noneviction protection. The court held that DHCR acted within its competence and authority. The court held that owner's right to evict a tenant or convert property to other uses remained unaffected, and the fact that a tenancy might be of indefinite duration did not, without more, render it a permanent physical occupation of property. The court held that owners failed to establish their claim that, facially, a permanent physical occupation of owners' property had been taken. The court concluded that owners did not meet their burden of showing the requisite deprivation of economically beneficial use of their property. The court concluded that no unconstitutional taking had been demonstrated.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the appellate court.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Separation of Powers - Validity of Regulations Enlarging Class of "Family Members" in Rent-Regulated Apartments Entitled to Noneviction Protection

1. Regulations promulgated by respondent Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR) enlarging, beyond blood or marriage, the class of "family members" entitled to succeed to a rent-regulated apartment on the death or departure of the tenant of record to include any other person residing with the tenant who can prove emotional and financial commitment and interdependence between such person and the tenant (9 NYCRR 2104.6 [d] [3] [i]; 2204.6 [d] [3] [i]; 2500.2 [n]; 2503.5 [d]; 2520.6 [o] [2]; 2523.5 [b]) are within the agency's rule-making authority. In defining the persons to be afforded noneviction protection in an ongoing housing crisis, DHCR has acted within its competence and authority. DHCR has not acted on a clean slate--noneviction protection in rent-regulated housing was first created by the legislature in the rent control and rent stabilization laws. Further, the challenged regulations fill in the interstices of the legislative mandate by redefining the protected class of people to include those who, in DHCR's experience as sole administrator of residential rent regulation and adjudicator of eviction disputes, are most in need of protection against loss of their homes in a continuing housing emergency. Nor has DHCR enacted categorical exemptions reflecting accommodations to special interest groups. Moreover, although 27 bills have been introduced in the legislature between 1986 and 1989 relating t succession rights, the legislature has not sought to alter succession rights in the years following DHCR's emergency and later permanent regulations enlarging the class of "family members".

Constitutional Law - Taking of Property - Permanent Physical Occupation of Property - Regulations Enlarging Class of "Family Members" in Rent-Regulated Apartments Entitled to Noneviction Protection

2. Regulations promulgated by respondent Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR) enlarging, beyond blood or marriage, the class of "family members" entitled to succeed to a rent-regulated apartment on the death or departure of the tenant of record (9 NYCRR 2104.6 [d] [3] [i]; 2204.6 [d] [3] [i]; 2500.2 [n]; 2503.5 [d]; 2520.6 [o] [2]; 2523.5 [b]) are not unconstitutional on their face because, without just compensation, they require owners of rent-regulated housing to suffer a permanent physical occupation of their property. The new regulations have not created perpetual tenancies. That a rent-regulated tenancy might itself be of indefinite duration does not, without more, render it a permanent physical occupation of property. Nor does the fact that an owner must offer a renewal lease to a departed tenant's newly defined family member--potentially a stranger to the owner--give rise to such a physical occupation. Because the challenged regulations may require the owner-lessor to accept a new occupant but not a new use of its rent-regulated property, the claim that, facially, a permanent physical occupation of property has been effected, has not been established. In any event, a "family member" for noneviction purposes, applying all of the criteria established by DHCR, is no more likely to be a stranger to the owner than a family member as formerly defined.

Constitutional Law - Taking of Property - Deprivation of Economically Beneficial Use of Property - Regulations Enlarging Class of "Family Members" in Rent-Regulated Apartment Entitled to Non-eviction Protection

3. Regulations promulgated by respondent Division of Housing and Community Renewal enlarging the class of "family members" entitled to succeed to a rent-regulated apartment on the death or departure of the tenant of record (9 NYCRR 2104.6 [d] [3] [i]; 2204.6 [d] [3] [i]; 2500.2 [n]; 2503.5 [d]; 2520.6 [o] [2]; 2523.5 [b]) do not, on their face, effect an impermissible regulatory taking on the ground that they deprive the property owners-lessors of both the benefit of rental increases that occur upon vacancy and the reversionary interest in their property. The challenged regulations do not affect the owner's right to receive the regulated rents, unchallenged as a reasonable return, and the owners are not deprived of their reversionary interest since the tenancies are not perpetual. Thus, the owners have not met their burden of showing the requisite deprivation of economically beneficial use of their property.

Constitutional Law - Taking of Property - Advancement of Legitimate Governmental Objectives - Regulations Enlarging Class of "Family Members" in Rent-Regulated Apartments Entitled to Non-eviction Protection

4. Regulations promulgated by respondent Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR) enlarging, beyond blood or marriage, the class of "family members" entitled to succeed to a rent-regulated apartment on the death or departure of the tenant of record to include any other person residing with the tenant who can prove emotional and financial commitment and interdependence between such person and the tenant (9 NYCRR 2104.6 [d] [3] [i]; 2204.6 [d] [3] [i]; 2500.2 [n]; 2503.5 [d]; 2520.6 [o] [2]; 2523.5 [b]) do not, on their face, effect an impermissible regulatory taking on the ground that they do not substantially advance the legitimate governmental objectives of prevention of unwarranted evictions and alleviation of homelessness. There is a close causal nexus between the challenged regulations and the stated purpose of preventing the eviction and resulting vulnerability to homelessness of the intended beneficiaries. People who would, absent the regulations, be threatened with eviction from their homes may now have the right to remain. The designation of classes of individuals to whom DHCR has extended noneviction protection is a matter that falls within the agency's expertise.

Administrative Law - Validity of Regulation - Compliance with State Administrative Procedure Act

5. Respondent Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR) complied with the State Administrative Procedure Act in promulgating regulations that enlarge the class of "family members" entitled to succeed to a rent-regulated apartment on the death or departure of the tenant of record (9 NYCRR 2104.6 [d] [3] [i]; 2204.6 [d] [3] [i]; 2500.2 [n]; 2503.5 [d]; 2520.6 [o] [2]; 2523.5 [b]). DHCR filed the proposed regulations with the Secretary of State, submitted a notice of adoption for publication in the State Register, issued appropriate regulatory impact statements and other analyses and held a public hearing.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Regulation - Vagueness - Regulations Enlarging Class of "Family Members" in Rent-Regulated Apartments Entitled to Noneviction Protection

6. Regulations promulgated by respondent Division of Housing and Community Renewal that enlarge, beyond blood or marriage, the class of "family members" entitled to succeed to a rent-regulated apartment on the death or departure of the tenant of record to include any other person residing with the tenant who can prove emotional and financial commitment and interdependence between such person and the tenant (9 NYCRR 2104.6 [d] [3] [i]; 2204.6 [d] [3] [i]; 2500.2 [n]; 2503.5 [d]; 2520.6 [o] [2]; 2523.5 [b]) are not impermissibly vague. The factors specified in the regulations to be considered in determining the existence of a qualifying relationship are objective, detailed and specific, and provide ample guidance in identifying the commencement of the relationship despite the absence of a marriage certificate or other legal document.

 

108 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Martinez


No. 255


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


83 N.Y.2d 26; 628 N.E.2d 1320; 607 N.Y.S.2d 610; 1993 N.Y. LEXIS 4363


November 11, 1993, Argued  
December 21, 1993, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged the order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) convicting him of criminal sale of a controlled substance and criminal possession of a controlled substance, contending that the jury was instructed with an erroneous presumption under N.Y. Penal Law § 220.25(2).


OVERVIEW: Defendant contended that the harmless error analysis was improperly employed where the jury returned a general verdict, and it was thus impossible to determine whether it convicted defendant under an erroneously submitted theory. The court agreed, and ordered a reversal and a new trial because of the defect in the conviction on the criminal possession count. The unknown aspect of the verdict involved the identity and legality of the theory that the jury chose for its verdict, not the tainting effect of some trial error on a known result. The court affirmed the lower court's determination that the evidence did not warrant a drug factory presumption charge under the statute. Thus, the court reversed the lower court's ruling, and a new trial was ordered.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the lower court's ruling and ordered a new trial where it was impossible to determine which theory of law the jury had used in convicting defendant.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Verdict - Invalid General Verdict - Erroneous "Drug Factory" Presumption Instruction

1. In the prosecution of defendant for criminal possession of a controlled substance in the third degree and a related charge, wherein the trial court instructed the jury that it could find defendant guilty of either actual possession or constructive possession, but erroneously instructed the jury as to the "drug factory" presumption of possession (see, Penal Law § 220.25 [2]), the jury's general verdict of guilty was invalid since it could not have been known if the result was predicated on the erroneous "drug factory" presumption or on the lawful alternative theory of constructive possession without the aid of the presumption.

Crimes - Harmless and Prejudicial Error - Harmless Error Analysis Improper Where Guilty Verdict Possibly Based on Illegal Theory - Erroneous "Drug Factory" Presumption Instruction

2. In the prosecution of defendant for criminal possession of a controlled substance in the third degree and a related charge, wherein the trial court instructed the jury that it could find defendant guilty of either actual possession or constructive possession, but erroneously instructed the jury as to the "drug factory" presumption of possession (see, Penal Law § 220.25 [2]), the Appellate Division erroneously applied the doctrine of harmless error after finding that the jury's verdict of guilty was invalid because it could not have been known if the result was predicated on the erroneous "drug factory" presumption or on the lawful alternative theory of constructive possession without the aid of the presumption. The Appellate Division was not presented with the problem of evaluating a trial error and the likelihood that it may have contributed to a result known to have been reached by the jury. Here, the result reached by the jury was unknown, and the unknown aspect of the verdict involved the identity and legality of the theory that the jury chose for its verdict, not the tainting effect of some trial error on a known result. Where it is impossible for a reviewing court to determine whether the guilty verdict was founded on an illegal theory, it may not review the evidence under a harmless error analysis and, in effect, assume the jury's fact-finding function by concluding that the jury must have reached its result on some alternative legal ground.

Crimes - Instructions - Erroneous "Drug Factory" Presumption Instruction - Existence of Evidence to Support Guilty Verdict on Erroneous Theory

3. In the prosecution of defendant for criminal possession of a controlled substance in the third degree and a related charge, wherein the trial court instructed the jury that it could find defendant guilty of either actual possession or constructive possession, but erroneously instructed the jury as to the "drug factory" presumption of possession (see, Penal Law § 220.25 [2]), the jury's general verdict of guilty was invalid, and cannot be upheld on the ground that there was insufficient evidence to support the verdict on the erroneous theory and, therefore, the jury must have based its verdict on a theory for which there was sufficient evidence. Under the improper "drug factory" presumption charge as given by the court here, there was evidence to support a verdict on that erroneous theory. Although a requirement for charging the presumption is that the drug be "in open view in a room, other than a public place, under circumstances evincing an intent to unlawfully mix, compound, package or otherwise prepare for sale such controlled substance" (Penal Law § 220.25 [2] [emphasis added]), the trial court's expanded charge that "the term open view [does not] necessarily mean the drugs themselves were in plain view or displayed", permitted the jury to conclude that drugs found in the space between the couch and the wall of the apartment searched by police would satisfy the statute. Moreover, as to the statutory requirement that a person be in "close proximity" to the drugs, the trial court's charge that "close proximity does not necessarily mean the same room where the drugs are found, so long as this room is either adjacent to or could be observed from the room that the person is located", made the presumption applicable to anyone present in the apartment when the warrant was executed. Finally, there was nothing in the charge restricting the evidence of observations or activities--either as to nature or time of occurrence--that the jury could consider as constituting "circumstances evincing an intent to unlawfully mix, compound, package or otherwise prepare for sale such controlled substance".

 

109 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Rose ex rel. Clancy v. Moody


No. 269


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


83 N.Y.2d 65; 629 N.E.2d 378; 607 N.Y.S.2d 906; 1993 N.Y. LEXIS 4343


November 18, 1993, Argued  
December 20, 1993, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, county commissioner and intervenor state attorney general, sought review on constitutional grounds of the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed an order of the family court that respondent indigent mother's child support obligation for her third, noncustodial child was $ 0.


OVERVIEW: The indigent mother's third noncustodial child lived with his grandmother. The county commissioner filed a petition for support against the mother on behalf of the grandmother. The appellate division affirmed the family court's decision against the commissioner and directed an award of nothing in child support because the mother's annual income was $ 0, and concluded that the Federal Child Support Enforcement Act prohibited a state from creating a conclusive presumption that $ 25 was the correct amount of child support to be awarded. The commissioner and intervenor state attorney general appealed on constitutional grounds alleging that § 413(1)(g) of the New York Family Court Act, which conclusively fixed a minimum $ 25 per month floor in all cases, was not preemptively nullified by any conflict with federal law under 42 U.S.C.S. § 667, which mandated a rebuttable presumption in all such instances. The court affirmed the determination of both lower courts in favor of the mother because the state act flatly contradicted the enabling legislation, which commanded an opportunity to rebut and drop the support award floor to $ 0, where impoverished conditions so warranted.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the appellate division, which affirmed the family court's determination that the indigent mother was not obligated to pay child support for her third noncustodial child.


HEADNOTES

Parent and Child - Support - Noncustodial Parent - Validity of $ 25 Per Month Floor on Child Support Obligations - Federal Preemption

Inasmuch as Family Court Act § 413 (1) (g) creates an irrebuttable presumption imposing on an indigent noncustodial parent a $ 25 per month floor on all child support obligations up to an accumulated debt of $ 500, it flatly contradicts the enabling legislation (42 USC § 667) that commands an opportunity in all cases to rebut and drop the support award floor to $ 0 when impoverished circumstances so dictate and, therefore, section 413 (1) (g) is preemptively nullified. Moreover, for a judicial decree to declare that an indigent parent owes what she cannot realistically or legally pay would degrade the value and integrity of the judicial decree, and would unjustly and unaccountably brand the parent a deadbeat.

 

110 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Longway v. Jefferson County Bd. of Supervisors


No. 270


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


83 N.Y.2d 17; 628 N.E.2d 1316; 607 N.Y.S.2d 606; 1993 N.Y. LEXIS 4341


November 18, 1993, Argued  
December 16, 1993, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an appeal by plaintiff residents from a judgment entered by the United States District Court for the Northern District of New York in an action against defendant county supervisors, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit certified the question of whether, for purposes of local legislative apportionment, "population", as defined in New York Mun. Home Rule Law § 10(1)(ii)(a)(13)(c), necessarily excluded transients.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff residents filed a federal class action alleging that the apportionment voting composition set by defendant county supervisors violated the equal protection and due process rights of county residents, by not providing substantially equal weight for voters, due to the inclusion in the apportionment base of transients, such as military personnel, incarcerated felons, and occupants of group homes. The lower court granted summary judgment to defendants and dismissed the complaint. On appeal to the intermediate federal appellate court, the following question was certified to this court: whether, for purposes of local legislative apportionment, "population", defined as "residents, citizens, or registered voters" in New York Mun. Home Rule Law § 10(1)(ii)(a)(13)(c), necessarily excluded transients, such as military personnel, incarcerated felons, and occupants of group homes. The court answered the question in the negative. It held that "residents" in the apportionment sense was construed more broadly then would be appropriate in terms of voting rights. The goals and objectives of the concepts differed significantly. Transients were integral parts of their communities.


OUTCOME: The court answered in the negative the certified question submitted by the intermediate federal appellate court on the appeal by plaintiff residents from a summary judgment entered by the lower court in favor of defendant county supervisors, in plaintiffs' class action challenging the constitutionality of the county apportionment base. The municipal home rule law did not necessarily exclude transients for local legislative apportionment.


HEADNOTES

Legislature - Apportionment - Local Governments - Inclusion of Transients in Apportionment Base

The term "population", defined by Municipal Home Rule Law § 10 (1) (ii) (a) (13) (c) for purposes of local legislative apportionment as "residents, citizens, or registered voters" does not necessarily exclude transients, such as military personnel, incarcerated felons, and occupants of group homes.

 

111 of 992 DOCUMENTS


McDermott v. Regan


No. 274


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


82 N.Y.2d 354; 624 N.E.2d 985; 604 N.Y.S.2d 890; 1993 N.Y. LEXIS 3894; 17 Employee Benefits Cas. (BNA) 1867


October 14, 1993, Argued  
November 16, 1993, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, Comptroller of the State of New York and others (comptroller), sought review of the judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department, (New York), which affirmed summary judgment in favor of respondents, a civil service employee individually and as president of an employee' association (employees). The employees had claimed that a legislative change in funding their pension was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: 1990 N.Y. Laws 210, changed the method of funding the civil service employees' pension plan from an aggregated cost method, which resulted in the funding of some benefits before they accrued, to another method, which required funding only when the benefits accrued. The net result was a cost savings for the state because it would pay a reduced annual contribution for a number of years. The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court, which had held that 1990 N.Y. Laws 210 violated the state constitution. N.Y. Const. art. V, § 7 provided that membership in the civil service employees pension constituted a contractual relationship, the benefits of which could not be impaired or diminished. The funding change in 1990 N.Y. Laws 210 radically impacted the pension and clearly impaired and diminished its value. The comptroller was a trustee of the fund, and was bound by the constitutional prohibition against reducing its value. Thus, his independent judgment on investment was to be protected. The court held that the legislature was bound by a fiduciary with respect to the administration with the fund, even though it had been given flexibility with respect to its administration.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court, which had, in turn, affirmed summary judgment in favor of the employees.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service - Retirement and Pension Benefits - Unconstitutional Impairment of Retirement Benefits - Legislative Imposition of Particular Funding Method - Projected Unit Credit Method of Funding Chapter 210 of the Laws of 1990, which changes the funding method for New York State Retirement Systems from an Aggregate Cost (AC) method to a Projected Unit Credit (PUC) method, violates NY Constitution, article V, § 7, requiring that a system member's benefits not be "diminished or impaired". Chapter 210 divests the State Comptroller, as trustee of the subject retirement funds, of his autonomous judgment as to whether the PUC method is preferable to the AC method. Said legislation allows employers to deplete moneys in the existing pension fund by reducing the amount of employer contributions. Employers are allowed a credit of a portion of the existing moneys, and need not contribute to the pension until the reserved moneys are drastically reduced. To later replenish the fund, employers and employees must increase the amount of their contributions to the pension fund. As such, the reserve moneys will not be available for immediate investment, the return on investment of moneys in the existing fund will be significantly decreased, and the additional security provided by the reserve moneys in the pension funds will be impaired.

 

112 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Teachers Ins. & Annuity Ass'n v. City of New York


No. 169


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


82 N.Y.2d 35; 623 N.E.2d 526; 603 N.Y.S.2d 399; 1993 N.Y. LEXIS 3278


September 1, 1993, Argued  
October 19, 1993, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant building owner commenced an action against respondents, a city, its preservation commission, and various officials, which alleged that the commission exceeded its authority under the Landmarks Law (Law), New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code tit. 25, ch. 3. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) affirmed the trial court's dismissal of the action. The building owner appealed that judgment.


OVERVIEW: The preservation commission landmarked the interior of a restaurant located in an office building. That action was challenged by the building owner on the grounds that it exceeded the authority granted to the commission by the Law, New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code tit. 25, ch. 3. The court found that the actions of the commission were consistent with the authority granted to it by the Law. The commission was authorized by two provisions of the Law, New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 25- 302(m), § 25-303(a)(2), to landmark an interior 30 or more years old that was customarily open or accessible to the public. Under those provisions, there was no requirement that the interior be a place of assemblage like a railroad station or a theater. Rather, it only had to a place to which the public was customarily invited. Moreover, another provision of the Law, New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 25-302(1), did not distinguish between personalty and realty. Thus, the commission's designation of items appurtenant to the restaurant's interior was authorized. Furthermore, the mere fact that the restaurant could be converted to private use in the future did not preclude the commission's actions.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment, which sustained the dismissal of the building owner's action.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations - Landmarks Preservation - Standard of Judicial Review - Determination of "Special Historical or Aesthetic Interest" With respect to judicial review of interior landmarking determinations of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, courts should defer to the expertise of the Commission as to interpretation of the statutory term "special historical or aesthetic interest" (Administrative Code of City of NY § 25-302 [m]).

Municipal Corporations - Landmarks Preservation - Standard of Judicial Review - Determination of Customary Public Openness With respect to judicial review of interior landmarking determinations of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, the meaning of "customarily open or accessible to the public" (Administrative Code of City of NY § 25-302 [m])--essential to the Commission's jurisdiction--is a law question for the courts rather than one of administrative expertise.

Municipal Corporations - Landmarks Preservation - Owner's Consent The New York City Landmarks Law (Administrative Code of City of NY, tit 25, ch 3) does not require an owner's consent as a prerequisite to designation. The owner is entitled to notice of the public hearing (Administrative Code § 25-313 [a]), but failure to give such notice does not invalidate a designation. So long as the statutory criteria are satisfied, the Landmarks Preservation Commission may make a valid designation over an owner's objection.

Municipal Corporations - Landmarks Preservation - Interior of Restaurant - Customary Public Openness An interior to which the general public is usually invited, regardless of its intended purpose, falls within the ambit of the New York City Landmarks Law which requires as a threshold to landmark designation that an interior be "customarily open or accessible to the public, or [a place] to which the public is customarily invited" (Administrative Code of City of NY § 25-302 [m]). That an interior currently open to the public can be converted to private use in the future cannot preclude the landmarking of an appropriate interior. Thus, a determination of the Landmarks Preservation Commission that the Four Seasons restaurant "customarily" invites the public for purposes of landmarking the restaurant's interior is not arbitrary or capricious.

Municipal Corporations - Landmarks Preservation - Interior of Restaurant - Restriction on Future Use In a CPLR article 78 proceeding challenging a determination of the Landmarks Preservation Commission designating the interior of the Four Seasons restaurant a landmark, appellant owner's argument that the designation impermissibly restricts future use of the space in violation of Administrative Code of the City of New York § 25-304 (a), because it includes certain items that purportedly render the space unusable for any other purpose is rejected. Whether or not the statute should be so read, appellant failed to establish its contention that the space will be unusable for other purposes.

Municipal Corporations - Landmarks Preservation - Interior of Restaurant - Items Appurtenant to Interior Items appurtenant to the interior of a restaurant designated as a landmark by the Landmarks Preservation Commission can properly be included in the designation notwithstanding that they fail to qualify as fixtures at common law. Accordingly, in designating the interior of the Four Seasons restaurant as a landmark, the Commission properly included hanging sculptures, a walnut bar, metal draperies, decorative metal railings and ceiling panels that were created and installed at the architect's direction, finding that each of the designated items was an integral element of the design of the interior. The Commission has drawn a rational distinction between items integral to the design of the interior space, and items that merely enhance the restaurant's ambiance.
