The Commission's interpretation is not unreasonable and thus the Commission did not exceed its authority by including the designated items. Moreover, the Commission's decision to include the designated items is supported by the record and not arbitrary or capricious and thus was within the proper exercise of the Commission's discretion.

 

113 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Roth v. Cuevas


No. 286


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


82 N.Y.2d 791; 624 N.E.2d 689; 604 N.Y.S.2d 551; 1993 N.Y. LEXIS 3825


October 14, 1993, Argued  
October 19, 1993, Decided


HEADNOTES

Local Laws - Term Limits for Certain Municipal Officials - Validity of Proposed Voter Initiative

In a proceeding to declare valid a voter initiative which would set term limits for the Mayor, Public Advocate, Comptroller, Borough Presidents, and Members of the City Council of the City of New York, an order of the Appellate Division, which affirmed a judgment declaring the proposed law valid, is affirmed for reasons stated in the opinion at Supreme Court, which concluded that the term limit legislation proposed by petitioner related to New York City's "affairs" and/or "government" as well as to the "terms of office" of its "officers" (see, Municipal Home Rule Law § 10 [1] [i], [ii] [a] [1]; see also, NY Const, art IX, § 2 [c]); that the proposed law is a proper subject of public referendum pursuant to Municipal Home Rule Law § 37, which permits the amendment of a city charter "however extensively"; that the proposed law would not be inconsistent with State law; that the proposed law is a permissible supplement to existing State law with respect to a topic on which State law is silent; that the limitation of the number of consecutive terms of certain City officials is not an arbitrary exclusion from office, but, rather, is a rational decision that would have a neutral application toward all candidates and would not discriminate on the basis of race, creed, color or sex; that the term limit legislation in question has rational bases, viz., to broaden opportunities for political and public participation, reduce the opportunities for corruption, and increase citizens' confidence in the integrity and effectiveness of their government; that the proposal would not disenfranchise citizens or impair fundamental rights; that the proposed law would not unconstitutionally infringe on the equal protection rights of elected officials to seek office; and that the proposed law is a proper subject of local legislation since it clearly implicates substantial matters of local concern.

 

114 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Brooklyn Heights Ass'n v. Macchiarola


No. 242


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


82 N.Y.2d 101; 623 N.E.2d 1140; 603 N.Y.S.2d 790; 1993 N.Y. LEXIS 3012


August 25, 1993, Argued  
September 7, 1993, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, members of a districting commission, sought review of an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) that affirmed a judgment in a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, directing respondents to redraw the New York City Council district lines.


OVERVIEW: The New York City Board of Estimate was declared unconstitutional because it violated the Equal Protection guarantee of "one person, one vote." Consequently, the Board of Estimate was abolished and some of its powers were transferred to the City Council. The task of redrawing the Council districts was assigned to appellants, districting commission. Thereafter, in a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, the appellate court affirmed a judgment directing respondents to redraw the New York City Council district lines. On appeal, the court reversed the appellate court decision. The court found that appellants' policy was not arbitrary and capricious, but was directly and reasonably related to implementing a census requirement. The court held, therefore, that its review was at an end and that the order of the appellate court should be reversed, without costs, and the petition dismissed.


OUTCOME: The court reversed an order of the appellate court that affirmed a judgment directing respondents to redraw the New York City Council district lines. The court found that the districting decision of appellants, members of a districting commission, was not arbitrary and capricious, but was directly and reasonably related to implementing a census requirement.


HEADNOTES

Elections - Redistricting Plan - New York City Districting Commission - Use of Census Tabulation Blocks The policy choice of the New York City Districting Commission not to split census tabulation blocks in redrawing New York City Council districts is not arbitrary and capricious. The Commission was required to use the "final count results" of the 1990 census (NY City Charter § 1152 [d] [11] [b]), and determined that it could best effectuate this mandate by building districts from tabulation blocks, the smallest geographical units for which census data was available. The Commission's policy choice not to split tabulation blocks was directly and reasonably related to implementing the Charter's requirement that census data be used in creating districts. Accordingly, the petition is dismissed in a CPLR article 78 proceeding challenging, as violative of the Charter's intact-neighborhoods requirement (NY City Charter § 52 [1] [c]), the decision of the Commission to place the whole of census tabulation block 105, a portion of which allegedly has historically been a part of the Brooklyn Heights neighborhood, into a different district than Brooklyn Heights in order to create a Latino-majority district pursuant to the districting plan's second-ranked priority of ensuring fair and effective minority representation (NY City Charter § 52 [1] [b]), rather than placing the disputed portion of census block 105 in the district encompassing Brooklyn Heights.

 

115 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Greater Poughkeepsie Library Dist. v. Poughkeepsie


No. 155


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


81 N.Y.2d 574; 618 N.E.2d 127; 601 N.Y.S.2d 94; 1993 N.Y. LEXIS 2169


June 3, 1993, Argued  
July 8, 1993, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant town sought review from an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) which affirmed a judgment of the supreme court insofar as it declared that the town was under a legal duty to pay to plaintiff library district the 1991 budget contribution to be computed pursuant to 1987 N.Y. Laws ch. 524.


OVERVIEW: Under 1987 N.Y. Laws ch. 524, which created the library district, the town must levy a tax to fund the library district in an amount fixed by the trustees of the library district. On appeal, the town contended that the statute violated the New York Constitution. The court agreed, concluding that the statute improperly delegated the power to tax. The court noted that although a complicated formula determined the actual amount the town must raise, the library trustees controlled the end result and thus effectively set the tax rate for the town. Thus, there was a delegation of taxing power to the library district. The state legislature has the sole power to tax. N.Y. Const. art. III, § 1; art. XVI, § 1. This power could be delegated to legislative bodies of municipalities and quasi-municipal corporations, but not to administrative agencies or other governmental departments. Special library districts are most like public improvement districts. Their function is to provide a mechanism for creating and funding library systems similar to those authorized under N.Y. Educ. Law, and thus special library districts could not be created as full-blown independent governmental units.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the appellate division. The court granted judgment declaring that the statute was unconstitutional and that the town was not under a legal duty to pay to the library district the 1991 budget contribution computed pursuant to the statute.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Delegation of Taxing Power to Special Library District

Laws of 1987 (ch 524), which created the Greater Poughkeepsie Library District and requires the City of Poughkeepsie and the Town of Poughkeepsie to levy a tax to fund the Library District in an amount fixed by the trustees of the Library District, improperly delegates the power to tax (NY Const, art III, § 1; art XVI, § 1) and is, therefore, violative of the State Constitution. There is a delegation of taxing power to the Library District because the library trustees control two of the three variables that dictate the amount of the Library District's budget that the Town must fund; thus, the library trustees effectively set the tax rate for the Town. Although the taxing power may be delegated to legislative bodies of municipalities and quasi-municipal corporations, it may not be delegated to administrative agencies or other governmental departments. The function of special library districts is to provide a mechanism for creating and funding library systems; they cannot be created as full-blown independent governmental units and are properly viewed as administrative departments. Moreover, the statute at issue contains none of the hallmarks of accountability associated with the power to tax and is, therefore, contrary to the policy that underlies the taxation power: broad discretion granted to the Legislature, moderated by accountability to the electorate.

 

116 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Grumet v. Board of Educ.


No. 120


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


81 N.Y.2d 518; 618 N.E.2d 94; 601 N.Y.S.2d 61; 1993 N.Y. LEXIS 1866


April 29, 1993, Argued  
July 6, 1993, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, boards of education and state officials, appealed the judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department, which affirmed the summary judgment for plaintiff citizen taxpayers in their action to have Laws of 1989 ch. 748 declared unconstitutional. Defendants contended that the statute, which created a separate school district for a religious community, did not violate the Establishment Clause.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff citizen taxpayers brought an action against defendants, boards of education and state officials, challenging the enactment of Laws of 1989 ch. 748. Plaintiffs alleged that the statute, which established a separate public school district in and for a religious community, violated the Establishment Clause of U.S. Const. amend. I. The lower court granted summary judgment for plaintiffs on state and federal constitutional grounds. On appeal, the court modified and affirmed the judgment for plaintiffs on federal constitutional grounds only. The court held that the statute violated the second prong of the Lemon test because its principal effect was to advance religion. The court found that the statute conveyed a message of government endorsement of religion because it authorized a religious community to dictate where secular public educational services should be provided to the children of the community and created a type of symbolic impact. The court determined that only children of that religious community would attend the public schools in the newly established district and that only members of that religious community would likely serve on the school board.


OUTCOME: The court modified and affirmed the summary judgment for plaintiff citizen taxpayers. A statute that established a separate public school district for a religious community violated the Establishment Clause because its primary effect was to advance religion. The statute authorized a religious community to dictate where secular public educational services would be provided to the children of the community and created a type of symbolic impact.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Establishment of Religion - Establishment of Public School District in and for Village Mainly Composed of Members of One Religious Sect

Laws of 1989 (ch 748), which established a separate public school district in and for the Village of Kiryas Joel, composed almost entirely of members of the Satmarer Hasidic sect, violates the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment of the Federal Constitution. The statute violates the second prong of the three-part test articulated by the United States Supreme Court in Lemon v Kurtzman (403 US 602) for evaluating the constitutionality of governmental actions under the Establishment Clause, which requires that the principal or primary effect of legislation be one that neither advances nor inhibits religion. The symbolic union of church and State effected by the establishment of the Kiryas Joel Village School District under Laws of 1989 (ch 748) is sufficiently likely to be perceived by the Satmarer Hasidim as an endorsement of their religious choices, or by nonadherents as a disapproval of their individual religious choices. Thus, the principal or primary effect of the statute is to advance religious beliefs.

 

117 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Board of Educ. of Community Sch. Dist. No. 29 v. Fernandez


No. 128


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


81 N.Y.2d 508; 618 N.E.2d 89; 601 N.Y.S.2d 56; 1993 N.Y. LEXIS 1741


May 5, 1993, Argued  
June 15, 1993, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner community school board sought a judgment against city school district chancellor, arguing that the chancellor's "special circular" requiring chancellor approval of community board's superintendent was invalid and unenforceable. The trial court granted the relief sought, but the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York) reversed the trial court, concluding that the circular was within the chancellor's powers.


OVERVIEW: The court interpreted N.Y. Educ. Law § 2590-e to require community school boards to exercise their enumerated powers and duties consistently with the policies established by the central city school board. The preamble to § 2590-e provided that the powers of the community boards are made subject generally to the policies established by the city board. Further, the immediate predecessor to § 2590-e (1) required that superintendent hiring be in accordance with rules and regulations to be promulgated by the board of education. Therefore, the community boards' hiring practices were required to conform to the city board's policies.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appeals court, which had reversed the trial court's decision, and concluded that the circular was enforceable.


HEADNOTES

Schools - Administrative Personnel - Validity of Community Superintendent Selection Process Established by New York City's Public Schools Chancellor

The superintendent selection process established by New York City's public schools chancellor (Special Circular No. 37) does not impermissibly interfere with the statutory power of local community schools to employ a community superintendent. Special Circular No. 37 requires each community school board to develop, and approve at a public meeting, the procedure by which its superintendent will be selected, requires each board to prepare and submit to the chancellor a comprehensive evaluation of each finalist measured against detailed educational, managerial and administrative criteria set forth in the circular, for the chancellor's assessment of the selection process and the issuance of appropriate directives, and requires that, if the board is considering renewal of an incumbent superintendent's contract, a summary of the district's parents' views be submitted to the chancellor in addition to the board's evaluation. As a matter of statutory interpretation the community boards' hiring practices must conform to the city board's policies (see, Education Law § 2590-e). Although a policy that eviscerates a community board's enumerated power to hire a superintendent would not comport with legislative intent underlying the Decentralization Law (Education Law art 52-A), and particular vigilance must be paid to assuring sufficient autonomy by community boards in this respect, neither the concept nor the specific terms of Special Circular No. 37 significantly intrude upon the community boards' power to employ a superintendent.

 

118 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Leirer v. Caputo


No. 130


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


81 N.Y.2d 455; 616 N.E.2d 147; 599 N.Y.S.2d 792; 1993 N.Y. LEXIS 1724


May 5, 1993, Argued  
June 15, 1993, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner employee filed a N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 proceeding against respondent comptroller, alleging that the comptroller improperly withheld money from each of her paychecks as a method of recouping wages paid to her when, allegedly, she was not on the job. The trial court entered judgment in part in the employee's favor, and the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) reversed. The employee appealed.


OVERVIEW: The issues on appeal were whether the comptroller was invested by statute or common-law right or both with a unilateral wages recoupment power and whether statutory or common-law procedural safeguards in the exertion of such power were met. The court held that while the comptroller had broad and important powers, the procedure he used in this matter was seriously flawed in that no tribunal was convened, no witnesses were sworn, no testimony was taken by anyone, no arbitration was conducted, and no contract was relied upon. Furthermore, the procedure suffered from the absence of any judicial action or legislative approval, and the comptroller sought none. The court held also that the Suffolk County Charter offered no authority for the comptroller's unilateral action in the case. The court concluded that statutory and common-law recoupment powers of the comptroller did not extend to the unilateral design and execution of a wage withholding regime to recoup purported salary overpayments under circumstances such as these when the basis for and amounts of the overpayments were never reduced to an established debt and when the county charter procedural rubrics had been ignored.


OUTCOME: The court reversed, with costs, and granted judgment for the employee in accordance with the opinion.


HEADNOTES

Counties - Comptroller - Power to Recoup Salary Overpayment from Wages of County Employee

The statutory and common-law recoupment powers of the Suffolk County Comptroller do not extend to the unilateral design and execution of a wage withholding regime to recoup purported salary overpayments when the basis for and amounts of the overpayments were never reduced to an established debt and when County Charter procedural rubrics have been ignored or bypassed. Thus, respondent Suffolk County Comptroller was not authorized to unilaterally withhold 10% from each of petitioner County employee's current paychecks as a method of recouping wages estimated by the Comptroller's audit to have been paid to petitioner when, allegedly, she was not on the job. Simply "deeming" or estimating the amount of an alleged past debt by a unilateral audit and ukase is unwarranted. That petitioner was afforded the opportunity to submit evidence of her work attendance to the Comptroller and attended conferences with and submitted documentation to him in an attempt to resolve the matter prior to the issuance of the disputed audit does not constitute the establishment of a genuine debt or provide sufficient procedural protection before allowing the Comptroller to unilaterally initiate this recoupment remedy. Moreover, the Suffolk County Charter offers no authority for the Comptroller's unilateral recoupment actions in this case; rather, the County Charter specifies a different regimen for the use of audits, which was not followed.

 

119 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Milhelm Attea & Bros. v. Department of Taxation & Fin.


No. 112


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


81 N.Y.2d 417; 615 N.E.2d 994; 599 N.Y.S.2d 510; 1993 N.Y. LEXIS 1736


April 28, 1993, Argued  
June 10, 1993, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff cigarette wholesalers sought review from an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which had been remanded down and which reversed a lower court's order and summary judgment to the wholesalers in favor of the state tax department in an action regarding the taxation of the wholesaler's sale of cigarettes to Indians on Indian reservations under N.Y. Tax Law § 471(1).


OVERVIEW: The court reviewed the regulations which regulated the sale of unstamped cigarettes to retailers on Indian reservations, which were enacted in an effort to decrease the purchase of unstamped cigarettes by non-Indians. The trial court had initially granted the wholesalers' motion for summary judgment, which was initially affirmed. However, further appeal resulted in a remand and the appellate court reversed its decision, holding that the "minimal burdens" imposed upon Indian traders by New York's tax scheme were not barred by federal preemption. Again on appeal, the court reversed the appellate division's remanded decision. The court held that Congress had fully preempted the field of regulating Indian traders, and that the state laws which imposed additional burdens were barred. The court noted that the tax regulations at issue here imposed significant burdens on the wholesalers, and that they impinged on the federal interest by regulating trade with Indians to a significant degree. As such, the court concluded that they were barred by federal preemption and could not be applied to cigarette wholesalers involved in trading with Indians on reservations.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the appellate division and granted judgment to the cigarette wholesalers in their action against the state tax department regarding the federal preemption of state taxation of sales to Indians.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - Tax on Cigarettes and Tobacco Products - Sales to Indians - Federal Preemption

Tax regulations applicable to cigarette sales made on Indian reservations located in New York State, which dictate to Indian traders the number of unstamped cigarettes they can sell to reservation Indians, direct with whom they may trade, require wholesale distributors to prepay taxes on all cigarettes delivered on the reservations in excess of the predetermined maximum amount and, with respect to those cigarettes, impose a sales tax on Indian retailers (see, 20 NYCRR 335.6, 335.7 [now 336.6, 336.7]), are barred by Federal preemption. Although the challenged regulations are designed to prevent the avoidance of State taxes by non-Indians who purchase untaxed cigarettes from Indian retailers, and the incidence of the sales tax is intended to be borne by the ultimate non-Indian consumer, the tax provisions nevertheless regulate, to a significant degree, trade between wholesale distributors and their Indian purchasers, an area preempted by Federal law. Accordingly, the tax regulations cannot be applied to cigarette wholesale dealers involved in trading with Indians on reservations located in New York State.

 

120 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Schulz v. State


No. 43, No. 44


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


81 N.Y.2d 336; 615 N.E.2d 953; 599 N.Y.S.2d 469; 1993 N.Y. LEXIS 1172


February 9, 1993, Argued  
May 11, 1993, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In two separate actions, appellant citizens sought review of a judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which reversed an order of the supreme court holding that the citizens did not have standing to challenge 1990 N.Y. Laws 190, 220.


OVERVIEW: Citizens challenged state financing schemes embodied in 1990 N.Y. Laws 190 (Act). In a separate action, citizens sought to invalidate various sections of chapter 220 of the Act establishing a local government assistance corporation for the issuance of bonds. The supreme court and the appellate division dismissed both proceedings for a lack of standing. On appeal, the court held that the citizens in the first action had standing because they expressly asserted a claim to standing as voters in their primary pleading. However, the equitable doctrine of laches applied, thereby barring the action, because the effect of the citizens' delay in challenging the legislation prejudiced the city. With respect to the second action, the court held that the citizens did not have standing to sue because they did not assert standing as voters in their primary proceeding, and therefore, a substantial constitutional question was not directly involved.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order in the first appeal and dismissed the second appeal.


HEADNOTES

Parties - Standing - Constitutional Voter Standing to Challenge Debt-Incurring Legislation 

1. Plaintiffs, a group of citizens, have standing on a constitutional voter basis to challenge sections of Laws of 1990 (ch 190) which deal with the extension of State credit and long-term debt without voter approval, because the express voter referendum requirement to incur debt contained in NY Constitution, article VII, § 11 is inextricably linked to the constitutional grant of debt-incurring authority. To the extent that Wein v Comptroller of State of N. Y. (46 NY2d 394), New York State Coalition for Criminal Justice v Coughlin (64 NY2d 660) and State Finance Law § 123-b have been read as a total ban on standing in cases involving challenges to the issuance of bonds or bond anticipation notes, they should not be followed, at least with respect to voter standing to sue on financing schemes subject to voter referendum approval.

Equity - Laches - Action Challenging Constitutionality of Debt-Incurring Legislation 

2. Although plaintiffs, a group of citizens, have constitutional voter standing to challenge sections of Laws of 1990 (ch 190) which deal with the extension of State credit and long-term debt without voter approval, their proceeding is nevertheless barred because the commencement of the litigation does not satisfy the equitable laches doctrine in the particular context and circumstances of the case. The challenged legislation was signed into law on May 25, 1990, and plaintiffs' proceeding was not commenced until April 29, 1991. During that time, in reliance on the presumed constitutionality and regularity of chapter 190, a total of $ 377,326,674 in bonds were issued and sold to investors, the sales of State properties contemplated by the legislation were completed, various other nonbond transactions were also carried out, and proceeds of $ 200 million and $ 20 million, respectively, were deposited in the Capital Projects Fund and General Fund. The time periods involved here do not meet the threshold test for avoiding application of the laches doctrine in light of the great prejudice certain to be inflicted on the State and its citizens at large when financial transactions of such magnitude and destabilizing impact are at stake and may be upset.

Appeal - Court of Appeals - Appeal as of Right - Substantial Constitutional Question - Failure to Assert Constitutional Voter Standing in Challenge to Bond Issue Legislation 

3. Where both Supreme Court and the Appellate Division dismissed, for lack of standing, a proceeding seeking to invalidate various sections of Laws of 1990 (ch 220) which establish the New York Local Government Assistance Corporation for the issuance of $ 4.7 billion in bonds, plaintiffs' appeal to the Court of Appeals from the Appellate Division order is dismissed on the ground that no substantial constitutional question is presented since plaintiffs did not expressly allege voter standing in the underlying proceeding. Moreover, a motion for leave to appeal made at oral argument is denied.

 

121 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Williams


No. 89, No. 90, No. 91


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


81 N.Y.2d 303; 614 N.E.2d 730; 598 N.Y.S.2d 167; 1993 N.Y. LEXIS 1176


March 25, 1993, Argued  
May 11, 1993, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed state court conviction of multiple counts of rape in the first degree, N.Y. Penal Law § 130.35, and sodomy in the first degree, N.Y. Penal Law § 130.50, alleging error applying the rape shield law, N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 60.42, and in failing to adequately instruct jury defense of mistake.


OVERVIEW: Defendants challenged evidentiary rulings of the trial court. The court found that the record supplied a sufficient analysis of the rape shield law's interests of justice exception for statutory and constitutional validity. While the offer of proof and judicial explanation of why the shield law barred the introduction of he evidence were very limited, defense counsel had a fair opportunity to describe the proposed evidence, but they failed to explain its relevance. The court adequately gave notice as to why the evidence was disallowed. Counsel failed to show the probative value of the evidence sought to be admitted. The prosecution did not fail to satisfy its burden of showing that the victim did not consent to the sex acts because defendants alleged coercive acts created an inference that the sexual contact was forcible. The crime was a general intent crime, and the court found the instructions given adequately covered the defense theory regarding mistake of fact.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the conviction.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Evidence - "Rape Shield Law" - Interest of Justice Exception - Adequacy of Procedure Employed in Rejecting Offer of Proof

1. In the prosecution of defendants for rape and sodomy, the trial court, in applying the "rape shield law" (CPL 60.42) to deny defendants' application to introduce evidence purportedly showing that the victim had previously engaged in group sex, did not deny them their minimal statutory right under CPL 60.42 (5) to make an offer of proof, where defense counsel was twice given an opportunity to summarize the proposed evidence and explain its relevance without restriction by the court, and, after doing so and asking the court to rule, the court rejected the offer of proof and gave an explanation for its ruling. CPL 60.42 (5) requires only that the trial court hear an "offer of proof" and provide a statement of its findings of fact essential to its determination, and both procedural requirements were met here. Although the court might better have commented on the specific proffer and explained why the "interest of justice" exception was inapplicable under the circumstances of the case, its statement adequately put defendants on notice of its reasoning and created a record for appeal.

Crimes - Evidence - "Rape Shield Law" - Due Process of Law - Federal Constitutional Rights to Present Evidence and Cross-Examine Witnesses

2. In the prosecution of defendants for rape and sodomy, the proceedings underlying the trial court's application of the "rape shield law" (CPL 60.42) to deny their application to introduce evidence purportedly showing that the victim had previously engaged in group sex, were not so limited that they violated due process and arbitrarily deprived defendants of their Federal constitutional rights to present evidence and cross-examine witnesses in their own defense. The burden for making a threshold showing of relevance rested on the defense as the moving party. There is nothing arbitrary about a trial court requiring a sensible proffer as part of a motion under CPL 60.42 and refusing to proceed to a more elaborate airing of the evidence in the absence of one. Here, counsel gave no explanation of why the evidence was probative, and the Constitution does not compel a court to proceed to a fuller consideration of the evidence until the proponent demonstrates some basis for its admission.

Crimes - Evidence - "Rape Shield Law" - Reconsideration of Ruling Rejecting Evidence

3. In the prosecution of defendants for rape and sodomy, the trial court was not required to reverse its determination under the "rape shield law" (CPL 60.42) denying defendants' application to introduce evidence purportedly showing that the victim had previously engaged in group sex, on the basis of a single remark from the People's summation which, for the first time on appeal to the Court of Appeals, defendants assert gave rise to a new theory of relevance for the evidence that previously was ruled inadmissible. Defendants do not even allege that their alternate theory of relevance became apparent during either their case or the People's, the remark passed without objection or request for relief by defendants, and the new theory of admissibility remains unclear, even with the advantage of hindsight unavailable to the Trial Judge. The trial court did not act arbitrarily when, in the absence of an objection, it failed to discern a nascent due process or Sixth Amendment violation in a rhetorical question contained in the People's summation.

Crimes - Instructions - Rape in First Degree - Sodomy in First Degree - Intent - Mistake of Fact

4. In the prosecution of defendants for rape in the first degree and sodomy in the first degree, where the jury was instructed that the "final element [the People must prove] is that the lack of [complainant's] consent resulted from the use of forcible compulsion [which] means to compel by either use of physical force, or a threat, express or implied, which places a person in fear of immediate death or physical injury to herself", the trial court did not commit reversible error in refusing to instruct the jury specifically on the mistake of fact defense and on intent as an element of first degree rape and sodomy. The defense theory was that the jury could reasonably have found from the evidence adduced at trial that defendants' mistaken belief as to complainant's consent to sexual relations negated the intent necessary for a finding of guilt on the various counts, i.e., the intent to forcibly compel another to engage in intercourse or sodomy. Manifestly, it is unnecessary to forcibly compel another to engage in sexual acts unless that person is an unwilling participant and, therefore, the jury by finding that defendants used forcible compulsion to coerce the victim to engage in sodomy and intercourse, necessarily found that defendants believed the victim did not consent. Thus, the instructions given covered the defense theory, and the court did not commit reversible error in declining to give additional instructions on mens rea or mistake of fact.

 

122 of 992 DOCUMENTS


King v. Cuomo


No. 78


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


81 N.Y.2d 247; 613 N.E.2d 950; 597 N.Y.S.2d 918; 1993 N.Y. LEXIS 1166


March 23, 1993, Argued  
May 6, 1993, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, with costs, and judgment granted in accordance with the opinion herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant citizens sought review of an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed the grant of a motion by respondent state to dismiss the complaint in a proceeding challenging the constitutionality of the bicameral recall procedure used by the legislature to reacquire an assembly bill from the governor's desk.


OVERVIEW: By long standing practice, if the state legislature desired to retrieve from the governor a bill it had passed, the legislature simply asked and the governor complied. Assembly Bill No. 9592-A, was such a case. It was passed by the legislature and sent to the governor. The next day the legislature requested that the governor return the bill. The bill was returned on the same day. The citizens brought a combined N.Y. C.P.L.R. § 78 and declaratory judgment action seeking a ruling that the method used by the legislature to retrieve the passed bill was unconstitutional, and that the passed bill automatically became law because the governor failed to act on it within 10 days of its delivery to his desk. The trial court dismissed the action and the appellate court modified to declare the recall practice constitutional. The court found the description in the constitution of the process to be a model of civic simplicity, either approval, rejection by veto, or approval by inaction. The court found the long-standing recall practice had little more than time and expediency to sustain it. The court found the practice unconstitutional, but gave it prospective application only.


OUTCOME: The court found that to permit the legislature to use its general rule-making powers, pertaining to in-house procedures, to create this substantive authority was untenable and undermined the integrity of the law-making process, as well as the underlying rationale for the demarcation of authority and power in this process. The court reversed the lower court's decision.


HEADNOTES

Legislature - Recall Procedure - Return of Bill to Legislature Following Delivery to Governor - Constitutionality of Bicameral Recall Practice

1. The bicameral recall practice used by the Legislature to reacquire passed bills which have formally been sent to the Governor is unconstitutional. New York Constitution, article IV, § 7 expressly creates three routes by which a passed bill may become a law by gubernatorial action or inaction or be rejected by veto. Since the putative authority of the Legislature to recall a passed bill once it has been formally transmitted to the Governor is not found in the Constitution, the bicameral recall practice is not allowed under the Constitution. The recall practice undermines the integrity of the law-making process as well as the underlying rationale for the demarcation of authority and power in this process. Requiring that the Legislature adhere to the constitutional mandate ensures that the central law-making function remains reliable, consistent and exposed to civic scrutiny and involvement.

Courts - Justiciable Questions - Bicameral Recall Practice Authorized by Internal Rules of Senate and Assembly

2. The Judicial Branch may review the question whether the bicameral recall practice, by which the Legislature reacquires passed bills which have formally been sent to the Governor, is constitutional under NY Constitution, article IV, § 7, which prescribes how a bill becomes a law and explicitly allocates the distribution of authority and powers between the Executive and Legislative Branches. The courts do not trespass into the wholly internal affairs of the Legislature when they review and enforce a clear and unambiguous constitutional regimen of this nature. The internal rules of the Assembly and the Senate, which reflect and even purport to create the recall practice, are entitled to respect but cannot immunize or withdraw the subsisting question of constitutional law-making power from judicial review.

Constitutional Law - Prospective Effect of Declaration of Unconstitutionality - Bicameral Recall Practice

3. In a combined CPLR article 78 proceeding and declaratory judgment action wherein the Court of Appeals held unconstitutional the bicameral recall practice by which the Legislature reacquired Assembly Bill No. 9592-A of 1990 that had been passed and formally sent to the Governor, an order compelling the Secretary of State to execute a certificate that Assembly Bill No. 9592-A became law on or about July 30, 1990, because the Governor failed to act on it within 10 days of its delivery to his desk on July 19, 1990 is not warranted. The recall practice has been in operation for over a century. It is impossible to calculate how many, and which, bills would be affected by a ritualistic approach to the relief related to the Court's declaration that the recall practice is not constitutionally authorized. In addition, despite the mitigation from the short four-month Statute of Limitations (CPLR 217), a retroactive ruling, or even a ruling with resuscitative effect, in the instant case would cause profoundly uncertain effects in particular and unwarranted disorder and confusion. Thus, the bicameral recall practice should be declared unconstitutional prospectively from May 6, 1993, the date of the Court of Appeals decision, forward.

 

123 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Boyd v. Constantine


No. 45


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


81 N.Y.2d 189; 613 N.E.2d 511; 597 N.Y.S.2d 605; 1993 N.Y. LEXIS 697


February 9, 1993, Argued  
April 8, 1993, Decided



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, the judgment of the Appellate Division should be reversed, with costs, respondent's determination reinstated, and the petition dismissed. Judgment reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant sought review of an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department, New York, which annulled a disciplinary determination for drug possession against appellee.


OVERVIEW: Drugs were found by city police officers in a vehicle pursuant to an unlawful search. Therefore, the drugs were excluded at the criminal trial of defendant, a state police officer. The disciplinary administrative dismissal from the state police force was reversed due to the admission of the drug evidence at the disciplinary proceeding. The court reinstated defendant's dismissal. The court held the city police officers were not agents of the state police. Therefore, the court held the state police department did not rely upon the unlawful and unconstitutional acts of its agents in using the evidence at a hearing seeking to discipline defendant for the unlawful possession of drugs.


OUTCOME: The court reversed and reinstated defendant's administrative dismissal because drug evidence was properly admitted at the disciplinary proceeding.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service - Police - Discipline of Police - Applicability of Exclusionary Rule in Disciplinary Proceeding against State Trooper

1. Evidence consisting of a quantity of marihuana that was the product of an unlawful search by the Buffalo City Police, and was suppressed in a criminal prosecution of petitioner, a State Trooper, may be used in an administrative disciplinary proceeding commenced against petitioner by the Division of State Police. The application and scope of the exclusionary rule is ascertained by balancing the foreseeable deterrent effect against the adverse impact of suppression upon the truth-finding process. Here, the benefit to be gained from precluding police officers, who unlawfully possess controlled substances from making arrests--including arrests for drug-related offenses--clearly outweighs any deterrent effect that may arise from applying the exclusionary rule to preclude evidence unlawfully obtained by Buffalo City police officers and sought to be admitted by the Division of State Police in an administrative disciplinary proceeding. Moreover, since nothing in the record indicates that the Buffalo City Police were acting as agents of the Division of State Police, it cannot be said that the Division of State Police, in seeking to discipline petitioner for unlawful possession of marihuana, relied upon the unlawful and unconstitutional acts of its agents.

Civil Service - Police - Discipline of Police - Substantial Evidence

2. A disciplinary determination that petitioner State Trooper knowingly possessed marihuana is supported by substantial evidence where a quantity of marihuana was seized from the console of an automobile in which petitioner and another man had been seated. Substantial evidence means such relevant proof as a reasonable mind may accept as adequate to support a conclusion or ultimate fact. The presence of a controlled substance in an automobile is presumptive evidence of knowing possession thereof by each and every person in the automobile at the time such controlled substance was found (Penal Law § 220.25 [1]).

Civil Service - Police - Discipline of Police - Propriety of Penalty of Dismissal

3. The penalty of dismissal imposed upon petitioner, a State Trooper who was found to have knowingly possessed marihuana, is not so disproportionate to the offense, in light of all the circumstances, as to be shocking to one's sense of fairness.

 

124 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Cooney v. Osgood Mach., Inc.


No. 74


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


81 N.Y.2d 66; 612 N.E.2d 277; 595 N.Y.S.2d 919; 1993 N.Y. LEXIS 615; CCH Prod. Liab. Rep. P13,497


February 18, 1993, Argued  
March 25, 1993, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff employee brought a products liability action against defendant seller. The seller brought a third-party action against third-party defendants, employer, manufacturer, and a company. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York), held that under Missouri law, the employer was not liable to the seller. The seller appealed that judgment.


OVERVIEW: The employee was injured in Missouri while cleaning a machine built by the manufacturer. He received worker's compensation benefits from the employer, and under Missouri law, that precluded the employer from any other liability to any other person. The employee brought an action against the seller of the machine in New York. The seller brought a third-party action against the employer, manufacturer, and a company to seek contribution for any liability. Missouri law did not allow a contribution claim against the employer, but New York law did. The court found that Missouri law applied because although the interests of the respective jurisdictions were irreconcilable, the accident occurred in Missouri, and unavailability of contribution more closely comported with the reasonable expectations of both parties in conducting their business affairs. The court also found that the public policy exception that allowed a court to refuse to enforce a foreign law that was against public policy was inapplicable to the instant case because the seller had not sustained its heavy burden of proving that the Missouri statute was offensive to New York's public policy.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the lower court in favor of the employer because although the interests of the respective jurisdictions were irreconcilable, the accident occurred in Missouri, and unavailability of contribution more closely comported with the reasonable expectations of both parties in conducting their business affairs.


HEADNOTES

Conflict of Laws - Law Governing Tort Actions - Interest Analysis - Missouri Law Barring Contribution Claim against Employer

1. In a products liability action against defendant, the initial sales agent of a machine, arising from injuries sustained by plaintiff employee, a Missouri resident, while he was cleaning the subject machine at his employer's Missouri plant, a Missouri workers' compensation statute barring contribution claims against an employer--which conflicts with New York law permitting such claims--should be given effect in a third-party action pending in New York in which defendant, a New York domiciliary, seeks contribution from plaintiff's employer, a Missouri domiciliary. Although the interests of the respective jurisdictions underlying these loss allocating statutes are irreconcilable, Missouri law should apply because the accident occurred in Missouri, and the unavailability of contribution would more closely comport with the reasonable expectations of both parties in conducting their business affairs.

Conflict of Laws - What Law Governs - Sufficiency of Contacts to Support Application of State Law - Full Faith and Credit - Due Process of Law

2. In a products liability action against defendant, the initial sales agent for the machine that injured plaintiff, a Missouri resident, while he was cleaning the machine at the Missouri plant where he was employed, application of New York law on the issue whether a contribution claim by the sales agent against plaintiff's employer is barred would not violate the Full Faith and Credit and Due Process Clauses of the Constitution (US Const, art IV, § 1; 14th Amend, § 1) since New York has, in the aggregate, sufficient contacts with the case. Defendant has alleged that plaintiff's employer has a substantial presence in New York, and there is indication in the record that the employer does business in New York. Additionally, defendant, which seeks contribution under New York law, is a domiciliary of New York. Moreover, defendant's alleged tortious conduct with respect to the machine arose in New York, where the machine was ordered, operated for several years, and eventually shipped out-of-State.

Conflict of Laws - What Law Governs - Public Policy Exception

3. New York's interest in a case involving a New York domiciliary, who may be cast in liability by the effect of the Missouri workers' compensation statute which, contrary to New York law, bars contribution claims against employers, is sufficient to warrant scrutiny under the public policy exception pursuant to which a court may refuse to enforce an otherwise applicable foreign law when it would violate some fundamental principle of justice, some prevalent conception of good morals, some deep-rooted tradition of the common weal.

Conflict of Laws - What Law Governs - Public Policy Exception - New York Public Policy Not Bar to Application of Missouri Statute Prohibiting Contribution Claim against Employer

4. New York's public policy permitting contribution claims against an employer does not preclude application of the Missouri workers' compensation statute, which bars contribution claims against an employer, in a third-party action pending in New York in which defendant, a New York domiciliary, seeks contribution from plaintiff's employer, a Missouri domiciliary, in connection with an underlying products liability action. Under the public policy exception, when otherwise applicable foreign law would violate some fundamental principle of justice, some prevalent conception of good morals, some deep-rooted tradition of the common weal, the court may refuse to enforce it. In this case, contribution is not a deeply rooted tradition of the common weal, having been introduced into New York law only relatively recently. Moreover, availability of contribution is not invariably guaranteed. Although defendant claims that being forced to pay more than its equitable share of plaintiff's damages is unfair, public policy is not measured by individual notions of expediency and fairness or by a showing that the foreign law is unreasonable or unwise. Thus, defendant has not sustained its heavy burden of proving that the Missouri statute is offensive to New York's public policy.

 

125 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Castillo


No. 249


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


80 N.Y.2d 578; 607 N.E.2d 1050; 592 N.Y.S.2d 945; 1992 N.Y. LEXIS 4243


October 16, 1992, Argued  
December 22, 1992, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed a judgment convicting defendant of criminal possession of a controlled substance and criminal possession of a weapon.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of criminal possession of a controlled substance in the second degree and criminal possession of a weapon in the fourth degree. The inculpating evidence was discovered after police executed a warrant, issued upon information supplied by a confidential informant, authorizing a search of defendant's apartment. After his arrest, defendant sought to inspect the warrant and the supporting documents and requested a hearing to challenge the issuing judge's determination that probable cause for the search existed. The court denied discovery and, following an in camera suppression hearing, denied the motion to suppress. Defendant argued that a suppression procedure conducted without his participation violated his constitutional rights to due process of law and the effective assistance of counsel. The order was affirmed on appeal, because defendant's opportunity to participate in the suppression proceeding yielded to the need for confidentiality, to protect the informant's identity. Moreover, there was reliable evidence of probable cause to support the issuance of the warrant.


OUTCOME: The order affirming the conviction of defendant was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Search Warrant - Confidential Informant - Propriety of Conducting Suppression Procedure without Participation of Defendant

Where defendant moved to suppress evidence seized pursuant to a search warrant issued on the basis of information supplied by a confidential informant, challenging the sufficiency of the warrant application and claiming that the search was tainted because of a prior police contact, the court properly denied defendant discovery of the search warrant and its supporting documents and conducted the suppression hearing in camera without defendant's participation on the ground that disclosure of the informant's identity and/or statements could compromise the safety of the informant or the integrity of future investigations. A defendant's interest in availing himself of the exclusionary rule may, in exceptional circumstances, be subordinated to safety precautions necessary to encourage citizens to participate in law enforcement. Here, both the issuing Judge and the suppression court questioned the police officer affiant and the informant under oath, and concluded that there was probable cause for the search, that the police officer's affidavit was truthful and that there was an overriding need for confidentiality. Although defense counsel's affidavit in support of the motion to suppress also contained allegations that prior police activities tainted the search, the court found after sufficient inquiry and on sufficient evidence that there was no taint. Therefore, there is support in the record for the suppression court's findings and under the circumstances the procedures it followed did not offend due process.

 

126 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Brady v. State


No. 277


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


80 N.Y.2d 596; 607 N.E.2d 1060; 592 N.Y.S.2d 955; 1992 N.Y. LEXIS 4241


November 18, 1992, Argued  
December 22, 1992, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayers sought review, by permission, of a judgment by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed an order of the supreme court that granted a motion for summary judgment by respondent State of New York and dismissed the taxpayers' complaint challenging the constitutionality of N.Y. Tax Law §§ 601(d) and (e).


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers, couples that lived outside of New York but earned income within New York, challenged N.Y. Tax Law §§ 601(d) and (e). The tax law called for the consideration of all income, whether or not earned in New York, for computation of the proper tax rate within New York. The trial court granted summary judgment to New York and the appellate court affirmed. On review, the court noted initially that legislative enactments enjoyed a presumption of constitutionality. Additionally, the court found the law well-settled that when the state levied taxes within its authority, property not itself taxable could be used as a measure of the tax imposed on property within the state and to do so was not a tax on foreign property. Thus, states could refer to nontaxable out-of-state assets in setting their rates for taxable assets. The Privileges and Immunities Clause of the United States Constitution, designed to place the citizens, including residents of each state, upon the same footing with citizens and residents of other states, so far as the advantages resulting from citizenship in those states are concerned, was not implicated by the administration of the tax law.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court, which affirmed summary judgment for the state, with costs.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - Personal Income Tax - Constitutionality of Nonresident Tax on New York Income - Due Process of Law

1. Tax Law § 601 (d) and (e), which establish a method of determining the nonresident tax on income earned in New York State whereby New York takes into account both New York and non-New York source income in calculating the tax rate to be applied to the New York income, do not violate due process on the ground that New York is in effect impermissibly taxing out-of-State income. The subject matter here regulated is a tax on in-State income, which is within the jurisdiction of the State. When the State levies taxes within its authority, property not itself taxable can be used as a measure of the tax imposed on property within the State and to do so is in no just sense a tax on the foreign property.

Taxation - Personal Income Tax - Constitutionality of Nonresident Tax on New York Income - Privileges and Immunities - Equal Protection of Laws

2. Tax Law § 601 (d) and (e), which establish a method of determining the nonresident tax on income earned in New York State whereby New York takes into account both New York and non-New York source income in calculating the tax rate to be applied to the New York income, do not violate the Privileges and Immunities and Equal Protection Clauses since similarly situated residents and nonresidents, i.e., those with the same total income, are treated the same.

 

127 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Genesis of Mount Vernon, Inc. v. Zoning Bd. of Appeals


No. 278


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


81 N.Y.2d 741; 609 N.E.2d 122; 593 N.Y.S.2d 769; 1992 N.Y. LEXIS 4224


November 18, 1992, Argued  
December 17, 1992, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order modified, without costs, in accordance with the memorandum herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent, Zoning Board of Appeals of the City of Mount Vernon (board), challenged a decision from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which declared unconstitutional the definitions of "boarding house" and "family" in Mt. Vernon, N.Y., Zoning Ordinance § 267-2.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner, a not-for-profit corporation, proposed to build a congregate housing facility for the elderly. The facility would consist of two units in a two-family house. The board denied the corporation's application for a building permit, in part on the grounds that the proposed project would be a "boarding house." On appeal, the court modified the order and excluded that part that declared the additional definition of "family" unconstitutional because that issue was not properly before the court inasmuch as the permit application did not involve the definition of "family." As to the definition of "boarding house," the court affirmed its facial unconstitutionality and held that the definition of "boarding house" was overbroad, invited arbitrary application, and lacked a rational relationship to legitimate goals. The definition of "boarding house" was so broad that it would have encompassed even a family consisting of a father, mother, and children in a rented house or apartment and did not serve the purpose for a reduction of parking and traffic problems, control of population density, and prevention of noise and disturbance.


OUTCOME: The court modified the order by vacating the order and judgment except insofar as it declared unconstitutional the definition of "boarding house," and it remitted the matter with directions to remand to the board for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion, and, as so modified, affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations - Zoning - Constitutionality of Definition of "Boarding House"

1. The definition of "boarding house" contained in a municipal zoning ordinance which provides that there must be a building, which is not a hotel, which offers accommodations for hire or hired out, to four or more persons, individuals or as families, and which either provides separate cooking facilities or a central kitchen or dining room, is unconstitutional. Since by its own terms, the definition includes a family consisting of a father, mother and children in a rented house or apartment, and because the prohibition against a "boarding house" includes a family expressly permitted under the zoning ordinance's definition of "family", the definition of "boarding house" is overbroad, thereby inviting arbitrary application. Thus, the definition lacks a rational relationship to legitimate goals (i.e., reduction of parking and traffic problems, control of population density, prevention of noise and disturbance) and is facially unconstitutional.

Appeal - Matters Reviewable - Issue Decided Prematurely

2. In a proceeding to annul a determination of a zoning board of appeals denying petitioner's request for use and area variances, the issue of whether the zoning ordinance's definition of "family" is unconstitutional is not properly before the Court of Appeals for decision where the local building department denied petitioner's application for a building permit on the ground that the proposed use would be a prohibited "boarding house", and the zoning board of appeals rejected petitioner's argument that the building department erred in classifying the use as a "boarding house", since respondents never denied petitioner's application on the basis that the proposed project would not fall under the definition of "family." Accordingly, inasmuch as respondents did not address the "family" issue, it was premature for Supreme Court to address the constitutionality of the zoning ordinance's definition of "family"; rather, the court should have sent the case back to respondents to pass on petitioner's alternative argument since the constitutionality of statutes ought not be decided except in an actual factual setting that makes such a decision necessary.

 

128 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re Edward B.


No. 238


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


80 N.Y.2d 458; 606 N.E.2d 1353; 591 N.Y.S.2d 962; 1992 N.Y. LEXIS 4220


October 15, 1992, Argued  
December 16, 1992, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant sought review of an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court for the First Judicial Department (New York) which affirmed a family court order that adjudicated appellant a juvenile delinquent upon a finding that he committed acts which, if committed by an adult, would have constituted first degree robbery and related offenses.


OVERVIEW: Appellant was charged with committing acts that, if committed by an adult, would have constituted first degree robbery and related offenses. The charges were embodied in a juvenile delinquency petition, accompanied by a supporting deposition that the 10-year old complainant had signed under oath. During a fact-finding hearing, respondent moved for dismissal of the petition on the ground that it was legally insufficient because the complainant did not have actual knowledge of its contents. The motion was denied and the dispositional order adjudicating appellant a juvenile delinquent was affirmed on appeal. The court affirmed the order of the appellate court holding that latent deficiencies in the accusatory instrument did not provide a ground for mandatory dismissal under N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 315.1(1)(a). Neither the statutes that established the criteria for accusatory instruments in juvenile delinquency proceedings nor their underlying policies suggested that an inquiry beyond the facial validity of the petition was necessary or appropriate. As the petition was sufficient on its face under the standards set forth in N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act §§ 311.1, 311.2, it was properly denied.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the appellate court, which affirmed the adjudication of appellant as a juvenile delinquent, because the accusatory petition was sufficient on its face, and the latent deficiencies discovered at the fact-finding hearing did not provide a ground for mandatory dismissal under the Family Court Act.


HEADNOTES

Infants - Juvenile Delinquents - Sufficiency of Petition - Nonhearsay Allegations - Latent Deficiency

1. Latent deficiencies in a juvenile delinquency petition that are revealed during the trial or hearing do not provide a ground for mandatory dismissal under Family Court Act § 315.1 (1) (a). Neither the statutes establishing the criteria for accusatory instruments in juvenile delinquency proceedings nor the policies underlying those statutes suggest that an inquiry beyond the facial validity of the petition is necessary or even appropriate. Accordingly, where the juvenile delinquency petition against respondent was sufficient on its face under the standards set forth in Family Court Act § 311.1 and 311.2, but during the fact-finding hearing it was revealed that the supporting deposition was hearsay because the complainant was not made aware of its precise contents before she signed it, respondent's midhearing motion to dismiss the petition on the ground that it was jurisdictionally deficient because it was supported in relevant part only by hearsay in violation of Family Court Act § 311.2 (3) was properly denied.

Appeal - Court of Appeals - Matters Reviewable - Latent Defect in Juvenile Delinquency Petition

2. In a juvenile delinquency proceeding, respondent's argument, raised for the first time on his appeal to the Appellate Division from the dispositional order, that the capacity of the 10-year-old complainant to sign the supporting deposition under oath had not been properly established through a voir dire conducted before her signature was affixed, cannot be reviewed by the Court of Appeals. Inasmuch as the claimed defect was not apparent from the face of the accusatory instrument, it was not the kind of nonwaivable "jurisdictional flaw" that the Court of Appeals may consider even in the absence of a timely objection.

Appeal - Court of Appeals - Matters Reviewable - Latent Defect in Juvenile Delinquency Petition

3. In a juvenile delinquency proceeding, respondent's claim on his appeal from the Appellate Division order affirming Family Court's dispositional order that the supporting deposition was legally inadequate because the complainant was not made aware of its precise contents before she signed it, has not been waived and is properly before the Court of Appeals notwithstanding that respondent's contention concerns a latent rather than a facial defect since the claim was the subject of a motion to dismiss.

Infants - Juvenile Delinquents - Sufficiency of Petition - Hearsay Nature of Supporting Deposition

4. In a juvenile delinquency proceeding, the statement contained in complainant's supporting deposition which was edited and revised by the Assistant Corporation Counsel before it was transcribed, and was neither read by nor to the complainant before she signed it, constitutes hearsay. The deposition was nothing more than a statement written by a law enforcement officer reporting what he or she had been told by an eyewitness. Although the complainant signed the deposition, she had never read--nor been read--its contents, and thus she never learned what the document actually said.

 

129 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Lovelace v. Gross


No. 259


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


80 N.Y.2d 419; 605 N.E.2d 339; 590 N.Y.S.2d 852; 1992 N.Y. LEXIS 3908


October 21, 1992, Argued  
November 24, 1992, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, a putative class of infant children of minor mothers residing with the mothers' parents, appealed from an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) which affirmed the trial court's declaration that N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 131-c (2), the "grandparent-deeming" statute, was not violative of either the New York State Constitution or the U.S. Constitution.


OVERVIEW: Under N.Y. Const. art. XVII, § 1, assisting the needy was a matter of constitutional command, not legislative grace. Plaintiffs, a putative class of infant children of minor mothers residing with the mothers' parents, urged that the "grandparent-deeming rule," N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 131-c (2), was out-and-out avoidance of the Legislature's constitutional responsibility. The trial court disagreed and upheld the statute, and the appellate division affirmed. On appeal, the court concluded that the rule fell within the ambit of permissible legislative discretion in defining the term "needy." The court found that the assumption underlying the rule -- that there were economies of scale in rent, food, fuel and other expenses of a single, three-generation household -- was not unreasonable. Moreover, the rule applied to cash benefits only and was not a complete bar to public assistance in other forms, such as food stamps and Medicaid. The court determined that the Legislature exercised its discretion reasonably and that the Legislature's application of the rule was rationally related to the State's interest in assuring consistency between the AFDC and Home Relief programs.


OUTCOME: The court agreed with the trial court and the appellate division that the "grandparent-deeming" statute was valid under both State and U.S. Constitutions. Therefore, the court affirmed the judgment.


HEADNOTES

Social Services - Public Assistance - Home Relief - Constitutionality of "Grandparent-Deeming" Rule - State Constitutional Requirement to Aid Needy

1. Social Services Law § 131-c (2)--the "grandparent-deeming" rule--which requires that a portion of the income of a grandparent who resides in the same household as an infant grandchild and minor parent under the age of 18, be deemed available to the infant in determining the infant's eligibility for Home Relief payments, does not violate the State constitutional requirement for the provision of public assistance to the needy (NY Const, art XVII, § 1), since the rule falls within the ambit of permissible legislative discretion in defining the term "needy". The rule is reasonable in that its conformance to the Federal Deficit Reduction Act of 1984 avoids risk to reimbursement, inequalities in treatment among program participants, and increased administrative costs. Further, the assumption underlying the rule--that there are economies of scale in rent, food, fuel and other expenses of a single, three-generational household--is not unreasonable. Nor is the assumption that grandparents residing in a family unit with their minor children will voluntarily share income with their infant grandchildren even though not legally obligated to do so. Moreover, the grandparent-deeming rule is not a complete bar to public assistance in forms other than cash benefits, and where available income still falls below the standard of need, the infant remains eligible for assistance.

Social Services - Public Assistance - Home Relief - Constitutionality of "Grandparent-Deeming" Rule - Equal Protection of Laws - Due Process of Law

2. Social Services Law § 131-c (2)--the "grandparent-deeming" rule--which requires that a portion of the income of a grandparent who resides in the same dwelling unit as an infant grandchild and minor parent under the age of 18, be deemed available to the infant in determining the infant's eligibility for Home Relief payments, does not subject the infants of minor mothers to disparate treatment in violation of the Equal Protection and Due Process Clauses of the State and Federal Constitutions. It is entirely reasonable for the Legislature to assume that grandparents will contribute to the support of infant grandchildren residing in their household, notwithstanding the absence of a legal obligation to do so. Similarly, the fact that grandparent-deeming ceases for minor mothers between the ages of 18 and 21 parallels the reasonable assumption of Federal law that, after the mother turns 18, grandparents may be less willing to contribute to the support of their grandchildren, and will instead ask that the minor mothers assume greater responsibility for their infants. In addition, Social Services Law § 131-c (2) furthers the State's legitimate goal of allocating limited public assistance resources to the neediest applicants. Further, while the Federal Deficit Reduction Act of 1984 requires only that the rule be applied to Aid to Families with Dependent Children (AFDC), the Legislature's application of the rule to New York State benefits is rationally related to the State's interest in assuring consistency between the AFDC and Home Relief programs.

Constitutional Law - Equal Protection of Laws - Rational Basis Test

3. The rational basis test is the appropriate standard of review for a challenge under the Equal Protection and Due Process Clauses of the Federal and State Constitutions to Social Services Law § 131-c (2), which requires that a portion of the income of a grandparent who resides in the same dwelling unit as an infant grandchild and minor parent under the age of 18, be deemed available to the infant in determining the infant's eligibility for Home Relief payments, since the statute involves economic and social welfare concerns, presenting no distinctions based on race, disability or other suspect classification.

 

130 of 992 DOCUMENTS


County of Rensselaer v. Regan


No. 240


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


80 N.Y.2d 988; 607 N.E.2d 793; 592 N.Y.S.2d 646; 1992 N.Y. LEXIS 3891



November 19, 1992, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [**1] Order affirmed, with costs, in a memorandum.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant comptroller appealed an order of the appellate court (New York) that the budget provision of a state traffic program violated N.Y. Const. art. V, § 1 and that plaintiff counties had standing to challenge the provision.


OVERVIEW: The legislature enacted a special traffic options program for driving while intoxicated (STOP-DWI) whereby a participating county could receive fines and forfeitures collected by courts within that county for alcohol-related driving offenses. In an effort to defray the costs of administering the program, the legislature provided that the state comptroller should collect, withhold, and receive up to two percent of these revenues received in any court, to be deposited in the general fund. The counties sought a declaratory judgment that this provision violated N.Y. Const. art. V, § 1. The comptroller argued that the counties did not have standing because the revenues were state, not county, funds. The court of appeals held that the counties had a proprietary claim to the fines which established standing to challenge the constitutionality of the assignment of the administrative duties to the comptroller. The court found that the methodology assigned by the legislature to accomplish its purposes was unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the appellate court that the budget provision violated the New York Constitution and that the counties had standing.

 

131 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Robert O. v. Russell K.


No. 191


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


80 N.Y.2d 254; 604 N.E.2d 99; 590 N.Y.S.2d 37; 1992 N.Y. LEXIS 3478


September 16, 1992, Argued  
October 27, 1992, Decided



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, the order of the Appellate Division should be affirmed, with costs. Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant father, who was not married to the mother, filed a claim seeking to vacate the final order of adoption of his son by respondent adoptive parents. The father sought reversal of the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed an order of the family court denying the petition to vacate.


OVERVIEW: The father did not know that his ex-girlfriend was pregnant and had a baby until 10 months after the baby was adopted. The court denied the father's claim that the mother or the State had a duty to ensure he knew of the birth, and that their failure to do so denied him his constitutional rights. The court held that inasmuch as the father failed to take any steps to discover the pregnancy or the birth of the child before first asserting his parental interest 10 months after the adoption became final, he was neither entitled to notice nor was his consent to the adoption required. The court found that there was no concealment or fraud involved. The court held that promptness was measured in terms of the baby's life not by the onset of the father's awareness, and that the demand for promptness was a logical and necessary outgrowth of the state's legitimate interest in the child's need for early permanence and stability. The court held that the father's equal protection claim failed because the existence or nonexistence of a substantial relationship between parent and child was a relevant criterion in evaluating both the rights of the parent and the best interests of the child.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the lower court, with costs.


HEADNOTES

Adoption - Notice to Putative Father - Consent - Unwed Father Who is Unaware of Child's Conception or Birth - Due Process

1. Petitioner, an unwed father, who was unaware of the pregnancy or the birth of his child until nearly 18 months after the child's birth, was neither entitled to notice nor was his consent to the adoption of his child required where he failed to take any steps to discover the pregnancy or the birth of the child before first asserting his parental interest 10 months after the adoption became final (see, Domestic Relations Law § 111-a [2]; § 111 [1] [e]). In determining whether an unwed father has created a liberty interest, the timing of the father's actions is the most significant element. The biological father must promptly manifest his parental interest through action on his part; absent that, the biological link of the father is insufficient to create a constitutionally protected interest. Here, petitioner's inaction was solely attributable to him and under the circumstances he is not entitled to the protections of constitutional due process.

Adoption - Notice to Putative Father - Consent - Unwed Father Who is Unaware of Conception or Birth of Child - Equal Protection

2. Petitioner, an unwed father, who was unaware of the pregnancy or birth of his child until 10 months after the child's adoption became final was not denied equal protection because the applicable statutes (Domestic Relations Law § 111-a [2]; § 111 [1] [e]) did not require notice to one in his position or require his consent to the adoption. The Equal Protection Clause does not preclude the State from withholding the privilege of vetoing an adoption from an unwed father who has never come forward to participate in the rearing of his child. That "unknowing" unwed fathers may be treated differently under the statute than other unwed fathers is not dispositive. The equal protection inquiry focuses on whether the statute's relation to the State interests it is intended to promote is so tenuous that it lacks the rationality contemplated by the Fourteenth Amendment, and petitioner has not met the burden of showing a lack of rationality in either the notice or the consent provisions of New York law.

 

132 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Santorelli


No. 115


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


80 N.Y.2d 875; 600 N.E.2d 232; 587 N.Y.S.2d 601; 1992 N.Y. LEXIS 1609


May 5, 1992, Argued  
July 7, 1992, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed from a judgment of the Monroe County Court (New York), which overturned the city court's order of dismissal of an information charging defendants with public exposure of their breasts in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 245.01.


OVERVIEW: Defendants argued that N.Y.
