The statute has a clear secular legislative purpose -- to extend unemployment insurance coverage to previously exempt employees of nonprofit organizations, while retaining the exemption for the benefit of a range of nonprofit organizations, including religious organizations, whose employees were not active members of the work force in the true sense and whose employment was stable. Thus, religious organizations did not receive the exclusive benefit of the exemption, but only received an incidental benefit accorded to a range of other organizations. Additionally, section 563 (2) (c) minimizes governmental intrusion into religious affairs by avoiding the necessity of scrutinizing a religious group's tenets each time an employee is discharged for reasons related to the group's religious mission. Further, the statute is not aimed exclusively or specifically at religious groups or organizations, and it does not impermissibly benefit religious organizations more than nonreligious organizations. Nor does section 563 (2) (c) require unconstitutional entanglement by the State in religious matters; rather, any entanglement between church and State is minimized by the exemption found in section 563 (2) (c), thereby effectuating a more complete separation between the two.

Unemployment Insurance -- Benefits -- Constitutionality of Statutory Exclusion from Unemployment Insurance Coverage of Persons Engaged in Religious Employment -- Equal Protection of Laws

2. Labor Law § 563, which excludes from unemployment insurance coverage, among others, persons performing duties of a religious nature at a place of worship (§ 563 [2] [c]), does not establish an impermissible classification in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution, since it is reasonably related to legitimate State interests. There is no fundamental right to unemployment insurance benefits and the statute does not involve a suspect classification; therefore, to withstand an equal protection challenge the exclusion need only bear a rational relation to a legitimate government interest. The statutory classification involved here is based upon the religious nature of appellant's employment. The original purpose of the exclusions of Labor Law § 563 (2) was to extend unemployment insurance coverage to employees of certain nonprofit organizations while retaining the exemption for some organizations, including religious organizations, in accordance with the "time-honored" tradition of sparing certain tax-exempt, nonprofit organizations from the burden of general taxation. In addition, the exemption promotes the efficient administration of the unemployment insurance program by avoiding undue government involvement in problems peculiar to religious employment. Section 563 (2) (c) is rationally related to these legitimate purposes and, therefore, does not offend the Equal Protection Clause.

 

147 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Allied-Signal, Inc. v. Commissioner of Finance


No. 165


COURT OF APPEAL OF NEW YORK,


79 N.Y.2d 73; 588 N.E.2d 731; 580 N.Y.S.2d 696; 1991 N.Y. LEXIS 5153


September 4, 1991, Argued  
December 23, 1991, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant corporate shareholder sought review of a decision from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) which denied appellant's petition to annul the determination of respondent finance department that appellant owed city taxes based on dividends and capital gains appellant realized from its investment in another corporation.


OVERVIEW: Appellant corporate shareholder was a Delaware manufacturing company that was headquartered in Michigan. Appellant owned shares of a New Jersey (NJ) corporation that was domiciled in New York City (NYC). This investment was managed exclusively from appellant's Michigan offices. Appellant's only connection with NYC was that its overseas business development office was there. Respondent finance department determined that under N.Y. City Admin. Code § 11-604 appellant owed city taxes based on dividends and capital gains it realized from its shares in the NJ corporation. The trial court denied appellant's petition to have this determination annulled and this decision was affirmed by an appellate court. This court also affirmed the trial court's decision. First, despite the lack of a unitary business relationship between appellant and the company in which its held shares, there was a sufficient enough nexus between appellant and the city to support the tax. Second, the imposition of the tax was in accordance with U.S. Const. amend. XIV and art. I, § 8, cl. 3, because it fairly reflected appellant's own presence and activities in the city.


OUTCOME: The decision denying appellant corporate shareholder's petition to annul the determination of respondent finance department that appellant owed city taxes based on profits appellant realized from its investment in another corporation was affirmed. The nexus between appellant and the city was sufficient to support the tax, and the tax was constitutional because it fairly reflected appellant's limited presence within the city.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - General Corporation Tax - Constitutionality of Taxing Investment Income of Nondomiciliary Corporation Derived from Corporation Conducting Business in City of New York - Sufficiency of Nexus

1. The City of New York may tax the portion of the dividend and capital gain income that a nondomiciliary corporation receives by reason of its investment in another corporation conducting business within the City (see, Administrative Code of City of New York § 11-603) in the absence of a unitary business relationship between the two corporations without offending either the Due Process Clause (US Const 14th Amend) or the Commerce Clause (US Const, art I, § 8) of the Federal Constitution. A unitary business relationship is not the exclusive means for satisfying the requirement of the Due Process and Commerce Clauses that there be some minimal connection or nexus between the income that a nondomiciliary corporation earns and the taxing jurisdiction in order for a State or municipality to tax that income. In determining whether a sufficient nexus exists, the inquiry should focus on whether the taxing power exerted bears fiscal relation to the protection, opportunities and benefits given by the taxing jurisdiction. Here, the City has afforded privileges and opportunities to the corporation conducting business within New York which have contributed to that corporation's capital appreciation and, thus, inured to the benefit of all its shareholders, including the nondomiciliary corporation. Accordingly, the City has given the nondomiciliary corporation something "for which it can ask return" and, therefore, a sufficient nexus existed to support the City's tax.

Taxation - General Corporation Tax - Constitutionality of Taxing Investment Income of Nondomiciliary Corporation Derived from Corporation Conducting Business in City of New York - Rational Relationship between Tax and Manner in which Income Generated

2. The tax imposed by the City of New York on the portion of the dividend and capital gain income that a nondomiciliary corporation receives by reason of its investment in another corporation conducting business within the City (see, Administrative Code of City of New York § 11-603) is not unconstitutional on the ground that none of that income can be said to be related to the nondomiciliary corporation's activities in New York because it planned, effectuated and managed the investment solely from its Michigan headquarters. Since it has not been demonstrated that the City's tax on the dividend and capital gain income that the nondomiciliary corporation derived from its investment in the corporation conducting business within New York bore anything but an inherently rational relationship to the manner in which that income was generated, the tax is not unconstitutional on that basis.

 

148 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Couch v. Perales


No. 214


Court of Appeals of New York


78 N.Y.2d 595; 585 N.E.2d 772; 578 N.Y.S.2d 460; 1991 N.Y. LEXIS 4923


October 16, 1991, Argued  
November 26, 1991, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner recipient challenged a determination by the respondent Commissioner of the New York State Department of Social Services pursuant to which her family's Aid to Families with Dependent Children (AFDC) grant was reduced by 10 percent in order to recoup an overpayment previously made. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) confirmed the Commissioner's determination. The recipient appealed.


OVERVIEW: The recipient contended that 42 U.S.C.S. § 602(a)(22) and 45 C.F.R. § 233.20 (a)(13), as well as N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 106-b and N.Y. Const. art. XVII § 1 permitted the Commissioner to recoup overpayment only from her pro rata share of the AFDC grant and prohibited recoupment of the overpayment from the entire assistance unit which included her minor children, unless there had been a prior demonstration that the needs of the children had also diminished. She also claimed entitlement to attorney's fees pursuant to 42 U.S.C.S. § 1988 because the reduction in the family's AFDC benefits constituted a violation of 42 U.S.C.S. § 602(a)(22), cognizable under 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983. The court found nothing in the laws or constitution that required recoupment of an AFDC overpayment to have been made from the proportionate share of the individual recipient, rather than from the family unit. Nor was there any requirement that there must have been a prior determination that the needs of the children had diminished before such recoupment could have been made from the grant to that family unit. Thus, the court rejected the recipient's challenges and affirmed the judgment of the lower court.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the lower court, which confirmed the Commissioner's determination that reduced the recipient's AFDC grant by 10 percent in order to recoup an overpayment previously made.


HEADNOTES

Social Services -- Aid to Dependent Children -- Recoupment of Overpayments from Family Unit -- No Federal Requirement of Recoupment from Proportionate Share of Overpaid Individual or Prior Determination of Diminished Needs of Children

1. Neither 42 USC § 602 (a) (22) nor 45 CFR 233.20 (a) (13) requires that recoupment of an overpayment of Aid to Families with Dependent Children only be made from the proportionate share of the individual recipient, rather than from the grant to the family unit. Although a State is given the option to obtain the entire sum from the individual receiving the overpayment or to reduce the amount of aid payable to the family or "assistance unit" at a rate of recovery not exceeding 10% of the monthly grant, nothing in the language of the statute requires a State to recoup the overpayment from the pro rata share of the overpaid individual in the first instance. Moreover, a State is not required to demonstrate, before recouping the overpayment from the family unit, that the needs of the child or children have diminished.

Social Services -- Aid to Dependent Children -- Recoupment of Overpayments from Family Unit -- No State Constitutional Requirement of Recoupment from Proportionate Share of Overpaid Individual or Prior Determination of Diminished Needs of Children

2. NY Constitution, article XVII, § 1, which mandates that "[t]he aid, care and support of the needy are public concerns and shall be provided by the state and by such of its subdivisions, and in such manner and by such means, as the legislature may from time to time determine", does not require that recoupment of an overpayment of Aid to Families with Dependent Children only be made from the proportionate share of the individual recipient of the overpayment, rather than from the grant to the family unit, or that there must be a prior determination that the needs of the children of a family unit have diminished before such recoupment can be made from the grant to that family unit.

Social Services -- Aid to Dependent Children -- Recoupment of Overpayments from Family Unit -- No State Statutory Requirement of Recoupment from Proportionate Share of Overpaid Individual or Prior Determination of Diminished Needs of Children

3. Social Services Law § 106-b, which mandates that social services officials "take all necessary steps to correct any overpayment or underpayment to a public assistance recipient", does not require that recoupment of an overpayment of Aid to Families with Dependent Children only be made from the proportionate share of the individual recipient of the overpayment, rather than from the grant to the family unit, or that there must be a prior determination that the needs of the children of a family unit have diminished before such recoupment can be made from the grant to that family unit.

Social Services -- Aid to Dependent Children -- Recoupment of Overpayments from Family Unit -- "Undue Hardship" -- No Requirement of Prior Determination of Diminished Needs of Children

4. Social Services Law § 106-b, which provides that the Commissioner of Social Services must establish procedures for correcting overpayments of public assistance that are designed to minimize adverse impact on the recipient, and to the extent possible avoid "undue hardship", and its implementing regulation which permits a recoupment rate of only 5% in cases where it is established that a 10% rate would produce undue hardship (18 NYCRR 352.31 [d] [2]), were not violated by respondent State Commissioner of Social Services imposing a recoupment rate of 10% against petitioner's family unit to recover an overpayment of Aid to Families with Dependent Children on behalf of petitioner without having first determined that the needs of the children in the family unit have diminished. Social Services Law § 106-b does not require respondent to guarantee that there will be no undue hardship in all cases; rather, it requires that the procedures be designed to minimize adverse impact and to the extent possible avoid undue hardship. 18 NYCRR 352.31 (d) (2) is consistent with and appropriately effectuates the statutory requirement to minimize the adverse impact of such recoupment. Moreover, petitioner was provided an opportunity to establish her undue hardship claim at a fair hearing as provided by the regulation, and respondent's determination that she failed to meet her burden so as to be entitled to an application of the lower recoupment rate is supported by substantial evidence in the record.

Civil Rights -- Federal Civil Rights Claim -- Counsel Fees

5. Inasmuch as respondent State Commissioner of Social Services' recoupment of an overpayment of Aid to Families with Dependent Children (AFDC) by a temporary 10% reduction of the AFDC grant to the family unit, rather than from the proportionate share of the individual recipient, and without a prior determination that the needs of the children of the family unit have diminished, does not violate 42 USC § 602 (a) (22), petitioner is not entitled to an award of attorney's fees pursuant to 42 USC § 1988.

 

149 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Prue v. Hunt


No. 179


Court of Appeals of New York


78 N.Y.2d 364; 581 N.E.2d 1052; 575 N.Y.S.2d 806; 1991 N.Y. LEXIS 4219


September 11, 1991, Argued  
October 24, 1991, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The parties cross-appealed an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court for the Fourth Judicial Department (New York) which reversed a judgment entered in a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78(a) denying the petition to annul a determination that respondent police chief reasonably terminated petitioner police officer from his position pursuant to N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 73.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner police officer was terminated from his position pursuant to N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 73, which authorize the termination of civil servants when they have been continuously absent from and unable to perform the duties of their position for one year or more by reason of a disability. The trial court held that the termination was justified and that the opportunity for post-termination hearing satisfied the requirements of due process. The appellate court reversed on the basis of decisional caselaw, which required that discharged civil servants be afforded a pretermination hearing. The court affirmed the decision of the appellate court. Petitioner's discharge implicated contested questions regarding his physical condition and whether his ability to perform the desk job he had filled for the preceding 10 years constituted an ability "to perform the duties of his position" within the meaning of § 73. Further, his termination was within respondent's discretion. The court held that in order to meet the minimum requirements of federal due process, petitioner was entitled to some pretermination opportunity to heard in addition to the post-termination procedures required by § 73.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the reversal of the trial court's holding that a posttermination hearing satisfied the requirements of due process because in order to satisfy the minimum requirements of federal due process, a civil servant must have been given some explanation of the grounds for the dismissal and an opportunity to be heard prior to his discharge.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service -- Termination of Employment -- Ordinary Disability -- Pretermination Notice and Opportunity to be Heard

1. The Federal Due Process Clause (US Const 5th Amend) requires that termination of a civil servant under Civil Service Law § 73, which authorizes the termination and replacement of civil servants when they have been continuously absent from and unable to perform the duties of their position for one year or more by reason of a disability, be accompanied by a pretermination notice and a minimal opportunity to be heard in addition to the posttermination procedures required by section 73 and Matter of Economico v Village of Pelham (50 NY2d 120). The potential for an erroneous discharge or an inappropriate exercise of the discretion conferred under section 73 justifies the minimal burden placed on the employer in requiring that a pretermination opportunity to respond be provided to the employee.

Civil Service -- Termination of Employment -- Ordinary Disability -- Pretermination Notice and Opportunity to be Heard -- Minimum Federal Due Process Requirements

2. With respect to the pretermination hearing required prior to the discharge of a civil servant under Civil Service Law § 73, the minimum demands of Federal due process are satisfied if the employee is given an explanation of the grounds for the discharge and an opportunity to respond prior to his or her discharge.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Civil Service Law § 73

3. In view of the Court of Appeals interpretation of Civil Service Law § 73 as requiring pretermination notice and opportunity to be heard comporting with the minimum demands of the Federal Due Process Clause (US Const 5th Amend), section 73 should not be held facially unconstitutional.

 

150 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Somers


No. 162


Court of Appeals of New York


78 N.Y.2d 1058; 582 N.E.2d 597; 576 N.Y.S.2d 214; 1991 N.Y. LEXIS 4216



October 22, 1991, Decided

 

151 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Citizens for Orderly Energy Policy, Inc. v. Cuomo


Nos. 182, 183, 184


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


78 N.Y.2d 398; 582 N.E.2d 568; 576 N.Y.S.2d 185; 1991 N.Y. LEXIS 4795


September 11, 1991, Argued  
October 22, 1991, Decided



DISPOSITION: In Matter of Citizens For An Orderly Energy Policy v Cuomo: Order affirmed, with costs. In Matter of Dollard v Long  Is. Power Auth.: Judgment affirmed, with costs. In Matter of Nassau Suffolk Contr.'s Assn. v Public Serv. Commn.: Judgment affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, individuals, business groups, and interest groups, brought N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 proceedings against respondents, governor, power authority, and others, to challenge the execution and approval of a settlement agreement. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), issued judgments for the governor and others. The individuals, business groups, and interest groups challenged those judgments.


OVERVIEW: The settlement agreement at issue was entered into so that the power authority could acquire a nuclear power plant and close it. The nuclear power plant was plagued with a number of problems and it was hoped that the closure of the plant would result in lower electricity rates for customers. The Long Island Power Authority Act (Act), created the power authority to achieve the desired results of the plant's closure and lower electricity rates. The governor signed a settlement agreement that provided the power plant would be sold to the power authority. The individuals, business groups, and interest groups argued that the settlement agreement contravened the Act and that the governor, power authority, and others exceeded their statutory authority. The court found that the governor, power authority and others acted within the purpose articulated and intended by the Act, the closure and decommissioning of the power plant. The legislature wanted the power plant closed and decommissioned, and it expressly declared its legislative policy that the power authority's acquisition, closure and decommissioning of the plant would accomplish an objective of the Act.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgments from the lower court in favor of the governor, power authority and others.


HEADNOTES

Public Authorities -- Long Island Power Authority -- Validity of "Settlement Agreement" Providing for Acquisition and Closure of Shoreham Nuclear Plant

1. Respondents, the Governor and various executive agencies, did not exceed their constitutional authority or their statutory authority under the Long Island Power Authority Act (Public Authorities Law § 1020 et seq.; L 1986, ch 517) by making a "Settlement Agreement", providing essentially for the Long Island Power Authority (LIPA) to acquire the Long Island Lighting Company's (LILCO) Shoreham Nuclear Plant and to close that plant, independent of LIPA's replacement of LILCO as the provider of power on Long Island. The language of the LIPA Act and its legislative history cogently portray the Act's objectives: LIPA's acquisition and closure of Shoreham, or LIPA's takeover and replacement of LILCO as a utility provider, or both, dependent only on control of rates (see, Public Authorities Law §§ 1020-a, 1020-h). The only condition attached to LIPA's decision to acquire any or all of the assets or stock of LILCO is LIPA's determination that such acquisition would result in rates to LILCO's customers not higher than LILCO would have charged had there been no such acquisition (Public Authorities Law § 1020-h [2], [4], [10]). Once that threshold is satisfied, LIPA is empowered -- but not required -- to make any such acquisition. No provision can be found anywhere in the LIPA Act which expressly or by reasonable implication requires that LIPA must exert its full acquisition authority contemporaneously with the acquisition and decommissioning of Shoreham itself. Thus, in making the Settlement Agreement, the respondents acted within their respective constitutional and statutory authority and effected a properly delegated discretionary policy and purpose articulated and intended by the LIPA Act.

Environmental Conservation -- Environmental Quality Review -- "Ministerial Act" Exemption -- Decommissioning of Shoreham Nuclear Plant

2. A "Settlement Agreement" (the Agreement) made by respondent Governor and various executive agencies, providing essentially for the Long Island Power Authority (LIPA) to acquire the Long Island Lighting Company's (LILCO) Shoreham Nuclear Plant and to close and decommission that plant, did not violate the State Environmental Quality Review Act (ECL art 8 [SEQRA]) on the ground that respondents failed to produce Environmental Impact Statements (EIS) before making or approving the Agreement, since the decommissioning of Shoreham was a "ministerial act" expressly exempt from SEQRA (see, ECL 8-0105 [5] [ii]; 6 NYCRR 617.2 [x]). The LIPA Act declares that LIPA's acquisition of LILCO's assets or stock is not State "action" subject to SEQRA, and that SEQRA "shall not be applicable in any respect to such acquisition or any action of [LIPA] to effect such acquisition." (Public Authorities Law § 1020-s [2].) When it passed the LIPA Act, the Legislature -- inescapably aware of the inherent environmental consequences of Shoreham's shutdown -- necessarily judged for itself the propriety of closure and decommissioning and mandated such action (Public Authorities Law §§ 1020-a, 1020-h [9]). LIPA's nondiscretionary action in complying with the Legislature's mandate that Shoreham be decommissioned was a ministerial act. It was not up to LIPA to produce an EIS to evaluate the propriety of the legislative policy choice of decommissioning because, in this case, mandating SEQRA review would have the effect of overriding the Legislature's express exemption (6 NYCRR 617.2 [q] [5]).

Environmental Conservation -- Environmental Quality Review -- Decommissioning of Shoreham Nuclear Plant -- Proposed Action by Power Authority of State of New York

3. A "Settlement Agreement" made by respondent Governor and various executive agencies, providing essentially for the Long Island Power Authority (LIPA) to acquire the Long Island Lighting Company's (LILCO) Shoreham Nuclear Plant and to close and decommission that plant, did not violate the State Environmental Quality Review Act (ECL art 8 [SEQRA]) on the ground that respondent Power Authority of the State of New York (PASNY) failed to do a SEQRA review before it agreed to aid LIPA in decommissioning Shoreham and constructing alternative generating facilities for LILCO, if requested. PASNY's agreement to aid LIPA concerns proposed actions which had not reached the point at which SEQRA review is required at the time the Settlement Agreement was made. No decommissioning plan had been proposed or selected; no plans to build generating plants to replace Shoreham had been proposed or formulated; and no decision even to build such plants had been made. The subsequent selection of a specific decommissioning method has already received full environmental review, culminating in a Final Generic Environmental Impact Statement. PASNY's construction of facilities -- if ever undertaken -- will be subject to independent SEQRA review when a specific project plan is actually formulated and proposed.

 

152 of 992 DOCUMENTS


N.Y. City Dep't of Envtl. Prot. v. N.Y. City Civil Serv. Comm'n


No. 144


Court of Appeals of New York


78 N.Y.2d 318; 579 N.E.2d 1385; 574 N.Y.S.2d 664; 1991 N.Y. LEXIS 3914


June 5, 1991, Argued  
September 12, 1991, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city environmental department sought review of an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed a determination by respondent city civil service commission reversing a determination by appellant finding respondent employee guilty of misconduct and terminating his employment. Respondent commission argued that its decision was not subject to judicial review.


OVERVIEW: Respondent employee was charged with misconduct by appellant city environmental department and subsequently was dismissed from his employment. Respondent employee appealed this determination to respondent city civil service commission, which reversed the order of appellant and ordered respondent employee restored to his former position. Appellant then initiated a N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 proceeding, and the action was transferred to the lower appellate court, which confirmed respondent city civil service commission's determination. Appellant sought review, and the court affirmed, holding that judicial review was mandated when the agency acted illegally, unconstitutionally, or in excess of its jurisdiction. There was no showing that respondent civil service commission acted illegally, unconstitutionally, or in excess of its jurisdiction. N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 76 permitted certain aggrieved employees to appeal a determination in a disciplinary proceeding either to respondent civil service commission or to the courts through a N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 proceeding. If such course of action were undertaken, N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 76(3) provided that respondent commission's decision was final.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the lower appellate court upholding the determination by respondent city service commission reversing the termination of respondent employee by appellant city environmental department. Judicial review was mandated when an agency acted illegally, unconstitutionally, or in excess of its jurisdiction. There was no showing that respondent commission acted unconstitutionally, illegally, or outside of its jurisdiction.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service -- Judicial Review -- Reviewability of Civil Service Commission Decision on Appeal from Determination in Disciplinary Proceedings

1. Civil Service Law § 76, which provides that the Civil Service Commission's decision on an appeal to it by an aggrieved employee from a determination in a disciplinary proceeding "shall be final and conclusive, and not subject to review in any court" (§ 76 [3]), precludes judicial review of the merits of a determination of respondent New York City Civil Service Commission reversing the determination of petitioner New York City Department of Environmental Protection rendered in an employee disciplinary proceeding. The Legislature is permitted to restrict the availability of judicial review of administrative determinations, and the language in section 76 is clear and unambiguous in its intent to preclude judicial review of Commission decisions. Further, despite the fact that the Commission disregarded the credibility determinations of the Administrative Law Judge, there is no showing that this was unconstitutional, illegal, or outside the Commission's jurisdiction. The Commission's determination should be treated, therefore, in all respects as final and conclusive.

Administrative Law -- Judicial Review -- Standard of Review Where Judicial Review of Administrative Determinations is Statutorily Precluded

2. Although the Legislature may restrict judicial review of administrative determinations, some sort of judicial review is mandated, however explicit the Legislature's intent to preclude such review, where a constitutional right is implicated or where the agency has acted illegally, unconstitutionally, or in excess of its jurisdiction. This is an extremely narrow standard of review, and once courts have determined that an agency has not acted in excess of its authority or in violation of the Constitution or of the laws of this State, judicial review is completed.

 

153 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Dozier


No. 122


Court of Appeals of New York


78 N.Y.2d 242; 577 N.E.2d 1019; 573 N.Y.S.2d 427; 1991 N.Y. LEXIS 1009


May 29, 1991, Argued  
July 2, 1991, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state appealed a judgment from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) that modified a judgment convicting defendant of two counts of first-degree robbery and sentencing him as a second violent felony offender under N.Y. Penal Law § 70.04. The modification consisted of vacating the finding that defendant was a second violent felony offender and remanding for resentencing.


OVERVIEW: The appellate court affirmed an order that modified a judgment convicting defendant of two counts of first-degree robbery and sentencing him as a second violent felony offender under N.Y. Penal Law § 70.04. The modification consisted of vacating the finding that defendant was a second violent felony offender and remanding the matter for resentencing. The appellate court held that defendant's most recent prior conviction, which was vacated and the indictment dismissed, could not toll the 10-year limitation period of section 70.04. Therefore, because the sentence on defendant's other prior conviction was imposed more than 10 years before the current felony was committed he could not be sentenced as a second violent felony offender. According to the court, when a repeat felony offender statute provided that incarceration "for any reason" extended the limitations period, it contemplated at least that defendant had not been imprisoned without reason or unconstitutionally. Defendant's prior conviction, for rape, was vacated after new evidence revealed that the complainant had psychiatric problems. According to the appellate court, defendant was imprisoned without reason.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed an order that modified a judgment convicting defendant of two counts of first-degree robbery and sentencing him as second violent felony offender by vacating finding that defendant was a second violent felony offender and remanding the matter for resentencing. The court held that defendant's prior conviction, which was vacated and the indictment dismissed, could not toll the limitation period of violent felony offender statute.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Sentence -- Second Felony Offender -- Extension of 10-Year Limitation Period for Prior Felony Conviction -- No Exclusion for Incarceration Resulting from Flawed Conviction

For purposes of enhanced sentencing of second violent felony offenders, the 10-year limitation on the time between imposition of sentence on the prior felony and the commission of the felony on which defendant currently is being sentenced (Penal Law § 70.04 [1] [b] [iv]) is not tolled pursuant to Penal Law § 70.04 (1) (b) (v) during a period of incarceration when the conviction on which the incarceration was based was vacated for newly discovered evidence under CPL 440.10 (1) (g) and the indictment subsequently dismissed on the District Attorney's affirmation that the People would not be able to establish defendant's guilt on a new trial. Section 70.04 (1) (b) (v), which excludes from the 10-year limitation period any period of time that the defendant was incarcerated "for any reason" between the time of commission of the previous felony and the commission of the current felony, should not be literally interpreted to mean that incarceration for any reason at all other than for an unconstitutional conviction tolls the limitation period; such a position is plainly unreasonable. The statute was not intended to be employed to permit the State to extend the 10-year limitation on prior violent felonies for an unjustified period of incarceration resulting from a flawed conviction under an indictment which was ultimately dismissed.

 

154 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Association of Surrogates & Supreme Court Reporters v. State


No. 157


Court of Appeals of New York


78 N.Y.2d 143; 577 N.E.2d 10; 573 N.Y.S.2d 19; 1991 N.Y. LEXIS 999


May 30, 1991, Argued and Submitted  
June 27, 1991, Decided



DISPOSITION: Following certification of a question by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit and acceptance of the question by this Court pursuant to section 500.17 of the Rules of the Court of Appeals (22 NYCRR 500.17), and after hearing argument by counsel for the parties and consideration of the briefs and the record submitted, certified question answered in the negative.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: On a certified appeal, the United States Court of Appeals asked the New York State Court of Appeals did the N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 204-a(1) make the compensation sections of collective bargaining agreements to which it applied conditional upon or subject to annual legislative appropriations? Plaintiffs, labor organizations and employees, filed an action alleging unconstitutional impairment of their contracts.


OVERVIEW: The labor organizations and employees filed an action challenging the lag payroll legislation, 1990 N.Y. Laws 190, § 375, which provided that the salaries of nonjudicial officers and employees of the New York court system would have been payable by the state two weeks after they became due. The federal district court granted summary judgment for the state, but the court of appeals certified that a novel question of state law was presented and asked the state appellate court to decide the question: did the N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 204-a(1) make the compensation sections of collective bargaining agreements to which it applied conditional upon or subject to annual legislative appropriations? On review, the court held that the legislative history of § 204-a(1) shed no light on the question and that the legislature's past practice in such matters demonstrated that the legislature had never regarded itself as having the power to approve separately each year of an approved multiyear collective bargaining agreement. The court held that § 204-a(1) did not make the compensation sections of the collective bargaining agreement conditional or subject to annual appropriations.


OUTCOME: The court held that past practices demonstrated that the legislature never regarded itself as having the power to approve separately each year of an approved multiyear collective bargaining agreement.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service -- Compensation and Benefits -- Compensation Sections of Collective Bargaining Agreement Not Subject to Annual Legislative Appropriations

Civil Service Law § 204-a (1), which provides that written agreements between public employers and employee organizations determining the terms and conditions of employment must contain notice that any provision requiring "legislative action to permit its implementation by amendment of law or by providing the additional funds therefor, shall not become effective until the appropriate legislative body has given approval", does not make the compensation sections of collective bargaining agreements to which it applies conditional upon or subject to annual legislative appropriations.

 

155 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Board of Educ. of Cold Spring Harbor Cent. School Dist. v. Rettaliata


No. 99


Court of Appeals of New York


78 N.Y.2d 128; 576 N.E.2d 716; 572 N.Y.S.2d 885; 1991 N.Y. LEXIS 879


April 24, 1991, Argued  
June 13, 1991, Decided



DISPOSITION: In each action, order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff school districts appealed from the orders of the Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department (New York), which reversed judgments of the trial court and granted defendant town supervisors' motions to dismiss the school district's complaints for failure to state a cause of action for money had and received on the grounds that the school districts had received the principal amounts owned under the Suffolk County Tax Act.


OVERVIEW: The court agreed with the school districts' contention that the statutory scheme was self-executing and that a town's obligation to make each payment by the cut-off date as determined by the statute arose automatically. Thus, when a town failed to make a payment by the required date it became liable in an action for money had and received, without the necessity of a demand and refusal, for the principal amount of the tax withheld with interest from the date of the improper withholding. Moreover, the town could not absolve itself from the automatically accruing liability for interest on the amounts improperly withheld simply by paying off the principal sum before the district could commence a lawsuit. The court likened the situation to a contract in which a debtor had agreed to pay interest on overdue amounts. In that situation, the receipt of partial payments applied on the principal did not relieve the debtor of the obligation to pay interest. The court held that from the moment the town failed to pay amounts due under the statute it was liable for both the principal and accumulated interest in the same way that the debtor who agreed to pay interest on overdue sums was liable.


OUTCOME: The order in each action was reversed, and the cases were remitted to the intermediate appellate court for further consideration of all issues.


HEADNOTES

Money Received -- Interest on Late Disbursements of Collected School Tax Moneys to School Districts by Towns -- Effect of Disbursement of Principal Sums Prior to Assertion of Cause of Action for Money Had and Received

Where defendant towns failed to disburse collected school tax moneys to plaintiff school districts at the times required by Suffolk County Tax Act § 13 (a) and § 14, the school districts may maintain a cause of action for money had and received to recover the unpaid accumulated interest notwithstanding their prior acceptance of the principal amounts of the taxes owed belatedly paid over to the districts by defendants on which that interest became due. The statutory scheme is self-executing and a town's obligation to make each payment for the apportioned amount and by the cut-off date as determined by statute arises automatically. Thus, when a town fails to make a payment by the required date it becomes liable in an action for money had and received -- without the necessity of a demand and refusal -- for the principal amount of the tax withheld with interest from the date of the improper withholding. The school districts' right to the interest under the self-executing provisions of the Act survives their late receipt of the principal sums and it would be contrary to the statutory scheme and to the equitable principles underlying an action for money had and received to hold otherwise; such a result would permit the towns to enjoy the use of the districts' money interest free provided only that they have succeeded in paying the principal amounts before suit.

 

156 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Abrams v. Brady


Court of Appeals of New York


77 N.Y.2d 741; 573 N.E.2d 556; 570 N.Y.S.2d 468; 1991 N.Y. LEXIS 689


March 21, 1991, Argued  
May 9, 1991, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant State sought review of a decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department, New York, which affirmed the judgment of the lower court and which dismissed the State's petition to escheat to the state certain unclaimed federal income tax refunds.


OVERVIEW: The State sought to recover from the government those unclaimed federal income tax refunds which, it alleged, had escheated to the State by operation of article XII-A of the Abandoned Property Law. The lower court found in favor of the government and the State appealed. The court affirmed and held that the challenged law was within Congress's constitutional powers and that Congress's evident intention to override the states' rights of escheat without reservation was to be given full effect. The State argued that the government had no interest in the funds once it determined that those funds represented overpayments that should be refunded to the taxpayers. The court held that the Omnibus Act, 26 U.S.C.S. § 6408, was a permissible exercise of Congress's powers under the Necessary and Proper Clause of the U.S. Const. art. I, § 8, cl. 18, because it implemented Congress's authority under the Sixteenth Amendment to lay and collect income taxes. Inasmuch as the statute had no exception for unclaimed refunds that may have already become subject to the State's escheat laws, the appeals court was correct in concluding that the State's petition should have been dismissed in its entirety.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the dismissal of the State's petition to escheat unclaimed federal tax refunds to the State.


HEADNOTES

Abandoned Property -- Escheat to State of Unclaimed Federal Tax Refunds -- Constitutionality of Federal Statute Nullifying State's Escheat Rights

1. The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1987 (26 USC § 6408 [Omnibus Act]), which operates to nullify the States' formerly existing escheat rights to certain unclaimed Federal income tax refunds, was a permissible exercise of Congress's powers under the Necessary and Proper Clause of the US Constitution (US Const, art I, § 8, cl 18) since it implements Congress's authority under the Sixteenth Amendment to "lay and collect" income taxes. Accordingly, under the Supremacy Clause of the US Constitution, the Omnibus Act must be recognized as a valid limitation on New York State's escheat rights to certain unclaimed Federal income tax refunds owed to New York citizens established by article XII-A of New York's Abandoned Property Law.

Abandoned Property -- Escheat to State of Unclaimed Federal Tax Refunds -- Application of Federal Statute Nullifying State's Escheat Rights to All Presently Held Unclaimed Refunds

2. The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1987 (26 USC § 6408), which prohibits Federal authorities from refunding any overpayment of income tax if the payment would escheat to a State, cut off New York State's right to all of its citizens' unclaimed refunds presently held in the United States Treasury, and is not limited in effect to those refunds that had not yet escheated at the time the statute became effective. The language and legislative history of the statute demonstrate clearly that application of the statute to all of the unclaimed funds now held in the United States Treasury was precisely what Congress intended, and that intention ought to be given full effect.

 

157 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Children of Bedford, Inc. v. Petromelis


Court of Appeals of New York


77 N.Y.2d 713; 573 N.E.2d 541; 570 N.Y.S.2d 453; 1991 N.Y. LEXIS 647; 18 Media L. Rep. 2255


March 26, 1991, Argued  
May 7, 1991, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, publisher and corporation, sought review of an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which declared that royalties for the author's book had to be deposited in escrow because the book was subject to N.Y. Exec. Law § 632-a (1). Petitioners contended that respondent board erred in finding the book subject to N.Y. Exec. Law § 632-a (1) and violated procedural due process.


OVERVIEW: Following an order that held that royalties from a book had to be deposited into escrow because the book was subject to N.Y. Exec. Law § 632-a (1), petitioners, publisher and corporation sought review, contending that respondent board erred in finding the book subject to N.Y. Exec. Law § 632-a (1). Petitioners argued that respondent board violated procedural due process. The court found that the statute was content-based and imposed a direct burden on speech, it singled out a category of speech based on subject matter and imposed special burdens on that category. Thus, the court reasoned that the statute had to be strictly scrutinized and unless it served a compelling governmental purpose and was narrowly tailored to accomplish that purpose, it was invalid. The court held that it was apparent from the preliminary negotiations that petitioner publisher believed the book's commercial value rested on the subject matter within the statute. The court concluded that the book was a publication subject to N.Y. Exec. Law § 632-a, that respondent board properly found it to be such and that petitioners' rights to free speech was not violated under either the federal or state constitution.


OUTCOME: The order that declared that royalties for a book be deposited in escrow was affirmed because the court found that the book was a publication subject to the provisions of the law that provided crime victims with financial assistance. The court held that respondent board properly found it to be such and that the statute did not violate petitioners', publisher and corporation, right to free speech under either the federal or state constitution.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Crime Victims Board -- Statute Requiring Escrow of Profits  Paid to Criminal for Reenactment of Crime -- Material Subject to Distribution Statute

1. The Crime Victims Board reasonably concluded that a book authored by a woman convicted of second degree murder is subject to Executive Law § 632-a, which governs the distribution of moneys owing to a criminal or her representatives pursuant to contract with respect to reenactment or depiction of the crime, because the book contains her version of the killing and expressions of her "thoughts, feelings, opinions or emotions" regarding the crime of which she was convicted (see, § 632-a [1]), in addition to a compilation of letters written by the children of imprisoned mothers. It is apparent the publisher believed the book's commercial value rested on subject matter within the statute. Before accepting the book, the publisher urged the author to expand it to include the crime and, before publishing it, the publisher advised the trade that the author's soon to be released book was "a spellbinding story of her life in and out of prison," that the author kept a diary in prison "full of new facts about her relationship with [the victim], her lover for over a decade whom she ultimately murdered," and stated that "[the author] comes to terms with herself [in prison] and recounts why she murdered her lover." Press reports originating from the publisher characterized the book as "the crime of the century -- by the woman convicted of committing it."

Crimes -- Crime Victims Board -- Statute Requiring Escrow of Profits Paid to Criminal for Reenactment of Crime -- Due Process of Law -- Notice of Material Subject to Distribution Statute

2. In concluding that a book authored by a woman convicted of second degree murder is subject to Executive Law § 632-a because it contains her version of the killing and expressions of her "thoughts, feelings, opinions or emotions" regarding the crime, the Crime Victims Board did not violate procedural due process by failing to give petitioners, the publisher of the book and the author's assignee, proper notice of the offending passages. The proposed determination issued by the Board contained a statement of the issues involved in the controversy, a detailed account of the facts which formed the basis for the Board's proposed determination, including page references to various passages in the book, and stated that the passages were found to contain "both detailed reenactment as well as numerous expressions of [the author's] thoughts, feelings, opinions and emotions regarding the crime for which she was convicted." These preliminary findings were made available to petitioners prior to the administrative hearing and were sufficient to apprise them of the Board's claims.

Crimes -- Crime Victims Board -- Due Process of Law -- Investigative, Prosecutorial and Adjudicative Functions Combined in Single Board

3. In concluding that a book authored by a woman convicted of second degree murder is subject to Executive Law § 632-a, the Crime Victims Board did not violate procedural due process on the ground that the Board improperly acted as both prosecutor and Judge by investigating the facts, issuing a proposed determination and order, holding a hearing on that determination and, ultimately, upholding it. The practice of combining investigative, prosecutorial and adjudicative functions in a single administrative agency or board is not improper and, without more, does not violate due process by creating an unconstitutional risk of bias. The petitioners here must demonstrate that because of the practice the Board has been prejudiced by its investigation or for some reason is disabled from hearing and deciding the matter on the basis of the evidence, and the record in this case contains no evidence of such prejudice or disability.

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Speech -- Content-Based Regulation -- Statute Requiring Escrow of Profits Paid to Criminal for Reenactment of Crime

4. Executive Law § 632-a, which requires the escrow of any profits paid to criminals for reenactment or depiction of their crimes for the benefit of the victims or legal representatives of the victims of the crimes, is content-based and imposes a direct burden on speech. If the subject matter being addressed by the criminal's work falls within the terms of the statute, the statute imposes a burden on the criminal's speech by regulating the financial aspects of it. Although the law does not foreclose the speaker's message, it imposes an economic disincentive or penalty for delivering it. Accordingly, to withstand a constitutional challenge under the First Amendment, the statute must be strictly scrutinized and be shown to serve a compelling State interest and to be narrowly tailored to achieve that purpose.

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Speech -- Statute Requiring Escrow of Profits Paid to Criminal for Reenactment of Crime -- Compelling State Interests

5. Executive Law § 632-a, which imposes a burden on speech by requiring the escrow of any profits paid to criminals for reenactment or depiction of their crimes for the benefit of the victims or legal representatives of the victims of the crimes, serves compelling State interests. The statute provides not only a method for victims to obtain compensation and to place the burden of compensating the victim on the criminal whenever possible, but it is a codification of the fundamental equitable principle that criminals should not be permitted to profit from their wrongs and an expression of the penological concept which provides that victims expect and are entitled to "retributive satisfaction" from the criminal justice system.

 Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Speech -- Statute Requiring Escrow of Profits Paid to Criminal for Reenactment of Crime -- Limitation of Statute to Governmental Purpose

6. Executive Law § 632-a, which imposes a burden on speech by requiring the escrow of any profits paid to criminals for reenactment or depiction of their crimes for the benefit of victims or legal representatives of the victims of the crimes, is narrowly tailored to meet the State's compelling interest in securing a victim's equitable right to be compensated from moneys earned by a criminal as a result of victimization. It creates a unique and identifiable resource and preserves it for the benefit of victims directly injured by a crime to compensate them for the damages sustained, gives them priority over the criminal's other creditors and extends the time within which a claim to the proceeds may be asserted by a victim. The statute regulates only the criminal's receipt of money, not the right to speak about the crime and it does not impose a forfeiture of all profits -- it merely delays payment (§ 632-a [11] [e]). Moreover, the statute does not prohibit anyone else from telling or publishing the criminal's story.

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Speech -- Statute Requiring Escrow of Profits Paid to Criminal for Reenactment of Crime -- Vagueness

7. Executive Law § 632-a, which requires the escrow of any profits paid to criminals for reenactment or depiction of their crimes for the benefit of the victims or legal representatives of the victims of the crimes, is not void for vagueness since the statute clearly delineates the class of individuals within its scope, the events that trigger its application, and the acts required for compliance and enforcement. Moreover, the statute is not vague because questions exist as to its applicability to victimless crimes or to material which contains only a fleeting reference to the crime. The Constitution does not require that a law be drafted with such specificity that it leaves no room for interpretation nor is it void for vagueness merely because situations may exist in which it should not be applied.

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Speech -- Statute Requiring Escrow of Profits Paid to Criminal for Reenactment of Crime -- State Constitution

8. Executive Law § 632-a, which requires the escrow of any profits paid to criminals for reenactment or depiction of their crimes for the benefit of the victims or legal representatives of the victims of the crimes, does not violate the Free Speech Clause of the State Constitution (art I, § 8) on the ground that there is lacking a "genuinely close fit" between the statute and its purpose because it is seriously underinclusive and inadequately designed to address the general problem of victim compensation. The statute is not designed to compensate all victims, only those who possess claims to the proceeds earned by the criminal as a result of their victimization. Moreover, assuming without deciding, that article I, § 8 does require some type of "genuinely close fit" between the statute and its purpose, this requirement is no more burdensome than requiring that the statute be narrowly tailored to meet its objective and section 632-a satisfies this test.

 

158 of 992 DOCUMENTS


ISCA Enterprises v. City of New York


Court of Appeals of New York


77 N.Y.2d 688; 572 N.E.2d 610; 569 N.Y.S.2d 927; 1991 N.Y. LEXIS 636


March 27, 1991, Argued  
May 2, 1991, Decided



DISPOSITION: In Matter of ISCA Enters. v City of New York: Order affirmed, with costs. In Campbell v City of New York: Order reversed, with costs, defendant's motion for summary judgment granted, and defendant declared to be the owner of the 13 subject parcels.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant former mortgagee sought review of the order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which dismissed its petition to vacate appellee city's title to certain real property acquired by in rem tax foreclosure.


OVERVIEW: Appellee city acquired title to certain real property pursuant to a judgment of foreclosure. Appellant former mortgagee filed a petition challenging the constitutionality of the city's "notice-by-request" procedure for in rem tax foreclosure actions. The trial court dismissed the former mortgagee's petition to vacate the city's title to the real property as time-barred. On appeal, the former mortgagee alleged that it had been denied due process in that it was not given notice reasonably calculated to apprise it of the pendency of the foreclosure action. The court held that the former mortgagee's petition was time-barred because it had actual notice of the foreclosure within the statutory period and the city's statutory scheme for giving notice to property owners met the requirements of due process. The court determined that the former mortgagee had actual notice of the foreclosure action well within the two-year limitation period and was precluded from challenging the conclusive presumption raised by a properly recorded foreclosure deed. The court found that the former mortgagee delayed commencement of its action for nearly four years from the date of notice.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order dismissing appellant former mortgagee's petition to vacate appellee city's title to certain real property acquired by in rem tax foreclosure. The court determined that the former mortgagee's petition was time-barred because it had actual notice of the foreclosure within the statutory period.


HEADNOTES

Limitation of Actions -- Two-Year Statute of Limitations -- New York City In Rem Tax Foreclosure -- Actual Notice of Tax Foreclosure -- Exhaustion of Administrative Remedies

1. A proceeding by petitioner mortgagee challenging the constitutionality of New York City's "notice-by-request" procedure for in rem tax foreclosure actions (see, Administrative Code of City of New York tit 11) was correctly dismissed as time barred where petitioner had actual notice of the underlying tax foreclosure, and the recording of the tax deeds, with more than a year and a half left to run on the two-year Statute of Limitations contained in Administrative Code § 11-412 (c), but did not commence this proceeding until nearly four years after learning of the foreclosure. Petitioner's actual notice of the foreclosure action well within the two-year limitation period precludes that party from challenging the conclusive presumption raised by the properly recorded foreclosure deed, that the in rem foreclosure action was conducted in accordance with all provisions of law relating thereto (see, Administrative Code § 11-412 [c]). Having itself delayed commencement of its action for nearly four years from actual notice, petitioner cannot be heard to complain of a constitutional infirmity in the original notice procedure. Moreover, petitioner was not required to exhaust administrative remedies before raising its constitutional claim in a judicial proceeding.

Taxation -- Tax Liens, Tax Sales and Tax Titles -- New York City In Rem Tax Foreclosure -- Adequacy of Notice to Owners -- Due Process of Law

2. New York City's "notice-by-request" procedure for in rem tax foreclosure actions (see, Administrative Code of City of New York tit 11) meets the requirements of due process as applied to plaintiffs, owners of parcels as to which ownership had been transferred to the City pursuant to tax foreclosure deeds. To be valid under the Due Process Clause notice must be reasonably calculated, under all the circumstances, to apprise interested parties of the pendency of the action. Under all of the circumstances presented in this case -- where the burden of individually searching the title records would be onerous for the City, and where the City publishes notices (Administrative Code § 11-406 [a]), sends notices to those who have filed request cards (Administrative Code § 11-406 [c]) and if no cards are filed, mails notices to the names and addresses on the assessment record (Administrative Code § 11-406 [c]) -- the Administrative Code notice provisions satisfy the minimum requirements of due process.

Limitation of Actions -- Tolling -- Constitutional Challenge to New York City In Rem Tax Foreclosure Notice Procedure -- Pursuit of Release Procedure for Forfeited Property

3. The two-year Statute of Limitations applicable to petitioner mortgagee's constitutional challenge to New York City's "notice-by-request" procedure for in rem tax foreclosure actions (Administrative Code of City of New York § 11-412 [c]) was not tolled by petitioner's pursuit of the New York City Board of Estimate procedure for release of forfeited property (Administrative Code § 11-424 [a]). Petitioner was free to bring its constitutional challenge regardless of its decision to pursue a release, and pursuit of that course should therefore have no tolling effect.

Limitation of Actions -- Two-Year Statute of Limitations -- New York City In Rem Tax Foreclosure -- Lack of Actual Notice of Tax Foreclosure

4. A consolidated action by plaintiff property owners pursuant to RPAPL article 15 challenging the constitutionality of New York City's "notice-by-request" procedure for in rem tax foreclosure actions (see, Administrative Code of City of New York tit 11) is not barred by the applicable two-year Statute of Limitations (Administrative Code § 11-412 [c]), on the ground that the original RPAPL article 15 actions comprising the consolidated action were commenced at least six years after the filing of the tax foreclosure deeds, since there is no evidence that plaintiffs had actual notice of the underlying foreclosure actions in time to bring their consolidated action. A challenge to the constitutionality of a notice provision, where the party had no timely notice, is not barred by the Statute of Limitations. Moreover, the burden is on the party charged with giving notice, regardless of whatever "fault" may be assigned to the delinquent taxpayer; knowledge of delinquency in the payment of taxes is not equivalent to notice that a tax sale is pending. Inasmuch as the status of owner is immaterial to the Statute of Limitations analysis, plaintiffs are not deemed to have had actual knowledge of the foreclosure action because such action is the logical sequel to tax delinquency.

 

159 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Weingarten v. Lewisboro


No. 48


Court of Appeals of New York


77 N.Y.2d 926; 572 N.E.2d 40; 569 N.Y.S.2d 599; 1991 N.Y. LEXIS 531


February 13, 1991, Argued  
April 4, 1991, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order modified, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff developers sought review of an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed an order granting defendant Town of Lewisboro's cross-motion for summary judgment to the extent of declaring that N.Y. Town Law § 277(1) and § 45.11 of the Lewisboro Land Development Regulations and the fee imposed thereunder was constitutional.


OVERVIEW: The developers filed a declaratory judgment action challenging the constitutionality of N.Y. Town Law § 277(1) and § 45.11 of the Lewisboro Land Development Regulations, which allowed the town's planning board to require a $ 5,000 per lot recreation fee as a condition of subdivision approval. The developers argued that the fee was unconstitutional because it lacked a close nexus to the legitimate governmental interest of providing recreational facilities. The trial court granted the town's cross-motion for summary judgment, and the appellate court affirmed. On further review, the court modified the order by dismissing the complaint. In so doing, the court found that the developers' challenge was not ripe for review because no such fee had been imposed upon them.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the developers' complaint challenging the constitutionality of a statute and regulation that allowed the town's planning board to require a $ 5,000 per lot recreation fee as a condition of subdivision approval.


HEADNOTES

Declaratory Judgments -- When Remedy Appropriate -- Ripeness of Issue for Judicial Determination -- Payment of Fee of Developers in Lieu of Setting Aside Land for Park Use

The complaint in plaintiff developers' declaratory judgment action challenging the constitutionality of a statute (see, Town Law § 277 [1]) and regulation allowing defendant Town's Planning Board of require a $ 5,000 per lot recreation fee as a condition of subdivision approval, should be dismissed since no such fee has been imposed upon any of the plaintiffs, and, hence, their challenges are not ripe for review. While one plaintiff has received a final approval resolution from the Planning Board which imposed the challenged fee, that plaintiff sought judicial review of that determination and the matter was ultimately remanded to the Board, where it is pending, for further determinations. The remaining plaintiffs are even farther from having the challenged fee imposed on them, since their applications for subdivision approval have not yet been passed upon by the Board.

 

160 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Alliance of American Insurers v. Chu


Court of Appeals of New York


77 N.Y.2d 573; 571 N.E.2d 672; 569 N.Y.S.2d 364; 1991 N.Y. LEXIS 380


October 16, 1990, Argued; February 7, 1991, Reargued  
April 2, 1991, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In three consolidated actions, appellants, insurers, trade associations and individuals (collectively insurers), sought review of the decision of the Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed a judgment finding certain laws constitutional, granting summary judgment to appellee, the Commissioner of the Department of Taxation and Finance (Commissioner), and dismissing the insurers' complaints.


OVERVIEW: The insurers claimed an interest in the statutorily created Property and Liability Security Fund (fund), N.Y. Ins. Law §§ 333, 334 (1969), to which they made contributions between 1970 and 1973. The insurers sought, along with related relief, a judgment declaring invalid certain aspects of L 1979, ch. 503, by which the state diverted fund earnings to its general fund, and L 1982, ch. 55, which diverted fund assets to the general fund in exchange for a "dry appropriation." The lower courts rejected the challenge and declared the laws constitutional. The court held that pursuant to N.Y. Ins. Law § 334 (1969), the insurers were granted rights in the income generated by their contributions and that such rights attached to all contributions made to the fund while that legislation remained in effect. The state could neither appropriate the earnings to itself nor deprive the fund of assets that would generate income. The court's decision rested on the constitutionally based protection against legislative interference with vested rights. Therefore, chapters 503 and 55 were constitutionally invalid to the extent they deprived the fund of income on contributions made under § 334.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order and granted the insurers' motion for a summary judgment. The laws in question were declared invalid to the extent they deprived the fund of earnings and income on assets attributable to the insurers' contributions.


HEADNOTES

Insurance -- Property and Liability Insurance Security Fund -- Unconstitutionality of Legislation Diverting Income and Assets of Fund to State's General Fund

1. Laws of 1969 (ch 189, § 3) created the Property and Liability Insurance Security Fund, and granted the contributors property rights in the income generated by their contributions by providing that income earned on new contributions to the fund would be either returned to the contributors or credited toward future contributions. The rights granted, which enjoy the constitutionally based protection against legislative interference with vested rights, attached to all contributions made to the fund while that legislation remained in effect, and thus the State may neither appropriate those earnings to itself nor deprive the fund of assets that would generate such income. Accordingly, Laws of 1979 (ch 503), which provided that all of the income earned on all fund assets was to be credited to the fund and that, if the net value of the fund exceeded $ 240 million, the excess was to be credited to the State's general fund, and Laws of 1982 (ch 55), which required the transfer of $ 87 million of the fund's corpus to the State's general fund in exchange for a "dry appropriation" in an amount equal to or greater than the amount transferred, are invalid to the extent that they deprive the Property and Liability Insurance Security Fund of income on contributions made by insurers pursuant to the 1969 legislation (see, L 1979, ch 503, § 4; L 1982, ch 55, §§ 90, 92 [4]; Insurance Law § 7603). When, as here, the Legislature grants to contributors property rights in the income of a fund and pledges the "full faith and credit of the State of New York" for the safekeeping of that fund it cannot simply ignore the pledge and abrogate those vested rights.

Insurance -- Property and Liability Insurance Security Fund -- Unconstitutionality of Legislation Diverting Income from Fund to State's General Fund -- Remedy

2. In view of the declaration of invalidity of Laws of 1979 (ch 503, § 4) insofar as it discontinued the practice of returning or crediting to the contributors the income earned on their contributions to the Property and Liability Insurance Security Fund made between 1970 and 1973 pursuant to Insurance Law former § 334, and diverted the fund earnings to the State's general fund in violation of the contributors' constitutionally protected property rights in that income, the State is required to reimburse the fund for any income attributable to section 334 contributions that was paid to the State's general fund and the fund is required to return or credit these amounts to plaintiff contributors as provided by section 334 (5) prior to the enactment of chapter 503. The reimbursement should include interest on the amounts wrongfully diverted by the State, with the measure of interest to be litigated in the proceedings to follow.

Insurance -- Property and Liability Insurance Security Fund -- Unconstitutionality of Legislation Diverting Assets of Fund to State's General Fund -- Remedy

3. Laws of 1982 (ch 55, §§ 90, 92 [4]), insofar as they required the transfer of $ 87 million of the corpus of the Property and Liability Insurance Security Fund to the State's general fund, in exchange for a "dry appropriation" in an amount equal to or greater than the amount transferred, violated the constitutionally protected property rights of the fund's contributors in the income earned on their contributions made between 1970 and 1973 pursuant to Insurance Law former § 334; therefore, plaintiff contributors were harmed by the loss of income that could have been generated by such moneys had they remained in the fund notwithstanding that the transfer, by itself, did not cause any harm to plaintiffs because it did not directly reduce the fund's value for purposes of determining whether contributions should resume. Accordingly, the State must account to the fund for the lost income and, until the moneys are returned to the fund, must continue to pay interest on the amount transferred at a rate equivalent to that which could be earned by the fund if those moneys were invested as authorized by Insurance Law former § 333 (6). As long as those moneys are generating a reasonable level of income for the fund, and as long as they are made available for the fund's purposes if that should become necessary, their use by the State does not offend the contributors' rights or breach the State's obligations and, thus, there is no need to order their immediate return.

Insurance -- Property and Liability Insurance Security Fund -- Unconstitutionality of Legislation Diverting Income and Assets of Fund to State's General Fund -- Entitlement of Certain Contributors to Refund

4. In view of the declaration of invalidity of Laws of 1979 (ch 503, § 4) and Laws of 1982 (ch 55, §§ 90, 92 [4]) to the extent that they deprived the Property and Liability Insurance Security Fund of earnings attributable to contributions to the fund made between 1970 and 1973 pursuant to Insurance Law former § 334, plaintiff contributors are entitled to a refund of those contributions they were required to make after the fund's value fell below $ 150 million in 1988, but only if and to the extent that those contributions would not have been required but for the invalid aspects of chapters 503 and 55.

Insurance -- Property and Liability Insurance Security Fund -- Effect of Invalidation of Legislation Diverting Income of Fund to State's General Fund -- Restoration of Prior Statutory Scheme

5. The effect of the declaration of invalidity of Laws of 1979 (ch 503, § 4), which provided that all of the income earned on all assets of the Property and Liability Insurance Security Fund was to be credited to the fund, and that if the net value of the fund exceeded $ 240 million, the excess was to be credited to the State's general fund, in violation of the fund's contributors' constitutionally protected property rights in the income earned on their contributions to the fund made between 1970 and 1973 pursuant to Insurance Law former § 334, is to restore the statutory scheme governing the distribution of the fund's income that was in effect prior to that legislation. Accordingly, plaintiffs' rights in the income allocable to section 334 contributions is restored, the provision requiring the fund's balance to exceed $ 240 million before distribution of any of the fund's earnings to the State is eliminated, and the scheme put in place by the 1973 amendments is revived, including the State's right to all earnings attributable to Insurance Law former § 333 contributions, less amounts paid for allowed claims and administrative expenses (see, Insurance Law former § 334 [5], as amended by L 1973, ch 861).

 

161 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Byrne


Court of Appeals of New York


77 N.Y.2d 460; 570 N.E.2d 1066; 568 N.Y.S.2d 717; 1991 N.Y. LEXIS 222


January 10, 1991, Argued  
February 19, 1991, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the order of the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed his convictions for violating N.Y. Alco. Bev. Cont. Law § 65(1).


OVERVIEW: Defendant and his brother each owned 50 percent of the shares in a corporation which owned a tavern. Defendant was also the president of the corporation. Defendant's brother sold alcoholic beverages at the tavern to two individuals who were under the age of 19. The state charged defendant and his brother with violating N.Y. Alco. Bev. Cont. Law § 65(1). After a jury trial, defendant was convicted and sentenced to pay a fine. The appellate term affirmed his convictions. Defendant appealed. The court reversed the order of the appellate term because N.Y. Alco. Bev. Cont. Law §§ 65(1), 130(3) did not create a crime of vicarious liability.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the appellate term because defendant could not be vicariously liable for his brother's sale of alcoholic beverages to two individuals who were under the age of 19.


HEADNOTES

Appeal -- Court of Appeals -- Appeal by Permission -- Denial of Leave Not Bar to Raising Issue on Subsequent Appeal

1. A denial of leave to appeal to the Court of Appeals by an individual Judge or Justice does not represent a determination on the merits barring further litigation of any claims which could have been litigated had the appeal been permitted. Accordingly, on an appeal to the Court of Appeals from an Appellate Term order which affirmed defendant's conviction under a theory of vicarious liability of selling alcoholic beverages to minors (Alcoholic Beverage Control Law § 65 [1]; § 130 [3]), defendant is not foreclosed from raising the vicarious liability question because his prior application for leave to appeal to the Court of Appeals, which concerned the same issue, following Appellate Term's reversal of a pretrial order dismissing the charges, was denied.

Intoxicating Liquors -- Sale to Minors -- No Vicarious Liability in Criminal Prosecution

2. Section 65 (1) of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law, which prohibits the sale of alcoholic beverages to minors, and section 130 (3), which makes a violation of that prohibition a misdemeanor, do not create a crime of "vicarious liability", permitting conviction of a natural person for the acts of another solely because of the parties' business relationship. In the face of legislative silence on the point, a legislative intent to authorize prosecution of one person for another's criminal conduct will not be inferred. Accordingly, an Appellate Term order which affirmed a judgment convicting defendant, a 50% shareholder and president of the corporate licensee, of violating section 65 (1) is reversed, and the complaint dismissed, where the evidence at trial established only that defendant's brother, the other 50% shareholder, had sold beer to two underage individuals on the licensed premises, and there was no proof that defendant was present during, or had any other connection with, the illicit sales for which he was charged.

 

162 of 992 DOCUMENTS


New York Public Interest Research Group, Inc. v. New York State Thruway Authority


Court of Appeals of New York


77 N.Y.2d 86; 565 N.E.2d 1259; 564 N.Y.S.2d 708; 1990 N.Y. LEXIS 4418


November 19, 1990, Argued  
December 20, 1990, Decided
