DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, citizens' group and members, brought an action against respondents, tollway authority and officials, claiming that a toll increase was unlawful for failure to comply with N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 2804(2), (3). The trial court dismissed the petition. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York) affirmed, finding § 2804(2), (3) unconstitutional. The citizens' group and members appealed.


OVERVIEW: The citizens' group and members asserted that § 2804(2), (3) did not violate the comptroller's discretionary review of public corporation accounts. The tollway authority and officials contended that § 2804(2) was unconstitutional. The court noted that although N.Y. Const. art. X, § 5 provided that every public corporation should be subject to the supervision of the comptroller, the comptroller's authority to supervise their accounts was entirely discretionary. The court determined that N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 2804(2), (3), by requiring the comptroller to review reports submitted by an authority, to utilize resources to analyze the report, and recommend whether the proposed increases should take effect, impermissibly interfered with the exercise of the comptroller's discretion in respect to a public corporation. The court stated that the fact that the State guaranteed the tollway authority's bonds and its power to issue nonguaranteed bonds was limited did not transform its funds into "money under control of the State," and that the State's "major concern" in the tollway authority's business did not serve to justify the impermissible interference with the comptroller's discretion.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the appellate division affirming the dismissal of the citizens' group and members' petition.


HEADNOTES

Public Authorities -- Thruway Toll Increase -- Validity of Statute Requiring State Comptroller to Review Proposed Toll Increase by Public Authority

Public Authorities Law § 2804 (2) and (3), which requires the State Comptroller to review reports submitted by an authority, to utilize his resources to analyze the report and to recommend whether the proposed increase in fees, tolls or charges should take effect, impermissibly interferes with the exercise of the Comptroller's discretionary power under the State Constitution to supervise the financial accounts of public authorities and, therefore, is invalid (see, NY Const, art X, § 5).

 

163 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Pelham Esplanade, Inc. v. Board of Trustees


Court of Appeals of New York


77 N.Y.2d 66; 565 N.E.2d 508; 563 N.Y.S.2d 759; 1990 N.Y. LEXIS 3720


October 12, 1990, Argued  
November 29, 1990, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) entered an order reversing a trial court order that dismissed a petition to annul a determination of appellant Board of Trustees of the Village of Pelham Manor (board) that denied respondent property owner's application to reconstruct a nonconforming dwelling that was destroyed by fire. The board appealed.


OVERVIEW: The property owner unsuccessfully sought the board's approval of its application to reconstruct a nonconforming multiple-family dwelling which was destroyed by fire. The property originally contained two apartment buildings on a single tax lot, but one of the buildings was entirely destroyed. The Village of Pelham Manor, N.Y. Zoning Ordinance § 32(5)(a) (ordinance) provided that no structure sustaining damage equal to more than 50 percent of its value could be repaired or rebuilt except in conformance with the ordinance. The court held that 1) the law disfavored nonconforming uses, rendering the property owner's burden high, 2) the proper test to evaluate a claim of reestablishing a nonconforming use after substantial destruction was functional interdependence, and 3) the issue of whether the combination of buildings functioned as a single, integrated, nonconforming use was one for the board, not the courts.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order, with costs, and dismissed the petition.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Nonconforming Use -- Resurrection of Extinguished Nonconforming Use -- Single, Integrated, Nonconforming Use

1. The petition in a CPLR article 78 proceeding challenging a determination of appellant Village Board of Trustees, denying a property owner's application to reconstruct one of two nonconforming multiple-family dwellings, located on a single tax lot, that was destroyed by fire, based upon the Board's application of a Village Zoning Ordinance provision, which prohibits rebuilding of a nonconforming structure if it is damaged to the extent of more than 50% of its value, to the destroyed building alone rather than to the entire property, is dismissed. The Board's determination that the combined apartment property was not devoted to a single, integrated, nonconforming use under the governing ordinance, and thus failed to qualify for the narrow exception recognized in Bobandal Realties v Worthington (21 AD2d 784, affd without opn 15 NY2d 788), was not arbitrary or capricious or an abuse of discretion. The Board considered the details of the proposed rehabilitation and the history and background of the ownership and use of the two distinct apartment dwelling places, concluded that the buildings were "independent" under Bobandal for purposes of applying the over-50% formula restriction of the ordinance, and found that there was no reason why the undamaged apartment building could not continue to operate as a nonconforming dwelling use without another nonconforming multiple-family dwelling arising anew next door.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Nonconforming Use -- Resurrection of Extinguished Nonconforming Use -- Test to Determine Single, Integrated, Nonconforming Use

2. In determining whether structures on real property are devoted to a single, integrated, nonconforming use for the purpose of resurrecting an extinguished nonconforming use under the narrow exception recognized in Bobandal Realties v Worthington (21 AD2d 784, affd without opn 15 NY2d 788), functional interdependence rather than economic interdependence or nature of the use, is more consonant with reasonably balancing the public interest in eliminating nonconforming uses at a legally opportunistic time with the property owner's interest in not having a property investment abruptly altered or terminated.

 

164 of 992 DOCUMENTS


B & F Bldg. Corp. v. Liebig


No. 234


Court of Appeals of New York


76 N.Y.2d 689; 564 N.E.2d 650; 563 N.Y.S.2d 40; 1990 N.Y. LEXIS 3719


October 16, 1990, Argued  
November 29, 1990, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff contractor sought review of the judgment from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, which affirmed the judgment of the Supreme Court granting a motion of defendants home owners to dismiss contractor's complaint for its failure to have a home improvement contractor license when it did the work and when it brought suit, thus precluding recovery under N.Y.C.P.L.R. 3015(e).


OVERVIEW: Home owners hired contractor to renovate their cooperative apartment. After paying a sum on account, they refused to pay any more, claiming contractor had breached their agreement. Contractor brought this action to recover amounts due on the contract or for a judgment declaring that it had a valid mechanic's lien. Owners counterclaimed for the expense of correcting the faulty work. The trial court dismissed contractor's complaint and rejected contractor's motion to amend its pleading to assert it later obtained the required license. The Appellate Division affirmed the trial court's judgment, and the court affirmed the judgments of the lower courts. The court held that N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3015(e) required contractor to have a home improvement contractor license both at the time of the work and at commencement of the action in order to recover for unpaid work. N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3015(e) did allow a contractor whose license had lapsed before suit was filed to regain its license and file an amended pleading so asserting, but that provision did not cover a contractor who was unlicensed at the time it performed the work.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgments of the Appellate Division and the Supreme Court dismissing contractor's suit. The court held that, while the law allowed a contractor lacking a license at the time of commencement of suit to obtain such license and amend its pleadings accordingly, it did not allow a contractor lacking such license when it did the work to obtain the license and keep its suit alive.


HEADNOTES

Pleading -- Sufficiency of Pleading -- Action Involving Business Required to be Licensed -- Amendment to Plead After-Acquired License

CPLR 3015 (e) which, in an action against a consumer arising from plaintiff's conduct of a business that is required by State or local law to be licensed, allows a plaintiff who does not possess a required license at the commencement of the action to amend the complaint to allege the particulars of an after-acquired license, is only applicable where the plaintiff was licensed at the time the work was done and cannot be used to validate a contract that was prohibited when performed. Accordingly, in an action arising from defendant consumer's refusal to pay the balance due under a home improvement contract, a cross motion by plaintiff to amend the complaint pursuant to CPLR 3015 (e) to assert the particulars of its after-acquired license was correctly denied where plaintiff, a home improvement contractor within the meaning of Administrative Code of the City of New York § 20-386, was not licensed, as the Code requires, when the agreement was signed or when the work was performed (Administrative Code § 20-387).

 

165 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Ohrenstein


Court of Appeals of New York


77 N.Y.2d 38; 565 N.E.2d 493; 563 N.Y.S.2d 744; 1990 N.Y. LEXIS 3514


September 5, 1990, Argued  
November 27, 1990, Decided



DISPOSITION:  People v Ohrenstein: Order affirmed. Matter of Ohrenstein v Morgenthau: Judgment affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The People challenged the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) order, affirming the dismissal of counts of an indictment, alleging that defendant elected officials violated various penal laws by assigning Senate employees to work on political campaigns. Defendants contested the order to the extent that it authorized the prosecution on counts related to "no show" employees.


OVERVIEW: Defendant elected officials were indicted for violating various penal laws based on having assigned their staff employees to work on election campaigns and on having permitted "no show" employees to receive compensation from the state. The appellate court affirmed the dismissal of the counts related to the campaign workers, but sustained the counts concerning "no show" employees and both sides sought review. The court affirmed, ruling that when the activities at issue occurred, the legislature was aware that its members were using staff employees in political campaigns, but had not restricted the practice. For the purposes of a criminal prosecution, the controlling factor was that there was no law, which either expressly or as interpreted by the courts, declared such acts to be criminal. The court ruled that the Speech or Debate Clause of the N.Y. Const. did not immunize defendants from liability for larceny based on having filed false payroll statements for employees who were never intended to do anything but receive state monies. The allegations were sufficient to sustain these criminal counts under N.Y. Penal Law §§ 155.30, 155.35, 175.35.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order dismissing the counts against defendant elected officials for using staff employees in political campaigns. There was no law in effect at the time which subjected defendants to criminal prosecution. The court affirmed the judgment sustaining the counts pertaining to "no show" employees. The speech and debate clause did not shield defendants from prosecution for larceny of state funds.


HEADNOTES

Legislature -- Immunity from Prosecution for Legislative Acts -- Acts Not Declared Criminal by Law -- Assignment of Senate Employees to Work on Political Campaigns

1. The Minority Leader of the State Senate may not be prosecuted criminally for having assigned employees of his Senate staff, largely during the year 1986, to work on political campaigns for members of his party seeking election or reelection to the Senate, since, at the time when the activities at issue occurred, there was no law which, either expressly or as interpreted by the courts, declared the acts to be criminal. Moreover, it cannot fairly be said that the Legislature otherwise forbade the conduct so that it could serve as a predicate for a conviction under general Penal Law provisions.

Legislature -- Immunity from Prosecution for Legislative Acts -- Constitutional Prohibition against Use of State Moneys for Private Undertakings Not Predicate for Criminal Prosecution

2. NY Constitution, article VII, § 8, which prohibits the use of State moneys for "private undertakings" and which has been construed to include partisan causes, does not support a criminal prosecution of the Minority Leader of the State Senate for having assigned employees of his Senate staff, largely during the year 1986, to work on political campaigns for members of his party seeking election or reelection to the Senate. The constitutional prohibition limits the power of the Legislature to appropriate, but it does not create a hidden limitation in every appropriation so that any expenditure which is facially valid, but constitutionally prohibited, can be deemed an unauthorized expenditure and therefore a predicate for a criminal prosecution.

Legislature -- Immunity from Prosecution for Legislative Acts -- No Immunity for Placing "No-Show" Employees on Senate Payroll

3. The Minority Leader of the State Senate and other defendants may be prosecuted criminally for having placed on the Senate payroll "no-show" employees, persons who did no work and were not expected to do anything to earn their salaries, on the theory that defendants filed false instruments when they certified on the payroll records that these employees performed "proper duties", and committed larceny when they induced the State to rely on the false statements. The allegations that these employees did nothing, that the defendants knew this, and that the defendants also knew that they had no duties are sufficient to sustain these criminal counts (Penal Law §§ 155.30, 155.35, 175.35).

Legislature -- Immunity from Prosecution for Legislative Acts -- Separation of Powers -- Prosecution for Placing "No-Show" Employees on Senate Payroll

4. The indictment and prosecution of the Minority Leader of the State Senate and other defendants for having placed on the Senate payroll "no-show" employees, persons who did no work and were not expected to do anything to earn their salaries, does not constitute an unwarranted intrusion into the affairs of the Legislature in violation of the separation of powers doctrine on the ground that it will permit the executive and the courts to determine what are proper duties for legislative staff. No such inquiry is necessary in this case if, as alleged, these staff members did nothing and were not expected to perform any duties.

Legislature -- Immunity from Prosecution for Legislative Acts -- Speech or Debate Clause of State Constitution -- Prosecution for Placing "No-Show" Employees on Senate Payroll

5. The prosecution of the Minority Leader of the State Senate and other defendants for having placed on the Senate payroll "no-show" employees, persons who did no work and were not expected to do anything to earn their salaries, is not prohibited by the legislative immunity granted pursuant to the Speech or Debate Clause of the State Constitution (NY Const, art III, § 11). No matter how far such immunity may extend under the State Constitution, it cannot be said that it was intended to provide a sanctuary for legislators who would defraud the State by knowingly placing on its payroll employees who were never intended to do anything but receive State moneys.

 

166 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Newball


No. 194


Court of Appeals of New York


76 N.Y.2d 587; 563 N.E.2d 269; 561 N.Y.S.2d 898; 1990 N.Y. LEXIS 3364


September 7, 1990, Argued  
October 23, 1990, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant sought review of the affirming of his conviction of criminal sale of a controlled substance in the third degree in the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York).


OVERVIEW: A police officer working on an undercover narcotics operation observed another officer buy cocaine from defendant and defendant left before he was arrested. Subsequently, the officer who tried to buy the drugs from defendant observed him and sent the officer who observed the attempted transaction to identify defendant. Prior to trial, the prosecution did not serve defendant with a notice notifying him of their intention to introduce at trial testimony from the officer who previously identified him as required by N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 710.30. At trial, the officer was allowed to testify and defendant was convicted of criminal sale of a controlled substance in the third degree. The intermediate appellate court affirmed the conviction. On appeal, the court reversed. The court held that notice under § 710.30 was required because the officer's second encounter was a police arranged identification. As it was an error to admit the officer's testimony because no hearing or notice was given, the court reversed, granted motion to suppress, and ordered a new trial.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the intermediate appellate court affirming of defendant's conviction of criminal sale of a controlled substance in the third degree. The court held that the prosecution failed to give proper notice of prosecution's intent on calling a police officer who had previously identified defendant and it was an error to admit the officer's testimony at trial. The court reversed, granted motion to suppress, and ordered a new trial.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Identification of Defendant -- Previous Identification by Police Officer

1. An undercover police officer's November 18, 1986 identification of defendant as the suspect she observed taking part in an October 21, 1986 sale of a controlled substance to another undercover officer, which identification was made after she was directed to defendant's location by the other officer, who had fortuitously spotted defendant, constitutes a previous identification within the meaning of CPL 710.30 and, therefore, the officer's testimony as to that identification should have been precluded at defendant's trial since the People did not serve a CPL 710.30 notice with regard to that testimony. The prior identification of defendant was police-arranged inasmuch as the identifying officer was specifically pointed to defendant's location by the other undercover officer. Further, since the prior identification cannot be said to have constituted the completion of an integral police procedure, and because of the significant lapse of time between the initial viewing and the later identification, the November 18th identification was not within the category of confirmatory identifications not ordinarily burdened or compromised by forbidden suggestiveness. Consequently, this case presents precisely the type of special circumstances which call for a CPL 710.60 (4) hearing and therefore implicate the notice requirements of CPL 710.30.

Crimes -- Identification of Defendant -- Notice of Intention to Introduce Previous Identification by Police Officer -- Prior "Knowledge" of Suspect

2. A police officer's prior "knowledge" of a suspect, who she identified as the defendant, which derived from her viewing the person for only a few minutes and from a distance of no closer than 50 feet, cannot be said to be other than distant and fleeting and, thus, does not excuse the People's failure to give notice of intention to introduce at trial testimony regarding that police officer's previous identification of defendant pursuant to CPL 710.30.

Crimes -- Harmless and Prejudicial Error -- Erroneous Admission of Prior Identification Testimony

3. In the prosecution of defendant, who was convicted of criminal sale of a controlled substance in the third degree, the trial court's error in admitting a police officer's prior identification testimony into evidence despite the People's failure to serve a CPL 710.30 notice with regard to that testimony is not harmless. Once that testimony is excluded, the People's case against defendant is left to depend almost entirely on the testimony of another police officer whose testimony was based upon an identification which occurred 28 days after that officer encountered the suspect. In light of the possible effects this passage of nearly a month's time may have had on the jury's assessment of the reliability of that officer's testimony, it cannot be said with any degree of certainty that had the erroneously admitted testimony, which tended to significantly bolster that officer's testimony, been excluded, the outcome would not have been different.

 

167 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Golden v. Clark


No. 277


Court of Appeals of New York


76 N.Y.2d 618; 564 N.E.2d 611; 563 N.Y.S.2d 1; 1990 N.Y. LEXIS 3411


September 12, 1990, Argued  
October 23, 1990, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff political party and officials sought to nullify a certain city charter provision as unconstitutional. The Supreme Court (New York) found the provision unconstitutional. Defendant administrators of the provision sought review.


OVERVIEW: A provision of a city charter prohibited certain high city office holders from also holding offices in political parties. Various political party and officials filed an action against the administrators of the provision complaining that the provision was unconstitutional. The trial court granted the political party and officials' motion for summary judgment and found the provision to be unconstitutional. The court determined that the provision did not deny the political and officials equal protection because it did not establish a classification which burdened their rights. The provision did not violate fundamental rights to association and free speech nor did it constitute an impermissible delegation of rulemaking authority to the administrators of the provision.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the lower court and found the provision at issue to be constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Right against Disfranchisement -- Right to Vote -- State Constitution -- Statute Prohibiting Certain New York City Officials from Holding Certain Political Offices -- Strict Scrutiny

1. New York City Charter § 2604 (b) (15), which requires high city officers to forego certain political offices as a qualification for holding public office, does not establish a classification that burdens fundamental rights under the State Constitution so as to be subject to strict scrutiny. Section 2604 (b) (15) neither imposes a barrier to candidacies based on wealth nor restricts the political opportunity of minorities, minority political parties or independents by means of an impermissible classification scheme. Rather, the section is neutral in its application and the burden it imposes on certain high officeholders does not depend upon political affiliation or political viewpoint. Moreover, the section has no direct impact on one's fundamental right to vote and it does not disfranchise any identifiable class of voters. (See, NY Const, art II, § 1; art I, § 1.) Its impact on voting rights is, at most, only incidental.

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection of Laws -- State Constitution -- Statute Prohibiting Certain New York City Officials from Holding Certain Political Offices -- Rational Basis

2. New York City Charter § 2604 (b) (15), which requires high city officers to forego certain political offices as a qualification for holding public office, does not violate the right of plaintiffs, various city and political party officials, voters and political parties, to equal protection under the State Constitution (NY Const, art I, § 11). Section 2604 (b) (15) is intended to eliminate conflicts of interest that arise when high public officials are simultaneously subject to the demands of both their constituencies and their political parties, to broaden opportunities for political and public participation, to reduce the opportunities for corruption inherent in dual officeholding, and, through all of these methods, to increase citizens' confidence in the integrity and effectiveness of their government. These are legitimate governmental purposes and have been identified as such both judicially and legislatively. Section 2604 (b) (15) is addressed to these State interests and is rationally related to advancing them.

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Association -- Freedom of Speech -- Political Parties -- State Constitution -- Statute Prohibiting Certain New York City Officials from Holding Certain Political Offices

3. New York City Charter § 2604 (b) (15), which requires high city officers to forego certain political offices as a qualification for holding public office, does not directly or indirectly impair fundamental rights of free speech and association secured to political parties by the State Constitution (NY Const, art I, §§ 8, 9) and, therefore, the City of New York need not demonstrate a compelling necessity for adopting it. The section is entirely neutral on issues involving party politics and does no more than prohibit the holding of both high political office and high public office at the same time. It does not deprive political parties or their members of the right to associate with the individuals of their own choosing or the right to identify the people who constitute a political party. Nor does it prohibit political parties from expressing their opinions or selecting their own style of internal organization. Section 2604 (b) (15) leaves political parties free to organize and participate in the election process without constraint.

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Association -- Freedom of Speech -- Individuals -- State Constitution -- Statute Prohibiting Certain New York City Officials from Holding Certain Political Offices

4. New York City Charter § 2604 (b) (15), which requires high city officers to forego certain political offices as a qualification for holding public office, does not impair fundamental rights of association and free speech secured to individuals by the State Constitution (NY Const, art I, §§ 8, 9) and, therefore the City of New York need not demonstrate a compelling necessity for adopting it. Section 2604 (b) (15) permits city officials to engage in a broad range of personal or financial activity in support of a candidate or cause. Any de minimis burden the Charter provision imposes on individual rights of expression or association is justified by the important governmental interests underlying it.

Constitutional Law -- Delegation of Rule-Making Authority -- Rules Promulgated Pursuant to Statute Prohibiting Certain New York City Officials from Holding Certain Political Offices

5. New York City Charter § 2604 (b) (15), which prohibits high city officials from holding certain political offices, does not impermissibly delegate rule-making authority to the Conflicts of Interest Board by authorizing the Board to promulgate rules defining (1) which enumerated public servants are "charged with substantial policy discretion", and therefore subject to the section's prohibition, and (2) the "lesser political office[s]" a member of the City Council may hold. Section 2600, which sets forth the guiding purpose of the Charter's conflict of interest provisions (NY City Charter ch 68) and section 2603 (a), which delegates to the Board the general power to make such rules as are necessary under chapter 68, together provide reasonable standards to govern the Board's action in a limited and specified field for a stated purpose. Thus, the conferral of authority upon the Board to promulgate those rules is not an unconstitutional delegation of rule-making authority.

 

168 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Scalza


No. 188


Court of Appeals of New York


76 N.Y.2d 604; 563 N.E.2d 705; 562 N.Y.S.2d 14; 1990 N.Y. LEXIS 3337


September 6, 1990, Argued  
October 18, 1990, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Second Judicial Department (New York) that upheld the judicial hearing officer referral statute, N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 255.20(4), and affirmed judgment of conviction on six counts of criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree.


OVERVIEW: Defendant's motion to suppress evidence was heard by a judicial hearing officer (JHO). The court affirmed the appellate division decision upholding the judicial hearing officer referral statute, N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 255.20(4), and the trial court order entered on the report from the JHO denying suppression. Defendant failed to prove the statute unconstitutional on its face. N.Y. Const. art. VI, §§ 10, 11, were not violated because the statute did not diminish the court's exclusive power to decide the issue. Due process and the right to be heard were not violated for defendant presented evidence to a neutral fact finder selected by the judge, and the JHO's findings and recommendation were fully reviewed and decided upon by the trial court de novo. The court refused to consider the as applied challenge, for defendant did not object to the JHO's qualifications or the procedures followed at the trial court.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate division upholding defendant's conviction because defendant failed to meet its burden of proving facial invalidity of the statute. Defendant's as applied challenge was not reached because defendant failed to preserve the issue for review.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Jurisdiction of County Courts -- References to Judicial Hearing Officers -- Facial Constitutionality of Statute Authorizing References of Pretrial Motions to Judicial Hearing Officers

1. CPL 255.20 (4), which provides that any pretrial motion may be referred to a Judicial Hearing Officer (JHO) to hear and report, is not facially unconstitutional on the ground that it undermines or diminishes the County Court's exclusive power to decide in violation of NY Constitution, article VI, §§ 10 and 11, which provide essentially for the organization and jurisdiction of County Courts. The core of the statutory authorization retains for the Trial Judge the sole authority to "determine" all issues referred to a JHO by expressly withholding from the JHO the power to "determine" anything. Nor do sections 10 and 11 of article VI of the NY Constitution expressly or impliedly prohibit referrals to JHOs to conduct suppression hearings. Thus, no unauthorized or unconstitutional diversion of the trial court's exclusive jurisdiction and responsibility to decide is threatened.

Crimes -- Reference of Pretrial Suppression Motion to Judicial Hearing Officer -- Due Process of Law -- State Constitution

2. In the prosecution of defendant, where the County Court preliminarily exercised its discretionary authority to refer defendant's pretrial suppression motion to an authorized Judicial Hearing Officer for the filing of a report as prescribed in CPL 255.20 (4), defendant's due process rights under the State Constitution were not violated on the ground that the manner and procedure under which the pretrial suppression motion referral operates deprived him of having this part of his case actually "heard" by a Judge. While the suppression Judge did not personally listen to the witnesses' testimony, the court "heard" the motion in a customary juridical sense of that phrase. Defendant's opportunity to present evidence and testimony to a neutral fact finder selected by the Judge who will decide the case and all its issues, coupled with the Trial Judge's de novo review powers and options, provides process that is due. Moreover, the investigative and empirical record also manifest a substantial State interest in the objective of CPL 255.20 (4) to lessen delay, a recognized evil to the fair administration of the criminal justice system, which is furthered by the discretionary statutory procedure.

Crimes -- Appeal -- Preservation of Issue for Appellate Review

3. A claim by defendant that CPL 255.20 (4), which authorizes a Trial Judge to refer any pretrial motion to a Judicial Hearing Officer (JHO) to hear and report, is unconstitutional as applied to him, is not preserved for review by the Court of Appeals where defendant failed to object to the qualifications of the specific JHO to whom defendant's pretrial suppression motion was referred.

 

169 of 992 DOCUMENTS


New York v. State


No. 217


Court of Appeals of New York


76 N.Y.2d 479; 562 N.E.2d 118; 561 N.Y.S.2d 154; 1990 N.Y. LEXIS 3150


August 29, 1990, Argued  
September 18, 1990, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, city and others, challenged an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed an order that denied plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and granted a cross motion by the state for summary judgment. The trial court found special law 1989 N.Y. Laws ch. 773 was constitutional.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs, city and others, challenged the constitutionality of 1989 N.Y. Laws ch. 773, which was a special law that prescribed a procedure for determining a borough's interest in secession from a city. The trial court denied plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and granted a cross motion for summary judgment filed by the state finding that the special law was constitutional. A lower appellate court affirmed. Upon review, the court affirmed the lower courts. The court held that the special law was constitutional because it did not require a home rule message under N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 2(b)(2) where the law was not an act in relation to the property, affairs, or government of the city. The court found that there was no state interference with the city because the special law did not authorize secession, it did not authorize the voters of the borough to decide the secession issue, and it did not initiate seccession or commit the state to support it. The court noted that the special law merely allowed the borough to explore its publicized interest in secession, and any decision made by the borough was without force until further act of the legislature.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed an order that denied a motion for summary judgment filed by plaintiffs, city and others, and granted a cross motion by the state for summary judgment. The court held that a special law that prescribed a procedure for determining a borough's interest in secession from a city was constitutional where the law did not intrude into the city's property, affairs, or government.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Home Rule Powers -- State Legislation Prescribing Procedure for Determining Interest of Staten Island Residents in Seceding from City of New York -- Act Relating to Property, Affairs or Government of City of New York -- Equal Protection of Laws

1. Chapter 773 of the Laws of 1989 (as amended by L 1990, ch 17), a special law that prescribes a procedure for determining Staten Islanders' interest in secession from New York City, and the basis on which they would wish such separation to be accomplished, is not an "act in relation to the property, affairs or government" of New York City (NY Const, art IX, § 2 [b] [2]) requiring a home rule message under the State Constitution. There is no State interference in New York City property, affairs or government. Chapter 773 does not authorize secession; it does not authorize the voters of Staten Island to decide the secession issue; it does not initiate secession, or commit the State to support it; it does not represent any relinquishment by the Legislature of any power it may have with respect to secession; and it in no way circumscribes whatever protections exist in the State Constitution home rule provision with respect to an act formally triggering secession. Moreover, the legislative choice to allow Staten Island voters to express their views as to whether, and how, they might wish to separate from New York City -- while affording them no unilateral right to do so -- is a reasonable classification based on the distinct interest of that subdivision of the State and, therefore, does not violate equal protection principles.

Courts -- Ripeness for Review -- Challenge to Constitutionality of Special Law Concerning Secession of Staten Island from City of New York

2. Chapter 773 of the Laws of 1989 (as amended by L 1990, ch 17), a special law that prescribes a procedure for determining Staten Islanders' interest in secession from New York City, and the basis on which they would wish such separation to be accomplished, is more than "advisory only", and is ripe for review, inasmuch as it authorizes the commitment of public funds and other public resources, potentially extending over a period of several years, to conduct studies, hold hearings and submit legislation that would effectuate Staten Island's separation from the City of New York if the Legislature ever passed such a law and the Governor ever signed it.

 

170 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re Raquel Marie X.


Nos. 133, 134


Court of Appeals of New York


76 N.Y.2d 387; 559 N.E.2d 418; 559 N.Y.S.2d 855; 1990 N.Y. LEXIS 1985


May 1, 1990, Argued  
July 10, 1990, Decided



DISPOSITION: In Matter of Raquel Marie X.: Order reversed, etc.

In Matter of Baby Girl S.: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In two consolidated appeals, appellants, in one case adoptive parents and in the other a natural father, challenged the orders of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) and the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) which determined a biological unwed father's rights in adoption proceedings pursuant to N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law §111(1).


OVERVIEW: Two adoption proceedings involving out-of-wedlock children whose birth mothers consented to their adoption by strangers were consolidated for appeal. The court analyzed the cases in light of N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law §111(1) which stated that an unwed father's consent to the adoption of his under-six-month-old child was required only where he had openly lived with the child or the mother for six continuous months immediately preceding the child's placement for adoption and had met other requirements. The court held that the "living together" requirement of N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law §111 (1) (e), which cut off unwed fathers' parental interest by imposing as an absolute condition an obligation only tangentially related to the parental relationship, rendered the statute unconstitutional. One appellate division order, which denied the petition for adoption because respondent father did as much as possible to fulfill the statutory requirements and therefore was entitled to veto the adoption, was affirmed. The other order allowing adoption was reversed because the appellate division did not review the facts necessary to a determination of appellant father's parental responsibility.


OUTCOME: The court held that the "living together" prong of New York's adoption statute rendered the statute unconstitutional, and affirmed the appellate division opinion which held that respondent father had a substantial parental interest entitling him to veto the adoption. The other appellate division order, which was entered against appellant father and in favor of the adoptive parents, was reversed and remitted for further review of the facts.


HEADNOTES

Adoption -- Consent -- Unwed Father -- Constitutionality of Consent Statute Requiring Father to Live with Mother

1. The requirement of Domestic Relations Law § 111 (1) (e) that an unwed father openly live with his child's mother for six continuous months before the child's placement for adoption, as a condition to the father's right of consent to adoption, renders the statute infirm under the Federal Constitution. The "living together" requirement of the statute, directed as it is principally to the father-mother relationship, neither legitimately furthers the State's substantial interest in adoption nor sufficiently protects the fundamental interest in a parental relationship of an unwed father who has promptly taken every available avenue to demonstrate that he is willing and able to enter into the fullest possible relationship with his infant child.

Adoption -- Consent -- Unwed Father -- Right to Continued Parental Relationship

2. In an adoption proceeding by strangers, an unwed father who has been physically unable to have a full custodial relationship with his infant child is entitled to the full measure of protection of his interest in the child under the Federal Constitution -- the right to a continued parental relationship absent a finding of unfitness -- so long as he promptly avails himself of all the possible mechanisms for forming a legal and emotional bond with his child.

Adoption -- Consent -- Unwed Father -- Constitutionality of Consent Statute Requiring Father to Live with Mother

3. Domestic Relations Law § 111 (1) (e), which provides that an unwed father's consent to the adoption of his under-six-month-old child is required only where he has openly lived with the child or the mother for six continuous months immediately preceding the child's placement for adoption, openly acknowledged his paternity during such period, and paid reasonable pregnancy and birth expenses in accordance with his means, is unconstitutional in its entirety. Although section 111 (1) (e) is challenged only as to the "living together" requirement, which renders the statute unconstitutional as neither legitimately furthering the State's interest in adoption nor protecting the father's interest in a parental relationship with the child, the format of the existing statute as well as contemporaneous expressions of intent indicate that the Legislature would not have wished to have the unchallenged portions of the statute stand alone as the sole measure of an unwed father's commitment to the child, entitling him to veto an adoption.

Adoption -- Consent -- Unwed Father -- Criteria for Determining Right of Consent

4. In light of the declaration of unconstitutionality of Domestic Relations Law § 111 (1) (e), and until there is new legislation, an unwed father seeking to establish the requisite interest in a parental relationship for a right of consent to the adoption of his infant child must demonstrate a willingness himself to assume full custody of the child -- not merely to block adoption by others, and a prompt manifestation of parental responsibility. With respect to the former, any unfitness or waiver or abandonment would be considered by the courts, as they would whenever custody is in issue. As to the latter, the father's manifestation of responsibility for the child is to be assessed in the six continuing months immediately preceding the child's placement for adoption; judicial evaluation of the unwed father's conduct in this key period may include such considerations as his public acknowledgement of paternity, payment of pregnancy and birth expenses, steps taken to establish legal responsibility for the child, and other factors evincing a commitment to the child.

Adoption -- Consent  -- Unwed Father -- Consent Required

5. An unwed father established the requisite interest in a parental relationship for a right to veto the adoption of his infant child under the applicable criteria prescribed by the Court of Appeals for the interim between that court's declaration of unconstitutionality of Domestic Relations Law § 111 (1) (e) and new legislation, where the father himself seeking full custodial responsibility virtually from the time he learned of the mother's pregnancy, did everything possible to manifest and establish his parental responsibility. The father's conduct included persistent and uniformly rebuffed expressions of concern, offers of support and requests for custody, as well as his efforts to establish paternity and secure custody -- within the six months preceding the infant's placement for adoption.

Adoption -- Consent -- Unwed Father -- Determination of Requisite Interest in Parental Relationship

6. In light of the Court of Appeals declaration that Domestic Relations Law § 111 (1) (e) is unconstitutional due to the statute's "living together" requirement, and its prescription of criteria to be considered by courts, until there is new legislation, in determining whether an unwed father has established the requisite interest in a parental relationship for a right of consent to the adoption of his infant child, a proceeding involving the adoption of an unwed father's infant child is remitted by the Court of Appeals to the Appellate Division for further review of the facts necessary to that determination of a requisite interest, since the Appellate Division, in concluding that the father had no right to veto the adoption because he failed to satisfy the statute's "living together" requirement, explicitly did not complete a review of the necessary facts.

Adoption -- Consent -- When Marriage Confers Automatic Right of Consent upon Father

7. In order for marriage to confer upon a father an automatic right of consent to adoption of his infant child, the marriage must take place by the time the child is born (Domestic Relations Law § 24 [1]).

 

171 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Niesig v. Team I


No. 155


Court of Appeals of New York


76 N.Y.2d 363; 558 N.E.2d 1030; 559 N.Y.S.2d 493; 1990 N.Y. LEXIS 1978


May 31, 1990, Argued  
July 5, 1990, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order modified, without costs, in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed. Certified question answered in the negative.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff employee, who worked for third-party defendant construction company, brought suit against defendants contractor and owner after being injured at a construction site. He challenged the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) that he could not conduct ex parte interviews of current construction company employees under N.Y. Jud. App., Code Prof. Resp. DR 7-104(A)(1).


OVERVIEW: Stating that a disciplinary rule did not have the force of law, the court wrote that in interpreting it, it was entitled to make its own decision in the interests of justice. Writing that the issue was which corporate employees should be deemed to be parties under the rule, which prohibited communications with represented parties, the court stated that the blanket rule against any contact with corporate employees adopted by the lower court was too broad, while the "control group" test, defining "party" to include only the most senior management exercising substantial control over the corporation, was too narrow. It concluded that the test that best balanced the competing interests was one that defined "party" to include corporate employees whose acts or omissions in the matter under inquiry were binding on the corporation or imputed to the corporation for purposes of its liability, or employees implementing the advice of counsel. Such a test, it stated, was consistent with the purpose of the rule, was rooted in developed concepts of the law of evidence and the law of agency, and was similar to that adopted by courts and bar associations throughout the country.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the lower court's order denying the employee's motion to permit ex parte interviews of current construction company employees.


HEADNOTES

Attorney and Client -- Communication with Adverse Party -- Ex Parte Communications with Employees of Corporation -- Employees Deemed "Parties"

For purposes of Code of Professional Responsibility DR 7-104 (A) (1), which prohibits a lawyer from communicating directly with a "party" known to have counsel in a matter, the employees of a corporate party who are also to be considered "parties" include current employees whose acts or omissions in the matter under inquiry are binding on the corporation (in effect, the corporation's "alter ego") or imputed to the corporation for purposes of its liability, or current employees implementing the advice of counsel. All other employees may be interviewed informally by adversary counsel. With respect to the actual conduct of such interviews, it is assumed that attorneys would make their identity and interest known to interviewees and comport themselves ethically. Accordingly, in a personal injury action, plaintiff's counsel is permitted to conduct ex parte interviews of employees of the corporate defendant who were merely witnesses to the underlying accident.

 

172 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Schneider v. Sobol


No. 150


Court of Appeals of New York


76 N.Y.2d 309; 558 N.E.2d 23; 559 N.Y.S.2d 221; 1990 N.Y. LEXIS 1437


May 30, 1990, Argued  
June 28, 1990, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, with costs to defendant and intervenor-defendant, plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment denied, defendants' cross motion for summary judgment granted, and 8 NYCRR 175.35 (e) (1) (i) declared constitutional. Cross appeal dismissed as academic in view of the disposition of the appeal.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, the commissioner of education (the commissioner), and intervenor-defendant, a teachers' association, appealed a judgment from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York) that affirmed an order that upheld plaintiff school administrators' constitutional challenge to N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 8, § 175.35(e)(1)(i). The administrators cross-appealed the effective date of invalidation.


OVERVIEW: N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 8, § 175.35(e)(1)(i) (the regulation) defined an "eligible teacher," for purposes of salary supplements under the state's Excellence In Teaching program (the program), as anyone who taught class and was compensated under teachers' salary schedules. The regulation excluded from eligibility for supplements those who, while also teaching, were primarily administrators and compensated under an administrative or supervisory salary schedule. Plaintiffs, certain school principals and other administrators (collectively, the administrators), who also taught classes, successfully challenged the regulation on grounds that it violated state and federal constitutional equal protection rights. That determination was upheld by an appellate court. On appeal, the court reversed the ruling that invalidated the regulation. The court held that the regulation drew a rational categorization that served the objectives of the program, which was to ensure salary supplements for under-paid teachers. The court held that the regulation permissibly reduced the diversion of limited program funds away from the needy teachers to relatively more highly compensated administrators.


OUTCOME: The court reversed an order that declared the regulation unconstitutional, denied the administrators' motion for summary judgment, granted the commissioner and the association's cross-motion for summary judgment, declared the regulation to be constitutional, dismissed the administrator's cross-appeal, and assessed costs against the commissioner and the association.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- Teachers -- Excellence In Teaching Funds -- Constitutionality of Regulation Excluding Educators Compensated under Administrative Salary Schedule from Eligibility for Salary Supplements -- Equal Protection of Laws

 8 NYCRR 175.35 (e) (1) (i), which, in defining an "eligible teacher" for purposes of salary supplements under the Excellence In Teaching (EIT) program (Education Law § 1950 [15] [a]; § 3602 [27] [a]), includes anyone who teaches class and is compensated under teachers' salary schedules, but excludes those who, while also teaching, are primarily administrators compensated under an administrative or supervisory salary schedule, is constitutional under the Equal Protection Clauses of the Federal and State Constitutions (US Const 14th Amend; NY Const, art I, § 11) as it draws a rational categorization serving the objectives of the EIT statute. The regulation creates a functional and economic predicate for EIT eligibility which is authorized and consonant with the statutory language and the legislative intent which spurred the creation of EIT. The line drawn between those paid as administrators and those paid as teachers, based on the categorical compensation method, is a distinction keyed at least somewhat proportionately to empirical data and is designed to assure that the essential statutory purpose of providing supplements to the salaries of teachers, as underpaid educators, is achieved. Moreover, this distinction also preserves the residual EIT funds for the "teachers-in-general" group and reduces the diversion of these limited funds away from needy targeted teachers, paid as such, to relatively more highly compensated school administrators, paid as such.

 

173 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Tap Electrical Contracting Service, Inc. v. Hartnett


No. 141


Court of Appeals of New York


76 N.Y.2d 164; 556 N.E.2d 427; 556 N.Y.S.2d 988; 1990 N.Y. LEXIS 1308; 29 Wage & Hour Cas. (BNA) 1478


May 2, 1990, Argued  
June 5, 1990, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order modified, with costs to respondent-appellant Commissioner of Labor, in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant challenged the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Division (New York), which annulled a lower court's decision requiring the classification of all employees on state-funded public work projects as either journeymen or apprentices because the project was jointly funded under the Federal-Aid Highway Act, 23 U.S.C.S. § 101 et seq.


OVERVIEW: A lower court required the classification of all employees on state-funded public work projects as either journeymen or apprentices because the project was jointly funded under the Federal-Aid Highway Act, 23 U.S.C.S. § 101 et seq. Appellant contractor challenged that opinion contending that the statute was preempted by 23 C.F.R. § 230.107 (b). The court disagreed, holding that, apart from certain limitations, states had broad latitude to select from alternative trainee programs as long as they conformed with the prevailing goals and restrictions set by the commissioner.


OUTCOME: The judgment requiring the classification of all employees on state-funded public work projects as either journeymen or apprentices was affirmed as modified. Apart from certain limitations, states had broad latitude to select from alternative trainee programs as long as they conformed with the prevailing goals and restrictions set by the commissioner.


HEADNOTES

Labor -- Prevailing Rate of Wages -- Classification of Workers as Journeymen or Apprentices -- Applicability to Construction Projects Jointly Funded by State and Federal Governments

1. Labor Law § 220, as interpreted in Matter of Monarch Elec. Contr. Corp. v Roberts (70 NY2d 91) to require that all employees on State-funded public work projects be classified as either journeymen or apprentices, and that an employee must be individually registered in a skills training program approved by the State Department of Labor in order to qualify as an apprentice, applies to construction projects jointly funded by the State and Federal governments under the Federal-Aid Highway Act (23 USC § 101 et seq.) and is not preempted by or in conflict with Federal law.

Labor -- Prevailing Rate of Wages -- Willful Violation of Statute Prescribing Prevailing Rate of Wages -- Hiring Federal Trainees Paid Less Than Journey-Level Wages

2. In a CPLR article 78 proceeding, there is substantial evidence in the record to support the determination of respondent Commissioner of Labor of the State of New York that petitioner employer willfully violated Labor Law § 220 because it adhered to its own policy of hiring Federal trainees paid less than journey-level wages after it was expressly notified that it was not conforming to the Department of Labor's policy.

 

174 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Cahill v. PSC


No. 110


Court of Appeals of New York


76 N.Y.2d 102; 556 N.E.2d 133; 556 N.Y.S.2d 840; 1990 N.Y. LEXIS 1092; 112 P.U.R.4th 240


March 29, 1990, Argued  
May 10, 1990, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent Public Service Commission sought review of a decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York) that affirmed a lower court decision that found the policy of respondent whereby rates were set that included recovery by utilities of charitable contributions as proper operating expenses was violative of the U.S. Const. amend. I.


OVERVIEW: The lower court found in favor of respondent ratepayer, holding that the policy of respondent state public service commission authorizing utilities to pass along to ratepayers part of the cost of corporate charitable contributions violated U.S. Const. amend. I. Appellant telephone company sought review, alleging the policy should be retained so long as it was "germane" to its duties. Upon review, the court affirmed. It first noted that appellant was required to demonstrate a compelling state interest in the policy. As such, it failed to do so, and the policy was properly found to impede free speech because it extracted payments on ratepayers, imposing on them potentially objectionable expressions and causes of a host of organizations.


OUTCOME: The order of the appellate division that affirmed the finding that the policy of respondent state public service commission authorizing utilities to pass along to ratepayers part of the cost of corporate charitable contributions violated the First Amendment was affirmed because respondent failed to demonstrate a compelling state interest in the policy.


HEADNOTES

Public Utilities -- Rate Making -- Inclusion of Part of Cost of Utilities' Charitable Contributions -- First Amendment

1. The policy of the New York Public Service Commission authorizing utilities to pass along to ratepayers part of the cost of corporate charitable contributions is violative of the First Amendment of the US Constitution. Under the First Amendment the ratepayers are entitled to protection against forced financial support for causes and messages personally distasteful to them, because that would render those individuals faithless to their own beliefs. The extracted payments impose on the ratepayers, in some measure actually and in their estimation subjectively, particular and objectionable expressions and causes of a host of organizations. Moreover, the utilities have not fulfilled their burden of demonstrating a compelling State interest for the imposition on their ratepayers, rather than on their shareholders, of the bill for their selected philanthropy.

Constitutional Law -- First Amendment -- Strict Scrutiny Standard -- Compelling State Interest Test -- "Germaneness Test"

2. The United States Supreme Court in Abood v Detroit Bd. of Educ. (431 U.S. 209) did not displace the compelling State interest test -- the traditional strict scrutiny standard by which First Amendment intrusions are measured -- with a "germaneness test". The "germaneness" notion is inextricably interwoven into the analysis of whether the State has established some government interest and is not a substitute for a State interest component.

 

175 of 992 DOCUMENTS


F.W.E. Stapenhorst, Inc. v. Public Serv. Comm'n


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


75 N.Y.2d 577; 554 N.E.2d 61; 555 N.Y.S.2d 24; 1990 N.Y. LEXIS 923; 112 P.U.R.4th 239


March 28, 1990, Argued  
April 26, 1990, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants public service commission and utility challenged the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed a judgment granting respondent electric company's petition to reform the contract between the utility and respondent for the purchase of electricity under N.Y. Pub. Serv. Law § 66-c and the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978, 16 USC § 2601 et seq.


OVERVIEW: Respondent electric company contracted to provide electricity to appellant utility at an agreed price structure. The contract was not profitable and respondent tried to reform the contract price. The lower courts granted respondent's petition and directed reformation of the contract. The court reversed and held that the N.Y. Pub. Serv. Law § 66-c(1) did not require reformation of the contract because it was executed before the enactment of the statute. Appellant public service commission thus could not have "required" the contract pursuant to the then-nonexistent statute, nor dictated any of the contract's terms and conditions, including the conditioned statutory minimum payment. The contract was private, so the public service commission had no input on the terms or conditions of the contract. Accordingly, the court held that the statutory minimum price under § 66-c(1) was unavailable to respondent. The court held that the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978, 16 U.S.C.S. § 2601 et seq., was likewise inapplicable because that regulatory scheme was not intended to affect contracts in place before the promulgation of the regulations, as this contract was.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment in favor of respondent electric company and held that it was not entitled to reformation of the contract price with appellant utility to gain the incentive benefits of Federal and State price support programs.


HEADNOTES

Public Utilities -- Purchase of Hydroelectric Power -- Mandatory Minimum Price under Public Service Law -- Reformation of Contract Executed before Enactment of Statute

1. Petitioner, a private hydroelectric producer, who contracted to provide electricity for 20 years to New York State Electric and Gas Corporation at an agreed price structure, is not entitled under Public Service Law § 66-c (1) to reformation of the contract to incorporate the statute's higher rate of payment, where the contract was executed by the parties more than 1 1/2 years before the enactment of section 66-c (1). The statute provides that the Public Service Commission (PSC) "shall require" utilities "to enter into long-term contracts" with alternate energy producers "under such terms and conditions as the [PSC] shall find just and economically reasonable"; then, the mandatory minimum price is limited to purchased electricity referable to a contract the PSC initially "required" and whose terms it affected. Since the parties' contract was executed prior to the enactment of section 66-c (1), the PSC could not have "required" it pursuant to the then-nonexistent statute, nor could the Commission have dictated any of the contract's "terms and conditions", including the conditioned statutory minimum payment. Moreover, the contracting parties' intent under this contract is clear and is therefore controlling. No cause for judicial contractual reformation, bestowing new additional benefits under the statute, is shown on the ground that the deal did not turn out to be as advantageous as petitioner had hoped.

Public Utilities -- Purchase of Hydroelectric Power -- Mandatory Minimum Price under Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978 -- Reformation of Contract Executed before Promulgation of Implementing Regulations

2. Petitioner, a private hydroelectric producer, who contracted to provide electricity for 20 years to New York State Electric and Gas Corporation at an agreed price structure, is not entitled under the Federal regulations (18 CFR part 292) implementing the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act (16 USC § 2601 et seq). to reformation of the contract to incorporate the regulations' assumedly higher "avoided costs" rate of payment, where the contract was executed by the parties before the promulgation of the regulations. Although petitioner's plant constitutes a "new capacity" facility to which the assumedly higher "avoided costs" benefit provided by the regulations would apply, the regulatory scheme clearly was not intended to affect contracts in place before the promulgation of the regulations, even if a contracting party qualified as a "new capacity" power producer (18 CFR 292.301 [b] [2]).

 

176 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Forti v. New York State Ethics Com.


Nos. 65, 66


Court of Appeals of New York


75 N.Y.2d 596; 554 N.E.2d 876; 555 N.Y.S.2d 235; 1990 N.Y. LEXIS 754


February 14, 1990, Argued  
April 5, 1990, Decided



DISPOSITION: In Forti v New York State Ethics Commn.: Order affirmed, with costs.

In Kuttner v Cuomo: Order affirmed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff former state employees (employees) in two separate actions challenged Ethic's Commission opinion that the provisions of N.Y. Pub. Off. Law § 73(8) applied to them and the employees alleged § 73(8) violated their constitutional rights. The trial court found for employees and the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department reversed and the employees sought review and presented a certified question.


OVERVIEW: The revolving door provisions were to prevent former state employees from unfairly profiting from or trading upon contacts, associations, and special knowledge acquired during their tenure. Section 73(8) was to determined to apply to only those legislative employees who terminated their employment on or after January 1, 1989 and that former executive branch employees were covered by § 73(8) regardless of when they left their employment. The court held that § 73(8) was not retroactive as it prohibited a class of employees from engaging in certain activity after the statute's effective date. The court found that the legislative intent was that § 73(8) applied to the employees who had left service prior to January 1, 1989 as the statute covered former employees, as well as other who would become former employees. The court found no disparate treatment as the employees did not prove absence of a rational basis for the disparities, identify a suspect class, or that they had a fundamental right to engage in the unrestricted practice of their professions. The due process claim failed as they were able to practice their professions except in a limited number of employment situations.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed and answered the certified question in the negative.


HEADNOTES

Public Officers -- Conflicts of Interest -- Retroactivity of "Revolving Door" Provisions of Public Officers Law

1. Application of the strengthened "revolving door" provisions of Public Officers Law § 73 (8), which impose new and expanded restrictions on the business and professional activities of certain former government employees following their separation from State service, to plaintiffs, former State employees who left State service before the statute's January 1, 1989 effective date, does not render the statute "retroactive" in any true sense of that term. As construed by New York State Ethics Commission Advisory Opinion 88-1, the statute merely prohibits a class of individuals from engaging in certain specified business and professional activities after the statute's effective date. A statute is not retroactive when made to apply to future transactions merely because such transactions relate to and are founded upon antecedent events. Thus, the principles of statutory construction which require clear expression of a legislative intention to make a new provision retroactive are inapplicable in plaintiffs' actions challenging the opinion of the Ethics Commission that the new "revolving door" provisions were intended to apply to them.

Public Officers -- Conflicts of Interest -- Postemployment Business and Professional Activities -- Ex Post Facto Effect of "Revolving Door" Provisions of Public Officers Law

2. Public Officers Law § 73 (8), whose strengthened "revolving door" provisions impose new and expanded restrictions on the business and professional activities of certain former government employees following their separation from State service, does not constitute an ex post facto law in violation of U.S. Constitution, article I, § 10, cl (1), with respect to plaintiffs, former State employees who left State service before the statute's January 1, 1989 effective date. A statute is not retroactive when made to apply to future transactions merely because such transactions relate to and are founded upon antecedent events. Thus, in plaintiffs' actions challenging the constitutionality of section 73 (8), the court need not consider whether the restrictions on professional activities imposed by the statute are within the class of punitive measures contemplated by the Ex Post Facto Clause.

Public Officers -- Conflicts of Interest -- Postemployment Business and Professional Activities -- Applicability of "Revolving Door" Provisions of Public Officers Law to Executive Branch Employees Leaving State Service before Effective Date of Provisions

3. The Legislature intended the new "revolving door" rules set forth in Public Officers Law § 73 (8), which impose new and expanded restrictions on the business and professional activities of certain former government employees following their separation from State service, to be applicable to plaintiffs and other former executive branch employees who left State service before the January 1, 1989 effective date of the statute. The statutory prohibitions, which were to become effective on that date, were made applicable to any "person who has served as a state officer or employee" (Public Officers Law § 73 [8]). Thus, on its face, the new statute encompassed employees who had previously served the State, as well as those who would become "former" employees in the future. Further, the express exemption for legislative employees who left State service before January 1, 1989 (L 1987, ch 813, § 26 [a]) furnishes strong proof that other State workers whose employment was terminated before that date were intended to be included. In addition, the absence of a savings clause -- or at least a specific legislative provision for a separate set of rules to govern former executive branch employees whose service was severed at some earlier point -- further supports the conclusion that such employees were intended to be covered under Public Officers Law § 73 (8).

Public Officers -- Conflicts of Interest -- Postemployment Business and Professional Activities -- Application of Lifetime Ban on Certain Activities to Attorneys Who Left State Service

4. The new provisions of Public Officers Law § 73 (8), which impose a lifetime ban on former State officers or employees appearing or otherwise practicing before their former agencies in connection with a matter in which they directly participated during their State tenure, is not harsh or unreasonable as applied to plaintiff attorneys, former State employees who left State service prior to the statute's effective date and entered private practice. The ban is designed to prevent former public servants from falling prey to one form of conflict of interest, or to the appearance of a conflict, and from taking unfair advantage of their insider's knowledge and contacts. All admitted attorneys within this State, including plaintiffs, have long been subject to such a restriction under DR 9-101 (B) of the Code of Professional Responsibility. The new provisions of section 73 (8) merely extend this reasonable limitation to nonattorneys formerly employed within the executive branch. Furthermore, any hardship resulting from plaintiffs' prior engagement on forbidden matters has been mitigated by the Legislature's decision to postpone the statute's effective date for almost 17 months after its enactment, thereby enabling individuals such as plaintiffs, as well as their clients, to make suitable alternative arrangements.

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Rational Basis Test -- Restrictions on Practice of Law by Attorneys Formerly Employed in Executive Branch of State Government -- Different Treatment of Former Legislative Branch Employees

5. Statutes or rules imposing reasonable restrictions on the right of admitted attorneys to practice law are subject to review, but only under the least exacting constitutional standard requiring a rational basis for the restriction. Accordingly, plaintiffs, attorneys who were formerly employed in the executive branch of State government, and are subject to the strengthened "revolving door" provisions of Public Officers Law § 73 (8) restricting the postemployment business and professional activities of certain former State employees, must demonstrate the lack of a rational basis for the statute's disparate treatment of former employees of the executive branch, as distinguished from those of the legislative branch who are subject to less stringent postemployment restrictions, in order to succeed in their argument that such disparate treatment violates their rights to equal protection under the State and Federal Constitutions.

Public Officers -- Conflicts of Interest -- Postemployment Business and Professional Activities -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Disparate Treatment of Former Executive and Legislative Branch Employees

6. Application of the strengthened "revolving door" provisions of Public Officers Law § 73 (8), which impose new and expanded restrictions on the business and professional activities of certain former government employees following their separati

 

177 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Akpan v. Koch


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


75 N.Y.2d 561; 554 N.E.2d 53; 555 N.Y.S.2d 16; 1990 N.Y. LEXIS 756


February 14, 1990, Argued  
April 5, 1990, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff interested individuals challenged an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) that granted a motion for summary judgment in favor of defendant city officials and dismissed plaintiffs' complaint alleging that defendants had violated the New York State Environmental Quality Review Act in approving an urban renewal project.


OVERVIEW: Defendant city officials entered into a source agreement with a private builder to develop an urban renewal area, and the project underwent several levels of municipal approval before it could be implemented. After an environmental impact statement was prepared, the city departments designated as co-lead agencies for the project concluded that it would not trigger significant secondary displacement of local residents. Plaintiff interested individuals filed an action for declaratory and injunctive relief, and the appellate division affirmed the supreme court's grant of defendants' motion for summary judgment. On appeal, the court affirmed, holding that defendants' lead agency had taken the required hard look at the issues concerning the project's potential impact on the secondary displacement of local residents and that its action in approving the project could not be characterized as arbitrary and capricious or as an abuse of discretion. The issue of secondary displacement had been raised at every level of the New York State Environmental Quality Review Act's process, and the court refused to substitute its judgment for the agencies' as to the accuracy of the data presented.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the grant of summary judgment in favor of defendant city officials after finding that the comprehensive review taken with respect to an urban renewal project included the requisite hard look at the issue of secondary displacement of local residents. Thus, the dismissal of the complaint was not arbitrary and capricious or an abuse of discretion.


HEADNOTES

Environmental Conservation -- Environmental Quality Review -- Consideration of Secondary Displacement Effect of Urban Development Project on Low-Income Housing -- "Protected Housing Study"

1. In approving a proposed urban renewal project, the Board of Estimate of the City of New York (BOE), as the lead agency for purposes of the State Environmental Quality Review Act (ECL art 8), took the required "hard look" at the issues concerning the project's potential impact on the secondary displacement of local residents and made a "reasoned elaboration" of the basis for its determination that the project would not trigger significant secondary displacement; therefore, the BOE's action in approving the project cannot be characterized as arbitrary and capricious or an abuse of discretion. Although the "protected housing study" submitted to the Department of City Planning (DCP), a co-lead agency, in response to that agency's request for additional information on the specific concerns about secondary displacement did not provide all the specific information requested by DCP, it cannot be said that the BOE's acceptance of the study's analysis in support of the conclusion that the project would not trigger significant secondary displacement was irrational; nor can the court substitute its judgment as to the accuracy of the data presented. Further, although the study did not provide all current information on every dwelling unit in the study area, it did provide a basis for a reasoned consideration of the secondary displacement issue.

Environmental Conservation -- Environmental Quality Review -- Final Environmental Impact Statement -- Secondary Displacement Effect of Urban Development Project on Low-Income Housing

2. With respect to the Board of Estimate of the City of New York's approval of a proposed urban renewal project, the State Environmental Quality Review Act (ECL art 8) was not violated because the raw data of a "protected housing study" concerning the potential impact of the project on the secondary displacement of local residents was not included in the final environmental impact statement (FEIS). There is no requirement that the FEIS contain all the raw data supporting its analysis so long as that analysis is sufficient to allow informed consideration and comment on the issues raised. The FEIS analysis for this project, which emphasized that the project would not alter the already established displacement trends in the study area, was sufficient to allow such informed consideration.
