Environmental Conservation -- Environmental Quality Review -- Consideration of Secondary Displacement Effect of Urban Development Project on Low-Income Housing -- Consideration of Other Unrelated Development Projects in Same Geographic Area

3. In approving a proposed urban renewal project, the failure of the Board of Estimate of the City of New York, as the lead agency for purposes of the State Environmental Quality Review Act (ECL art 8), to consider the cumulative impact on secondary displacement of the proposed project and other, unrelated development projects in the same geographic area does not render the agency's consideration of the issue of secondary displacement deficient. While it was within the agency's discretion to consider the cumulative impact of such unrelated projects, the agency was not required to do so.

Environmental Conservation -- Environmental Quality Review -- Approval of Urban Development Project by Lead Agency -- Propriety of Designation of Non-Decision-Making Agencies as Co-Lead Agencies

4. In approving a proposed urban renewal project, the Board of Estimate of the City of New York (BOE) properly acted as lead agency for purposes of the State Environmental Quality Review Act (ECL art 8 [SEQRA]), notwithstanding the BOE's designation of two non-decision-making agencies -- the Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) and the Department of City Planning (DCP) -- as co-lead agencies. The BOE reviewed and evaluated the draft environmental impact statement and the final environmental impact statement (FEIS), conducted public hearings on the FEIS, determined that the project would not have a significant impact on the environment, and ultimately made the final decision to approve the project. Although the DCP and DEP were undeniably involved in the SEQRA review process, the BOE merely relied upon the expertise of these agencies, while fully retaining and exercising its role as the lead agency assessing the environmental impact of the project.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Zoning Amendments -- "Well-Considered Plan"

5. Land use changes approved for an urban renewal project by the Board of Estimate of the City of New York, as the lead agency for purposes of the State Environmental Quality Review Act (ECL art 8), were in accordance with a well-considered plan for the City of New York despite the project's failure to provide for low-income housing. Such zoning amendments meet the general requirement for a well-considered plan when, as here, they are carefully studied, prepared and considered and are adopted for a legitimate government purpose. Moreover, there is no requirement that a particular development project include low-income housing.

 

178 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Jiggetts v. Grinker


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


75 N.Y.2d 411; 553 N.E.2d 570; 554 N.Y.S.2d 92; 1990 N.Y. LEXIS 713


February 7, 1990, Argued  
April 3, 1990, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The appellate division of the Supreme Court for the First Judicial Department (New York) reversed the order of the lower court, which denied defendants, State of New York and New York City Commissioners of Social Services' motion to dismiss plaintiff ADC recipients' complaint. ADC recipients appealed.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff ADC recipients filed suit against defendants, State of New York and New York City Commissioners of Social Services, alleging that the shelter allowances they received were inadequate. The trial court denied defendants' motion to dismiss for failure to state a cause of action. The appellate court reversed and dismissed ADC recipients' complaint. On appeal, the court reversed the decision of the appellate court. The court examined the legislative intent of N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 350(1)(a) and determined it imposed a duty on defendants to have established shelter allowances which bore a reasonable relation to the cost of housing in New York City.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision of the appellate court, which had dismissed ADC recipients' complaint against defendants.


HEADNOTES

Social Services -- Aid to Dependent Children -- Duty of State Commissioner of Social Services to Establish Shelter Allowances Bearing Reasonable Relation to Cost of Housing

Social Services Law § 350 (1) (a), which requires the State Commissioner of Social Services to establish "adequate" shelter allowances for recipients of Aid to Families with Dependent Children (ADC), imposes a statutory duty on the State Commissioner to establish shelter allowances that bear a reasonable relation to the cost of housing in New York City. Section 350 (1) (a), as well as sections 344 (2) and 350-j (3) of the Social Services Law, manifest the Legislature's determination that family units should be kept together in a home-type setting and impose a duty on the Department of Social Services to establish shelter allowances adequate for that purpose. A schedule establishing assistance levels so low that it forces large numbers of families with dependent children into homelessness does not meet the statutory standard. Accordingly, a claim by plaintiffs, recipients of public assistance in the form of ADC residing in New York City whose shelter costs exceed the maximum allowance payable to them under the Department of Social Services schedules (18 NYCRR 352.3), that the State Commissioner has failed to perform that duty presents a justiciable controversy involving the alleged failure of the executive branch of government to comply with the directions of the legislative branch and, therefore, an Appellate Division order granting motions by defendants, the State and City Commissioners of Social Services and plaintiffs' landlords, to dismiss the complaint for failure to state a cause of action is reversed, and the motions are denied.

 

179 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re Tyler


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


75 N.Y.2d 525; 553 N.E.2d 1316; 554 N.Y.S.2d 806; 1990 N.Y. LEXIS 608


February 13, 1990, Argued  
March 27, 1990, Decided



DISPOSITION: Determined sanction accepted, without costs, and Josephine D. Tyler removed from the office of Justice of the Caneadea Town Court.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner county justice sought review of a determination of respondent state judicial conduct commission that petitioner should have been removed from the office of county justice. Petitioner contended that she should not have been charged with misconduct for certain of her actions and she also argued that the sanction imposed was too severe.


OVERVIEW: Respondent state judicial conduct commission found that petitioner county justice issued a warrant of arrest pertaining to a dishonored check given to petitioner's husband, the complainant, by an offender. Despite her relationship to the complainant, petitioner refused to disqualify herself, committed the offender to jail in lieu of bail, and failed to appoint counsel at arraignment. Respondent also found that petitioner improperly issued an order directing an offender charged with harassment to pay child support, sent personal communications on court stationary, and struck an offender across the face with a book. Respondent determined that the sanction of removal from office was appropriate. On review, the court accepted the determined sanction. The court did find that the proof was insufficient to sustain a finding of misconduct under the count charging her with ordering the child support. However, the court found that petitioner's other contentions regarding her guilt were without merit. The court also found that the sanction was not too severe. Petitioner's continuance in office would have posed a threat to the proper administration of justice.


OUTCOME: The court accepted the sanction of removing petitioner county justice from office, as determined by respondent state judicial conduct commission. Petitioner's conduct displayed a lack of the basic qualities of fairness, impartiality, and self-restraint. Petitioner clearly displayed favoritism to her husband in an action whereby she sentenced an offender who gave her husband a bad check, to jail in lieu of bond and failed to appoint an attorney.


HEADNOTES

Judges -- Disciplinary Proceedings -- Removal from Office Petitioner, a Town Justice, who issued a warrant of arrest pertaining to a dishonored check given to petitioner's husband, the complainant, by defendant, presided over defendant's arraignment, and committed the defendant to jail in lieu of $ 5,000 bail, sent a written communication on court stationery to a private contractor contesting the balance allegedly owed the contractor by petitioner's father, struck a young man in court with a telephone directory when he denied having written obscenities on the court's table, and sent letters in Town Court envelopes to various individuals concerning the use and quality of well water in an apartment building owned by her father, is guilty of misconduct, and the determined sanction of removal is accepted. Petitioner's continuance in office would pose a threat to the proper administration of justice.

 

180 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Keyes


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


75 N.Y.2d 343; 552 N.E.2d 617; 553 N.Y.S.2d 81; 1990 N.Y. LEXIS 264


January 9, 1990, Argued  
February 20, 1990, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant challenged order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York) reversing dismissal of indictment for promoting a sexual performance by a child pursuant to N.Y. Penal. Law § 263.15, and reinstating the indictment.


OVERVIEW: Defendant procured child pornography from an undercover officer, and was charged with promoting a sexual performance by a child pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 263.15. Trial court threw out the charge, finding that the statute punished the distribution of child pornography, and not its acquisition for personal use, but lower court reinstated charge. Court found that the statutory language of "promoting," which was defined to include "procuring," included defendant's actions, reading the statute according to its plain language and the legislative history, which indicated the legislature was not concerned solely with punishing persons who profited from the distribution of child pornography. Statute was not unconstitutional, as defendant was not charged merely with possession of the material.


OUTCOME: Affirmed, as defendant was not charged merely with the possession of child pornography, and because statute was to be read according to its plain meaning and in view of its legislative history.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Indictment -- Promoting Sexual Performance by Child -- What Constitutes "Procurement" -- Acquisition of Child Pornography for Personal Consumption

The procurement of child pornography for personal use falls within the ambit of Penal Law § 263.15, which criminalizes the promotion of a sexual performance by a child. Although the term "procure" is not defined in the Penal Law, the leading definition commonly assigned to the term is "to get possession of: obtain, acquire * * * esp: to get possession of by particular care and effort". Understood in this sense, the term "procure" as used in Penal Law § 263.00 (5) defines "promote" for the purposes of Penal Law § 263.15 as simply the acquisition of child pornography, whether for personal consumption or for distribution to others. Moreover, the legislative history of Penal Law article 263 indicates that the Legislature intended to employ broad measures to eradicate child pornography in all its forms -- that history contains no suggestion that the consumers of such material were to be excluded from the reach of those measures. Consistent with its efforts to eradicate the social evil of child pornography, Penal Law § 263.15 is directed at the consumers of child pornography as well as at its manufacturers and distributors. Accordingly, the Appellate Division correctly reinstated the indictment charging defendant with promoting a sexual performance by a child in violation of section 263.15 based on allegations that defendant, knowing the contents thereof, procured child pornography through the mail, and procured child pornography in his home from an undercover officer.

 

181 of 992 DOCUMENTS


McGraw-Hill, Inc. v. State Tax Com.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


75 N.Y.2d 852; 552 N.E.2d 163; 552 N.Y.S.2d 915; 1990 N.Y. LEXIS 232


January 11, 1990, Argued  
February 20, 1990, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, with costs, in a memorandum.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Franchise Tax on Business Corporations -- Tax on Print Media Advertising Revenue -- Constitutionality of Differentiation between Print and Broadcast Media

1. In a proceeding to review a determination of the State Tax Commission sustaining a corporate franchise tax assessment imposed against petitioner, which publishes magazines for distribution nationwide, a judgment of the Appellate Division, which annulled the determination and granted the petition, should be affirmed for the reasons stated in the opinion thereat, which concluded that the difference in treatment between the print media and the broadcast media under 20 NYCRR 4-4.3 (f) (2), whereby the latter were permitted to allocate receipts for advertising according to the percentage of listeners or viewers they had in each State, while the print media were required to treat all advertising revenues as originating in New York if the commercial contracts were executed in New York, violated the First Amendment guarantee of freedom of the press; that a tax that singles out the press for differential treatment is presumptively unconstitutional; that a taxing scheme which taxes some members of the press but exempts others does not escape First Amendment scrutiny even if businesses outside of the press are also not exempt; that given the different treatment between the two types of media, it was incumbent upon respondent Commission to show that the regulation was necessary to serve a compelling State interest, and that respondent failed to make such a showing.

Taxation -- Franchise Tax on Business Corporations -- Tax on Print Media Advertising Revenue -- Repayment of Sums Improperly Charged

2. In a proceeding to review a determination of the State Tax Commission sustaining a corporate franchise tax assessment imposed against petitioner, which publishes magazines for distribution nationwide, a judgment of the Appellate Division, which annulled the determination and granted the petition, should be affirmed. Inasmuch as respondent Commission has not established that requiring repayment to petitioner of almost $ 1.75 million in taxes, interest and penalties would impose any undue burden, the court's decision, based upon amendment to the Commission's rules and a session law (L 1981, ch 103, § 1), may be applied retroactively, notwithstanding that the methodology for assessing the tax had been approved prior to the statutory and regulatory changes, since precluding repayment would leave petitioner virtually remediless. After the rule was changed, petitioner had little reason to pursue this expensive and lengthy litigation except to recover the sums improperly charged against it.

 

182 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Besser v. E. R. Squibb & Sons, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


75 N.Y.2d 847; 552 N.E.2d 171; 552 N.Y.S.2d 923; 1990 N.Y. LEXIS 217


January 11, 1990, Argued  
February 15, 1990, Decided


HEADNOTES

Limitation of Actions -- Revival Statute -- Toxic Torts -- Borrowing Statute

In an action to recover damages for personal injuries sustained by plaintiff, who was born in Pennsylvania and who was allegedly exposed, in utero, to diethylstilbestrol (DES) during her gestation, and who became ill and was diagnosed as having a DES-related disease while a resident of New Jersey, an order of the Appellate Division, which affirmed an order granting defendants summary judgment, is affirmed for the reasons stated in the opinion at the Appellate Division, which concluded that the "borrowing statute" (CPLR 202) requires that a foreign Statute of Limitations apply where a cause of action accrues outside New York in favor of a nonresident if it is shorter than the applicable New York limitation period; that the Toxic Tort Revival Statute (L 1986, ch 682, § 4) provided a one-year window period for those New Yorkers whose claims based on the exposure to certain chemicals, including DES, were previously barred by the "last exposure" rule; that the Legislature's purpose in enacting the revival statute was merely to remove the obstacle of the "last exposure" rule, not to repeal the salutary purpose underlying the borrowing statute, i.e., the prevention of forum shopping; that New York had no interest in reviving the claims of nonresident plaintiffs who were adequately protected under their own States' Statutes of Limitation; that Pennsylvania, where plaintiff was exposed to DES, and New Jersey, where her injuries were manifested and diagnosed, had Statutes of Limitation which began to run upon discovery of the injury; that the introductory phrase of the revival statute, viz., "[notwithstanding] any other provision of law", was intended to obviate the proscriptions of CPLR 214, and that the failure to apply the "borrowing statute" would divest defendant drug companies of those vested rights created by the laws of sister States where the action would otherwise be barred.

 

183 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Vespucci


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


75 N.Y.2d 434; 553 N.E.2d 965; 554 N.Y.S.2d 417; 1990 N.Y. LEXIS 229


January 3, 1990, Argued  
February 15, 1990, Decided



DISPOSITION: In each case: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants sought review of a judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York), which affirmed a judgment of the trial court, which convicted defendants, upon their pleas of guilty, of coercion in the first degree, conspiracy in the fifth degree, attempted coercion in the second degree, official misconduct, attempted bribe-receiving in the second degree, and perjury.


OVERVIEW: Defendant pled guilty to coercion in the first degree, conspiracy in the fifth degree, attempted coercion in the second degree, official misconduct, attempted bribe-receiving in the second degree, and perjury. The appellate court affirmed convictions of the trial court, and defendants sought review and contended that the New York State Organized Crime Task Force (NYSOCTF) lacked authority to be an applicant for eavesdropping warrants. Pursuant to Title III of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 (Act), 18 U.S.C.S. § 2510 et seq., minimum constitutional criteria were imposed upon the states for electronic surveillance. The Act limited those who could apply for eavesdropping warrants to the principal prosecuting attorney or any subdivision thereof, under 18 U.S.C.S. § 2516(2). The court held that the NYSOCTF had the authority to secure the pertinent eavesdropping warrants and that it was not in violation of the Act. The court affirmed judgments of the lower courts.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed judgments of the lower courts, which convicted defendants of numerous crimes as a result of electronic eavesdropping warrants obtained by the New York State Organized Crime Task Force (NYSOCTF). The court held that, pursuant to the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act, the NYSOCTF had the authority under the state to secure the pertinent warrants.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Eavesdropping Warrants -- Validity of State Statute Authorizing Director of Organized Crime Task Force to Apply for Warrants

1. CPL 700.05 (5), in expressly including the Director of the New York State Organized Crime Task Force (OCTF) as a law enforcement officer authorized to apply for eavesdropping warrants, is consistent with its Federal enabling statute (18 USC § 2516 [2]), which limits those who may be applicants for court-authorized eavesdropping warrants to "[the] principal prosecuting attorney of any State, or the principal prosecuting attorney of any subdivision thereof, if such attorney is authorized by a statute of that State". The CPL 700.05 (5) authorization of the Deputy Attorney-General in charge of the OCTF does not impermissibly broaden the literal letter and the overarching purpose of 18 USC § 2516 (2). The State and Federal statutes are specific and in harmony and, therefore, the New York applicant authorization statute is valid. Accordingly, in light of the State statute's validity, and since there was no infirmity in the statute's utilization to secure eavesdropping warrants obtained by OCTF's Director in accordance with the valid State statute and procedures as part of the OCTF's investigation into organized crime infiltration of Long Island's refuse-carting industry, evidence garnered pursuant to those warrants was properly held admissible and not suppressible in the prosecution of defendants for coercion and conspiracy arising out of the OCTF's investigation.

Crimes -- Eavesdropping Warrants -- "Immediate" Sealing Requirement

2. The sealing of six eavesdropping tapes was accomplished "immediately" within the intendment of CPL 700.50 (2) where, although the tapes were not sealed immediately upon the expiration of the warrant periods, the prosecutor in each instance made alternative arrangements in advance with court approval and directions. On five of these six occasions, the period expired at midnight on a Saturday night and, in preexpiration meetings, the issuing Justice directed that the tapes be presented for sealing on the first business day after expiration. In the sixth instance, the prosecutor immediately presented the tapes for sealing but was informed by court officials of the issuing Justice's unavailability at that particular moment. The prosecutor complied with the issuing Justice's direction to return the next day and the tapes were then sealed.

 

184 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Fosmire v. Nicoleau


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


75 N.Y.2d 218; 551 N.E.2d 77; 551 N.Y.S.2d 876; 1990 N.Y. LEXIS 91


November 16, 1989, Argued  
January 18, 1990, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) vacated an ex parte order of the trial court that granted appellant medical center authorization to administer blood transfusions to respondent patient against her express refusal of such transfusions. The medical center appealed.


OVERVIEW: The patient was a Jehovah's Witness and indicated on her admission forms that she expressly refused any treatment that included blood transfusions. Subsequent to a Caesarian birth and complications, the patient again refused blood transfusions. The medical center sought a court order granting permission to administer blood transfusions. The trial court granted the order and the medical center administered the blood transfusions. The court held that the trial court order violated the patient's rights to due process and the patient's right to refuse consent to medical treatment. Because the patient had a right to refuse medical treatment, the court did not consider the patient's constitutional right to religious freedom. The patient was a competent adult who had a right to determine the course of her own treatment, including the right to decline blood transfusions. There was no showing that the State had a superior interest in preventing the patient from exercising her right to consent to medical treatment. The State's interest in preserving the family unit was insufficient to provide the state with a superior interest over the patient's right to refuse treatment.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the appellate division that vacated the trial court's ex parte order that granted medical center authorization to administer blood transfusions to a patient after she refused such transfusions.


HEADNOTES

Hospitals and Asylums -- Court-Ordered Medical Treatment -- Lack of Patient Consent -- Propriety of Ex Parte Application -- Emergency Doctrine

1. Supreme Court should not have signed an order authorizing a hospital to administer blood transfusions to a patient over the patient's personal objections, without giving the patient or her husband notice and an opportunity to be heard. Applications for court-ordered medical treatment affect important rights of the patients and should generally comply with due process requirements of notice and the right to be heard before the order is signed. The patient's condition was not so grave that there was no opportunity for prior notice and a hearing. In addition, the patient's medical file recorded a long-standing unequivocal personal decision to decline transfusions. Since three hours elapsed between the time the application was made and the time the order was signed and an additional six hours passed before it was executed, there was ample time to provide notice and an opportunity for a hearing, however informal. Moreover, the emergency doctrine, which permits a doctor or a hospital to provide treatment to a patient in need of immediate medical attention, who is unconscious or otherwise unable to consent, without first obtaining a court order, is inapplicable here because the patient clearly stated before admission to the hospital and throughout her stay that she would not consent to blood transfusions.

Hospitals and Asylums -- Right of Competent Adult Patient to Decline Blood Transfusions

2. A competent adult has a personal common-law and statutory right (Public Health Law §§ 2504, 2805-d) to determine the course of his or her own medical treatment. This right is not absolute, however, and may have to yield to superior State interests in certain circumstances. Accordingly, Supreme Court should not have authorized a hospital to give blood transfusions to an adult Jehovah's Witness who refused to consent to blood transfusions prior to the delivery of her baby and who persisted in the refusal after losing a substantial amount of blood following the birth of the child. The patient, as a competent adult, had a right to determine the course of her own treatment, which included the right to decline blood transfusions, and there is no showing that the State had a superior interest in preventing her from exercising that right because she is a young, otherwise healthy person facing a risk of death which could be completely eliminated by the transfusion, or because she is a parent.

 

185 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Motor Vehicle Mfrs. Ass'n v. State


[No number in original]


Court of Appeals of New York


75 N.Y.2d 175; 550 N.E.2d 919; 551 N.Y.S.2d 470; 1990 N.Y. LEXIS 89


November 14, 1989, Argued  
January 18, 1990, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff trade associations sought review of a decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York), which affirmed a decision of the supreme court in favor of defendants, the state and others, and held that the alternative arbitration mechanism of N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 198-a(k) of the New Car Lemon Law (Lemon Law), N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 198-a, did not violate the state constitution or the New York Administrative Procedure Act (APA).


OVERVIEW: The court held that: (1) the trade associations were not entitled to a jury trial because the replacement remedy under the Lemon Law was analogous to specific performance and would not have been subject to a jury trial under common law; (2) the refund remedy of the Lemon Law was also equitable in nature and thus did not entitle the trade associations to a jury trial because it permitted the consumer to seek rescission to undo the wrong and return to the status quo ante and did not require the consumer to revoke and cancel the contract before litigation; (3) the mechanism did not abridge the constitutionally guaranteed jurisdiction of the supreme court because the supreme court was vested with jurisdiction once a consumer decided to litigate a claim in court or either party decided to seek review of the arbitration proceeding; (4) the mechanism did not unconstitutionally delegate sovereign judicial power to private arbitrators because the Lemon Law carefully outlined standards to guide the arbitrators and authorized judicial oversight; and (5) the APA requirements did not apply to the mechanism because it applied only to "agencies" conducting adjudicatory proceedings.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles -- Lemon Law -- New Car Lemon Law -- Alternative Arbitration Mechanism -- Right to Jury Trial -- Refund Remedy

1. The New Car Lemon Law alternative arbitration mechanism (General Business Law § 198-a [k]) does not violate NY Constitution, article I, § 2 by depriving automobile manufacturers of their right to a trial by jury with respect to the statute's remedy of a refund of full purchase price of a vehicle (General Business Law § 198-a [c] [1]). The constitutional guarantee of a jury trial in article I, § 2 applies to all cases afforded a jury trial under the common law prior to 1777, i.e., those in which the nature and substance of the relief requested was legal as opposed to equitable, and to all cases to which the Legislature extended a right to a jury trial prior to 1894. The Lemon Law refund remedy is an action seeking a rescission and restoration of the status quo ante, similar to an action for restitution, and is equitable in nature. It would not have been triable under the common law and is not entitled to a jury trial under NY Constitution, article I, § 2. That incidental fees and charges are recoverable under the Lemon Law refund remedy does not compel a contrary conclusion; a party may receive full relief in an equitable action and the awarding of fees as an incident of the equitable relief sought to restore the status quo ante does not disturb the equitable nature of the action.

Motor Vehicles -- Lemon Law -- New Car Lemon Law -- Alternative Arbitration Mechanism -- Right to Jury Trial -- Replacement Remedy

2. The New Car Lemon Law alternative arbitration mechanism (General Business Law § 198-a [k]) does not violate NY Constitution, article I, § 2 by depriving automobile manufacturers of their right to a trial by jury with respect to the statute's remedy of acceptance of a replacement vehicle (General Business Law § 198-a [c] [1]). The constitutional guarantee of a jury trial in article I, § 2 applies to all cases afforded a jury trial under the common law prior to 1777, i.e., those in which the nature and substance of the relief requested was legal as opposed to equitable, and to all cases to which the Legislature extended a right to a jury trial prior to 1894. The replacement remedy provided by the Lemon Law is analogous to specific performance; it is designed to produce, as nearly as practicable under the circumstances, the same performance promised under the contract. The remedy is equitable in nature and would not be subject to a jury trial under common law. Accordingly, plaintiffs are not entitled to a jury trial under NY Constitution, article I, § 2 when the consumer seeks the replacement remedy under General Business Law § 198-a (c) (1).

Courts -- Jurisdiction -- Supreme Court -- New Car Lemon Law Alternative Arbitration Mechanism

3. The compulsory arbitration mechanism implemented by the New Car Lemon Law (General Business Law § 198-a [k]) does not abridge the constitutionally guaranteed jurisdiction of the Supreme Court (NY Const, art VI, § 7 [a]) insofar as it limits the Supreme Court's jurisdiction to CPLR article 75 review when a consumer elects compulsory arbitration in the first instance. The Supreme Court has lost no jurisdiction as a result of General Business Law § 198-a (k) because the jurisdiction secured to it by the Constitution does not attach until a claim is made litigable, that is, made the subject of a suit or litigation in a court of law. If the consumer chooses to litigate a Lemon Law claim, the Supreme Court has full jurisdiction to adjudicate it. If the consumer chooses arbitration, the claim becomes litigable when either party seeks review of the award. Although the type of adjudication differs when a consumer elects arbitration, the statute does not withhold or abridge the court's "general original jurisdiction".

Motor Vehicles -- Lemon Law -- New Car Lemon Law -- Alternative Arbitration Mechanism -- Abridgement of Powers of Judiciary -- Violation of Separation of Powers or Accountability

4. The New Car Lemon Law alternative arbitration mechanism (General Business Law § 198-a [k]) does not unconstitutionally abridge the powers of the judiciary or violate fundamental concepts of separation of powers or accountability. The Legislature may, by statute, provide for compulsory references in certain instances provided that it does not violate rights guaranteed to the parties by the Constitution and, since claims arising under the Lemon Law are not entitled to a jury trial, adjudication by arbitrators in the first instance is permissible under the Constitution. Moreover, arbitrators are selected pursuant to detailed standards, the procedures they must follow are specified, the grounds for relief defined and their determinations are subject to judicial review under CPLR article 75 to ensure compliance with these standards.

Motor Vehicles -- Lemon Law -- New Car Lemon Law -- Alternative Arbitration Mechanism -- Applicability of State Administrative Procedure Act

5. The New Car Lemon Law alternative arbitration mechanism (General Business Law § 198-a [k]) does not violate the State Administrative Procedure Act by not requiring that the arbitrator's decision include findings of fact, conclusions of law, or reasons for the determination (see, State Administrative Procedure Act § 302 [1]). The State Administrative Procedure Act requirements apply to "agencies" conducting "adjudicatory proceedings" (see, State Administrative Procedure Act §§ 100, 102). General Business Law § 198-a (k) provides that the alternate arbitration procedure shall be conducted by a professional arbitrator or arbitration firm, presently the American Arbitration Association, which is not an "agency" within the meaning of the State Administrative Procedure Act (see, State Administrative Procedure Act § 102 [1]).

 

186 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Cintron


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


75 N.Y.2d 249; 551 N.E.2d 561; 552 N.Y.S.2d 68; 1990 N.Y. LEXIS 76


October 17, 1989, Argued  
January 11, 1990, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed a judgment upon a verdict convicting defendant of attempted rape, attempted sodomy, and sexual abuse of a child.


OVERVIEW: Defendant challenged the validity and application of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 65, which authorized a trial court, under specified circumstances in certain sex crime cases, to permit a child witness to testify from a testimonial room over live, two-way, closed-circuit television. On appeal, the court held that § 65 was constitutional on its face, but only when the presumption of constitutionality was applied, and N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 65.20(10) was read as embodying the additional requirements of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 65.10(1), which included that the likelihood that the child witness, as a result of "extraordinary circumstances," would suffer severe mental or emotional harm if required to testify at a criminal proceeding without the use of live, two-way, closed-circuit television must be established by clear and convincing evidence. The court concluded that it was reversible error for the trial court to allegedly make such a finding based only on its observations of the witness over a two-hour period during which she was in the courtroom, without other evidence relating to the witness's mental or emotional response to the alleged incident.


OUTCOME: The order affirming the judgment convicting defendant was reversed. There was an insufficient basis for making the required threshold determination of vulnerability in permitting the child witness to testify from a testimonial room over live, two-way, closed-circuit television.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Right of Confrontation -- Face-to-Face Confrontation between Defendant and Witness -- Use of Closed-Circuit Television for Certain Child Witnesses

1. CPL article 65, which authorizes a trial court, under specified circumstances, in certain sex cases, to permit a child witness to testify from a testimonial over live two-way closed-circuit television in defendant's absence, does not necessarily violate the defendant's constitutional right of confrontation. Face-to-face confrontation with the defendant is not an absolute requirement under either the Federal or State Constitution. A defendant's right of confrontation must occasionally give way to considerations of public and the necessities of the case. The use of closed-circuit television technology is permitted where an appropriate individualized showing of necessity is made, and the infringement on defendant's confrontation rights is kept to a minimum. This rule strikes a proper balance between the State's manifest interest in protecting the child witness in child sexual abuse prosecutions and the defendant's right to confront adverse witnesses.

Crimes -- Right of Confrontation -- Face-to-Face Confrontation between Jury and Witness -- Use of Closed-Circuit Television for Certain Child Witnesses

2. CPL article 65, which authorizes a trial court, under specified circumstances, in certain sex crime cases, to permit a child witness to testify from a testimonial room over live two-way closed-circuit television is not facially invalid because it permits the child to testify from a place removed from the courtroom and thereby avoid face-to-face confrontation with the jury. A statute which tolerates some infringement of the witness-jury confrontation right can meet constitutional requirements provided it contains sufficient limitations and safeguards.

Crimes -- Right of Confrontation -- Constitutionality of Statute Permitting Use of Closed-Circuit Television for Certain Child Witnesses

3. CPL article 65, which authorizes a trial court, under specified circumstances, in certain sex crime cases, to permit a child witness, who has been declared by the court to be vulnerable (CPL 65.20 [1], [10], to testify from a testimonial room over live two-way closed-circuit television, does not, on its face, offend the defendant's rights under the State or Federal Constitution to have the witness confront the jury or the defendant, but only when the presumption of constitutionality is applied and CPL 65.20 (10) is read as embodying the additional requirements of CPL 65.20 (1). The Legislature in drafting article 65 provided for a two-way simulcast of the child witness's testimony so that the curtailment of defendant's confrontation rights would be minimized. Moreover, article 65 was drawn to require an individualized showing of necessity for use of the procedures based on clear and convincing evidence; the standards for an individualized showing of necessity are sufficiently stringent to meet the facial attack on article 65. When the determination of vulnerability is sought on a motion made before trial, the requirements for a showing of necessity for the determination of vulnerability contained in CPL 65.10 (1) are clearly adequate on their face to satisfy constitutional mandates. However, when the determination of vulnerability is sought during the course of a trial, CPL 65.20 (10), if read literally, appears to authorize a court to make its determination solely from its "own observations". To avoid the constitutional infirmity that such a literal construction of CPL 65.20 (10) would produce, that section can and should be construed as requiring the same findings by clear and convincing evidence (see, CPL 65.10 [1]) as required for a determination of vulnerability made pursuant to a pretrial motion under CPL 65.20 (1).

Crimes -- Witnesses -- Use of Closed-Circuit Television for Certain Child Witnesses -- Determination of Vulnerability -- Clear and Convincing Evidence

4. For purposes of permitting a child witness to testify from a testimonial room over live two-way closed-circuit television (CPL art 65), CPL 65.10 (1) and its procedural requirements apply to all determinations of vulnerability under CPL 65.20. Thus, a determination of vulnerability, either under CPL 65.20 (1) or (10), must be supported "by clear and convincing evidence" and the "severe mental or emotional harm" must be the "result of extraordinary circumstances" (CPL 65.10 [1]). Accordingly, the requirements of the statute were not satisfied where the trial court's determination of vulnerability under CPL 65.20 (10) was based solely on its observations of the child witness over the two-hour period she was in the courtroom and no other evidence relating to the child's mental or emotional response to the alleged incident had been adduced. The court's subjective impressions, in this case, provide an insufficient basis for a factual finding required to be predicated on "clear and convincing evidence". There was no legal proof in the record from which an appeals court could determine whether the disputed finding of "severe mental or emotional harm" was supported by clear and convincing evidence. Moreover, the substantive requirements of the statute -- i.e., what must be found for a determination of vulnerability -- were not met.

Crimes -- Harmless and Prejudicial Error -- Permitting Use of Closed-Circuit Television for Testimony of Child Victim in Sex Crime Case

5. In the prosecution of defendant for attempted rape and related crimes involving a four-year-old, the trial court's error in allowing the victim to testify using CPL article 65 procedures without having a sufficient basis to make the required threshold determination of vulnerability (CPL 65.10 [1]; 65.20) was not harmless beyond a reasonable doubt. On this record, it cannot be concluded that there is no reasonable possibility that the error in permitting the jurors to view the victim's televised testimony of the intimate details of the alleged sexual abuse contributed to defendant's conviction.

Crimes -- Witnesses -- Expert Witness -- Sex Crime Case Involving Child Victim

6. In the prosecution of defendant for attempted rape and related crimes involving a four-year-old girl, the trial court acted within its discretion in permitting the testimony of an expert witness in the fields of child sexual abuse and child development as to her diagnosis of the victim and the reactions of child sexual abuse victims to courtroom procedures, and in ruling that the reactions of a four-year-old victim of sexual abuse are not within the ken of a typical juror, and are thus a proper subject for expert testimony.

 

187 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Hilbert v. Sahlen Packing Co.


(1426) CA 99-277.


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, FOURTH DEPARTMENT


267 A.D.2d 939; 701 N.Y.S.2d 564; 1999 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 13636



December 30, 1999, Decided  
December 30, 1999, Filed


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from an order of the Supreme Court, Erie County (New York), which granted the impleaded third-party's motion for summary judgment dismissing the third-party complaint.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff sustained personal injuries when he was catapulted out of a bucket truck while attempting to remove a utility pole. Plaintiff commenced an action against defendant owner of the premises, alleging common-law negligence and violations of N.Y. Lab. Law §§ 200, 240(1), 241(6). Defendant impleaded plaintiff's employer. Defendant appealed from an order granting the impleaded party's motion for summary judgment dismissing the third-party complaint. The court affirmed the judgment, holding that defendant's constitutional challenges to the 1996 amendments were without merit. Regarding defendant's contention that the amendments should not be applied retroactively, the court held that plaintiff was injured on September 11, 1996, the day after the amendments became effective, and that, in any event, the relevant inquiry was the date of commencement of the action, not the date of the accident.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment, holding that defendant's constitutional challenges to the 1996 Workers' Compensation Law amendments were without merit.

 

188 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Thibodeau


(1593) KA 97-2174.


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, FOURTH DEPARTMENT


267 A.D.2d 952; 700 N.Y.S.2d 621; 1999 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 13652



December 30, 1999, Decided  
December 30, 1999, Filed


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Related proceeding at People v. Thibodeau, 267 A.D.2d 955, 700 N.Y.S.2d 924, 1999 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 13653 (N.Y. App. Div. 4th Dep't, Dec. 30, 1999)
Appeal denied by People v. Thibodeau, 95 N.Y.2d 805, 733 N.E.2d 245, 2000 N.Y. LEXIS 2187, 711 N.Y.S.2d 173 (May 26, 2000)
Writ of habeas corpus denied Thibodeau v. Portuondo, 486 F.3d 61, 2007 U.S. App. LEXIS 11118 (2d Cir. N.Y., May 11, 2007)
Post-conviction relief denied at People v. Thibodeau, 2017 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4569 (N.Y. App. Div. 4th Dep't, June 9, 2017)


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the judgment of Oswego County Court (New York), convicting him upon a jury verdict of kidnapping in the first degree. Defendant also appealed two orders that, following a hearing, denied his motion to vacate that judgment.


OVERVIEW: Defendant appealed his conviction of kidnapping in the first degree. The court found that admission of certain testimony concerning defendant's statements to the witness did not violate the hearsay rule but did fall within the exclusionary rule because the slight probative value of the evidence was outweighed by its prejudicial impact. However, the admission of the evidence, together with the failure of the state to give notice of their intention to use it, was harmless error. There was overwhelming evidence of defendant's guilt and no significant probability that the jury would have acquitted defendant but for the error. There was no merit to defendant's challenge to the constitutionality of the presumption of death contained in the kidnapping statute, N.Y. Penal Law §135.25 (3), which was not unconstitutionally vague. The evidence was legally sufficient to support defendant's conviction.


OUTCOME: Judgment was affirmed because the evidence was legally and factually sufficient to support the verdict, error in admitting precluded evidence was harmless, and the kidnapping statute was not unconstitutionally vague.

 

189 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Association of Trade Waste Removers


2786, 2787, 2788, 2789


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, FIRST DEPARTMENT


267 A.D.2d 137; 701 N.Y.S.2d 12; 1999 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 13258



December 21, 1999, Decided  
December 21, 1999, Entered


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Certiorari Denied October 2, 2000, Reported at: 2000 U.S. LEXIS 6521.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed their convictions, after a joint jury trial in Supreme Court, New York County (New York) of enterprise corruption under the Organized Crime Control Act, N.Y. Penal Law § 460.00 et seq., and various substantive counts.


OVERVIEW: After an undercover operation concerning the private sanitation industry, involving a cartel of various carters operating through four trade associations with connections to organized crime, defendants were convicted of enterprise corruption under the Organized Crime Control Act (OCCA), N.Y. Penal Law § 460.00 et seq., and various substantive counts. On the defendants' appeal, the court affirmed the convictions. An individual defendant's claim that his convictions were not supported by legally sufficient evidence or were against the weight of the evidence was rejected. The trial court gave proper jury instructions, and correctly declined to instruct the jury as to certain principles of agency law that had no applicability to the situation. Testimony of the undercover detective was properly admitted. Under the circumstances, the OCCA was not unconstitutionally vague. Denial of motions for severance and mistrial were proper exercises of the trial court's discretion. Defendants' other claims of error were similarly rejected.


OUTCOME: Convictions affirmed; the evidence supported an individual defendant's conviction, jury instructions were correct, organized crime statute was not unconstitutionally vague, detective's testimony was properly admitted, the trial court did not abuse its discretion, and other claims were rejected.

 

190 of 992 DOCUMENTS


ARBOR HILL PTNRS. v. NEW YORK STATE COMM'R OF HOUS. & COMMUNITY RENEWAL


84755


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, THIRD DEPARTMENT


267 A.D.2d 675; 699 N.Y.S.2d 544; 1999 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 12773



December 9, 1999, Decided  
December 9, 1999, Entered



DISPOSITION: The order is affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant filed its appeal from an order of the Court of Claims (New York), which granted defendants' cross motion for summary judgment dismissing appellant's claim alleging that unfairly low rental rates constituted a "taking" of appellant's housing project.


OVERVIEW: Appellant was the owner of a state-financed housing project until the property was lost in foreclosure. Respondent, the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, established the rental rates to be charged to the project's low-income tenants. Appellant filed the instant claim alleging that the rental rates established since the project's opening in 1975 resulted in its inability to pay its mortgage and constituted a "taking" of the property. The trial court ruled that the claim was barred by the three-year statute of limitations. The court affirmed, holding that the instant claim accrued, at the latest, in 1988 following the last rental rate determination which appellant challenged, and the nearly simultaneously commenced mortgage foreclosure action. The alleged deprivation of the economically viable use of the property was certainly reasonably ascertainable by that time. Thus, the claim, filed over eight years later, was untimely.


OUTCOME: Summary judgment was affirmed, because the claim accrued, at the latest, in 1988, following the last administrative determination which appellant challenged. The alleged deprivation of the economically viable use of the property was certainly reasonably ascertainable by that time, so the claim was untimely.

 

191 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Texas Eastern Transmission Corp. v. Tax Appeals Tribunal


84246


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, THIRD DEPARTMENT


260 A.D.2d 127; 699 N.Y.S.2d 560; 1999 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 12830; 144 Oil & Gas Rep. 595



December 9, 1999, Decided  
December 9, 1999, Entered


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Amended March 9, 2000.



DISPOSITION: Determination confirmed, without costs; petition dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner sought review of a determination of respondent Tax Appeals Tribunal (New York), which denied petitioner's claim for a refund of a corporation tax assessment.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner sought tax refunds, contending it was subject to tax as supplier under N.Y. Tax Law § 186. Division of Taxation denied refund claims, finding petitioner did not qualify as transportation corporation because it derived over 50 percent of gross receipts from sale of natural gas as merchant. On administrative review to respondent, petitioner additionally argued that if it was subject to taxation under § 186, that provision was unconstitutional as applied because statute imposed franchise tax upon petitioner's unapportioned gross receipts. Respondent affirmed findings and petitioner appealed, arguing gross receipts tax under § 186 was constitutionally flawed because tax was not fairly apportioned and violated dormant Commerce Clause. The court affirmed, holding statute was internally and externally consistent, because it imposed tax only upon gross earnings from all sources within state, and petitioner did not show tax reached beyond portion of value fairly attributable to economic activity within state.


OUTCOME: Judgment affirmed. N.Y. Tax Law § 186 imposed a tax only upon gross earnings from all sources within state and there was thus no risk of multiple taxation, and petitioner failed to demonstrate tax reached beyond portion of value fairly attributable to economic activity within state.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Tax on Natural Gas Suppliers - Commerce Clause - Internal and External Consistency

Petitioner, an out-of-State corporation which was required to pay franchise taxes as a gas supplier pursuant to Tax Law § 186 for the years 1989 through 1991 because the gross receipts from its sales of natural gas as a merchant exceeded the gross receipts from its transportation of natural gas for third parties as a common carrier through its interstate pipeline system, has failed to meet its heavy burden of demonstrating that Tax Law § 186 is facially unconstitutional. A tax satisfies the requirement of the Commerce Clause (US Const, art I, § 8, cl [3]) that it be "fairly apportioned" if it is both internally and externally consistent. Internal consistency is preserved when the imposition of a tax identical to the one in question by every other State would add no burden to interstate commerce that intrastate commerce would not also bear. External consistency looks to the economic justification for the State's claim upon the value taxed to discover whether a State's tax reaches beyond that portion of value that is fairly attributable to economic activity within the taxing State. Tax Law § 186 satisfies the internal consistency test, since the statute imposes a tax only upon "gross earnings from all sources" within the State and does not seek to tax petitioner's gross earnings regardless of the out-of-State activity that contributed to those earnings. Furthermore, petitioner has also failed to demonstrate that the tax imposed by the statute is externally inconsistent.

 

192 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Wood


(1299), KA 97-5394.


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, FOURTH DEPARTMENT


260 A.D.2d 102; 698 N.Y.S.2d 122; 1999 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11892



November 12, 1999, Decided  
November 12, 1999, Filed


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Following his conviction for criminal contempt and aggravated harassment in the Supreme Court, Monroe County (New York), appellant argued that his prosecution on the contempt charges constituted double jeopardy in violation of U.S. Const. amend. V and N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 40.20(2).


OVERVIEW: Appellant's conviction for criminal contempt and aggravated harassment arose from having telephoned his ex-wife on five occasions, in violation of an order of protection. Appellant argued his criminal prosecution for disobeying the City Court order of protection was a subsequent prosecution for the same offense of which he was previously found guilty in the Family Court proceeding, which constituted double jeopardy. Respondent, the People, contended that the criminal charge of contempt in the first degree contained an additional element, which set it apart from the Family Court charges. The court reversed, stating that the reasonable doubt standard in Fam. Ct. Act art. 8, combined with a subsequent incarceration, rendered the Family Court proceeding so punitive in nature that it could not be viewed as civil in nature. However, there was no need to join the aggravated harassment charges with the contempt charges because those crimes had different elements.


OUTCOME: Conviction reversed, because the reasonable doubt standard in the Family Court act, combined with a subsequent incarceration, rendered the Family Court proceeding so punitive in nature that it could not be viewed as civil in nature, and the subsequent prosecution in City Court violated the Double Jeopardy Clause.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Former Jeopardy - Criminal Contempt Prosecution Based upon Same Underlying Conduct Involved in Prior Family Court Contempt Proceeding - "Same Elements" Test

1. Defendant's criminal contempt prosecution (Penal Law § 215.51 [c]) for having violated a City Court order of protection by making five harassing telephone calls to his ex-wife violated the constitutional prohibition against double jeopardy where defendant had previously been found guilty of contempt in a proceeding pursuant to Family Court Act § 846-a, resulting in the imposition of a six-month jail term, for having willfully violated a Family Court order of protection based upon the same underlying conduct. For double jeopardy purposes, the incarceration penalty in article 8 of the Family Court Act must be viewed as a criminal prosecution. In addition, since the same conduct that provided the basis for the Family Court proceeding also formed the basis of the criminal contempt prosecution, the two criminal prosecutions must be deemed to be for the same offense under the "same elements" double jeopardy test. Consequently, defendant should not have been tried in criminal court for criminal contempt subsequent to the Family Court finding that he violated a court order of protection. Once defendant was found guilty of the lesser included Family Court offense, the Double Jeopardy Clause prohibited the subsequent prosecution for the greater offense. Furthermore, the fact that the criminal contempt charges stem from a City Court order of protection does not remove the double jeopardy bar, since the criminal contempt and the Family Court contempt proceedings still involved the same statutory elements being applied to the same conduct.

Crimes - Former Jeopardy - Statutory Double Jeopardy Bar - Criminal Contempt Prosecution Based upon Same Underlying Conduct Involved in Prior Family Court Contempt Proceeding

2. Defendant's criminal contempt prosecution (Penal Law § 215.51 [c]) for violating a City Court order of protection by making five harassing telephone calls to his ex-wife violated the statutory prohibition against double jeopardy ( CPL 40.20 [2] [b]) where defendant had previously been found guilty of contempt in a proceeding pursuant to Family Court Act § 846-a, resulting in the imposition of a six-month jail term, for having willfully violated a Family Court order of protection based upon the same underlying conduct. Under the statutory double jeopardy bar, a "person may not be separately prosecuted for two offenses based upon the same act or criminal transaction unless: ... [e]ach of the offenses as defined contains an element which is not an element of the other, and the statutory provisions defining such offenses are designed to prevent very different kinds of harm or evil." Defendant's prosecution on the criminal contempt charges satisfies both prongs of the statutory test. The Family Court and City Court orders of protection were designed to prevent precisely the same "kinds of harm or evil," to wit, harassment of defendant's ex-wife by prohibited contact with her as well as vindicating the authority of the court that issued the order.

Crimes - Former Jeopardy - Separate Prosecution of Jointly Prosecutable Offenses - Aggravated Harassment and Criminal Contempt

3. Although defendant's criminal contempt prosecution (Penal Law § 215.51 [c]) for violating a City Court order of protection by making five harassing telephone calls to his ex-wife violated the constitutional and statutory ( CPL 40.20 [2] [b]) prohibitions against double jeopardy where defendant had previously been found guilty of contempt in a proceeding pursuant to Family Court Act § 846-a based upon the same underlying conduct, thereby requiring reversal of defendant's conviction of five counts of criminal contempt in the first degree, defendant's separate conviction of five counts of aggravated harassment in the second degree (Penal Law § 240.30 [2]) should be affirmed. The People were not required to join the harassment charges with the contempt charges pursuant to CPL 40.40, since the harassment charges require proof of different elements than the criminal contempt charges. Consequently, the two types of charges did not violate the Double Jeopardy Clause. Moreover, although defendant raised the issue of multiplicity at trial, he failed to contend that the indictment was invalid due to the missing times of the phone calls or to contend that the indictment failed to give him notice of the cause of the accusation. Thus, his present contention that the indictment was insufficient to give notice of the time of each phone call is unpreserved for appellate review. Furthermore, since the five charges of aggravated harassment were each based on a separate phone call, regardless of their closeness in time, it was not improper for the District Attorney to charge defendant with five counts rather than one.

 

193 of 992 DOCUMENTS


City of New York v. Dezer Props., Inc.


1451N


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, FIRST DEPARTMENT


259 A.D.2d 116; 697 N.Y.S.2d 41; 1999 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10889



October 28, 1999, Decided  
October 28, 1999, Entered


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Order of October 28, 1999, Reported at: 259 A.D.2d 116 at 127.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, City of New York and others, appealed from an order of the Supreme Court, New York County (New York) in a nuisance abatement proceeding which granted defendants' motion to reopen its adult establishment pursuant to the "substantial portion" language of New York Zoning Resolution § 12-10.


OVERVIEW: In a nuisance abatement proceeding plaintiff City sought to prevent the reopening of defendant's adult establishment pursuant to the "substantial portion" language of New York, New York Zoning Resolution § 12-10. Defendants failed to prove compliance with the 60-40 rule and instead showed only an attempt to skirt its prohibition by means of superficial measures leaving the essentially non-conforming nature of their business intact. There was no conceivable reason why anyone uninterested in topless dancing would choose defendants' club over the many other nightclubs, bars and restaurants in the Flatiron district, many of which had no cover charge. Defendants' establishment was still clearly an integrated adult enterprise and of the type that was intended, under New York, New York Zoning Regulation § 12-10 to be removed from residential city areas, and their attempt to comply with the 60-40 rule was, as a matter of law, a sham.


OUTCOME: Order reversed since defendants' establishment was still an integrated adult enterprise and of the type that was intended to be removed from residential city areas, and their attempt to comply with the 60-40 rule was, as a matter of law, a sham.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations - Zoning - Adult Establishments - Application of "60-40 Rule" to "Single Use" Adult Establishments

1. The New York City Zoning Resolution's "60-40 rule," which is used to determine whether a "substantial portion" of a commercial establishment's floor space is devoted to adult entertainment and is thus subject to certain zoning restrictions (New York City Zoning Resolution § 12-10), should be applied to "single use" adult eating or drinking establishments and is not limited to only adult book and video stores. Neither the Zoning Resolution on its face nor in its legislative history affords any basis for different treatment to any adult use.

Municipal Corporations - Zoning - Adult Establishments - "60-40 Rule"

2. In a proceeding under New York City's Nuisance Abatement Law (Administrative Code of City of NY § 7-701 et seq.) to enjoin adult entertainment at defendants' club because it is located in a residential area in which adult establishments cannot be maintained or sited, defendants' attempts to reconfigure the club so as to allow adult entertainment in less than 40% of the club's floor space by limiting adult entertainment to the club's mezzanine, which occupies approximately 28% of the club's total floor space, does not comply with the "60-40 rule" (New York City Zoning Resolution § 12-10). Under the 60-40 rule, a substantial portion of an adult eating or drinking establishment is devoted to adult use and the establishment must, therefore, conform to the Zoning Resolution when at least 40 percent of the floor and cellar areas accessible to customers are available for adult performance and viewing purposes. Here, the club clearly remains an integrated adult enterprise of the type that was intended, under the Zoning Resolution, to be removed from residential City areas. The front area requires a cover charge and there is no separate entrance or cover charge for the topless-dancing area. Even without performers, the downstairs area cannot reasonably be seen as anything but a staging area used in the course of attracting customers to the upstairs performances. There is still no conceivable reason why anyone uninterested in topless dancing would choose defendants' club over the many other nightclubs, bars and restaurants in the zoning district.

 

194 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Brault v. New York State Tax Appeals Tribunal


83791


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, THIRD DEPARTMENT


265 A.D.2d 700; 696 N.Y.S.2d 579; 1999 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10678



October 21, 1999, Decided  
October 21, 1999, Entered



DISPOSITION: Determination is confirmed, without costs, and petition dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Proceeding to review a determination of respondent New York State Tax Appeals Tribunal which sustained the denial of petitioners' applications for a refund of personal income tax.


OVERVIEW: Proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 (initiated pursuant to N.Y. Tax Law § 2016) to review a determination of respondent Tax Appeals Tribunal which sustained the denial of petitioners' applications for a refund of personal income tax. In July 1994, petitioners filed claims seeking refunds of state personal income taxes paid in the years 1986 through 1988 based upon the inclusion of federal retirement benefits in their state taxable income. The Department of Taxation and Finance denied petitioners' refund claims for taxable years 1986 through 1988 on the ground that they were not timely filed within the three-year Statute of Limitations provided by N.Y. Tax Law § 687 (a). Upon appeal, respondent Tax Appeals Tribunal upheld the denial. On appeal, the court held that the statute of limitations was a permissible procedural protection and did not deprive petitioners of due process.


OUTCOME: Determination is confirmed, without costs, and petition dismissed. Three-year limitations period on tax refund claims was a permissible procedural protection, and did not deprive petitioners of due process.

 

195 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Cathedral of the Incarnation in the Diocese of Long Island, Inc. v. Garden City Co.


97-08971


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, SECOND DEPARTMENT


265 A.D.2d 286; 697 N.Y.S.2d 56; 1999 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9668


October 1, 1998, Argued  
October 4, 1999, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed grant of summary judgment by the Nassau County Supreme Court (New York) in favor of plaintiff in action to modify or extinguish restrictions on use of land for charitable purposes.


OVERVIEW: In an action by plaintiff cathedral pursuant to N.Y. Real Prop. Acts. Law § 1955 to modify or extinguish restrictions on the use of land held for charitable purposes, defendant appealed from judgment, which granted plaintiff's motion for summary judgment and extinguished challenged deed restrictions requiring that premises not be used or occupied for any other use or purposes than as sites or grounds for buildings or institutions connected with the cathedral. The court affirmed summary judgment for plaintiff, agreeing with trial court that the deed created a right of reentry, not a possibility of reverter. There was nothing in the language of the deed nor in the record as a whole to support the conclusion that the grantor's heirs intended the cathedral's estate to terminate automatically if the land were used for other than church purposes.


OUTCOME: Judgment affirmed; deed created right of reentry, not possibility of reverter. Nothing in language of the deed nor in record as a whole supported conclusion that the grantor's heirs intended the cathedral's estate to terminate automatically if land were used for other than church purposes.

 

196 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Baran v. Giambra


(1080) CAE 99-699.


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, FOURTH DEPARTMENT


265 A.D.2d 796; 705 N.Y.S.2d 740; 1999 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9811



October 1, 1999, Decided  
August 18, 1999, Filed


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant Erie County Republican Committee sought review of an order of the Supreme Court, Erie County (New York), which concluded that state election law was violated by expenditures made by appellant on behalf of its endorsed candidate for the office of Erie County Executive.


OVERVIEW: In this special proceeding, the trial court concluded that N.Y. Elec. Law § 2-126 was violated by expenditures made by appellant, Erie County Republican Committee, on behalf of its endorsed candidate for office of Erie County Executive before petitioner filed a designating petition seeking the Republican Party's nomination. On appeal, the court held that the statute was not violated because until petitioner filed a designating petition, which triggered the necessity for a primary election, the endorsed Republican candidate was not a person to be voted for at a primary election. Thus, expenditures made on his behalf by appellant prior to that time did not violate the statute. Further, the expenditures made by appellant before petitioner filed a designating petition were not made in aid of the nomination of the endorsed candidate against a primary. The court rejected the contention of appellant that the statute unconstitutionally inhibited First Amendment rights.


OUTCOME: Order modified and ,as modified, affirmed. Remitted to the trial court to determine whether any funds were expended on behalf of the endorsed candidate after July 13, 1999, the date on which petitioner's designating petition was filed.

 

197 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Peterson


1611, 1611A


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, FIRST DEPARTMENT


264 A.D.2d 574; 695 N.Y.S.2d 550; 1999 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8946



September 9, 1999, Decided  
September 9, 1999, Entered


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Certiorari Denied October 2, 2000, Reported at: 2000 U.S. LEXIS 5259.
Appeal denied by People v. Peterson, 94 N.Y.2d 865, 725 N.E.2d 1103, 1999 N.Y. LEXIS 4519, 704 N.Y.S.2d 541 (1999)
Writ of certiorari denied Peterson v. New York, 531 U.S. 831, 148 L. Ed. 2d 46, 121 S. Ct. 85, 2000 U.S. LEXIS 5259 (2000)
Magistrate's recommendation at, Habeas corpus proceeding at Peterson v. New York, 2003 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 7127 (S.D.N.Y., Apr. 24, 2003)



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant challenged judgment of the Supreme Court, New York County (New York), contending that he was deprived of his right to be sentenced without unreasonable delay pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 380.30(1) and as such the court lost jurisdiction over him, mandating dismissal of the indictment.


OVERVIEW: Appellant was convicted and sentenced for attempted criminal sale of a controlled substance. The trial court denied appellant's motion to vacate the judgment and set aside the sentence. Appellant contended that he was deprived of his right to be sentenced without unreasonable delay pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 380.30(1). Appellant was originally sentenced five years prior to the action. Yet, due to a federal parole violation, the sentencing judge ordered that he be released to federal custody for sentencing and that the sentences run concurrently. The order was not followed at that time. On appeal, the court held that where there was an extended delay, but plausible reasons are offered to explain it, the court must balance the factors involved before determining whether dismissal was warranted. Since the delay in sentencing was excusable, there was no basis for dismissal.


OUTCOME: Finding that the delay in appellant's sentencing was excusable, the court held that there was no basis for dismissing the indictment against appellant.

 

198 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Public Util. Law Project of N.Y. Inc. v. New York State PSC


83095


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, THIRD DEPARTMENT


263 A.D.2d 879; 694 N.Y.S.2d 522; 1999 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8476



July 29, 1999, Decided  
July 29, 1999, Entered



DISPOSITION: The order is reversed, on the law, without costs, motion granted and petition dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, utility project and others, and respondent Public Service Commission filed cross appeals from an order of the Supreme Court (New York), which denied respondent's motion to dismiss the petition challenging its authority to exempt private electric service companies from certain regulatory provisions.


OVERVIEW: Respondent Public Service Commission proposed a plan to promote competition in retail electric markets by allowing consumers to purchase electricity from private electric service companies. It planned to exempt such companies from the Home Energy Fair Practices Act, N.Y. Pub. Serv. Law §30 et seq., which afforded protections to customers in their relationship with utilities. Petitioners, utility project and others, claimed that the lightened regulation of private electric service companies was not authorized by statute and was illegal. They commenced a proceeding seeking to invalidate the plan, asserting they had standing under N.Y. Fin. State Law §123-b and also common law. Respondent's motion to dismiss petitioners' claims was denied by the trial court. On cross appeals by both parties, the court reversed. Petitioners did not have standing under the finance law, which addressed expenditure of funds, not the extent of the regulatory authority in issue. Petitioners also lacked common law standing, as they failed to allege facts demonstrating that they would suffer direct harm different from that suffered by the public at large.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the denial of respondent Public Service Commission's motion to dismiss petitioner utility project's suit challenging its authority to exempt private electric service companies from certain laws because petitioners lacked standing under statute or common law.

 

199 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Couser


(868) KA 98-8316.


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, FOURTH DEPARTMENT


258 A.D.2d 74; 695 N.Y.S.2d 781; 1999 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 7903



July 9, 1999, Decided  
July 9, 1999, Filed


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant prosecution sought review of the decision of the Onondaga County Court (New York) which granted defendant's motion to dismiss the second count of the indictment charging defendant with first degree felony murder based on the allegation that he commanded the death of the victim or intended victim. Trial court held that term "command," as found in N.Y. Penal Law § 125.27(1)(a) was unconstitutionally vague.


OVERVIEW: While defendant was incarcerated and awaiting trial, he allegedly directed a gang member to murder the complainant. A hit squad led by the gang member entered the complainant's home to kill him and instead they two children and an elderly woman in the head, execution style. Defendant was indicted for the crime of murder in the first degree in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 125.27(1)(a)(vii). Pursuant to § 125.27(1)(a)(vii), a person could not be convicted of first degree felony murder without committing the homicidal act unless that person "commanded" another person to cause the death of the victim or intended victim. The trial court dismissed the indictment on grounds the term "commanded" was unconstitutionally vague. Upon the state's appeal, the court reversed, holding that the trial court erred by not affording the term its commonly understood meaning in order to avoid a constitutional challenge. The court ruled that the trial court erred in analyzing the constitutionality of § 125.27(1)(a)(vii) from a U.S. Const. amend. VIII perspective. Because this was not a death penalty case, defendant's vagueness argument should have been measured instead by due process.


OUTCOME: The trial court's dismissal of the second count of the indictment on grounds term "command" was unconstitutionally vague, was reversed. The court concluded that as applied to this defendant, the limitation on accomplice liability was not unconstitutionally vague. The court held that the trial court erred by not affording the term its commonly understood meaning in order to avoid a constitutional challenge.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - First Degree Felony Murder - Term "Command" Not Unconstitutionally Vague

The statutory limitation on Penal Law § 20.00 accomplice liability for first degree felony murder and death penalty eligibility to only those accomplices who actually "commanded" the death of the victim or intended victim (Penal Law § 125.27 [1] [a] [vii]) is not unconstitutionally vague as applied to defendant's noncapital felony murder prosecution for having allegedly directed a member of his street gang to murder complainant, which resulted in the execution-style shooting death of a woman in complainant's home. County Court erred in refusing to afford the term "command" its plain meaning and determining that, in the absence of a statutory definition, the limitation on accomplice liability is unconstitutionally vague. Since the prosecutor failed to seek the death penalty (see, CPL 250.40), defendant's vagueness challenge should be measured by due process, not Eighth Amendment standards. For due process purposes, Penal Law § 125.27 (1) (a) (vii) is sufficiently definite to serve as the statutory definition of a crime. A determination that the statute is sufficiently definite to serve as the basis for a criminal prosecution is not inconsistent with a determination that it is not sufficiently definite to serve as the basis for the imposition of the death penalty. Furthermore, County Court also erred by failing to accord the statute the strong presumption of constitutionality to which it is entitled and not construing the statute to preserve its constitutionality. In the absence of a specific statutory definition, the term "command" should have been given its commonly understood meaning in order to avoid the constitutional challenge, especially since defendant's actions fall plainly within the ambit of the statute. There was sufficient evidence before the Grand Jury to establish the existence of the gang, defendant's authoritative position within the gang and that defendant summoned a gang member to jail to make arrangements to "take care" of complainant's family to keep complainant from testifying. Such evidence, if believed, establishes that defendant did not merely request, solicit or importune someone to kill complainant but acted as a boss-accomplice to order a member of his gang to commit the crime. Accordingly, the first degree felony murder count of the indictment is reinstated and the matter is remitted to County Court for further proceedings.

 

200 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Clear Channel Communs., Inc. v. Rosen


84328


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, THIRD DEPARTMENT


263 A.D.2d 663; 692 N.Y.S.2d 812; 1999 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 7850



July 8, 1999, Decided  
July 8, 1999, Entered



DISPOSITION: The petition is dismissed, as moot, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners brought a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding to vacate and enjoin enforcement of respondent judge's order declining to declare N.Y. Civ. Rights Law § 52 unconstitutional, warranting refusal of petitioners' request to televise a trial in which they had intervened. Respondent judge cross-moved to dismiss the petition on the ground of mootness because respondents, defendants in the underlying action, had been acquitted.


OVERVIEW: Petitioners commenced an action for prohibition pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, seeking to vacate and enjoin the enforcement of respondent judge's order declining to declare N.Y. Civ. Rights Law § 52 unconstitutional, warranting refusal of petitioners' request to televise a trial in which they had intervened. Respondent judge cross-moved to dismiss the petition on the ground of mootness because respondents, defendants in the underlying action, had been acquitted. The court dismissed petitioner's action for prohibition first, explaining that petitioners did not have a clear legal right to demand that cameras be permitted in the courtroom because respondent merely complied with the provisions of § 52, as it then existed. The court then stated that an art. 78 proceeding was not the proper mechanism by which the constitutionality of a legislative enactment could be challenged. Moreover, petitioners had numerous opportunities and sufficient time to have brought a declaratory judgment action challenging the statute's constitutionality, given the fact that the statute had been in existence for several decades.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed petitioners' prohibition action seeking to vacate and enjoin the enforcement of respondent judge's order. The court explained that a prohibition action was not the proper mechanism by which to challenge the constitutionality of a statute where petitioners had had numerous opportunities and sufficient time to challenge the statute in a declaratory judgment action.
